webTitle: Peugeot adds voice to warnings on strong pound's threat to jobs

fields.headline: Peugeot adds voice to warnings on strong pound's threat to jobs
fields.trailText: French car manufacturer Peugeot, which has a strong presence in the West Midlands, employing more than 3,000 people, is the latest manufacturer to suggest that it may have to cut back investment and jobs because of the strength of the pound.
fields.body:
French car manufacturer Peugeot, which has a strong presence in the West Midlands, employing more than 3,000 people, is the latest manufacturer to suggest that it may have to cut back investment and jobs because of the strength of the pound.

A senior source at Peugeot said jobs were at risk because the pound's high value, particularly against the euro, was making UK investment decisions 'hard to predict'.

The news comes at a time when Nissan, Toyota and Ford have all recently admitted struggling in the current high exchange rate climate. Last month, BMW cited sterling's strength as a reason for selling Rover, a move which threatens to ravage the the West Midlands economy.

In January, Peugeot, the majority of whose 4,000 UK workers are employed in Coventry, announced plans to produce a new Citroën car there to build on the success of its 206 model. The plant now produces the 206 model at the rate of 160,000 a year.

While the Peugeot source stopped short of saying this plan was now on hold, he did say that components would probably be sourced abroad rather than in Britain.

He urged the Government to state once and for all whether Britain would enter the single currency. 'Two-thirds of our production is for export,' he said. 'It's a big concern not just now but for the future, because the high level of the pound against sterling makes future investment difficult.'

Peugeot's managing director, Tod Martin, recently visited Prime Minister Tony Blair with other leading motor industry executives to express these concerns.

The French carmaker's warning comes as traditional manufacturing industries in Labour heartlands are struggling to maintain a market share in Europe.

Other industries are also feeling the pinch. Neil Eisberg of the Chemical Industries Association, whose members employ 250,000 UK workers, said: 'The EU is our largest export market, so, yes, the high exchange rate against the euro does effect our business.

'The vast majority of the UK chemical industry is run by overseas companies. So we run the real risk of them pulling investments or not even considering us in the future. We made that point to Treasury officials earlier this year, but these concerns were simply not addressed in last month's Budget.'

Industry sources fear that the country's leading chemicals companies - such as German-based BASF and Rhodia of France - could relocate plants if the current situation continues.

And last week, Leicester-based textile union KFAT said that in the past year clothing manufacturers had axed 40,000 jobs. Current losses are running at 650 a week, the union says.

fields.headline: Capital's dead - long live people
fields.standfirst: Management: In the latest rethink, the brainy few stand to reap huge rewards, says Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: McKinsey calls it 'the war for talent' - the most important issue facing business today. And McKinsey should know: like the rest of the old employment aristocracy, the blue-blooded consultancy is suddenly staring down the barrel of a gun. It can no longer automatically recruit the pick of today's business-school graduates - it can't even keep those it has.
fields.body:
McKinsey calls it 'the war for talent' - the most important issue facing business today. And McKinsey should know: like the rest of the old employment aristocracy, the blue-blooded consultancy is suddenly staring down the barrel of a gun. It can no longer automatically recruit the pick of today's business-school graduates - it can't even keep those it has.

Scores of consultancies and businesses are in this position. What's going on?

What has happened, according to Alec Reed, founder and chairman of temping agency Reed Executive, is that the world has changed. And not just because of the recent Internet frenzy. The old big-company incentive levers - whether it's making partner, making money or making schmooze with the corporate great and good - just aren't connected any more. All established businesses are affected. The old system of employment relations is ending, and a new one is taking its place. Socialism is dead; capitalism is dying. Welcome to the new world of 'peoplism'.

This is not, Reed accepts, a satisfactory name for a movement that will benefit the well-equipped few rather than the average many - at least initially. But it does suggest the underlying truth - that organisations are entering a strange and difficult world, with different economic and ideological ground rules.

With socialism, the means of production and distribution are socially determined; with capitalism, capital is the scarce resource and organising principle. Peoplism, as Reed defines it, is an economic state where individuals (or some of them) own and carry round with them the most important factor of production: brainpower.

Reed the man decided to do something about the changing order when he found he was wondering what was going on not just once a month but twice a day.

Change was leaving all short and long-term attempts to tweak or re-engineer the company's business looking frayed and inadequate. New competitors were arriving as if from outer space. The importance of physical assets was eclipsed, and returns to a few brain-rich yet capital poor individuals were enormous.

'The only way we can survive is by being a truly creative business,' concludes Reed. Capital isn't creative - look at all those bricks-and-mortar companies that can't find anything to do with it except give it away or buy back their shares. It's people - or some people - who are creative. 'These are the ones we want, and we have to adapt to the consequences.'

Those consequences aren't necessarily comfortable. Peoplism, says Reed, is 'fast, footloose and fancy free'. Fast: two young co-workers told him a rival agency was planning to launch a dot.com enterprise in a couple of months' time. So the pair put up a Reed website in a week - and the firm's share price shot up 30 per cent in one day.

Footloose: Reed set up a niche agency before Christmas for placing well paid executives in specialised jobs. It was doing well and won several important contracts. But after Christmas, four partners in the start-up failed to reappear. End of business.

Fancy-free: one of Reed's most creative graduates decided to take time off to explore South America. He may or may not return. Another has signed up for a course of singing lessons in Moscow - ditto.

To tease out the implications of emerging peoplism, Reed has set up a new think tank, the Academy of Enterprise, with work contracted out to Demos, the Smith Institute and the Employment Policy Institute.

Some of the issues they will look at are technical - how can managers and investors keep score when traditional accountancy disintegrates around them, for example.

Reed ticks off the points: 'Budgeting is meaningless. It's too restricting: things just don't happen annually. Apart from the cash element, you can't rely on balance sheets, because fixed assets are unimportant, and stock can become worthless overnight. And profit and loss is too crude to measure service businesses, which are spending heaps on R&D, but out of revenues, not capital.'

Trying to tell this story to investors is one reason for the dot.com valuation anarchy.

Other issues are profoundly socio-economic. A peoplist age, Reed admits, is unlikely to be kinder than a capitalist one; it will just be unkind in a different way.

From a national point of view the UK lacks brains at the top and jobs at the bottom. 'New Deal' type initiatives (in which Reed is involved) will be needed at one end. Encouraging a brain injection at the other may be the only way not to lose out to 'e-lance' projects such as web development in Minsk or dealing with complaints letters in New Delhi. Meanwhile, the tax system will have to be adjusted to allow for the volatility of postmodern wealth: e-millionaire one day, e-pauper the next.

Reed is not waiting for the think tank to report before taking action on his own account. Internally the company no longer manages by budget but by business plan, switching between scenarios as necessary. It has given up interviewing bright young graduates for jobs ('after 40 years we know interviewing is hopeless') in favour of the reverse: having looked at paper qualifications, it invites candidates to interview the company and then decide.

Once recruited, individuals decide pay increases for themselves - within limits. Reed's business plan commits to making some people (those who aspire to it) very rich - a few millionaires a year.

'We really do try to treat people differently,' says Reed. Individuals are 'co-workers' - 'they're not employees, that's plain wrong' - and in its behaviour towards them Reed aims to benchmark itself not against another employer but against, somewhat startlingly, the ideal Mum. So anyone who needs a loan for whatever purpose can have up to £1,000 at any time, for however long, interest-free. (Reed has a lot of loans outstanding.) And it pays for 100 per cent of all vocational and 50 per cent of non-vocational training that any co-worker wants.

'Fast learners will be fast earners,' says Reed. One challenge - which the Academy aims to address - is equipping individuals with the enterprise necessary for them to thrive in the peoplist economy. Another is to develop social as well as economic entrepreneurship, so that peoplism doesn't just become rampant individualism.

'I'm optimistic, yes,' says Reed. Let's hope that's well-founded.

simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Internet market starts picking up the pieces

fields.headline: Internet market starts picking up the pieces
fields.standfirst:
The bubble may not quite have burst, but it is shrinking, reports Jamie Doward
E-finance: special report
Net floatations: special report
fields.trailText: The bubble may not quite have burst, but it is shrinking, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
After the deluge, the damage analysis. It is clear that the tumultuous events of 10 days ago, when the world's major stock markets fell off a cliff, have hastened the collapse of many Internet companies' sky-high valuations. Whereas the Internet sector had hitherto seemed invincible against standard valuation models, the markets' recent slide show just how fragile such businesses are when reality bites.

True, as last week progressed, all the main market indices, including that of Nasdaq, the US exchange for high-tech stocks, bungee-jumped enthusiastically. On Tuesday, Nasdaq soared by 7.2 per cent, its biggest one-day jump.

Coupled with a modest rise the previous day it meant the Nasdaq had more than clawed back Friday's loss after just two days of trading. The bears, those who have been predicting that 10 years of stock-market upswing was about to come to an end, were ignored as market euphoria returned.

But the shrewder analysts argue the Lazarus-style resurrection of tech stocks over the past week masks the wider issue. Perhaps because the Internet sector is often described as a bubble, we have been waiting for it to burst. But in reality the bubble has been shrinking since March.

As highly respected Merrill Lynch analyst Henry Blodget pointed out in a briefing note last week: 'The pullback in technology stocks has been brutal on the Internet sector: the stronger stocks are down 40 to 50 per cent from their highs, the weaker ones by 80 to 95 per cent.'

A glance at some of the best known Internet companies confirms this assessment. Bookseller Amazon is currently worth around $18 billion, half of what it was worth last May. Music retailer CDnow is worth $100 million. A few months ago it was worth 20 times this.

Overall, Nasdaq is still nearly 20 per cent off its peak. Freeserve, the UK Internet service provider, is now valued at just over half the £8 bn it was worth in February.

These slumps pale when compared with what has happened to some of the smaller Internet investment companies. Oxygen Holdings, which aims to invest in campus start-ups, has seen its share price fall from 60p to 12p in a couple of months, and is now valued at less than £50m.

Jellyworks, the investment vehicle headed by 24-year-old City whizzkid Jonathan Rowland, was worth 120p a share at the start of the year. Now its share price stands at 34p, and the company has seen its market capitalisation plunge from nearly £280m to £77m.

The fallout doesn't stop there. The big telecoms companies such as Colt, and Cable & Wireless, whose values soared as the City started to view them as Internet stocks, have also seen their share prices slide. Likewise those firms which make the equipment which allows the Internet to function (Baltimore Technologies) or who were seen as key content providers (BSkyB and Reuters) have also taken a hammering.

As the economists Varian and Shapiro famously observed: 'Technology changes. Economic laws do not.'

If the Internet emperor has not been shown to be naked, he is at least now in an embarrassing state of déshabillé .

Over the past few months, the Internet sector appears to have entered a more mature growth phase. And, as the sector continues to mature, further corrections look likely. Despite the slide since March, valuations of Internet stocks continue to be far higher than those of older companies which dare to make profits.

Jeremy Batstone, head of research at NatWest Stockbrokers, believes the events of 10 days ago are likely to be repeated: 'We can expect to see more of the same. I've been encouraged by the way the markets recovered their poise, but I wonder if they are behaving irrationally by rising so strongly.'

Even Blodget's favoured Internet stocks are still valued at between 25 and 100 times their estimated earnings for 2002, suggesting there is still some pretty hefty downside to come if Nasdaq takes another tumble. It is likely that this will happen sooner rather than later.

Global investment strategists at HSBC argue that a 'further correction in US asset prices is likely in the next two quarters, particularly in the Nasdaq _ the risks associated with US equities appear to be rising as valuations remain stretched'.

And, of course, as the valuations of many Internet companies become increasingly shaky, and investors and financial backers turn shy, a credit crunch looms.

'More and more companies are going to face a cash crisis,' said Victor Basta, managing director of the investment bank, Broadview, which focuses on the technology sector. 'Look at some of the up-and-coming companies, many of which are loss-making: they've raised one or two years' worth of cash by going public at a very early stage. Basically they've used public money as venture capital. But the markets' turbulence means raising more money will be increasingly difficult for some.'

Last Thursday alone, 11 of the 16 Internet companies that were scheduled to float on Nasdaq pulled their Initial Public Offerings - purely because of the downturn in market sentiment.

Given this slide in enthusiasm, the natural inclination for many of the smaller Internet companies, especially those focused on the business-to-consumer (B2C) market - whose business plans are based more on hope and marketing than on substance - will be to merge or die.

'I'm quite confident that 75 per cent of B2C companies won't be in their present form within two years,' said David Pannell, senior consultant at Durlacher, the high-tech investment bank. 'There will be a lot of consolidation. There are five garden centre sites at the moment, for example. Soon there will be no more than two, which will align themselves with the biggest mainstream garden centres.'

Those who fail to find partners face a gloomy future. 'We believe the spoils will go to the few, not the many,' Blodget said.

This consolidation in the market will in part be driven by the larger Internet companies looking to scoop up the smaller firms. 'It will precipitate deals between mid-sized players as they get approached by the larger players,' Basta said. 'Many will evaluate the strengths of a merger rather than an outright sale.'

Concerns about the smaller players' long-term futures should also boost the established players. 'In any turbulent market, said Basta, 'you have people flooding to safe companies whose valuations will get bigger. There will be more opportunities for the big Internet companies to become consolidators.'

As the value of many tech shares jag south, cash becomes king, a move which strengthens the positions of established companies with proven earnings streams. 'A number of bricks-and-mortar companies will move in to buy e-commerce companies,' Pannell said.

Recently, for example, Dutch supermarket giant Ahold bought online retail chain Peapod for £73m. Marks & Spencer has also started making acquisitions in online firms. Last September it launched a venture fund which has subsequently taken stakes in upmarket lingerie firm Splendour.com and Talkcast, the digital information provider.

Continued slides in the value of technology stocks will prompt further predatory action from the offline sector, which has started to come back into vogue. The valuation schisms between the old- and new-economy businesses are narrowing.

Internet mania is fast becoming an anachronism.

Safety and sanity? What the experts think...

 Mary Meekler of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, speaking two weeks ago, argued that the market was overheated. 'We believe that 10 per cent of the Internet stocks are undervalued; 90 per cent may be overvalued,' she said on American television. She believes that the recent market correction is helping focus investors' attention on the quality end of the sector, a move that will separate the leaders from the laggards.

 Abby Joseph Cohen of Goldman Sachs described the slump of 10 days ago as 'a market event rather than an economic event'. Cohen argued that investors were looking for signs that might provide comfort, and was confident that forthcoming corporate profits reports from some of the major US companies would reassure them.

 Henry Blodget of Merrill Lynch argues that the Internet sector is entering a mature growth phase which will cause further shake-outs and consolidation: 'Extreme volatility has been inescapable in the Internet sector for the past five years, and has worsened of late. We believe that the safest and sanest approach to the sector for the majority of investors is an indirect one: own the stocks of "old-economy" companies positioned to benefit from the Internet.

jamie.doward@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: ...or feeling home alone?
fields.trailText: John left office employment and took up flexible, home-based working six years ago. He would jump at another traditional job if he could find one because - like many people - he is not a natural at working alone.
fields.body:
John left office employment and took up flexible, home-based working six years ago. He would jump at another traditional job if he could find one because - like many people - he is not a natural at working alone.

Life as a freelance journalist has been extremely difficult. His earnings have plummeted - and he believes that, on about £15,000-a-year, he brings in about half of what he would otherwise get.

'You've got to be very disciplined - more even than when you work in an office,' he says. 'You've got to set the alarm and get up when it goes off. That's how I ought to do it. But if you're prone to attacks of the black dog, life is very difficult. Writer's block does exist and it's terrible.'

After a few days or weeks, he usually feels better and will get down to work.

He has friends who are even worse off than he is. Another naturally gregarious friend has become clinically depressed by being alone so much, and is now on Prozac.

'In the office you have people there asking if you haven't done something,' says John. 'Or they'll be asking why you aren't on the phone getting stories.'

Despite the difficulties, he can still appreciate the advantages. 'I always hated the rush hour with a passion, so I used to turn up in the office very early. Also, working from home, I've had people call me at 7.30am and 1am. You wouldn't like to be hanging round the office until then.'

fields.headline: Enjoying a squeeze...
fields.trailText: Chris Cox believes that many benefits have come from his decision to opt for 'compressed work' four years ago. Senior branch manager of the main Lloyds TSB branch in Reading, he now works from 8am to 6pm four days a week, from Tuesday to Friday.
fields.body:
Chris Cox believes that many benefits have come from his decision to opt for 'compressed work' four years ago. Senior branch manager of the main Lloyds TSB branch in Reading, he now works from 8am to 6pm four days a week, from Tuesday to Friday.

An elongated three-day weekend means that he can spend far more time with his two young sons, aged five and four. 'This is fantastic for me. I am able to see my children grow up and to get involved in parental tasks.'

Another major benefit has been the effect on his wife. 'The arrangement allowed my wife to resume her career sooner than would have happened otherwise.' She was very keen to return to work - but would probably not have been able to afford it for another year or two if the couple had to pay childcare costs for five days of the week.

Chris is in charge of a staff of 60 in the Market Place branch. His deputy also does a compressed four-day week, and is on duty on Saturday and Monday when Chris is not around.

About 40 per cent of the 60 staff have a flexible working arrangement to suit their personal conditions or temperaments.

There are the late risers and late leavers, for example, and the early birds who then get to leave early in the afternoon.

The flexibility works well. The bank, which is open for a total of 45 hours each week, needs to have employees who will work flexible or unorthodox hours.

webTitle: How to survive on a working party

fields.headline: How to survive on a working party
fields.trailText: 1 Understand that you are swimming in treacherous waters. If your IT director simply wants to purchase a new computer system, he will either make up his own mind or get a subordinate to produce recommendations. If he sets up a working party instead, he is buying time, postponing the issue, aiming for a fudge or indulging in some other nefarious aspect of office politics. You could be the fall guy for anything that goes wrong.
fields.body:
1 Understand that you are swimming in treacherous waters. If your IT director simply wants to purchase a new computer system, he will either make up his own mind or get a subordinate to produce recommendations. If he sets up a working party instead, he is buying time, postponing the issue, aiming for a fudge or indulging in some other nefarious aspect of office politics. You could be the fall guy for anything that goes wrong.

2Work out why the WP has been established. The Royal Commission on Long-Term Care - a grandiose form of WP - was set up to buy time for the Government and to produce cheap recommendations. Its possibly naive members were surprised when the Government did not implement their (costly) proposals - and a bit upset when spin doctors briefed against them.

3 Decide what you want from the experience. If you are a careerist, you want to get the credit for any successes - so probably want a role as secretary, chair or author of a report. Arrange things so that you can be largely absent towards the end if it goes pear-shaped.

4 Take a lower profile but do more of the work if your priority is to go down a certain route. 'Ensure that you are better briefed than anyone else, particularly at the beginning,' says Francis, veteran of many WPs. 'You don't necessarily want to be the leader - if you can dominate the leader, you effectively have two votes.'

5 Be very wary if the person who commissioned the WP is always congratulating you on your sterling work. Many a WP is set up to keep someone potentially troublesome occupied on a scheme that will never be fulfilled. You may be asked to do large amounts of research and to report back regularly at other meetings - where the chief Svengali will slap you on the back and tell you how important your contribution is.

6 Don't trust your colleagues to be sensible. Lords Jenkins, Franks and Widgery are just some of the big names who produced ludicrous reports after chairing WPs. Even the most talented people can produce whitewashes, grotesque fudges and unworkable proposals.

fields.headline: Don't panic
fields.standfirst: Terrified when shares plunged? Read Jill Insley and Neasa MacErlean's guide to fear-free investment
fields.trailText: If you are worrying yourself sick about your shares, the chances are that you are a novice investor. People who invested in February and early March have lost most because they invested at the peak of the stock market.
fields.body:
If you are worrying yourself sick about your shares, the chances are that you are a novice investor. People who invested in February and early March have lost most because they invested at the peak of the stock market. Someone who put £1,000 into Framlington's NetNet fund then would now have only about £650.

But financial advisers and stockbrokers say they got very few anguished phone calls after the sharp falls last week. Those they did receive tended to come from investors who were new to the market. 'Most of our clients can remember the 1987 crash,' says Colin Jackson of Baronworth. 'They are taking this as a slight blip - which is what it is. Our advice to them in 1987 was to sit tight. We would give the same advice now.'

Ian Millward of Bath-based Chase de Vere is typical of advisers in telling his clients to resist the temptation to make rash decisions.

Sitting tight was the best advice for most of those who could afford to do so in 1987. It took two years, on average, for unit trusts to recover their value after October 1987, according to the Association for Unit Trusts and Investment Funds. The current volatility - though quite likely to continue for a few months - is not in the same league as the nosedive of 1987. And volatile markets tend to go up just as quickly as they fall. The technology-dominated Nasdaq fell by 1,100 points the week before last, but rose by 500 points in just the first two days of last week.

People who want to get their decisions right in future should consider the following points:

 Start off in safer investments such as unit trusts if you are going to put money into the stock market. Your risk is spread in a fund between dozens or hundreds of different stocks. One reason that so many day traders will get their fingers burnt is that they are investing directly in individual company shares. This makes them far more vulnerable to the collapse of a single company than someone who invests in a unit trust, and may hardly notice the impact of a single firm going under.

 View equity investments as long-term commitments, to be kept for at least five or 10 years. This way you will expect fluctuations, and you will probably be able to get through a crash of the size of the one in 1987. Charles Levett-Scrivener of financial adviser Towry Law says: 'Investing in equities becomes gambling if you can't cope with the downside or can't wait for things to go right.'

 Unless you are an experienced stock market investor with plenty of time to spend on following your shares, do not try to make your money on the stock market by the close timing of your investment decisions. Very few people make money this way. You will be better off sticking to funds run by professional managers.

 Spread your risk. Millward says: 'The best way to protect your money is to go for a balanced portfolio, with some money in cash deposits, some in bonds and some in stocks and shares.'

 Do not invest at all if you cannot bear the possible downside. If you would be ruined by a 25 per cent decline in the value of your portfolio, you should find a safer home for your money.

The present volatility is regarded as a correction in excessive valuations of technology, and particularly Internet, companies, rather than a deterioration in their fundamentals. Experts think the uncertainty will continue because there is no consensus yet on how to value these firms. Chris Bell, fund manager of the NetNet fund, says: 'If everyone is using a different number-crunching valuation model, the market will continue to be volatile.'

webTitle: What sort of investor are you?

fields.headline: What sort of investor are you?
fields.trailText: Frequent dealers who obeyed the rules of investment should have set up cut-off points at which to take profits as the market moves up or down, and should by now be sitting on a tidy pile of cash.
fields.body:
The frequent share dealer

Frequent dealers who obeyed the rules of investment should have set up cut-off points at which to take profits as the market moves up or down, and should by now be sitting on a tidy pile of cash.

Such investors are in a good position to take advantage of the current market volatility, says Justin Urquart Stewart of Barclays Stockbrokers. Frequent dealers have tended to concentrate on small, relatively unknown companies with low share prices, where it has been easier to make a quick profit. But Urquart Stewart says the price of shares in good-quality companies is now much lower than several months ago.

'You are going to see a winnowing-out of wheat from the chaff. Frequent traders won't have to risk themselves in rinky-dink stocks, but can follow good-quality ones. Marconi is down from £11 to £7.50, Cable & Wireless was selling for £15.62 in March and is now down to £10.13, and Lloyds TSB, which was selling for over £10 last year is at £6.61.'

However, rather than simply plunging in, Urquart Stewart says investors should follow the companies they are interested in and wait until they have started climbing in value again to buy shares.

Sadly, many of the new wave of frequent dealers have been so enthralled at making seemingly easy gains, they have failed to take profits or put stop losses in place to protect themselves. However, Jeremy Batstone, of NatWest Stockbrokers, says if such investors learn from this and set up suitable investment disciplines, they will be best placed to benefit from future stock market growth.

Like many commentators, Batstone believes earnings growth is set to decrease, making it impossible to achieve 20 per cent a year by simply sitting back and doing nothing. To make decent returns, investors must learn to take smaller profits on a regular basis.

He says: 'Investors must learn when to buy and sell, rather than buy and hold. It's not a good outlook for passive investors. People are going to have to become more proactive in their selling strategies.'

Investor with a lump sum

If you've got several thousand pounds sitting in your bank account, what should you do?

'Invest it,' says Jonathan Gumpel at London adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer. 'People should not be afraid of buying into the market at the moment. Provided they are long-term investors, everything is cheap now.

The market may have further to fall, but it may not. Old-economy stocks were already cheap, and there are super earnings figures coming from technology companies in the US. Stocks cost 40 per cent less now than they did two weeks ago.'

However, Gumpel says investors should buy funds rather than individual stocks. He explains: 'It's not a case of buy old economy or new economy; it's a case of buying winners. It's very hard for individual investors to spot those, so I would buy funds to get blanket coverage.'

He recommends the Perpetual Income & Growth fund, an investment trust standing at a 20 per cent discount, for solid 'old economy' investment, plus the Aberdeen Technology unit trust or the Invesco English and International investment trust (at a 24 per cent discount) to give coverage of the so-called 'new economy'.

Ian Millward of Bath independent adviser Chase de Vere Investments says investors should proceed as if the market were stable. 'Aim for a balanced portfolio, with some money in cash, some in fixed- rate bonds and some in stocks and shares, making use of your Isa allowance. Ideally you should have about 50 per cent invested in the UK market, and 50 per cent internationally, including 5 to 10 per cent in pure technology funds.'

Investor who put money into technology stocks and funds a year ago

People who have had money invested in technology stocks over the past year are likely to be sitting on a tidy profit, despite the fall over the past two weeks.

Investors in Framlington's NetNet fund, a unit trust that targets Internet companies and those making profitable use of the Internet, are still benefiting from a 50 per cent increase year on year, and have even seen their units increase in value last week.

Lesley Hankin, marketing manager for Framlington, says: 'The NetNet fund went up by 5 per cent on Tuesday, for example, and we wouldn't be surprised if it has gone up by another 10 to 15 per cent by the beginning of next week. It's a very volatile market.'

As a product provider, Framlington can't advise investors on how to handle their holdings, but Hankin says: 'We believe in the long-term story of the sector. We launched the fund on the basis that people should invest their money for long periods.'

Gumpel of Brooks Macdonald Gayer agrees: 'They should sit tight. They're in profit and in the right long-term growth sector. They've just got to run with it.'

However, Chase de Vere's Ian Millward says that it is quite reasonable for investors to take some of their profits out now, either to rebalance their portfolio or simply to spend.

'We are firm believers in the technology sector, and there are still big returns to be had from it,' he says. 'It just depends on how comfortable you feel leaving your profits in place.'

Pensioner or soon-to-be pensioner

If you are a pensioner dependent on the income from your equity or corporate bond fund, you will not be affected by any short-term falls in the market. 'You can just wait for the markets to calm down,' says Charles Levett-Scrivener of adviser Towry Law.

If you are a pensioner with capital of less than £40,000, equity investments are a bit of a risky home for your money, suggests Colin Jackson of adviser Baronworth. It is only if you have more than about £50,000 that you could really be comfortable with some degree of risk through equities.

If the current stock market nervousness makes you unable to sleep at night, you probably should not be invested there. 'No one should be relying on capital growth to fund life's necessities,' says Levett-Scrivener.

If you are within 10 years of retirement, you should be starting a gradual process in your pension fund of divestment from equities into less risky fixed-interest funds or with-profits funds that are designed to smooth out stock market fluctuations.

Adviser Chartwell suggests starting this process right now if you are 10 years away. 'Most people coming to retirement don't want added risk,' says spokesman Patrick Connolly.

If you are in a final salary pension scheme, you do not have to worry about these issues - you are guaranteed a pension which is a certain proportion of your pay at retirement. But if you are in a personal pension or occupational 'money purchase' scheme, you are building up an investment fund - so investment issues are important to you.

Most occupational 'money purchase' schemes will suggest to you that you divest in the decade before your planned retirement.

Middle Englander: forty-something with family, mortgage, pension and some investments

'If you have got more than 10 years to go to retirement then the bulk of your investments should be in equities - unless you are really cautious,' says Charles Levett-Scrivener of Towry Law So the advice from most financial advisers to most clients in these circumstances will be to sit out the stock market fluctuations that we are likely to see continuing this summer.

If you have invested sensibly, you will have a spread of investments through your pension fund, personal equity plans, individual savings accounts and, possibly, an endowment to back your mortgage.

The trustees of your company pension scheme, for instance, will have anticipated exactly this sort of stock market nervousness when they devised their investment strategy.

Your pension fund assets are likely to be spread between indexed funds, UK stocks, foreign shares, property and some fixed-interest vehicles.

If you know that you will need some of the money - to help a child through university, for example - you should decide how much risk you can bear.

If your total savings cover that expected cost and no more, you should probably play safe and put it on deposit if you need the money soon.

If, however, you can tolerate a 10 per cent fall in the value of your investments and still pay these costs, you may not want to put that money on deposit yet.

Similarly, if you have £70,000 accumulated in Peps to pay off your £80,000 mortgage in two years, you have a choice of cashing in the investments now (if you could not afford the possibility of a fall in value at the time you will need the money) or leaving the investments in place in the hope that they mature to reach £80,000.

If you have an endowment plan, you have to be particularly careful about early surrender (or selling it on the 'traded endowments' market) since many life offices will penalise you heavily for having cashed it in early.

Person who wants to invest each month

Most advisers agree on this one. If you regard the money as a long-term investment (which should be more than 10 years) you should start a broadly-based unit trust or other savings plan now and not worry. Over any period of a few years, your investments will probably go down for a while. But over five to 10 years, equity investments will usually outperform cash, fixed-interest funds, property and other assets.

'Go for growth funds - so the managers can go into technology when it looks good value,' says Patrick Connolly of Chartwell. Technology will undoubtedly be a factor in stock market growth over the foreseeable future - but with a broad unit or investment trust, managers can move in and out of technology stocks as they think fit.

An obvious home for your money is an equities Isa - protecting you against capital gains tax and income tax - useful benefits for higher-rate taxpayers. The advantages of Isas are less marked for basic-rate taxpayers, but if you choose a low-charging provider you could find it a worthwhile investment in that the charges on the Isa are less than the tax you would have paid.

'No one should be relying on capital growth to fund life's necessities,' says Levett-Scrivener. If you are within 10 years of retirement, you should be starting a gradual process in your pension fund of divestment from equities into less risky fixed-interest funds or with-profits funds that are designed to smooth out stock market fluctuations. Adviser Chartwell suggests starting this process right now if you are 10 years away. 'Most people coming to retirement don't want added risk,' says spokesman Patrick Connolly. If you are in a final salary pension scheme, you do not have to worry about these issues - you are guaranteed a pension which is a certain proportion of your pay at retirement. But if you are in a personal pension or occupational 'money purchase' scheme, you are building up an investment fund - so investment issues are important to you. Most occupational 'money purchase' schemes will suggest to you that you divest in the decade before your planned retirement. Middle Englander: forty-something with family, mortgage, pension and some investments 'If you have got more than 10 years to go to retirement then the bulk of your investments should be in equities - unless you are really cautious,' says Charles Levett-Scrivener of Towry Law So the advice from most financial advisers to most clients in these circumstances will be to sit out the stock market fluctuations that we are likely to see continuing this summer. If you have invested sensibly, you will have a spread of investments through your pension fund, personal equity plans, individual savings accounts and, possibly, an endowment to back your mortgage. The trustees of your company pension scheme, for instance, will have anticipated exactly this sort of stock market nervousness when they devised their investment strategy. Your pension fund assets are likely to be spread between indexed funds, UK stocks, foreign shares, property and some fixed-interest vehicles. If you know that you will need some of the money - to help a child through university, for example - you should decide how much risk you can bear. If your total savings cover that expected cost and no more, you should probably play safe and put it on deposit if you need the money soon. If, however, you can tolerate a 10 per cent fall in the value of your investments and still pay these costs, you may not want to put that money on deposit yet. Similarly, if you have £70,000 accumulated in Peps to pay off your £80,000 mortgage in two years, you have a choice of cashing in the investments now (if you could not afford the possibility of a fall in value at the time you will need the money) or leaving the investments in place in the hope that they mature to reach £80,000. If you have an endowment plan, you have to be particularly careful about early surrender (or selling it on the 'traded endowments' market) since many life offices will penalise you heavily for having cashed it in early. Person who wants to invest each month Most advisers agree on this one. If you regard the money as a long-term investment (which should be more than 10 years) you should start a broadly-based unit trust or other savings plan now and not worry. Over any period of a few years, your investments will probably go down for a while. But over five to 10 years, equity investments will usually outperform cash, fixed-interest funds, property and other assets. 'Go for growth funds - so the managers can go into technology when it looks good value,' says Patrick Connolly of Chartwell. Technology will undoubtedly be a factor in stock market growth over the foreseeable future - but with a broad unit or investment trust, managers can move in and out of technology stocks as they think fit. An obvious home for your money is an equities Isa - protecting you against capital gains tax and income tax - useful benefits for higher-rate taxpayers. The advantages of Isas are less marked for basic-rate taxpayers, but if you choose a low-charging provider you could find it a worthwhile investment in that the charges on the Isa are less than the tax you would have paid.

webTitle: Europe's marathon man runs the gauntlet, but dodges Italian race

fields.headline: Europe's marathon man runs the gauntlet, but dodges Italian race
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Romano Prodi is taking a short Easter break at home in Bologna, but he is definitely not getting involved in the search for a new government in Rome. Watching the crisis from afar, the European commission president insists that he has no wish to be Italian prime minister again.
fields.body:
Romano Prodi is taking a short Easter break at home in Bologna, but he is definitely not getting involved in the search for a new government in Rome. Watching the crisis from afar, the European commission president insists that he has no wish to be Italian prime minister again.

In his first interview with a British newspaper since a recent flurry of criticism of his performance at the EU's helm - and dark, though unsubstantiated rumours of a plot to oust him - Mr Prodi, 60, says he is ready for a long haul in Brussels.

"I am not a sprinter. I am a marathon man," he declares combatively. "This is a marathon. And a difficult one."

Clearly bruised by speculation about his future, he reels off a neat list of his alleged gaffes and misjudgements to argue that he is doing fine running the EU's executive arm.

Mr Prodi, who took over from the disgraced Jacques Santer of Luxembourg last autumn, is far more relaxed in private than in public, where he can come across as rambling and ineffective.

"Ah, I see you have not brought an interpreter," he jokes, a reference to suggestions that his English is poor. It is good enough - what may be more of a problem is that it is better than his French, which is no longer the automatic lingua franca in Brussels.

Anxious aides look on as he negotiates the minefield he faces in any contact with the British public, this week rated in a Eurobarometer survey as the most hostile in the union to the EU and its works.

Strikingly, not a word of criticism passes his lips about Tony Blair, not even the prime minister's reluctance to campaign positively on the burning issue of British membership of the single currency.

Of course, argues Mr Prodi, never happier than when talking about the economics he used to teach, there are "obvious" consequences to not being a member of a large currency area - exchange rate fluctuations, disincentives to inward investment.

But are there political consequences too? "Probably yes, in the sense that there will be other forms of cooperation among the euro countries because they have the common currency. To be out is a choice." But it is strictly a choice for the British people.

On defence too, he is anxious to avoid waving red rags at excitable Eurosceptic bulls. He never uses the phrase "European army," he says, yet he is a strong supporter of EU-run peacekeeping to make the union a bigger global player.

He exercises similar hyper-caution on Denmark, where a referendum in September on joining the single currency will be closely watched as a dry run for one after the election in Britain.

On less controversial ground, Mr Prodi insists his top priority remains the enlargement of the 15-country EU to the east and south - another area where he has been criticised for suggesting delaying the entry of the first candidates.

"If we do not succeed with enlargement Europe will collapse," he warns. "Strategically, we will be the biggest economic and political entity in the world - 500m people at the end of this process - twice the population of the US."

But enlargement needs many changes if the EU's decision-making procedures, often encumbered by national vetoes, are to work in a union of up to 27 members. Mr Prodi raised eyebrows by putting forward his own proposals, on tax issues in particular, though reform is strictly a matter for governments.

He is keen on the proposed EU charter of fundamental rights, to codify and simplify existing rights, but he agrees that national capitals, not Brussels, will have the last word on that too.

Winding down before his holiday, Mr Prodi does not sound beleaguered. But he is being forced to defend himself against powerful, if anonymous, forces - in Berlin and Paris in particular, where there are those who see him as an Anglo-Saxon stooge.

Closer to home, there is a sense that the commission is being overshadowed by the council - where EU governments come together to work on defence, justice and home affairs - and by a parliament which, though still weak, is more feisty than ever.

Mr Prodi's response is that he is not being squeezed between the other two institutions but rather burdened with new tasks - not least in the Balkans, or following up the ambitious Lisbon summit agenda on e-commerce, computer literacy and education.

"I should like to be squeezed, but every day they ask us to do something new with the same budget and resources."

He is particularly defensive about his contacts with the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, arguing that he did a "useful job" in opening up a dialogue with a man other EU leaders were also "queueing up" to meet.

Critics of that move, perhaps Mr Prodi's most controversial yet, say that the president of the commission has simply forgotten that he no longer has the freedom he enjoyed as prime minister.

"If you have responsibility for a developing institution, the only thing you cannot pretend is that you have clear-cut power," he says. "I am prepared to be criticised many times, because when an institution is new it is fated to have problems of borders.

"It is a different type of power from the power I had in Italy, but it is so interesting because you have to create something new every day. This is power too, even if the results come later."

webTitle: Slow death of black farmer's dream

fields.headline: Slow death of black farmer's dream
fields.standfirst:
A slow death for the resettlement dream

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Langton Chikosha looks over his tiny patch of farm land and laments the slow death of his modest dreams.
fields.body:
Langton Chikosha looks over his tiny patch of farm land and laments the slow death of his modest dreams.

As one of Zimbabwe's landless blacks, he was given 12 acres of formerly white-owned farm land eight years ago from which he hoped to cultivate a steady income to support his two wives and their 15 children.

But with so little land and no access to the loans he needs to buy the proper tools, pesticides and fertilisers, Mr Chikosha has never made a profit from his farm and has reverted almost entirely to subsistence farming.

"I am a farmer since forever," Mr Chikosha said. But after years of hard work, "you're left with nothing at all".

Throughout Zimbabwe, thousands of squatters supported by President Robert Mugabe have occupied hundreds of white-owned farms, demanding that land be parcelled out to the country's impoverished blacks. But for the 90,000 blacks who have already been given land, resettlement has rarely led to prosperity.

Nearly two-thirds of the 7.4m acres bought from white farmers and distributed to landless blacks have reverted to mainly subsistence plots. The government says it does not have the money to install the roads, water pipes and other necessary infrastructure to make the plots profitable.

Mr Chikosha and 39 other farmers live in Chiota, 40 miles south-east of Harare, on what was once a single white-owned tobacco and cattle farm.

Unlike the white farmers, who can use their land as collateral for bank loans, Mr Chikosha and the other resettled black farmers do not own their farms. The state holds the deeds and gives them farming rights.

Government loans allow Mr Chikosha to buy little more than fertiliser.

Most of his land sprouts maize, peanuts and other subsistence crops. But he has reserved a tiny corner of his farm to nurse his dreams of prosperity - tobacco.

Experts have told him that this plot can produce more than 6,000lb of tobacco. Mr Chikosha has never come near to that .

Last year he harvested 2,000lb and earned £500, which just covered his costs.

Other farmers do not even break even. Five of the farms in Mr Chikosha's resettlement area have been abandoned to the weeds after their farmers found it impossible to make a living.

As he surveys his plot, Mr Chikosha laments that 12 acres may not be enough to support his family:

"I want more," he says.

webTitle: Jittery neighbours prepare for regional market slump

fields.headline: Jittery neighbours prepare for regional market slump
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The shock wave from Zimbabwe's worst political crisis since independence is destroying the country's already fragile economy and spreading turbulence to markets throughout southern Africa, analysts warned this week.
fields.body:
The shock wave from Zimbabwe's worst political crisis since independence is destroying the country's already fragile economy and spreading turbulence to markets throughout southern Africa, analysts warned this week.

Inflation is running at more than 70% a year, half the workforce lacks jobs and fuel shortages have been endemic for months.

Meanwhile, a foreign-exchange crisis is looming and the tobacco industry, which accounts for one fifth of the economy, is threatened by the conflict over white-owned farms.

One analyst said on Wednesday that the country faced complete economic meltdown. "The risk is that the political crisis will result in full-scale economic collapse," said Rian Le Roux, head of economic research at a leading investment house in South Africa.

The white-owned farms at the centre of the unrest are the mainstay of the tobacco industry, which accounts for 40% of the country's export earnings and employs 65% of the workforce.

Zimbabwe is the world's third largest exporter of tobacco and most of its 4,500 commercial farms are owned by whites, with the bulk involved in tobacco production.

Analysts fear that with farmers abandoning their properties, planting for next year's harvest may be delayed or abandoned entirely.

Those who have remained on their properties face hurdles selling this year's crop because the government has yet to devalue the Zimbabwe dollar, which is trading at 10% below its official value on the black market.

The tourism industry, a key foreign exchange earner, is on its knees as reports of widespread lawlessness have brought an avalanche of cancellations. "We are hurting badly, very badly," a local industry source said.

Hotel occupancy at Victoria Falls, one of the world's top tourist destinations, was less than half the usual for this time of year, the start of the southern hemisphere autumn, industry sources said.

Some fear that the Z$10bn (£166m) the country earned from its 2m visitors in 1999 could be halved this year.

The decline of the labour-intensive tourism industry threatens to add to the existing mountain of jobless and will intensify Zimbabwe's looming foreign exchange crisis.

Reserves are drying up and international donors are unwilling to arrest the country's fiscal deficit, which has also been in part caused by costly deployment of President Robert Mugabe's army in the civil war raging in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

The concern felt by Zimbabwe's neighbours, whose markets have also been hit by the regional instability stemming from the former Rhodesia, was highlighted on Wednesday when South Africa's central bank governor, Tito Mboweni, urged a swift resolution to the crisis.

"There's a bit of a negative mood [in the markets] emerging from the events there. The quicker they resolve things there, the better for us," Mr Mboweni told the South African parliament's finance committee.

This week, the South African rand hit a 20-month low against the dollar and markets throughout the region on Monday took their biggest battering since October 1997 before recovering some ground ahead of the Easter weekend.

In Zimbabwe, shares fell by 4.3% after nervous foreign investors jumped ship, prompting one broker to say: "The political climate is chasing most foreign investors out, and they will stay out until we know just where this country is headed."

webTitle: After 24 years, Lovemore is still fighting for freedom

fields.headline: After 24 years, Lovemore is still fighting for freedom
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: At the age of 12 Lovemore Moyo left the rural district of Matobo in Matabeleland to help liberate Rhodesia from white minority rule. After a long walk and an even longer truck ride he made it to Zambia via Botswana, and received military training for one of the liberation movements, Zapu.
fields.body:
At the age of 12 Lovemore Moyo left the rural district of Matobo in Matabeleland to help liberate Rhodesia from white minority rule. After a long walk and an even longer truck ride he made it to Zambia via Botswana, and received military training for one of the liberation movements, Zapu.

By the time he was ready for combat the struggle was over. He returned to a black president, Robert Mugabe, a new country, Zimbabwe, and a new kind of oppression.

Mr Mugabe had branded Zapu members, most of whom, like the young Moyo, were from the Ndebele ethnic group, as dissidents. He sent the North Korean-trained fifth brigade to massacre the Ndebele in their thousands.

Mr Moyo, now 36, is a candidate for the opposition Movement for Democratic Change in the Matobo district in the forthcoming elections. He says his political motivation is the same now as it was when he packed his bags at 12.

"I left my home to fight for land and freedom. And 20 years after liberation we are waiting for both," he says.

"I did not risk my life so that one man or one party could stay in power, but so that we could choose our rulers. And we are still waiting for the land.

"Mugabe has rediscovered the issue for his own political purposes. But for the past two decades he has done nothing about it apart from give it to his friends and cronies.

"So I will just have to continue fighting. And just like before I realise I may even lose my life."

Like Mr Moyo, Matebeleland is no stranger to conflict. It is in its past - in the late 19th century Cecil Rhodes's troops destroyed Kraal and burned down the main city, Bulawayo, in a desperate search for mineral deposits.

It is in its present - Bulawayo is now overrun with white farmers who have fled the countryside since the murder of Martin Olds on Tuesday. They fear a "hit squad" of squatters is making its way to the region this weekend to continue the campaign of occupations and political intimidation.

And it is in its language. Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, means "the killing place"; Ndebele denotes "those who carry long shields"; and Mr Mugabe's last reign of terror here in the 80s is known as mkuruhundu - "the spring rain that washes away the chaff of the last season".

"There is a distinctly differ ent feeling in this region, even among members of Zanu [Mr Mugabe's ruling party]," says Shari Eppel, who spent six years investigating the 1983-88 massacres.

"People here know what it is like to come from a region that has been deliberately neglected by this government. And the mkuruhundu means many people know those who were executed or tortured by this government."

That is why the land occupations were late to catch on in Matabeleland. The first serious attempt by squatters to seize a white farm in the region was repelled by black farm labourers. It took the arrival of Chenjerai "Hitler" Hunzvi, the war veterans' leader, to personally take charge of an invasion for the campaign to work. It also explains why squatters are being bussed in to Matebeleland from areas where support for the government is stronger.

"Because of what happened here in the 80s there isn't a lot of heartfelt support for Mugabe," says David Colthart, secretary for legal affairs in the Movement for Democratic Change.

Two weeks ago there was a huge MDC rally in Nyamandlovhu. That is why they targeted the area earlier this week. In this region Zanu are very worried so they have stepped up the campaign before the elections."

Ms Eppel believes Mr Mugabe is adopting exactly the same tactics as he did during the mkuruhundu .

"Of course it is not on the same scale," she says. "But he is conflating ethnic tension with political tension. Before he said, 'If you are Zapu you are a dissident.'

"Since Zapu were mostly Ndebele that effectively meant anyone who spoke Ndebele was a target. Now he is saying, 'Whites are enemies of the state.' "

Most Ndebele believe that the only thing that will stop Mr Mugabe this time is international pressure. "Now that he's made an example of whites I think he will find it politically embarrassing internationally to continue that," says Ms Eppel.

"He'll probably start cracking black skulls in the rural areas soon, just like he did before, and the foreign media will lose interest."

webTitle: Russia votes for nuclear test ban

fields.headline: Russia votes for nuclear test ban
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President-elect Vladimir Putin yesterday seized the international arms control initiative and put Washington under pressure to follow suit when the Russian parliament ratified the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty by a sweeping majority.
fields.body:
President-elect Vladimir Putin yesterday seized the international arms control initiative and put Washington under pressure to follow suit when the Russian parliament ratified the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty by a sweeping majority.

Breaking with years of arms reduction deadlock imposed by a recalcitrant Russian parliament, yesterday's decision gave Mr Putin his second arms control coup in a week on the eve of a major nuclear non-proliferation conference in New York and just as his foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, travels to the US.

The vote backing a test ban treaty which the US senate refused to ratify last year put Mr Putin in a position to seize the moral high ground. Washington has angered Russia with its plan to build a national missile defence system - known as "son of star wars" - in breach of the ABM treaty of 1972, the keystone of the modern age's arms control edifice.

Last week the duma, loyal to Mr Putin after constant confrontation with his predecessor, Boris Yeltsin, abandoned seven years of opposition and endorsed the Start-II arms control treaty halving US and Russian strategic arsenals.

Yesterday's vote by 298 for the test ban with 74 against underlined the assembly's support for Mr Putin two weeks before he is sworn in as head of state. That the Kremlin has engineered the two arms control votes within a week illustrates the eagerness with which Mr Putin is embracing the issue and highlights his tactical astuteness in moving to isolate the Americans.

The new president is keen to push the Start-III arms reduction agreement with the US which should cut both sides' strategic nuclear arsenals to some 1,500 missiles. But he has declared that all his arms control commitments could be void if the US proceeds to ditch the 1972 anti-ballistic missiles treaty and go it alone on the missile shield.

For economic reasons, how ever, Mr Putin is patently keen to embark on arms cuts rather than becoming embroiled in a new arms race. His national security council adopted a military doctrine yesterday lowering Russia's nuclear threshold.

The doctrine, replacing Mr Yeltsin's 1993 document, updates Russian security strategy and reflects the pitiable condition of the armed forces by making it plain that the Kremlin will have little option but to "go nuclear" to thwart serious, but conventional, threats to national security.

Mr Ivanov goes to New York and Washington tomorrow to prepare the first Putin-Clinton summit in June in Moscow, at which the ABM row will figure prominently.

Britain was quick to welcome yesterday's ratification vote. The Foreign Office minister Peter Hain said: "We hope the US and China will now do likewise."

webTitle: African heads of state stand by Mugabe

fields.headline: African heads of state stand by Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Mozambican president says Britain should pay to settle land issue as violence overshadows summit

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: African leaders at a regional summit yesterday backed President Robert Mugabe's call for land redistribution, giving the embattled Zimbabwean leader a much needed political boost as tensions worsened in rural areas.
fields.body:
African leaders at a regional summit yesterday backed President Robert Mugabe's call for land redistribution, giving the embattled Zimbabwean leader a much needed political boost as tensions worsened in rural areas.

Joaquim Chissano, the president of Mozambique, said western governments should stump up the cash promised at a 1998 donor conference to fund land redistribution, the issue at the heart of escalating violence which has cost eight lives so far.

"We think the donors, including Great Britain, have to deliver," Mr Chissano said after talks with Mr Mugabe and the South African president, Thabo Mbeki. "They have to fulfil their commitments."

Meanwhile, hundreds of people demanding peace marched through the Zimbabwean capital yesterday as violent tension rose in rural areas.

A multiracial crowd took to the streets of Harare in a Good Friday procession to call for an end to the violence that threatens to spiral out of control over the ownership of farm land. "We always pray, but this year we are praying for peace in our country," said one participant. "We're praying for God to give wisdom to our leaders."

The regional summit at Zimbabwe's Victoria Falls - supposedly to chew over the war in the Democratic Republic of the Congo - was hijacked by the host country's land crisis.

Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of Zimbabwe's Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), which poses the biggest challenge to the ruling Zanu-PF party in parliamentary elections next month, called on the leaders to put pressure on Mr Mugabe to resolve the crisis.

Despite public pledges made on Wednesday by Mr Mugabe and his ally, the war veterans' leader Chenjerai Hunzvi, that peace would prevail on the white-owned farms, violent attacks have continued against white farmers and many black workers.

Black self-styled veterans of Zimbabwe's liberation war in the 1970s have invaded hundreds of farms, obstructing the production of crops on which the country largely depends for food and foreign exchange.

While white farmers are the target, their black farm workers are bearing the brunt of the increasingly lawless campaign. On several farms on the outskirts of Harare, labourers were carting off their possessions to relatives in urban areas, fearing that they might be the next target.

"People are very scared. We just want to be left alone to do our work" said Enoph Enoph, a 22-year-old labourer on a farm 28 miles east of Harare, as he stood in his empty house.

Mr Mugabe says his supporters must take back the land stolen from them by white colonialists during the Rhodesian era. But government critics charge that he is simply whipping up antagonism on the land issue to win the support of peasants in the upcoming elections.

The festering war in Congo - which threatens to suck several countries into a region-wide conflict and is the ostensible reason for the summit - has only added to Mr Mugabe's political woes.

Zimbabwe has 11,000 troops in Congo fighting alongside smaller contingents from Namibia and Angola to shore up the beleaguered Congolese president, Laurent Kabila. Rebel forces battling Mr Kabila are backed by troops from Uganda and Rwanda.

A ceasefire agreement reached last July has collapsed.

Zimbabwe's involvement in the Congo war has worsened the country's economic problems and is unpopular with ordinary Zimbabweans, who suspect that Mr Mugabe's ruling clique is trying to cash in on Congo's mineral riches.

webTitle: President's 'brownshirts' lay waste the wealth of the land means of support

fields.headline: President's 'brownshirts' lay waste the wealth of the land means of support
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: As our vehicle approached the roadblock about 30 men jumped up, and one motioned us to come closer. We thought better of it and began to turn round. The men ran at us, brandishing clubs and sticks in a most menacing way. We managed to drive off with only a thump on the back of the truck from a thrown stone.
fields.body:
As our vehicle approached the roadblock about 30 men jumped up, and one motioned us to come closer. We thought better of it and began to turn round. The men ran at us, brandishing clubs and sticks in a most menacing way. We managed to drive off with only a thump on the back of the truck from a thrown stone.

Supporters of President Robert Mugabe had closed Chifumbi Road, 25 miles north-east of Harare. They were almost certainly some of the 200 men who burned down the homes of 1,000 farm labourers on Thursday and beat to death the farmer's dogs and other domestic animals. It did not seem wise to try to speak to them.

"They asked me what political party I support," said Tendai Badza, a young man walking along the road. "I said 'I back the ruling party,' so they let me pass."

We later discovered that Mr Badza was one of the invaders of a nearby farm.

Uniformed policemen less than half a mile away were told of the roadblock and merely shrugged.

The men at the roadblock stopped journalists visiting the Atlanta and Rudolfia farms, which were invaded and vandalised on Thursday.

Alan Windrum, the owner of Rudolfia farm, was Zimbabwe's biggest tomato producer, employing 1,000 workers, and a supporter of the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC).

"He spent millions of [Zimbabwe] dollars building those homes, putting in water, sewage and electricity. He looked after his labour well," said Horace Kirton, who works with farmers in the area.

"Windrum left his farm to Mugabe's invaders. Now look what they've done, they've destroyed valuable property. They've destroyed the belongings of poor farm workers.

"Now 5,000 people are homeless. They are not doing this to get land. They are doing this to frighten people from voting for the MDC."

The roadblock contradicts the assurances given by Mr Mugabe and the war veterans' leader Chenjerai Hunzvi on Wednesday that there would be no more violence against white farmers.

Mr Mugabe said it would be safe for the farmers to return to their farms without any special police protection.

His public statement may have been for the benefit of the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, and other international leaders concerned about the increasing breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe. On the ground though, his followers are still on the warpath.

The Chifumbi roadblock was not an isolated incident. Similar roadblocks have closed access to white farming areas in Enterprise, Arcturus, Macheke, Murehwa and Wedza, in central Zimbabwe. Since two white farmers were killed, increasing numbers of farming families have fled their homes.

It is reported that workers on the big farms are being beaten and their homes ransacked by the invaders, many of whom are armed. They accuse white farmers, motorists and farm labourers of supporting the MDC.

They have closed the Nyamapanda border post, north-east of Harare, saying that the customs officers there support the MDC, the Daily News has reported. The post lies on the main road from Zimbabwe to the city of Tete in Mozambique, and to Malawi.

Although large areas of Zimbabwe are lawless, the rest of the country appears eerily normal. A couple of miles from the barricade in Chifumbi Road, fields of peas and beans were being watered and a greenhouse covering two acres (almost a hectare) was under construction.

Only a cluster of huts of thatch and plastic sheeting showed that squatters were occupying the farm.

Less than a mile from the roadblock a British army colonel was training a group of more than 50 Zimbabwe army officers in map reading and orienting.

"We are carrying out routine training to improve the Zimbabwe army's peacekeeping capacity," said Colonel Aubrey Fletcher, a member of the British military advisory and training team.

"We come to this area every year for this map reading exercise. It just so happens that on this occasion there is trouble nearby."

The farm invaders have carried out a scorched earth policy: tobacco crops have been burned and fresh flowers ready for export ruined.

"These are the export crops that are supposed to pay for the fuel we are importing and the electricity we are importing," Mr Kirton said

"This is crazy. This destruction will only dig this country deeper and deeper into a bottomless pit. Mugabe doesn't care about this country anymore."

A minister in Mr Mugabe's cabinet was asked at a private meeting yesterday why the government was not obeying court orders and upholding the country's laws. "This isn't a legal matter, it is a political matter," he replied.

Mr Mugabe and his supporters may find this a convenient answer, but his critics say that the policy is taking Zimbabwe towards an irreversible course of lawlessness.

"The war veterans have become Mugabe's brownshirts," said Iden Wetherell, deputy editor of the Zimbabwe Independent.

"They are his private militia charged with carrying out his campaign of rural terror. They are beyond the reach of law enforcement agencies.

"Mugabe has conducted a coup against the constitution and the law of Zimbabwe."
