fields.headline: Pioneers predict e-health explosion
fields.standfirst:
Analysts and entrepreneurs say net can cut waste in European medical sector

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's nascent e-health sector is on the verge of a dramatic expansion that could transform the way health care is administered and delivered, according to the leading players in the region. That was the message from companies, analysts and investors attending a European e-health conference organised by Ernst & Young and Atlas Ventures in Amsterdam earlier this week.
fields.body:
Europe's nascent e-health sector is on the verge of a dramatic expansion that could transform the way health care is administered and delivered, according to the leading players in the region. That was the message from companies, analysts and investors attending a European e-health conference organised by Ernst & Young and Atlas Ventures in Amsterdam earlier this week.

Colin Wyatt of Ernst & Young said that although health care has been late to adopt e-commerce, it is now "the fastest growing application on the internet".

In the US, 30% of the population has used the internet for medical information, and 85% of doctors use the web.

Simon Brodie of Boots says the new investment comes at a time of increased consumer interest in health.

Individuals are becoming increasingly affluent, independent, green, diet conscious and inquisitive, he said. Many now use the internet to find out about disease, buy health products and communicate with other patients.

However, Atlas's Rob Zegelaar believes the internet's biggest impact on health care could be in the way services are delivered and waste is cut out of a system that is coming under increasing financial and structural pressure. He envisages portals where suppliers, doctors and patients can communicate and trade online.

"The European health care sector is coming under increasing pressure to bring down prices, increase efficiencies, examine its cost structures and deliver better quality," Mr Zegelaar said.

"The internet is about getting rid of inefficiencies, connecting people to information and suppliers, empowering the consumer. The potential impact it could have on health care is enormous.

"The real opportunity in the health care industry is to get the connectivity between doctors patients pharmacists and reimbursers right.

"The challenge is to make a very inefficient community efficient and take with it an entire market."

Adam Frisch of Warburg Dillon Read adds: "Hospitals need to reduce operating costs by automating various processes. In the US health care industry, 25% or $1.2bn of costs are avoidable each year." Health is a conservative industry split by technology, geography and tradition. Thousands of suppliers serve thousands of customers scattered across large territories. The opportunity for centralised online trading is great.

The medical supplies market in Europe is worth $30bn but the supply chain is fragmented with 12,000 hospitals and 5,000 suppliers.

Similarly Europe's pharmaceuticals market is worth $85bn (£53.7bn), according to Musa Dhalla of Middlesex-based Pharmalife. He is working on a business that will connect the 100,000 pharmacies and 275,000 pharmacists located in mainland Europe, allowing them to trade and communicate on line.

The US is home to the most advanced e-health firms. One of the sectors pioneers is maverick Netscape founder Jim Clark. Four years ago, when he claimed he could revolutionise one of the US's most vital and pressurised industries, even his most loyal of supporters questioned his sanity.

Mr Clark claimed that by building Healtheon, an online system to automate tasks such as referrals, data retrieval, and claims processing, he could change the way insurers, doctors, pharmacies and patients interacted, cutting billions of dollars in administrative costs.

Today Healtheon-Web MD, the combination of several merged companies, has the backing of Microsoft, Intel and News Corporation. Although huge losses on the balance sheet make the company appear sickly, Healtheon and its competitors are gradually moving forward. The same cannot be said for most of their share prices.

Healtheon-WebMD has seen its share price fall from $75 in February to around $19 today as the sector has fallen out of favour with investors.

Last month the auditors to the health care portal, Drkoop.com, the brainchild of former US surgeon general C Everett Koop, warned that the company might not have enough money to stay in business - despite being one of the most visited health sites in the US and a major content provider to AOL. Last year it lost $56.1m on $9.4m in revenues. Analysts blame Drkoop's dependency on advertising revenues and believe its only chance of survival is to merge with a competitor.

Mr Frisch admits: "There are no role models in the US internet health care space. It is a market searching for leader ship." Mr Brodie believes a shake-out is on the cards. "There are many e-commerce offerings in the health arena which are simply not economically viable. There will be many casualties, but for the few the prize is great."

European e-health operators have an even tougher market to crack and will need to overcome formidable challenges relating to regulation, culture and attitudes. "The complexities of the European market make it very difficult to navigate," said Francois Maisonrouge of Credit Suisse First Boston

However, operators such as PlanetMedica, which plans to become a European equivalent of Healtheon, and eLabsEurope, a business to business e-commerce company providing laboratory supplies to scientists, are trying to build a presence in European mainland markets. "It is very important to be pan-Eu ropean in this market," said Karsten Bode of eLabs. Mark Clough of law firm Ashurst Morris Crisp says there are numerous regulatory barriers to be overcome, and they can vary wildly from country to country.

Mr Clough says that in general pharmacists have monopolistic tendencies: their regulation, administration and advisory roles are usually subject to government approval. Marketing authorisation, labelling, pricing and intellectual property laws can be problematic, and privacy and confidentiality issues are raised by online record keeping.

The market's complexity is illustrated by the fact that Boots trades in the UK, Holland and Thailand - but is unable to replicate its model in France and Germany, due to local pharmacy regulations.

Moves are under way at both national and EU levels to change legislation, but the challenge for many firms is that cultural and regulatory issues are likely to move at far slower pace than the rate at which they burn cash.

Some analysts predict venture capitalists will pull the plug before the issues are resolved. It means the speed and quality with which the business plan is executed becomes more important than ever.

Mr Zegelaar believes the winners in the European e-health space will be those that have multiple, recurring revenue streams. He also highlights broad distribution through affiliations and partnerships with key players, a leading market position, first mover advantage, technology and management credibility as defining traits of successful companies.

Despite the challenges, Mr Zegelaar believes the revolution will come. "The health care sector in Europe is generally not delivering right now," he said. "The potential for change cannot be ignored."

"There are many e-commerce offerings in the health arena which are simply not economically viable. There will be many casualties, but for the few the prize is great." European e-health operators have an even tougher market to crack and will need to overcome formidable challenges relating to regulation, culture and attitudes. "The complexities of the European market make it very difficult to navigate," said Francois Maisonrouge of Credit Suisse First Boston However, operators such as PlanetMedica, which plans to become a European equivalent of Healtheon, and eLabsEurope, a business to business e-commerce company providing laboratory supplies to scientists, are trying to build a presence in European mainland markets. "It is very important to be pan-Eu ropean in this market," said Karsten Bode of eLabs. Mark Clough of law firm Ashurst Morris Crisp says there are numerous regulatory barriers to be overcome, and they can vary wildly from country to country. Mr Clough says that in general pharmacists have monopolistic tendencies: their regulation, administration and advisory roles are usually subject to government approval. Marketing authorisation, labelling, pricing and intellectual property laws can be problematic, and privacy and confidentiality issues are raised by online record keeping. The market's complexity is illustrated by the fact that Boots trades in the UK, Holland and Thailand - but is unable to replicate its model in France and Germany, due to local pharmacy regulations. Moves are under way at both national and EU levels to change legislation, but the challenge for many firms is that cultural and regulatory issues are likely to move at far slower pace than the rate at which they burn cash. Some analysts predict venture capitalists will pull the plug before the issues are resolved. It means the speed and quality with which the business plan is executed becomes more important than ever. Mr Zegelaar believes the winners in the European e-health space will be those that have multiple, recurring revenue streams. He also highlights broad distribution through affiliations and partnerships with key players, a leading market position, first mover advantage, technology and management credibility as defining traits of successful companies. Despite the challenges, Mr Zegelaar believes the revolution will come. "The health care sector in Europe is generally not delivering right now," he said. "The potential for change cannot be ignored."

webTitle: An Easter tale of greed and gullibility

fields.headline: An Easter tale of greed and gullibility
fields.standfirst:
The bunny learns a lesson in 'new economy' investing

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: It was the day before the Easter break. Rain fell in stair-rods, hammering the City pavements. A phalanx of brokers and bankers elbowed their way down Throgmorton Street under a rainbow of golfing umbrellas.
fields.body:
It was the day before the Easter break. Rain fell in stair-rods, hammering the City pavements. A phalanx of brokers and bankers elbowed their way down Throgmorton Street under a rainbow of golfing umbrellas.

Buffeted by this army of financiers, a lone figure struggled against the general flow. At another time his floppy ears and fluffy tail might have attracted attention. But the markets were about to open, and there were financial fires to douse.

The Easter Bunny (for it was he) was headed for his office in a converted loft to the east of Spitalfields market - an E1 address that avoided City rates. In his hand he clasped a new generation WAP-enabled mobile. Not for him the audio communications of technology's jurassic era, the late second millennium.

The liquid crystal display of his Nokia told a sorry tale. With only a millisecond's delay, the price of April 2000 Easter egg call options was continuously updated before his eyes. With less than a day to expiry, the Bunny's holding of egg contracts was to all intents worthless.

It was tempting to blame the new technologies for his "old economy" woes. Chocolate at Easter had become passé. Today's children hoped to receive interactive egg games, or a booster pack of Pokémon cards.

In his heart, however, the Bunny knew he only had himself to blame. Reality had set in with the rain a couple of weeks ago. Until then he'd allowed himself to be seduced by the strength of the economy. Markets were up, wages were rising, stores were full. Everyone, it seemed, felt good. And in the past, the correlation between consumer confidence and Easter egg consumption had been near perfect.

Confident that he knew a winner when he saw one, and angry with himself for missing out on the boom in dot.com stocks, the Bunny bet the warren on a bumper Easter for chocolate eggs. Spurning the market in real eggs, he backed his hunch in the derivatives market - effectively gearing up his exposure to the expected rise in egg prices.

For a while he felt like an investment god. Forget Warren Buffett, he was the great Bunny Warren. There wasn't anything you could teach this rabbit about investment. His paper profits were such that he contemplated a late entrance to the auction of next-generation mobile licences.

Instead he decided to diversify his portfolio by investing in the dot.com end of the stockmarket. It was late, but this technology was revolutionary and here to stay.

The Bunny wanted to run his egg options right up to their Maundy Thursday expiry. He expected a late squeeze on prices as those waiting for a setback before buying realised there wasn't going to be one. So he bought his dot.com stocks on margin, using his egg options as collateral.

The rest, as they say, is rabbit pie. When tomorrow's market historians write the history of the Great Easter Egg Meltdown of 2000, they'll disagree over what crashed first - the techs or the eggs. Those focusing on the role of the Bunny will come closest to the truth.

The first wobble on Nasdaq served as a wake-up call to most tech investors. But the Bunny's financial pyramid was inverted, allowing no room for such warnings. The initial fall in US technology stocks triggered margin calls from his brokers. He was forced to cash in some of his Easter egg options.

Dealers on the floor of the London International Confectionery Exchange (LICK-EX), thought the Bunny knew something they didn't. Egg options crashed, destroying the value of the Bunny's collateral that supported his dot.com stocks.

There was nowhere to hide, apart from his parent's warren under the oak tree at the bottom of the garden. And anyway, hiding was hardly going so save his financial skin. So he sold what he could, driving down the price of many tech stocks to previously unimaginable levels.

In time bargain hunters stepped in. Those who'd waited before loading up on chocolate were rewarded with cut-price eggs on the Lastminute.com website. The Nasdaq took slightly longer to rebound than the egg market - investors initially felt more comfortable going back into the "old" rather than the "new" economy.

And the Bunny? Rest assured, he'll be back next year. But with maybe just a little less spring in his step.

 Edmund Warner is chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities

webTitle: Chile faces moment of truth with hearing to seal off Pinochet's escape route

fields.headline: Chile faces moment of truth with hearing to seal off Pinochet's escape route
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A team of leading human rights lawyers aided by the Chilean government has convinced the supreme court to take legal action against General Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
A team of leading human rights lawyers aided by the Chilean government has convinced the supreme court to take legal action against General Augusto Pinochet.

Seven weeks after he was released from house arrest in Britain and returned to Chile, the effort to put the former dictator under formal investigation is due to begin next week.

A hearing will be held on Wednesday to decide whether he can be stripped of his immunity and tried on human rights charges.

In a series of unprecedented government moves against Gen Pinochet, the state defence council has taken an active role in helping the prosecution.

Carmen Hertz, a human rights lawyer and author, called the development Chile's "moment of truth".

"Now we will see who has the power," she said. "The elected civilian authorities or the military."

There are rumours circulating that the US will ask for Gen Pinochet's extradition should the Chilean justice system fail to put him on trial.

Following up the murder case known as "The Letelier Bombing", in which the former Chilean ambassador to the US, Orlando Letelier, and his aide were killed by a terrorist car bombing in Washington 24 years ago, the US justice de partment recently sent a team of FBI investigators to Chile to question key Pinochet aides.

But many believe that this was no more than than a public relations effort to satisfy victims of the Pinochet regime.

Except in the case of the sometime Panamanian strongman Manuel Noriega, who was also a close ally of US military intelligence, Washington has avoided charging its former Latin cronies on US soil.

Doubts about the Chilean judicial system's ability to work independent of military pressures are being fully tested by the Pinochet case.

Under Chilean law, civilian judges are often subservient to their military counterparts and are legally barred from entering military facilities to carry out investigations.

As commander in chief of the military junta for nearly 25 years, Gen Pinochet led a government that committed thousands of murders and carried out systematised torture sessions.

But because of an amnesty law created by Gen Pinochet himself in Chile's 1980 constitution, and his status as a self-appointed "senator for life", he has never been investigated in Chile.

Before a criminal case can begin, he must first be stripped of this immunity.

Gen Pinochet's lawyers have tried on several occasions to have the case thrown out by submitting medical tests that prove that he is legally "crazy and demented", as Chilean law designates those mentally incapable of defending themselves.

But there is no provision in the law to let Gen Pinochet's mental condition be a factor in deciding whether he should be stripped of his senatorial privileges. Medical reasons can only be considered later in the process - for example, in a criminal trial.

"The immunity hearing is exclusively focused on two points [the charges of being the intellectual author of 19 assassinations and an accessory to those crimes]," said Crisologo Burgos, a lawyer for the Chilean government, who is assisting the prosecution.

In an effort to deflect the efforts to prosecute him, the 84-year-old general's children reluctantly agreed that their father was mentally ill and unfit for trial.

The fact that their decision came after widely publicised haggling with the defence lawyers did little to dampen speculation that the general's mental illness was being managed with military precision.

Gen Pinochet's circle of supporters has so withered in the past months that the Pinochet Foundation has reverted to denouncing the pending court actions as plots by '"extreme leftists" designed to besmirch the general's good name.

In a hasty effort to galvanise that flagging support, the Pinochet defence team has begun working with public relations agencies.

The slogans chosen for the new Pinochet image have not yet been released but, based on the recent flurry of confessions by retired military officers, the general's ability to recreate an air of impunity seems to be slim.

A recent public opinion poll showed that 50% of Chileans had a very negative impression of the once-revered general. Insanity now appears to be the only recourse that might let the military strongman who just two years ago walked in self-created glory live his last days in relative peace.

Eighty-six separate cases are pending against him, and further ones are being filed almost daily. The sheer number of criminal complaints and the hundreds of victims involved have led the investigating judge, Juan Guzman Tapia, to sort the cases chronologically and geographically.

The first of them is the 1973 "Caravan of Death", in which at least 72 political prisoners were kidnapped and executed by a roving hit squad. The prosecution accuses Gen Pinochet of being the "intellectual author" and an accessory to the crimes.

The strongest evidence against Gen Pinochet comes from high-ranking military officers who have implicated him in 19 separate assassinations. Sergio Arellano Stark, an army general who is alleged to have led the death squad, is said to have received written orders from Gen Pinochet.

Gen Stark and five other senior officers have already been arrested and are being investigated for the Caravan of Death murders.

None of them enjoys senatorial immunity.

Judge Guzman's interviews with Gen Pinochet's aides have led to unprecedented evidence that he directly ordered assassinations, according to copies of the Guzman documents which were recently published in the Argentine daily Phania 12.

In an attempt to save Gen Pinochet, several far-right political groups, including the Independent Democratic Union (UDI), have unsuccessfully sought to cobble together a deal by which the dictator would be allowed a "dignified exit" from the political arena without being prosecuted.

But the interior minister, Jose Miguel Insulza, has ridiculed the idea.

"These are issues beyond the reach of congress and government," he said.

"The Pinochet issue must be resolved in a legal arena."

The recently elected president, Ricardo Lagos, called the UDI party actions "inappropriate". President Lagos has repeatedly insisted that his administration will support the judicial branch.

"There is no doubt that by attempting to influence the conduct of judges, [rightwing senators] have fallen away from their constitutional obligation to respect the independence of the judiciary."

But despite recent events, there remain many obstacles to a Pinochet trial in Chile. Efforts to televise the initial hearings were rejected by judges as too invasive, and in recent weeks the judges have objected to the public interest in the case, leading many observers to doubt that he will even be investigated.

The spectacle of the once feared leader being tried or convicted is, to many Chileans, unthinkable.

"They are not going to do anything in the end," said Elda Bravo, 40, a school teacher who believes the country's judiciary is merely making a bit of noise to avoid criticism for its 30 years of inaction.

"The government has never wanted to judge him, they just want Pinochet to retire."

fields.headline: AbFab's Patsy on health kick
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.clickmango.com
fields.trailText: Log on to Clickmango.com today and you will be confronted by articles on folic acid, thrush, osteopathy for pets and spotty foreheads.
fields.body:
Log on to Clickmango.com today and you will be confronted by articles on folic acid, thrush, osteopathy for pets and spotty foreheads.

You will find mail-order health products for sale, diet advice, a message board and information on more than 200 common ailments.

It went live two weeks ago, as "a natural health & beauty site dedicated to helping you live a happier, healthier life". Its target is a European natural health products market estimated to be worth $25bn. In the UK the retail market is worth $3.8bn, while 25,000 alternative medicine practitioners generate revenues of $1.5bn.

Actress Joanna Lumley has been given equity in the company to promote it. Co-founders Robert Norton and Toby Rowland say Ms Lumley's "health-challenged" image - she plays the heavy smoking and drinking Patsy in television's Absolutely Fabulous - will broaden the company's appeal.

Mr Rowland adds: "Many people become inquisitive about natural health if they feel that traditional medicine has let them down. Others simply want to pamper themselves with the best and most natural products they can buy. We offer a new and interactive means of buying such products."

Sophisticated data technology will be used to develop a database of customers' interests and requirements and used to sell them additional products and services.

Financing of £3m was raised in eight days from Atlas Ventures and the family interests of Lord Rothschild. Rivals include Thinknatural.com set up by former Carlton Online managing director Carol Dukes.

fields.headline: MP campaigns for cannabis cafes
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A Labour MP yesterday launched a campaign to stimulate public debate on the decriminalisation of cannabis by asking fellow MPs to back the licensing of Amsterdam-style cafes where users can buy and smoke their joints legally.
fields.body:
A Labour MP yesterday launched a campaign to stimulate public debate on the decriminalisation of cannabis by asking fellow MPs to back the licensing of Amsterdam-style cafes where users can buy and smoke their joints legally.

Paul Flynn, MP for Newport West, has long been a thorn in the flesh of successive governments over restrictive attitudes towards soft drugs, which a Police Foundation report has said would not be more widely used if some penalties were cut.

Tony Blair and the home secretary, Jack Straw, have been vigorously hostile to liberalisation, although Mr Straw recently conceded the case for a wider debate, after the Daily Telegraph wrong-footed Downing Street, by admitting that the issue should be aired - and a trial period of legalisation granted.

Mr Flynn, a former industrial chemist and arthritis sufferer, said yesterday: "I have been told by a very sensible Tory that 60 to 80 Tory MPs would support the licensing of cafes in a free vote if William Hague was not so opposed.

"I do not believe it would be an electoral liability. You would lose people at one end and gain them at the other end - where voters think the government is being daft."

Mr Flynn yesterday wrote to all his fellow MPs, except hard line opponents of legalisation of cannabis, urging them to back two Commons motions. One would promote the medical use of cannabis, which is known to ease the pain of multiple sclerosis sufferers, the other would be in favour of a "cafe" system.

With Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, calling for public debate on the drugs issue, Mr Flynn will see how much support he has before presenting two bills - based on the motions - to the Commons on June 9.

He is also taking a report to the Council of Europe, where he is rapporteur of the social policy and health committee, examining drug use in two "repressive" states - Britain and Switzerland - and two liberal ones, Sweden and the Netherlands. Use is similar, but drug-related social problems are worse under repressive regimes, he will argue.

But critics say that 20 years of liberalisation have built up deep problems for the Netherlands, including one of the highest levels of Class A drug use - notably heroin - in Europe.

The Police Foundation report suggested that penalties for possession of illegal drugs should be reduced, but supplying them should remain a serious offence. It recommended that possession of cannabis should be punishable only by cautions or fixed fines.

webTitle: How No 10 rottweiler became a TV poodle

fields.headline: How No 10 rottweiler became a TV poodle
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Pierce Brosnan has one for stunts, Saddam Hussein has dozens to thwart assassins, and showbiz agencies hire hundreds out for parties - but has Alastair Campbell now also got a body double?
fields.body:
Pierce Brosnan has one for stunts, Saddam Hussein has dozens to thwart assassins, and showbiz agencies hire hundreds out for parties - but has Alastair Campbell now also got a body double?

The rottweiler of Downing Street, once feared across Westminster for his savage attacks on those judged insufficiently respectful of his master Tony Blair, has become a gentle poodle.

The prime minister's loyal press secretary looks the same and sounds the same, but he is acting and speaking very differently.

Brutality has been replaced by kindness, obstruction by co-operation, snarls by smiles and put-downs by praise in one of the most remarkable personality transformations in modern British politics.

Renowned for his catchphrase "Crap - that's C-R-A-P" to dismiss unwelcome stories, even the swearing has stopped with the apparatchik adopting "garbagick" - a phrase more acceptable before the 9pm watershed.

The fears of lobby journalists that not everything was quite right were confirmed when Mr Campbell hopped aboard their bus instead of into the back seat of the premier's car during a trip to Wales.

"Either there are two of them or the old one has changed drastically. I bet he really hates having to be so nice all of the time."

Mr Campbell's unexpected decision to catch the bus during a tour of south Wales was spoiled slightly by the sight of a camera crew clambering on behind him.

An unusual invitation for representatives of the fourth estate to dine with him was marred somewhat by the sound man's mike.

Political editors and their partners invited for canapes in Downing Street were disappointed, though by this stage not altogether surprised, to find chats interrupted by the appearance of a boom.

fields.headline: TV ratings war
fields.standfirst: Bonnets make way for glamorous twentysomethings
fields.trailText: The battle of the bonnets is over: the new ratings war between the BBC and ITV is to be fought in the bedrooms of impossibly glamorous metropolitan twentysomethings rather than in the discreet parlours of 18th century aristocracy.
fields.body:
The battle of the bonnets is over: the new ratings war between the BBC and ITV is to be fought in the bedrooms of impossibly glamorous metropolitan twentysomethings rather than in the discreet parlours of 18th century aristocracy.

Two rival series are at the centre of a tussle between the two channels over the key 18-35 audience. One comes from the same Granada stable which produced the highly acclaimed Cold Feet; the other is an attempt by the BBC to reclaim the advantage gained by ITV in the young drama genre.

There are remarkable similarities between the two new shows. Both centre on a group of good-looking young friends who met at a provincial university, both take up their story a few years later in London, and both feature plenty of bedroom action, real or imagined.

Executives at the two broadcasters are so sensitive about the new shows that they have both been swapped around the schedules several times in recent weeks.

ITV's offering, Metropolis, will start on May 1 at 10pm, directly after a celebrity edition of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? The second episode will be broadcast at the same time the following night. After ITV announced its schedule BBC1 brought forward Hearts and Bones to April 30.

Metropolis stars a relatively unknown cast, including James Purefoy, Matthew Rhys and Louise Lombard. The Hearts and Bones team is more familiar, headed by Ballykissangel star Dervla Kirwan, Amanda Holden from the 1970s spoof series The Grimleys, and Hugo Speer of Full Monty fame.

ITV has placed Metropolis in the problematic 10pm slot vacated by the News at Ten, in which it has been attempting to woo a younger audience. The strategy has had mixed success, and David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes, hopes the new show will fare better.

Spot the difference

Metropolis Writer: Peter Morgan

Premise Picks up the tale of glamorous twentysomething friends about five years after graduating in Leeds.

Plot Tanya, a radio agony aunt, is in hospital after a car crash. To her bedside comes handsome Nathan, who tells her of the wonderful time they have been spending together. Tanya has no recollection of him, but falls for him anyway. Her friend Sophie is suspicious.

The hype 'This sharp and immediate series is underpinned by the darkly wicked wit of writer Peter Morgan'.

Guardian rating 8/10

Hearts and Bones Writer: Stewart Harcourt

Premise Picks up the tale of glamorous thirtysomething friends almost 10 years after graduating in Coventry.

Plot Mark and Emma have survived eight years together because of their son, Sam. They are about to break up when Mark proposes and Emma accepts. But she thinks she is in love with Mark's brother.

The hype 'Highly original writing and an all-star cast make for some of the most involving scenes to appear on screen for some time'.

Guardian rating 7/10

fields.headline: The big cheese
fields.trailText: Most visitors to Pembrokeshire, where I was last week, sooner or later come across the history of Nest. It is a remarkable story, too, largely unknown in England, and one which convinces me that she deserves a place in the pantheon of Britain's great women, not to mention your local Odeon. This, in essence, is it:
fields.body:
Most visitors to Pembrokeshire, where I was last week, sooner or later come across the history of Nest. It is a remarkable story, too, largely unknown in England, and one which convinces me that she deserves a place in the pantheon of Britain's great women, not to mention your local Odeon. This, in essence, is it:

Nest is the daughter of Rhys ap Tewdwr (Anthony Hopkins), king of Deheubarth and a big Welsh cheese. The roaming eye of a Norman nobleman, Gerald of Windsor (Gérard Depardieu) falls favourably upon the clever and beautiful damsel, and they wed - though according to the celebrated historian Gerald of Wales (Rufus Sewell), who should know as he's Nest's grandson, Windsor's motives for marriage are mainly political; he wishes to link himself with the local aristocracy.

In 1106 or thereabouts, the Windors are visited by her cousin Owain (Ryan Giggs), who, noticing that she is played by Catherine Zeta-Jones, instantly falls in love with her. He sets fire to their home, Pembroke castle (very photogenic) and abducts her, together with two of her sons by Gerald and two of his children from two other mothers (Madonna and Geri Halliwell). A war ensues, after which the couple are reunited. He dies. Six children are thereby orphaned*.

She also at some stage produces a further child with Stephen, constable of Cardigan (Jude Law), whom she may or may not have married, as well as four others by further unspecified lovers. Her most notable conquest, however, is King Henry I (Michael Douglas) who chances on her while visiting Wales, leaving her with a son, also called Henry. Various busybodies (Thora Hird, Christine Hamilton) like to allege that Nest is the mother of Robert, Earl of Gloucester (Chris Evans) but that is a mere canard (Donald Duck). Director: Mel Gibson. The part of Nest as an older woman will be played, if Smallweed is listened to, by Sian Phillips.

*correct use of orphaned, which means losing one parent as well as losing both.

Smallweed was sorry to see that Winsford of the Unibond League premier division went down by 9-0 to Worksop on Saturday. I blame myself. In the past few weeks I have failed to offer one word of encouragement to this gallant outfit which prospered so mightily after I first drew attention to its long run of bad results late last year. And now my neglect is repaid by another appalling defeat. Post hoc, propter hoc, as one of the wiser ancients observed.

Even so, this reverse is less spectacular than the recent result obtained by the Metropolitan Police, a rugby XV, in the Jewson National League, second division, south. They went down on Saturday to Penzance-Newlyn by 136 points to six, provoking the question: would they have won even if they'd been playing not Penzance and Newlyn but Penzance and Newlyn police?

This collection of catastrophic coppers, pathetic peelers and ramfeezled rozzers has lost every one of its 25 games this season, scoring nine points per game on average while conceding 50. I would like to see Ann Widdecombe pressing Jack Straw, who has charge of the Met under present arrangements, to make a statement to parliament. I would like even more to see her packing down in the second row of the Met Police scrum. That would really make oppositions shudder.

The Abbey National, telephoned by Mrs Smallweed this week about some document which had failed to turn up, reassuringly disclosed that she would not have much longer to wait, since the documents would be "doormatting" at the end of May. I had never heard this expression before. Doorstepping yes, but never doormatting. Are they taught this kind of language in staff training classes?

Nature notes: I should never have stumbled into this territory. My claim that nightingales do not venture north of the Trent is disputed in a letter from Harrogate from a reader who spotted one in Knaresborough, that fine town on the river Nidd, some five years ago. JR Mather's The Birds of Yorkshire, he adds, devotes two whole pages to the nightingale in the county.

As for the talented songster's alleged boycott of Scotland, Valerie Thom in her Birds in Scotland records 64 sightings there between 1950 and 1983.I do, however, have a defence for referring in this context to West Bridgeford, on the nightingale-infected southern side of the Trent close to Nottingham, rather than to West Bridgford. Despite what detractors say, I am told that either spelling is acceptable. There is even a West Bridgeford website.

Eric Maschwitz, who wrote the nightingale lyric I never quite quoted last week, is recalled in Frank Muir's memoir, A Kentish Lad. He seems to have been a bit of a masher (or mascher) who once proposed producing a book in which various hands would chart their most memorable sexual encounters. His own, he claimed, occurred when he was on an illicit tryst in the grounds of Woburn Abbey, where his inamorata observed in mid-frenzy what he too had noticed: that the earth really seemed to be moving this time.

"It feels," he murmured into his partner's enraptured ear "like a charging bison". Which, this being Woburn, was just what it was. They had penetrated the zoo area and a force of inquisitive bison was converging on the intruders. I have no idea if this story was true, but regret that he never got round to writing a lyric about it.

"When bison rampaged in Woburn Park" would fit neatly with the tune of the song that I dare not quote. Rhymes like dark, stark, and perhaps even Alan Clark spring nimbly to mind.

fields.headline: Forever Ingerland
fields.standfirst:
Our patron saint came from the Middle East, chips are a Belgian invention . . .

What is Britain: special report
fields.trailText: St Patrick's Day, an annual excuse to sink a Guinness or three and come all over Celtic. St Andrew's Day is toasted by piper and a helping of haggis. St David's Day, when grown men can be seen with a daffodil pinned to the lapel, no doubt dreaming of the leek soup they have to look forward to. But St George's Day, who gives a damn?
fields.body:
St Patrick's Day, an annual excuse to sink a Guinness or three and come all over Celtic. St Andrew's Day is toasted by piper and a helping of haggis. St David's Day, when grown men can be seen with a daffodil pinned to the lapel, no doubt dreaming of the leek soup they have to look forward to. But St George's Day, who gives a damn?

In fact most left-leaning Guardian reader pals of mine don't just ignore our national day, they are hard-pressed to even name the date, and when they do finally remember it (actually it is tomorrow) they come over all awkward and agitational about the very idea of celebrating Englishness.

"Long to reign over us, happy and glorious", the Great British national anthem that is still sung so lustily by the English in place of our own tune, says it all really. We wallow in our subjecthood, unable to break free from an anything-but-United Kingdom.

Our independence becomes translated into cutting ourselves off from Europe, the last stand of the little Englander. Who would want to bother with all this baggage?

But the creeping realisation that England isn't the same as Britain is becoming irresistible. Hardly surprising when the past 12 months have witnessed the opening of the Scottish parliament, the Welsh assembly and the still faltering steps of a Northern Ireland peace settlement. Things are changing at a statist level, yet it is in popular culture that the shift has a real sense of the English dynamic.

The nostalgia pics of England's 1966 World Cup triumph show a sea of Union flags in Wembley's stands. The championship mascot was a distinctively British lion, World Cup Willie, complete with Union flag on his chest. Thirty years of hurt later and Euro '96 Wembley was a sea of St George Cross flags. ("Ingerland!!").

Not a result of diktat or instruction, but a realisation from below that, at least on the football field, the Scots are a foreign nation and England stands apart. From expensive Hackett knitted St George Cross jumpers, to a traditional kitchen designed by the company Plain English, via Sir Terence Conran's latest eating emporium, the George, Englishness has a growing sense of its own fashionable identity.

But how can we celebrate it? An all-day showing of Norman Wisdom, Tony Hancock and Fawlty Towers may help even the most self-loathing of the English to realise that for every Bernard Manning or Jim Davidson making a notorious living out of a cruel laugh at others' expense there is a comedy classic founded on our ability to laugh at ourselves. "Don't mention the war", or the bumbling bank manager turned wartime antihero Captain Mainwaring - if this isn't the English lightening up, what is?

As for food, we love to knock our national non-existent cuisine. But a regional mix of Lancashire hotpot, Yorkshire puddings and cockney jellied eels, rounded off with some Devon clotted cream and scones, suggests a country made up of difference. Perhaps a St George's Day meal should be a double helping of chicken tikka masala and takeaway pizza in tribute to our intestinal internationalism. Or maybe chips with everything?

Culinary historians teach us that these are in fact a continental invention, probably Belgian, though their preference for mayonnaise over Heinz tomato ketchup as the spuds' topping has proved an import too far.

The fact that our national vegetable dish isn't authentically English doesn't pull down the entire edifice of our emerging national identity. After all, St George himself was a knight of Middle Eastern origin who probably wouldn't pass muster as a genuine refugee or asylum seeker in these hate-filled times.

Raymond Williams was one of the first to recognise that England as a "mongrel nation" is a potential source of its enduring appeal. Williams was part of a group of 50s historians and cultural theorists who made it their business to engage with the specificities of being English alongside a dogged determination to break up Britain.

Writers of impeccable leftist credentials such as Edward Thompson and Christopher Hill were joined later by Tom Nairn, Perry Anderson, Sheila Rowbotham and others in uncovering a history that might help us construct another England.

The Fabian Society, from deep within the New Labour edifice, has launched its report, The English Question, a prescient attempt to link this radical championing of an alternative Englishness with the goal of some measure of English devolution.

But England shouldn't be reduced simply to constitutionalising. Feeling good about being English is a vital part in bidding farewell to Britain. Not to forget our imperial past, Rule Britannia's ugly refrain "Britons never shall be slaves" speaks to a history that will forever be stained. It is time to turn this legacy on its head with a positive blast of Blake's Jerusalem.

A passionate call for a new England free of exploitation and pollution which has a multi-faith, and non-faith, resonance well beyond its Christian origins. A rousing rendition will more than likely be helped in its enthusiasm, if not its melody, by sharing in a round of our great national drink, beer.

Eccentrically labelled ales such as Theakston's Old Peculiar, Bishop's Finger and the Mordue Brewery's Radgie Gadgie have their place alongside our liking for European wines and continental lagers. The national and the international co-existing in one party six-pack.

The soundtrack to my celebration of St George's Day? Well most of Britpop is in fact Eng-pop, Blur and Pulp being the most obvious exponents of a southern, and a northern, sense of being English yet part of a fast-moving world culture. Drum and bass, jungle, and a dose of new Asian dance music all sound like a national culture that can absorb and include as well as it can repel and exclude. A homegrown dance music play-list is a testament to an Englishness that is urban, yet enjoys itself in a rural festival site and joins the European youth-tribe in Ibiza every summer just to prove its cosmopolitan credentials.

Of an age when the music can start all sounding the same, I'll stick to Billy Bragg, the Clash's English Civil War and Steel Pulse's Brum reggae mix for my favourite English party tunes. And if I get round to baking my celebratory fairy cakes topped with an icing sugar St George's Cross I'll have the party food, and my masculinity, sorted.

Meanwhile the big picture writers tell me every step on the way towards globalisation is matched by a parallel intensification of localisation. Internationalism is only possible in the face of globalisation once we know where we are coming from. Learning to celebrate St George's Day is a small yet significant part of that process. It is about all our yesterdays, it is for a better tomorrow too.

Mark Perryman is editor of The Ingerland Factor: Home Truths from Football, published by Mainstream, £9.99

Williams was part of a group of 50s historians and cultural theorists who made it their business to engage with the specificities of being English alongside a dogged determination to break up Britain. Writers of impeccable leftist credentials such as Edward Thompson and Christopher Hill were joined later by Tom Nairn, Perry Anderson, Sheila Rowbotham and others in uncovering a history that might help us construct another England. The Fabian Society, from deep within the New Labour edifice, has launched its report, The English Question, a prescient attempt to link this radical championing of an alternative Englishness with the goal of some measure of English devolution. But England shouldn't be reduced simply to constitutionalising. Feeling good about being English is a vital part in bidding farewell to Britain. Not to forget our imperial past, Rule Britannia's ugly refrain "Britons never shall be slaves" speaks to a history that will forever be stained. It is time to turn this legacy on its head with a positive blast of Blake's Jerusalem. A passionate call for a new England free of exploitation and pollution which has a multi-faith, and non-faith, resonance well beyond its Christian origins. A rousing rendition will more than likely be helped in its enthusiasm, if not its melody, by sharing in a round of our great national drink, beer. Eccentrically labelled ales such as Theakston's Old Peculiar, Bishop's Finger and the Mordue Brewery's Radgie Gadgie have their place alongside our liking for European wines and continental lagers. The national and the international co-existing in one party six-pack. The soundtrack to my celebration of St George's Day? Well most of Britpop is in fact Eng-pop, Blur and Pulp being the most obvious exponents of a southern, and a northern, sense of being English yet part of a fast-moving world culture. Drum and bass, jungle, and a dose of new Asian dance music all sound like a national culture that can absorb and include as well as it can repel and exclude. A homegrown dance music play-list is a testament to an Englishness that is urban, yet enjoys itself in a rural festival site and joins the European youth-tribe in Ibiza every summer just to prove its cosmopolitan credentials. Of an age when the music can start all sounding the same, I'll stick to Billy Bragg, the Clash's English Civil War and Steel Pulse's Brum reggae mix for my favourite English party tunes. And if I get round to baking my celebratory fairy cakes topped with an icing sugar St George's Cross I'll have the party food, and my masculinity, sorted. Meanwhile the big picture writers tell me every step on the way towards globalisation is matched by a parallel intensification of localisation. Internationalism is only possible in the face of globalisation once we know where we are coming from. Learning to celebrate St George's Day is a small yet significant part of that process. It is about all our yesterdays, it is for a better tomorrow too. Mark Perryman is editor of The Ingerland Factor: Home Truths from Football, published by Mainstream, £9.99

webTitle: 'Feed the world' opportunity seen for GM salmon

fields.headline: 'Feed the world' opportunity seen for GM salmon
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Refusal to accept genetically modified fish as food was a rich man's stance that would be a "terrible mistake, a moral mistake", the president of a US company expecting to market GM salmon said yesterday.
fields.body:
Refusal to accept genetically modified fish as food was a rich man's stance that would be a "terrible mistake, a moral mistake", the president of a US company expecting to market GM salmon said yesterday.

Responding to critics, Elliot Entis cited a United Nations estimate that a sevenfold increase in the production of seafood was needed in the next 25-30 years if the present per capita consumption of fish was to be maintained for a growing world population.

Transgenic fish, he argued in an interview with the Guardian, were likely to be one of the few ways of providing protein for millions of people at a reasonable price.

Mr Entis, president and chief executive of Aqua Bounty Farms in Boston, believes that his group could soon get regulatory approval from the US food and drug agency to produce transgenic salmon for the retail market, with the first fish appearing on supermarket shelves in the US by 2002.

Mr Entis has run into serious resistance in Europe, not only from environmental groups but also from salmon farmers, and he acknowledged that consumers in Britain were "not yet ready" for his product.

But, he argued, objecting to GM foods was "a rich white man's argument": activists in Europe had this luxury because people in their region had enough to eat.

Outside the US, Mr Entis is to target his fish particularly at Asia; China is avidly interested in using fish modification to feed its population of more than 1bn.

Criticising some campaigners and some British media, the Guardian included, Mr Entis said: "I feel very deeply that all this focus on the disadvantages merely ignores and puts to one side any benefits.

"There are many benefits to this technology. Bio-technology can lead to greater productivity, far less use of noxious chemicals we all complain about, and far better use of land and water.

"I think that to ignore or put in the trash can this kind of technology is a terrible mistake, it's a moral mistake."

If civilisation was to survive with everyone having enough to eat, he argued, exploitation of bio-technology was essential. But, he added: "I am not stuffing it down people's throats" - capitalism weeded out products based on whether they met a need.

He was critical of some of the assertions made about transgenic salmon. Fish with four to six times normal growth rates did not grow into salmon 12ft long weighing 200lb - they grew to the same size as wild fish, but in a shorter time.

In natural conditions salmon grew to 60 to 70 grammes (less than three ounces) in 15 months. With a growth gene inserted, this weight was achieved in three or four months.

After that, the growth rate began to slow, and at the end of 14-18 months the genetically modified salmon were between one and three kilogrammes (2.2 and 6.6 lbs).

Once the fish reached sexual maturity the growth rate slowed to normal rates, he said. "Quite why this is, we do not fully understand; but we are on the fourth generation of these fish, and we have bred thousands of them and the results are the same."

He said that the largest fish his firm had ever produced, called "Bertha", weighed in at 16 kilos (35 lbs), well below the record sizes of wild Atlantic salmon.

He thought most concerns regarding the technology centred on potential mixing and mating with wild species, rather than on food safety. He predicted that permission for transgenic salmon might initially be given for breeding them on shore in tanks, rather than in sea pens.

Critics argue that sea-based captive breeding could see transgenic salmon escaping and interbreeding with wild species.

Mr Entis said that all his salmon were bred to be sterile and, although no system could be perfect, in the thousands of tests, not one of his fish had been found to be fertile.

webTitle: Speed complaints hoist villagers by own petard

fields.headline: Speed complaints hoist villagers by own petard
fields.trailText: For years residents of two Somerset villages complained to police about motorists speeding past their homes.
fields.body:
For years residents of two Somerset villages complained to police about motorists speeding past their homes.

When a police speed trap was set up on a 30mph stretch of the A368 between Compton Martin and Bishop Sutton, the locals were delighted.

Their euphoria turned to shame when it emerged yesterday that a large proportion of the drivers caught speeding by the laser camera were the very same villagers.

Of 133 motorists caught in a fortnight, 30 were from the two villages. They are being prosecuted by police along with the others.

Sergeant Mike Smalley, who set up the trap, said: "It's often the case that we catch a high proportion of locals, and some of those will have expressed concern about speeding in the first instance."

Pensioner John Wilkes, who has lived near Compton Martin for 18 years, described it as being more like Piccadilly Circus than a peaceful village.

"I think local people should have known better. We are complaining about speeding, but how can you complain if you don't abide by it? It has got a lot worse as time has gone by."

Katie Court, whose partner was one of those caught, saidshe thought that the lorries were more of a problem. "My husband was only doing 35mph and I don't think he deserved it.

"Speeding in the village doesn't really bother me - I just hop into the hedges as the cars go past."

Rosemary Evans, chairwoman of Bishop Sutton parish council, described the results as very unfortunate. "But you should not be speeding through your own village," she added.

fields.headline: RUC orders Omagh review
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A major review of the police investigation into the Omagh bombing is under way, the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, said yesterday.
fields.body:
A major review of the police investigation into the Omagh bombing is under way, the RUC chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, said yesterday.

He has set up a team of detectives to re-examine the inquiry in a new push to bring charges against dissident republicans who murdered 29 people.

Officers from Greater Manchester and the Metropolitan police, including those who reviewed the Jill Dando killing, had already advised the squad, he said.

The chief suspects in the August 1998 bombing by the Real IRA have been identified, including those who assembled the car bomb in Co Monaghan and drove it into Omagh. But, because of insufficient evidence, no one has been charged.

All have been questioned, some in the Irish Republic where police carried out their own inquiry. One man is to stand trial in Dublin next year in connection with the attack.

Sir Ronnie said the review would be detailed and thorough: "We owe nothing less to the relatives. The original investigation was and continues to be of the highest order, and this is merely an application of fresh minds to review everything that has been done.

"We want to be absolutely satisfied beyond any doubt there are no avenues left unexplored - we have very good intelligence, but intelligence in a liberal democracy does not equal evidence that can be presented before a court."

The review team, based at Antrim RUC station, is headed by Chief Superintendent Brian McVicker, who is in charge of Belfast CID.

Relatives of the victims, including the families of the three from Spain, were told yesterday of the move.

fields.headline: Collars up for war
fields.trailText: In the Grand Final eliminators for Robot Wars (BBC2), Chance II with its flipping ramp was pitted against Firestorm with its flipping arm. "Flipping" was used descriptively here.
fields.body:
In the Grand Final eliminators for Robot Wars (BBC2), Chance II with its flipping ramp was pitted against Firestorm with its flipping arm. "Flipping" was used descriptively here. In the other eliminator, Hypno-Disc, with its 600rpm rotating wheel and unpleasant spikes, confronted Steg-O-Saw-Us, with suggestive knobbles along its back and a thumping dinosaur's tail powered, I believe, by a lawnmower engine.

Robot Wars is a very strange spectacle, rather like WWF wrestling meets Young Scientist of the Year, or Operation Desert Storm meets county-level table tennis. The film-maker Nanni Moretti once dramatised the history of the Italian communist party as a game of water polo. Robot Wars is of the same stamp, the hostility of the western male sublimated into something less troubling, something that can be knocked up in the garage and then unleashed like a screaming id on wheels.

Most of this final episode consisted of action replays from the 16-heat series, in which 600 robots were slashed, burned and symbolically defiled. There was a coffin on wheels that got flung into a pit, which was some kind of poetic justice. There were robots called Sir Killalot, Judge Shred, Toe Cutter and Plunderbird. There were others whose names make less sense, such as Facet. And others which were intentionally wrongly spelled, such as Prizephita. There wasn't one called Effete or Poetry Reading, which was a shame.

Commentator Jonathan Pearce was particularly unfeeling when he reported on the defeat of Big Cheese, a motorised yellow triangle on wheels. "Big Cheese thought they were fondue for success, but they were grated," said Pearce in that purportedly punning martial-speak beloved of football commentators who have a misplaced sense of the game's importance. Fondue? How does that joke work?

The real conflict, though, was between the shrieking presenters (Craig Charles and Philippa Forester) and the all-male robot operators, many of whom wore sweatshirts over their ordinary shirts but with the collars arranged nicely over the top. The latter were the kind of people who would quite possibly also have been regular participants on Why Don't You Just Switch off Your Television Set and Go and Do Something Less Boring Instead. They probably all made their own pipe racks, and, when they opened their sandwiches at lunchtime, wondered earnestly what their wives had prepared for them. I liked them immediately.

Craig and Philippa, by contrast, came from Media Hell, eternally cursed with the belief that stupid scripts and shouting can catalyse excitement in anybody but the studio audience.

Craig Charles set the scene by shouting: "There's more tension here than Pavarotti's underpants." Two points: one, there was hardly any discernible tension; moreover, surely Luciano wears big pants to prevent such problems. Perhaps Craig should have asked him before slurring the tenor's sartorial skills. Philippa's job was to interview the contestants as they prepared their machines for "battle". In one culture clash, Forrester attempted to interview a man as he repaired Hyno-Disc's battle-damaged wheel. He was monosyllabic, no doubt hoping she leave so that he could concentrate on the deployment of his power tools.

In the final, Chaos II braved Hypno-Disc's spinning wheel, flipped the 78kg opponent, and then set about the house robots. "Chaos II attacks Matilda!" shouted Pearce. "You can see the chainsaw come off Matilda - what an untidy and ghastly sight she makes." Such was the poignant conclusion to these costly wars.

fields.headline: From the top
fields.trailText: It seems that the only issue that all the major political parties agree on is the importance of enterprise to economic success. Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy compete to show that theirs is the party for ambitious entrepreneurs, especially those capable of creating growth and wealth.
fields.body:
It seems that the only issue that all the major political parties agree on is the importance of enterprise to economic success. Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy compete to show that theirs is the party for ambitious entrepreneurs, especially those capable of creating growth and wealth.

New institutions like the Small Business Service are created to meet their needs. School children, students, workers, managers and pensioners are encouraged to take the risks and meet the challenge of the enterprise economy.

It is bizarre then to watch many of the same politicians join in attacks on economic migrants. Criticised in parliament, maligned in the media, refugees are attacked from all sides. Critics forget that much of Britain's wealth was created by people who faced economic and social problems and migrated to the UK for many of the same reasons.

When Britain was the economic centre of the world, it was migrants like Nathan Rothschild, Hans Renold and Ludwig Mond who provided much of the drive and creativity. Migration did not just occur across international boundaries. Scottish, Welsh and Irish migrants joined others from Eastern and Central Europe in building Liverpool, Birmingham, Leeds and Newcastle into dynamic, international economies.

Migrants share with religious and other out-groups a disproportionate role in business creation. Marks & Spencer, Shell, Diageo and Tesco are just a few leading UK companies that are firmly rooted in the enterprise of people who saw the UK as a place offering security and prosperity. Nothing in the tone of recent debates about migrants suggests that a Seiff or a Deterding would be any more welcome now.

Britain's leadership role was lost when new generations of migrants saw the US as the most welcoming and supportive economic environment. Carnegie, Ford, Morgan, Forbes and a host of others snatched economic leadership from their ancestral home.

Migrants and entrepreneurs have much in common. Both fight against being victims of their circumstances. Economic migrants travel to seek out new opportunities. The cutting edge of entrepreneurship is dissatisfaction with current circumstances and a determination to do better. Their struggle to do better for themselves generally means they end up doing better for others. Success comes because they spot new opportunities or look at problems and issues in different ways.

The latest Fortune survey of business performance in the US showed that new and diverse companies outperform the stock market. These companies challenge assumptions, look at issues from different perspectives and come up with innovative solutions. Besides this, they understand the diverse groups that make up markets and are confident in handling change.

Managing change is the crucial task for leaders of organisations. Faced with swift change, mono-cultures are in trouble especially if they fail to adapt. There are not enough perspectives and talent struggles to emerge.

Responsible companies measure and monitor the extent to which non-traditional groups can win jobs and promotion. They take action to overcome barriers. Being open to talent, need, endeavour and diversity is seen as a crucial leadership role.

Apart from Charles Kennedy, few political leaders have shown the same type of attitudes during recent debates on refugees. It is, however, unlikely that any government can achieve its goals for new business creation, entrepreneurial activity or business success without a massive injection of effort from migrants.

Professor Tom Cannon is chief executive, Management Charter Initiative

webTitle: Mock crucifixion makes Easter shoppers cross

fields.headline: Mock crucifixion makes Easter shoppers cross
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A Good Friday procession that included a portrayal of Jesus on the cross was so realistic that onlookers in a South Wales town centre yesterday called an ambulance.
fields.body:
A Good Friday procession that included a portrayal of Jesus on the cross was so realistic that onlookers in a South Wales town centre yesterday called an ambulance.

Focal Point, a Christian charity, had hired actor Gerald Tyler, 32, to play the part of Jesus in their Easter parade in Porth, Rhondda.

Mr Tyler had been smeared with blood and made to look as if he had been nailed to a wooden cross, but he was so convincing in the role that paramedics and police were called to the scene.

Officials from the charity were later accused of bad taste after people were left shocked and in tears.

But charity spokesman Ian Willis said: "The idea was to get people away from chocolate eggs and bunny rabbits.

"We believe the image of a man covered in blood hanging from a cross has a big impact on passers-by.

"We hope it will get people to reconsider the whole idea of Easter and how they view Jesus."

A spokesman for South Wales police said: "It was very realistic but we were able to assure people it was all an act."

fields.headline: Talking heads
fields.standfirst: David Thomas, managing director at Cendant International, a leading provider of payment protection for banks and credit card companies
fields.trailText: David Thomas, managing director at Cendant International, a leading provider of payment protection for banks and credit card companies
fields.body:
When did you first become a manager?

January 1993 when I was promoted to regional sales manager, American Express. On my first day as manager my boss told me that our biggest UK contract with IBM had been cancelled - sort that out, he said!

What has been your best moment in management?

Winning back the contract with IBM - it took two years and became the biggest contract Amex held in any international market.

What was your greatest mistake?

Working too hard and not spending enough time with my family. Fortunately I had a second chance!

Which deal would you most like to have done?

Devising Charles Schwab's e-commerce strategy.

What do you find most annoying in your staff?

Sending e-mails when a face-to-face meeting or phone call would be more effective.

Does your organisation have a glass ceiling?

No.

What management wisdom is most overrated?

Managers know all the answers.

What single lesson would you pass on to budding managers?

Build a successful team. If you achieve this you can achieve most things and have fun.

Which management guru do you believe in?

I don't believe in any guru! However I have learned a lot from several bosses at Cendant and American Express.

Who is your management hero?

Sir Richard Branson.

Who is your favourite politician?

There are very few I rate now. I did meet Douglas Hurd once whom I respect a lot for his intelligence and integrity.

If you could change one aspect of British business, what would it be ?

Shout more about successes.

What phrase or saying do you most overuse?

Sorry I'm late.

Apart from quality time with your family, what else makes you happiest in life?

Enjoying an afternoon out at Wasps Rugby Club with friends.

What annoys you most?

Van drivers!

How do you relax?

Playing golf, racing sailing dinghies or watching Wasps and Wales play rugby followed by a few beers afterwards.

What was your last cultural experience?

Visiting the Design Museum in London with my 16-year-old daughter as part of her GCSE project.

What is your favourite city?

Bath.

Favourite journey?

Catamaran sailing in the Bahamas.

What is your greatest regret?

None comes to mind.

What is your biggest fear?

Failure without knowing the reason.

What would you really like to have been?

Fly-half for Wales.

fields.headline: Dot.com your coms
fields.standfirst: Michael Ross runs a growing business selling underwear to women via the internet for overnight delivery.  Michael Edmands met the smalls entrepreneur
fields.trailText: Michael Ross runs a growing business selling underwear to women via the internet for overnight delivery.  Michael Edmands met the smalls entrepreneur.
fields.body:
Everybody knows the best place to think up ideas. Eureka - that's right, in the bath and if that bath's in the home of an inventor in Ohio all the better. That's where Michael Ross was sitting not so long ago when his idea came to him and so it was goodbye Columbus and back home to open his first business while still at university. Now, barely 10 years later, he runs one of the biggest e-commerce knicker shops in the UK.

"I was up at Trinity where I helped launch the Cambridge Comedy Society, the most unsuccessful and unfunny comedy group ever. One weekend we were running a stand selling cartoons for charity when an American tourist, Michael Braunstein, stopped by and began chatting about humour.

"I didn't hear from Mr Braunstein for two years and then he called me up and told me he had given up script writing and had become an inventor and invited me to stay with him and look over his latest invention.

"It was Christmas 1989 and in his huge house he had built his weather patio. I had brought a friend who likes photography with me and we sat in his Jacuzzi trying to think of ideas for putting this weather room on the map. Instead, this made us think of an idea that might work for us back in England.

"The next year, we opened a map business and started selling aerial views of Cambridge to local businesses who could put their names on the map and give them away to customers."

The business grew and three years later they were selling 52 maps across the UK, employing 37 people and doing a million pounds worth of business and still losing money. "We made every mistake a small business can make and we were fed up and decided it was time to quit."

By this time, Michael Ross was being head-hunted at university by McKinsey and joined them in 1994. At first working on future uses for TV, he was soon moved on to "internet stuff". For five years he thought about quitting McKinsey. Then he enjoyed another break through his mother's cousin Daniel Nabarro. Unlike other City high-flyers, quitting and setting up his own internet company with all the attendant risks, he was able to join a family firm. He left a lucrative job as consultant at McKinsey in December 1998, when he was taken on as chief executive of easyshop. This retailer had been set up in 1995 and was funded by Mr Nabarro. As competition in that area hotted up, Mr Nabarro redirected the company's activities to e-commerce. In late 1998, easyshop.co.uk opened selling women's under-wear. As Mr Nabarro started to spend serious money getting the business up and running he looked to young Michael Ross who had shown an aptitude for the internet in talks at family get-togethers, and made him the boss.

"When my uncle (as he calls him) asked me to come and work for him, I could see that selling underwear on the net was an inspired choice of product. It is the best selling item of clothing on the internet for the simple reason that most women know their bra and knicker sizes and the brand they prefer. Moreover, it's light and cheaper to post."

As he shows me around his North Finchley packing room, Mr Ross says: "Fashion people don't understand the net. Calvin Klein and Hugo Boss don't want to know. Maybe they are just biding their time, but for now they are chary."

And it's big -some £3bn annually in the UK alone with Marks & Spencer accounting for some 40% of sales. Easyshop, by contrast, is selling just £1m a year. "We are minuscule," he admits, "for the moment".

Why North Finchley? "In selling underwear on the web, the trick is speed," he says. "My uncle was told about the excellent postal sorting office nearby and that was a major factor.

"Just imagine, a young lady could get home from work in the evening, throw her dirty underwear in the basket, send us an e-mail and a replacement set will drop through the letterbox next morning."

The secret, apparently, is a golf wagon to roam the aisles and quickly find the right size and brand. Find it, put it in an envelope and then sort it before sending the package to the Post Office. "We can take an order up to 10 o'clock at night," he says.

Now Mr Ross has his sights on Europe. Moonkiss.com is the working title for an online shopping arm due to make its debut in the spring with delivery anywhere in Europe.

fields.headline: From me to you...
fields.standfirst: Diaries and personal letters of the Beatles' former manager could break records, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Diaries and personal letters of the Beatles' former manager could break records, says Stewart Dalby.
fields.body:
Rock memorabilia can be among the hottest items in auction rooms these days, providing the provenance is right. Christie's South Kensington in London is holding a guitar auction, with 15 guitars belonging to the American producer Chips Moman on offer. A 1957 Gibson Super 400 CES which was given to Chips in the early 60s by Elvis Presley's guitarist Scotty Moore is expected to fetch between £25,000 and £35,000.

On this occasion, though, the guitars could be over shadowed by the inclusion in the sale of a unique selection of diaries, letters, manuscripts and photographs belonging to the late Brian Epstein.

Brian Epstein was the legendary pop manager who ran a string of artists from his native Liverpool in the 60s, including Cilla Black and Gerry and the Pacemakers. He is most famously remembered, however, as the man who discovered the Beatles playing in the dingy Cavern Club in Liverpool and propelled the foursome into becoming the most famous musicians in the world.

Although as a group the Beatles split up in 1970 and one of their members, John Lennon, is now dead, interest in them has remained extraordinarily high and it is the Beatles that have broken most collecting records.

Anything at all connected with them is voraciously sought after by collectors. Last summer, the hand written lyrics of the John Lennon song I am the Walrus sold at auction for £78,000. A note book belonging to Paul McCartney containing a number of lyrics including the words to Hey Jude fetched more than £100,000.

Epstein's association with the Beatles will mean great interest in the sale. Epstein was often referred to, and liked to be known as, the fifth Beatle. But despite his great success he was a deeply troubled person, haunted by his homosexuality and his arrest for importuning in 1957. He died tragically in 1967 at the age of 32.

The collection is being offered for sale now by Bryan Barrett, who was Epstein's chauffeur and bodyguard for the last two years of his life. His reasoning is that it was so long ago and with Epstein's mother Queenie now dead the intimate and controversial contents of his diaries will no longer offend.

The collection contains a number of personal items like Epstein's birth certificate and his unwitnessed will, the only one known to exist (£1,000-£1,500), and an 18ct gold watch given to Epstein as a 21st birthday present by Queenie (£1,500 to £2,000).

But the highlight of the sale is the unique collection of 13 personal diaries dating from various years between 1949 and 1963, which record events and influences affecting the progress of his life, including the now legendary first official meeting with the Beatles in 1961. These will be sold in one lot and carry an estimate of £10,000 to £15,000.

Three notebooks inscribed in Epstein's hand in ink and pencil between 1950 and 1960 give an emotional account of his childhood, teenage years and his early 20s. The second book apparently traces with brutal honesty, the development of Epstein's homosexuality, culminating with his arrest for soliciting.

Other significant items include a four-page autographed letter circa 1966/67 from Paul McCartney to Brian Epstein estimated at £10,000 to £12,000. This is believed to be the first example of any personal corre spondence between one of the Beatles and their manager to appear at auction. According to Christie's, this important letter gives a rare insight into the tensions that existed in McCartney's and Epstein's relationship during the last years of Epstein's life when he was suffering from depression.

Finally, there is a pen and ink hand-drawn Christmas card designed by John Lennon circa 1966. Inscribed with the message "Happy Christian Brian from John", it is thought that Lennon's interpretation of the seasonal message is an ironic reference to Epstein's Jewish faith. This is estimated at £7,000.

But these are all estimates. They could be exceeded. Perhaps it should not be forgotten that Sir Paul McCartney is an avid collector of Beatles memorabilia himself and has sometimes gone to great lengths to acquire pieces. So there could be fireworks.

For further information, tel: 020-7581-7611 or go to www.christies.com
