fields.headline: Exposing landlords from hell
fields.trailText: A service that aims to weed out rotten landlords and nightmare tenants will be launched this month by the trade body the Association of Residential Letting Agents. The referencing service sets out to protect both sides.
fields.body:
A service that aims to weed out rotten landlords and nightmare tenants will be launched this month by the trade body the Association of Residential Letting Agents. The referencing service sets out to protect both sides.

This is the latest initiative aimed at improving the often acrimonious relationship between tenants and landlords. Letting agents who are ARLA members will notify a database of landlords who harass tenants unreasonably, withhold deposits, or refuse to carry out safety checks on gas and electrical appliances.

Tenants who fail to pay rent, neglect the property, refuse to leave at the end of the tenancy or are a nuisance to neighbours will also have their names added. The system is also linked to a credit reference agency. Operation of the database will comply with data protection rules, says ARLA.

Renting a property in the private sector is full of pitfalls for those on both sides of the agreement. Inexperienced landlords often hand the selection of tenants and management of the property over to a letting agent - who, like estate agents - are unregulated.

Many tenants and landlords unhappy with the way they have been treated by a letting agent have turned to the ombudsman for estate agents, Stephen Carr-Smith, in the hope of redress. In his annual report published last month, the ombudsman said he had received a significant number of complaints involving letting and tenancy agreements. Sadly, they fall outside his remit so he was powerless to act.

Mr Carr-Smith wants to add disputes involving letting agencies to his remit. But even if he is successful, there are problems: the ombudsman can deal only with complaints against member agents and membership is voluntary. To date only 30% of estate agents are members.

A clearer picture of the level of dissatisfaction with the sector should emerge following a change in the way trading standards departments categorise complaints. From April last year, letting agencies and property management became a category on its own.

In the first quarter of 1999 local authority trading standards officers reported 929 complaints. This compares with 2,800 against estate agents. Keith Hale of Lacots, the organisation representing local authority trading standards, says complaints against letting and accommodation agencies range from advertising non-existent properties to encourage people to register to taking deposits that are never returned.

"People looking for accommodation or using a letting agency's services are often among the most vulnerable in society, and in need of protection," comments Mr Hale.

Last month, the Independent Housing Ombudsman launched the Tenancy Deposit Scheme, which aims to provide a quick and cheap way of resolving disputes.

The pilot scheme is funded by a £460,000 government grant and will run in the London boroughs of Brent and Camden, Birmingham, Brighton (right) and Hove, Merseyside and Norwich and cover 30,000 tenancies over two years. Landlords participating in the pilot will have two choices; they can hang on to the deposit during the tenancy and take out insur ance to guarantee repayment should there be a dispute. Alternatively, they can place the deposit in an account at the Nationwide, where the money will only be released when both landlord and tenant sign a withdrawal form.

Independent adjudicators appointed by the Independent Housing Ombudsman will resolve disputes. If the pilot is successful, the scheme will be rolled out nationally.

Malcolm Harrison, spokesman for ARLA, says that letting can be a minefield for tenants, landlords and letting agents. Anyone can set themselves up as a letting agent. Mr Harrison argues that anyone who uses an ARLA member is in safe hands - it demands that members are fully bonded to safeguard clients' money and carry insurance.

webTitle: Anything to declare for a border post?

fields.headline: Anything to declare for a border post?
fields.standfirst: Whether it's thwarting the drugs drink and cigarette smugglers, or preventing VAT fraud, Customs officers have a key role to play. David White considers the career prospects
fields.trailText: Whether it's thwarting the drugs drink and cigarette smugglers, or preventing VAT fraud, Customs officers have a key role to play. David White considers the career prospects.
fields.body:
New opportunities are on offer for a career that can combine crime fighting and intelligence gathering with the knowledge that you are also helping to protect government finances. The customs and excise is recruiting an extra 955 staff as part of a £209m drive against smugglers trading in everything from tobacco, drink, cocaine, heroin and pornography to rare species of animals.

"We want to attract applications from a wide range of backgrounds to reflect the diversity of the real world they will be dealing with," says Mike Rickwood, the department's head of personnel management. "More women and people from ethnic minorities would be particularly welcome."

There are exciting and varied careers available both on the frontline, say as a customs officer, or in a headquarters role advising on strategy. Apart from tackling crime, the department also has the vital role of collecting more than 40% of central government taxation every year via sources such as customs and other duties and VAT.

But whether you fancy yourself as a would-be James Bond or the female equivalent foiling plans to flood Britain with contraband cigarettes or as a genius with figures able to crack the most sophisticated VAT fraud, the first hurdle will be passing the department's selection process.

Entry for those who can expect to move quickly into key anti-smuggling posts will join at job band 5/6 level (formerly known as executive officers) via an interview lasting about 40 minutes. Less qualified applicants enter at lower levels, but are offered the chance to climb a well-defined career ladder. (See opposite for grade and pay structure).

"We expect candidates to know something about what we do as a department," says Mr Rickwood. (Tip: visit the department's internet site on www.hmce.gov) "But while the work and life experience of older applicants can be extremely useful, we are very keen to develop potential. The interview is used to look for evidence of bright, inquiring minds that can be stretched by the demanding work we do."

The department values in particular team players, interpersonal skills and adaptability - and applicants are well advised to prepare examples of how they have demonstrated these qualities. Specialist knowledge should always be highlighted as the department's remit calls for varied expertise - everything from court room knowledge to computer skills.

Those offered jobs will typically spend up to nine months training for their first post. Talent spotting by senior managers is used to identify aptitudes at an early stage and steer staff to where they can be most effective. Development centres fast-track those showing the greatest promise.

Graduates making their mark can expect to reach an annual salary scale of between £34,000 and £42,000 within six years. "We encourage staff to gain the widest possible experience within the department and through secondments to other parts of the civil service and the private sector," says Mr Rickwood. "The aim is for individuals to balance their specialist expertise with a grasp of the 'big picture'."

The emphasis of the current recruitment drive is on reversing the upward trend in tobacco smuggling and was announced after the latest increase in tobacco duty unveiled in the budget.

So what specific qualities are needed on the front line at Britain's ports and airports? "Frontier staff wage a never-ending battle of wits which requires the painstaking gathering of intelligence information, unflagging vigilance and the ability to think clearly on your feet, even at the end of a long shift," says Ian Davies, a team leader in the department's headquarters anti-smuggling division.

"We are not only dealing with the relatively crude methods of White Van Man chancing his arm with cigarettes and drink, but with sophisticated international gangs trying to smuggle huge quantities of tobacco as well as hard drugs, pornography and anything else on which they seek to make money."

He says customs officers often have to make split-second decisions about who to stop and, depending on responses to questions, on the scale of follow-up searches and inquiries.

All 'front line' officers complete 13-week individually tailored training programmes which include a residential course where experienced colleagues play the role of smugglers using the latest scams and lines in 'chat'. Mock interviews are seen as an effective way of teaching new recruits to tell fact from fiction when assessing answers to their questions." When new methods of smuggling and new trends emerge, we make sure every officer is informed," says Mr Davies.

"Every section of the department works as a team, sharing information and offering mutual support - it is one of our greatest strengths."

The additional staff being taken on will allow an extra 520 customs officers to be deployed in key border and inland locations including 170 at channel ports. Investigation teams targeting large-scale smuggling gangs will be boosted by 310 staff; intelligence staff based here and abroad will be increased by 95 and there will be 30 new posts in the customs solicitors office.

To obtain an up-to-the-minute account of life on the customs front line, I spoke to an officer working at the British checkpoint on the French side of the Channel Tunnel. "Tackling smugglers and making a real impact on what has become big business for highly organised gangs is a huge challenge," says Bob - it's not his real name as customs officers need to keep a low personal profile to remain effective.

"We have to use all our training and experience in order to deploy available resources in the most effective way possible and it can mean very long days and a lot of hard work. But when it does all come together and we find the carefully concealed millions of cigarettes or whatever, it really does bring about feelings of a job well done."

Although hi-tech equipment such as scanners - which are especially useful for detecting hidden compartments in vehicles - can make the job easier, Bob says there is often no substitute for instincts honed over years of watching and analysing the behaviour pattern of travellers.

"Every customs officer can give examples of how some hunch sparked by past experience led them to stop one particular traveller and perhaps to ask the extra couple of questions that led to a gang being unravelled or some seizure that could not have been foreseen.

"Being on the alert for anything that looks out of place becomes second nature. A man wearing a coat on a hot day was searched - and the pockets were found to be stuffed with snakes on the endangered species list!"

Bob, 30, entered the department as a 16-year-old school leaver and describes the career structure that enabled him to rise through to the executive grades as extremely motivating.

So would he recommend the customs and excise as a career to friends, family and anyone else? "Put it this way," he says, "people in the department believe they are doing worthwhile work and I would say there has never been a better time to join us."

The customs and excise is recruiting an extra 955 staff as part of a £209m drive against smugglers trading in everything from tobacco, drink, cocaine, heroin and pornography to rare species of animals. "We want to attract applications from a wide range of backgrounds to reflect the diversity of the real world they will be dealing with," says Mike Rickwood, the department's head of personnel management. "More women and people from ethnic minorities would be particularly welcome." There are exciting and varied careers available both on the frontline, say as a customs officer, or in a headquarters role advising on strategy. Apart from tackling crime, the department also has the vital role of collecting more than 40% of central government taxation every year via sources such as customs and other duties and VAT. But whether you fancy yourself as a would-be James Bond or the female equivalent foiling plans to flood Britain with contraband cigarettes or as a genius with figures able to crack the most sophisticated VAT fraud, the first hurdle will be passing the department's selection process. Entry for those who can expect to move quickly into key anti-smuggling posts will join at job band 5/6 level (formerly known as executive officers) via an interview lasting about 40 minutes. Less qualified applicants enter at lower levels, but are offered the chance to climb a well-defined career ladder. (See opposite for grade and pay structure). "We expect candidates to know something about what we do as a department," says Mr Rickwood. (Tip: visit the department's internet site on www.hmce.gov) "But while the work and life experience of older applicants can be extremely useful, we are very keen to develop potential. The interview is used to look for evidence of bright, inquiring minds that can be stretched by the demanding work we do." The department values in particular team players, interpersonal skills and adaptability - and applicants are well advised to prepare examples of how they have demonstrated these qualities. Specialist knowledge should always be highlighted as the department's remit calls for varied expertise - everything from court room knowledge to computer skills. Those offered jobs will typically spend up to nine months training for their first post. Talent spotting by senior managers is used to identify aptitudes at an early stage and steer staff to where they can be most effective. Development centres fast-track those showing the greatest promise. Graduates making their mark can expect to reach an annual salary scale of between £34,000 and £42,000 within six years. "We encourage staff to gain the widest possible experience within the department and through secondments to other parts of the civil service and the private sector," says Mr Rickwood. "The aim is for individuals to balance their specialist expertise with a grasp of the 'big picture'." The emphasis of the current recruitment drive is on reversing the upward trend in tobacco smuggling and was announced after the latest increase in tobacco duty unveiled in the budget. So what specific qualities are needed on the front line at Britain's ports and airports? "Frontier staff wage a never-ending battle of wits which requires the painstaking gathering of intelligence information, unflagging vigilance and the ability to think clearly on your feet, even at the end of a long shift," says Ian Davies, a team leader in the department's headquarters anti-smuggling division. "We are not only dealing with the relatively crude methods of White Van Man chancing his arm with cigarettes and drink, but with sophisticated international gangs trying to smuggle huge quantities of tobacco as well as hard drugs, pornography and anything else on which they seek to make money." He says customs officers often have to make split-second decisions about who to stop and, depending on responses to questions, on the scale of follow-up searches and inquiries. All 'front line' officers complete 13-week individually tailored training programmes which include a residential course where experienced colleagues play the role of smugglers using the latest scams and lines in 'chat'. Mock interviews are seen as an effective way of teaching new recruits to tell fact from fiction when assessing answers to their questions." When new methods of smuggling and new trends emerge, we make sure every officer is informed," says Mr Davies. "Every section of the department works as a team, sharing information and offering mutual support - it is one of our greatest strengths." The additional staff being taken on will allow an extra 520 customs officers to be deployed in key border and inland locations including 170 at channel ports. webTitle: Quids in when you're out with the kids

fields.headline: Quids in when you're out with the kids
fields.trailText: The Easter weekend could see you run ragged as you ply back and forth to the cashpoint. While dyed boiled eggs for breakfast, a clean handkerchief for church, a walk through a bluebell wood and a few chocolate bunnies for tea may have kept children enthralled years ago, today your family day out will need to have a bit more pizzazz built in.
fields.body:
The Easter weekend could see you run ragged as you ply back and forth to the cashpoint. While dyed boiled eggs for breakfast, a clean handkerchief for church, a walk through a bluebell wood and a few chocolate bunnies for tea may have kept children enthralled years ago, today your family day out will need to have a bit more pizzazz built in.

If you're a dream parent, the minute you hear: "I'm bored!", you reach for your stock of envelopes, which you fan out, Cilla-style, asking: "Who's going to choose?", as your wide-eyed children select from a dazzling array of days out at Alton Towers, Legoland or Disneyland Paris, choices which are bound to make you popular and guaranteed to drain your wallet.

But if you're looking for value days out or even freebies, museums should be the number one family trip. While the Government's election manifesto included a pledge to make entrances to national museums and galleries free, it has transpired that due to a tax problem, some of the existing "charging" museums might actually prefer to continue with their entrance fees. Once a museum stops charging for entrance, it technically loses its status as a business and is therefore no longer entitled to VAT benefits. The current state of the debate is that Chris Smith, the culture secretary, has suggested that entrance fees should not be free, but reduced to £1 for all adults from September 2001. Children and the over-60s will continue to be entitled to free admission.

Yet for a museum such as the Science Museum, which currently charges £6.95 for adults, this would result in a substantial reduction in income. The debate continues, with the Government needing to offer compensation to the current "chargers" to make up for their box office losses.

The "Quids In" policy has been described by the Science Museum Director, Sir Neil Cossons, as "innovative", but it remains to be seen whether some of the charging museums will in fact reduce their admission fees to £1 next year.

While you're waiting for 2001, you may well be attracted by other fun spots where children are admitted for free. But the "When is a child not a child?" question is rather a grey area, with many places reckoning that children become adults when they hit 14, yet others stick resolutely to 16. And "child" often only kicks in after the age of 3, 4 or 5, according to the whim of the organisation.

So, whether you're loaded or strapped for cash, here are some ideas for doing the family thing before the children go back to school. Prices are based on two adults and two children.

£500 and over:

An army of 1.5m Brits will be heading off abroad this weekend, with Spain the most popular destination. Why not push the boat out and do the eight loops on the largest rollercoaster in Europe, the Dragon Kahn?

Port Aventura is only one hour from Barcelona and easyJet has flights at £180 each. A one day pass to Port Aventura, which is owned by Universal Studios and has a new water ride called Tutuki Splash, costs £18 for adults and £13 for children.

And if you want to "do" Disneyland Paris, two nights accommodation at the Santa Fe hotel costs £142 for adults and £44.00 for children. Eurostar tickets £58.00 return for children; £170 for adults.

EasyJet: 01582 702 900; Port Aventura: 0800 966 540 www.portaventura.es; Eurostar: 08705 186 186 www.eurostar.com.

£100 and over

It's not too late to book a balloon flight anywhere in the country by calling The British School of Ballooning on 01428 707 307 or clicking on www.hotair.co.uk. £120 for adults and £65 for children (£370 for a family of four) will include one hour in the air and champagne or orange juice when you hit the ground.

You need to be over 4ft tall to see over the top of the basket. If you fancy something faster, Daytona Raceway in Park Royal, London or Daytona International in Milton Keynes offers karting at around £50 per hour, per person. Tel: 0500 145 155.

Gorge yourself on chocolates for the day in Antwerp or Bruges - hop on Eurostar (08705 186 186 www.eurostar.com). Tickets are available on Easter Sunday and Monday - a flexible ticket costs £180, children (4-11) £58.

£50 and over

Alton Towers, Staffordshire. Adults £19.95; Children £15.95 (£71.80 for a family of four). "The queues!" is something you always hear in the same breath as "Alton Towers", and that's just for the telephone information line, tel: 08705 20 40 60 .

Or try Blackpool Pleasure Beach; nostalgia for grandparents and parents and hi-tech excitement for teenagers. You pay for rides as you go - price bands according to thrill factor. A rides (Big Dipper) £2.25, B rides (Rollercoaster) £1.75 and C rides (Haunted Swing) £1.25. Some 145 rides and the Pepsi Max Big One is terrifyingly charged as a double A ride. Tel: 0870 444 55 66 www.blackpoolpleasurebeach.co.uk

Chessington World of Adventures, Surrey. Adults £19.50, Children (over 4) £15.50 Family ticket: £59. Samurai is the main ride but there are also Toytown rides for "young adventurers". Tel: 0870 444 7777 www.chessington.com.

The Dome Egg Hunt: always cited as an example of pricey tickets, the Dome is offering added value this weekend with an egg hunt on 23 and 24 April. Family ticket £57 (2 adults and 2-3 children).

Tel: 0870 6062000 www.dome2000.co.uk/tickets

Legoland, Windsor, (tel: 08705 040404) Adults £17.50; Children £14.50 (3-15 years) Christine Holden, mother of Jake (9) and Albie (4) describes it as "the number one day out for any child". On April 23 and 24 Lego brick Easter eggs will be hidden in the 150-acre park. There's a new Lego Dome and a Wave Surfer ride.

Thorpe Park, Chertsey, Junct 11 or 13, M25 £18.50 Adults; £14.50 Children; £56 family ticket.

Tel: 0870 4444466 .

£30 to £50

Chester Zoo. Adults £9.50 Children (3-15) £7.00 Family ticket: £34.00. New for Easter is the 'Islands in Danger' which include birds of paradise and Komodo dragons. Tel: 01244 380 280.

Hampton Court. Adults £10.50; Children £7.00 (under 5-16) Family ticket £31.40 (2 adults and up to 3 children). Special Easter events include Henry VIII's favourite sports (the mind boggles) and a chance for children to get their mitts on the armour. There's an egg hunt in the Georgian rooms - you have to look for a jewelled egg and then trade it in for a chocolate one. Tel: 020 8781 9791 www.hrp.org.uk

Longleat House, Warminster, Wiltshire. Adults £13 Children £11 (4-14). (Family of four £48). Watch out for the monkeys, as they're quite chipper after the winter. Longleat has just been voted 'Best animal attraction' in the Which? Guide to Tourist Attractions. Tel: 01985 844 400 www.longleat.co.uk (Others are Chester Zoo and Slimbridge Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust). Tickets include: Safari boat trip around Gorilla Island, parrot show, the longest UK maze, Postman Pat's village, Dr Who exhibition, butterfly garden, adventure castle and a free egg hunt.

Madame Tussauds and the Planetarium. Combined tickets £13.45 adults and £9 children.

£20 to £30

London Aquarium. Adults £8.50 Children (3-14) £5.00 Family tickets £24. Tel: 020 7967 8000 www.londonaquarium.co.uk.

Edinburgh Zoo, £7 Adults; £4 Children (Family of four £22) Tel: 0131 334 9171. On April 23 and 24 there are two egg trails with chocolate animal prizes through the park: one for children under 7 and one for age 8 and over.

Leeds Castle, Maidstone, Kent. The egg hunt used to be a big event at Leeds Castle but it all got too competitive. Bigger children got to the eggs first and then tried to sell them to the younger children.

This year there is a Celebration of Easter event where you can make musical instruments and join a band with Gary the Musical Clown, April 22-24. £7.50 Adults; £4.50 Children (5-15). (Family of four £24). 0870 600 88 80 www.leeds-castle.co.uk.

Warwick Castle (01926 40 66 00) Adults £9.75; Children (4-16) £5.95. £28 family ticket. "No eggs here," says Corrina Jacob of Warwick Castle. "But there's something happening every half hour".

The theme is 1000 Years of the Castle. Authenticity around every corner, particularly in the smell, see, and hear section where you can experience the smells of a medieval household.

Bluebell Railway, East Sussex (www.bluebell-railway.co.uk 01825 722 370) Adults £7.80 Children £3.90 (Family of four £23.40)

Romney, Hythe and Dymchurch Railway, New Romney Station, Kent (01797 362 353) Adults £9, £4.50 children (3-15), (family of four £27).

£10 to £20

Imperial War Museum, Duxford, Cambridgeshire (01223 83 5000) Adults £7.40; Children (under 16) Free. (Family of four £14.80). There will be flying demonstrations of Spitfires and classic jets on Easter Monday, although "it's not an air show", cautions the press officer.

Weald & Downland Open Air Museum, Singleton, West Sussex (01243 811 348). Fine Food Fair on Easter Sunday and Monday. Adults £6; Children £3 (Family of four £18).

London Transport Museum, Covent Garden (0207 379 6344) Adults £4.95; Children £2.95 (Family of four £15.80)

Spitfire Scramble at the Imperial War Museum (020 7416 5320 www.iwm.org.uk). You can learn about rationing, dried eggs and other wartime things as you explore four floors of the museum to find eggs. Children (up to 16) Free; Adults £5.50. (Family of four £11).

Kew Gardens, Surrey. An egg hunt on April 23 and 24 with a Peter Rabbit appearance for younger children. (020 8332 5000). Children (5-16) £2.50; Adults £5. (Family of four £15).

Science Museum Adults: £6.95; Children (16 and under) free. For details:

www.sciencemuseum.org.uk 020 7942 4454/4455/4000.

Victoria and Albert Museum: Adults £5, children free. Natural History Museum: Adults £6.50; Children (5-17) £3.50.

Merseyside Maritime Museum, Albert Dock, Liverpool ( 0151 478 4499). Children (16 and under) free; adults £3. Includes the Leaving of Liverpool: role play characters from 1854 and follow the journey taken by emigrants leaving for the New Worlds. April 20-24, 1.30-4.30 pm

Slimbridge Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, Gloucestershire (01453 890333 www.wwt.org.uk). Adults £5.75, £3.50 children. Egg trails, Easter bonnet making, competitions and interactive activities in the new visitor centre.

Stourhead, Mere, Wiltshire (01747 841 152). Adults £4.60; children £2.60; family ticket £10. King Alfred's Tower is a particular attraction.

The National Trust has Easter egg trails, Easter bonnet workshops, and real Easter chicks hatching before your eyes all over the country this weekend. (Tel: 020 8315 1111 www.nationaltrust.org.uk)

Dragons, damsels and fighting knights are just some of the things being organised by English Heritage at Wrest Park Gardens, Bedfordshire, Old Sarum Castle, Wiltshire, Richmond Castle, North Yorkshire, Witley Court Worcester, Kirby Hall, Northamptonshire and about 40 other places throughout the country over the Easter weekend. Call English Heritage on 01793 414 910 www.english-heritage.org.uk for more information.

Free

Family Fun Day at Hebden Bridge, West Yorkshire on Easter Monday. Jugglers, jazz, oompah band, Easter bunnies and duck race (01422 843831). Also on Easter Monday is the Hare Pie Scramble and Bottle Kicking in Hallaton, Leicestershire, and in London there's the Easter Parade in Battersea Park, London.

On April 26, there is Egg engraving for children aged 8 and over at the Natural History Gallery in The Horniman Museum, Forest Hill, south London (020 8699 1872 www.horniman.demon.co.uk) and in Liverpool, there's a free Art Quest on Easter Sunday afternoon at the Tate Gallery, Albert Dock, Liverpool (0151 702 7400/7402 www.tate.org.uk).

At the Booth Museum of Natural History in Brighton there's a free exhibition called Hard Boiled with live duck eggs, dinosaur eggs and party-bag chocolate eggs (01273 292 777) and at Palace- rigg Country Park in Cumbernauld there are Easter events: baby rabbits, chicks, games, fun and competitions and chocolate prizes on Sunday and Monday (01236 720 047).

And some museums which have always remained resolutely free are The British Museum, (020 7636 1555, www.british-museum.ac.uk), the National Gallery, (020 7306 0055) and the Tate, (020 7722 3333).

Costing nothing in Glasgow, is the Kelvingrove Park transport museum and art gallery complex (0141 287 2700 www.seeglasgow.com).

In London, the Bethnal Green Museum of Childhood (020 8980 2415) , is offering free digital camera workshops throughout the Easter holidays.

Finally, there's a Watership Down event at Selfridges until 6pm today. Characters from the book will tell stories, paint faces and and give out free chocolate eggs (020 7629 1234).

webTitle: Guerrilla gardeners plot to reclaim the world

fields.headline: Guerrilla gardeners plot to reclaim the world
fields.standfirst: On May Day London will see the latest protest by a group out to inspire opposition to global capitalism
fields.trailText: The scene is the Cock Tavern behind Euston station. In a back room, accessible only via the gents, 70 or more people from Reclaim the Streets (RTS) are organising the nitty-gritty of what might, or might not, happen on May Day in central London.
fields.body:
The scene is the Cock Tavern behind Euston station. In a back room, accessible only via the gents, 70 or more people from Reclaim the Streets (RTS) are organising the nitty-gritty of what might, or might not, happen on May Day in central London.

On its website and handouts RTS says it is not organising a protest, so much as an "aspirational", "creative" event based around urban gardening and greening the city. Organisers say they want to return waste urban land to something useful and "share a common vision of building communities".

But the police fear that, rather than thousands of people peacefully and symbolically planting seeds and saplings, the event will turn into a Seattle-style pitched battle between the police and a hard core of about 500 anti-capitalists and anarchists. They admit their intelligence about RTS and its plans is scant and that they are unable to make contact with the organisers.

Three police forces - the Met, the City of London and the British Transport police - are working together and have been planning their response since November. All leave has been cancelled and thousands of riot police and officers will be on hand. It is, they say, the biggest planned police response to any political event in the past 30 years.

Labelled

Although the RTS meeting at the Cock is nominally open to the public, the media is barred. Since June 1999 when RTS's Stop the City carnival in the square mile turned into the worst riots since the poll tax protests, a stream of articles have labelled the group as revolutionaries, extremists, and anarchists.

It is now harder to get RTS organisers to discuss their ideology, politics or motivation than almost any global revolutionary group.

But four men and a woman, who ask not to be identified, agree to meet the Guardian the next day at the Barbican. They say they represent a broad consensus within RTS, but emphasise that they are only talking as individuals.

"RTS is a banner name under which people come together," says one. "It is a network, a coalition. Different people organise different events. It includes anthropologists, situationists, scientists, ecologists and others. There is no leadership, no executive body, no central planning. It is not an institution in itself. There is no membership. People represent very broad concerns. What makes it interesting is the diversity. There's no dogma or ideology, no one way of thinking."

"That's why the the police and the state fear us," says another. "They find it hard to understand how we organise and want to live our lives. Our aim is not to overthrow the state but to undermine it to the point where it is irrelevant. We want to decrease people's dependence on it to the point where they don't need it."

The May Day meeting, they say, aims to be a mixture of democracy and ecology, a positive and symbolic statement built around the notion of "guerrilla-gardening". This began in New York where a group called the Green Guerrillas began to plant gardens among the tenements in Manhattan in the 1980s.

What began as squats by environmental activists and poor residents eventually became full-blown community gardens. The idea of turning wasteland to gardens is now spreading in Bristol and other British cities.

The five say that there was broad consensus among the people who go to the weekly meetings at the Cock that it was time for people to do something, to be pro-active rather than reactive, and that May Day - "a people's festival for centuries" - should not be a protest or a street party.

"The idea came out of the genetics campaign, the crop squats, the experiences of the guerrilla and community gardeners in the US. People are being asked to come with seeds, water, earth and saplings and to decide for themselves what and where to plant. It demands participation. We want to see people getting their hands dirty and gardening," says the woman.

"Hopefully, groups of guerrilla gardeners will go all over London," says another. "The plan is to have a positive action, to create a beautiful working garden in the concrete jungle. For it to happen requires direct involvement on an unprecedented level."

They will not say where it will take place, and it is likely they do not know because, as with most RTS events, a final decision on where to go is left until the last minute.

RTS has its roots in the US environmental direct action group Earth First! and the Twyford Down and M11 road protests, they say. Its first "action" was to block off Camden High Street to traffic and create a massive street party in 1995. Since then there have been parties in more than a a dozen British cities and, increasingly, actions linked to protests around the world against globalisation and capitalism.

"In just a few years I think we have injected a Utopian element into [cities]. The actions allow a glimpse of change. We are catalysts of hope and possibility," says one of the five.

"Our role is to inspire people," says another. "The creativity, craziness and cheek helps. It's not about lobbying parliament - it's about saying 'Let's turn the centre of global capitalism into a party', or 'Let's take over an eight-lane motorway'. We want to show people some positive alternatives."

The five agree that RTS went beyond single issue environmental events years ago. It now seems to be moving towards a broad social ecology political analysis. It represents a fundamental shift away from many environmentalists who see nature and man as separate. Today RTS's thinkers - and there are many - see themselves as part of the rapidly evolving rainbow of global grassroots concern, linking social and ecological justice, human rights, debt, marginalised peoples and anti-racism, that was seen at Seattle.

Uniformly against globalisation, the five say they owe little to the old left and have no links with leftwing parties. Their inspirations, they say, come not from books or ideologies such as Marxism or socialism, but from their "everyday life experiences" of the "insanity" and injustice they see around them.

"People to a large extent are informed by the struggle in their own lives, to put bread on the table, pay the bills," says one.

What they all find exciting is the ping-pong of inspiration, going backwards and forwards. "For instance, we helped inspire Seattle, now we in Britain are being inspired by people in the US. The whole thing has gone global. Before June 18 [the J18 City riots] it was largely theoretical. Now there are global days of protest everywhere," says one of the five.

Greed

The group say they are broadly persuaded that the global system is now beyond reform. "There is massive disillusionment with the economic hierarchy and authoritarian structures. It's at an unprecedented level. Capitalism at its core rewards the darker side of human nature - greed, competitiveness and egotism. We want to see the tables turned upside down and to dance on the tables. It is not possible to reform the beast."

They claim that violence on May Day will largely come from the police and will be triggered by their presence in such large numbers. "Effectively you will have thousands of armed people in armour turning up, being opposed by people with seeds and saplings. If there is a huge police presence there will be a riot. If there's only a small one, then all that will probably happen is that we'll disrupt the traffic. A massive police presence will create a different atmosphere that would be conducive to violence."

They believe that the police will be looking for trouble. But they accept that protesters who intend violence from the outset will come along too.

Several of the five admit they will be unable to control the violence. They have been holding workshops on non-violent direct action, hoping, they say, to show that violence is not effective as a catalyst for change.

"I personally do not know one person who will be confronting the police on May Day," says one of the group. "I don't want to work with anyone who seeks violence," says another.

But the fact that RTS neither condones nor condemns violence makes it easy for the police to condemn them as terrorists. "Judging things morally is not necessarily productive," says one. "I don't think condemning helps the issues. It may actually worsen the situation."

fields.headline: Leeds fans charged after violence
fields.trailText: Fourteen Leeds United fans are to appear in court after drunken violence at the highly-charged match with the Turkish champions Galatasaray which knocked the club out of the Uefa Cup on Thursday night.
fields.body:
Fourteen Leeds United fans are to appear in court after drunken violence at the highly-charged match with the Turkish champions Galatasaray which knocked the club out of the Uefa Cup on Thursday night.

The men will face magistrates in Leeds on May 4 accused of a range of offences, including affray, using threatening behaviour, and being drunk and disorderly. Three other men arrested for criminal damage and car theft are expected to be charged later today.

Six more, including two Turks who were arrested for their own safety after unveil ing their national flag at a tense moment during the evening, were released without charge.

Police said that overall the city had escaped lightly from a night which was widely dreaded following the murder of two United fans in Istanbul before the first leg.

"I would like to pay tribute to the people of Leeds for keeping their cool," said the West Yorkshire assistant chief constable, Paul Garvin, who headed the £100,000 security operation.

"Tensions were obviously running high but I'm pleased that the outcome was no worse than a normal high security game.

"There was a small outbreak of disorder prior to the game involving known trouble makers but that was soon quelled - their actions were little different to those on most match days.

I would also like to pay tribute to our officers for their professional planning and handling of the event, and to Leeds United for the way they handled a difficult situation."

There was widespread relief in Leeds at the end of the dismal episode which started with provocative behaviour by Leeds fans in Istanbul, including "mooning" from buses and insulting local women and the Turkish flag.

In the street-fighting which followed, pub landlord Kevin Speight, 40, and fibre-optics engineer Chris Loftus, 37, neither of whom had been involved in the rowdiness, were stabbed to death.

Although minor by comparison, the violence in Leeds made a mockery of appeals by the club - including full-page advertisements in national newspapers - for a peaceful evening.

Just before kick-off about 100 fans attacked a police video surveillance team and tried to beat up four TV camera crews, one Turkish.

A brick was thrown at a coach carrying Turkish club officials, smashing a window, and Galatasaray striker Hakan Sukur was hit on the pitch by a missile, in an incident which has been reported to Uefa. The Turkish team left for Istanbul by plane from Leeds-Bradford airport soon after the game.

One Leeds fan, who has not been named, suffered a suspected heart attack shortly before kick-off and died in hospital. An Asian-origin man was treated for cuts in hospital after a fight involving about 30 people at the Walkabout bar in central Leeds where the match was shown live on television.

Galatasaray's 4-2 victory on aggregate makes them the first Turkish club to qualify for a European final. They will face Arsenal in Copenhagen in June.

webTitle: Resort's 'death zone' left to the sea

fields.headline: Resort's 'death zone' left to the sea
fields.standfirst: Environment Agency abandons defences for 3,000 homes
fields.trailText: A "death zone" at Eastbourne in which hundreds of coastal homes are being built and many more are planned will no longer be protected from the sea by the Environment Agency, the organisation has warned.
fields.body:
A "death zone" at Eastbourne in which hundreds of coastal homes are being built and many more are planned will no longer be protected from the sea by the Environment Agency, the organisation has warned.

The agency said it was forced into the warning by an imminent planning application by Beazer Homes, which wants to build many more houses in the most vulnerable area at the biggest marina complex in Europe.

It said the land owners, Sovereign Harbour, had failed to honour a 1988 agreement to bolster the sea defences in the area and the agency was not prepared to step in with taxpayers money.

Already nearly one third of 3,000 planned homes at the Sovereign Harbour development are occupied by people who have no idea of the serious danger the agency says they are in. They each pay the property company £125 a year towards the cost of the sea defences.

Ray Kemp, a spokesman for the agency, said: "Our engineers call the area where Beazer Homes want to build the 'death zone'.

"They believe that in the next big storm - like the one that hit France at Christmas - houses in this area will be washed away like matchsticks."

Carillion, formerly the Tarmac company, the owners of Sovereign Harbour, said it was in dispute with the Environment Agency over the 1988 agreement which, in its view, made the agency responsible for maintaining the foreshore.

"The agency cannot legally or morally dissociate itself from the agreement," a spokesman for the company said.

The area to the north of Eastbourne has been ear marked for a prestige development surrounding the marina and yachting club.

It was the building of the harbour which caused part of the problem because the shingle piles up on the west side. It then has to be regularly shifted to the east side to prevent the sea breaching the defences.

Beazer Homes said last night it was "surprised" about the warning the agency had issued and would be investigating before it decided to go ahead with construction plans.

Ian Hayes, development manager for Eastbourne council, said: "The agency has been raising objections to further development in this area for some time but we are powerless to prevent it." He said outline planning permission was given on the Beazer Homes site in 1997 "so we cannot stop it".

The problem for potential house buyers was that the lack of sea defences does not show on a solicitor's search, he said.

Roger Wesson, one of the first residents in the area in 1992, said: "We have been sent packs about what to do in the event of a flood, and we have had warnings, but nothing has happened.

"I have no idea how serious the situation is. We pay £120 a year for the flood defences and I would like to know what they do with the money. No accounts are published."

Peter Midgley, the Environment Agency's Sussex area manager, said: "It is wrong to expect taxpayers to subsidise works to the defences to protect the new development."

He said the company should use the money collected from householders to fund the defences. If it was a new greenfield site, he said, the agency would object to any development, "but decisions taken many years ago had left the agency and the local community in a difficult position".

The harbour company has accused the agency of issuing misleading statements and hindering its attempts to protect householders. It said Sovereign Harbour was working on the sea defences using the money it collected from householders.

"The protection for the local community has been provided by the developers - and is neither paid for, nor subsidised by, taxpayers," a spokesman said.

He added that Sovereign Harbour was prepared to reopen talks with the agency to try and resolve the problem.

webTitle: The vicar, his parish and a church in crisis

fields.headline: The vicar, his parish and a church in crisis
fields.standfirst:
Packed congregations will celebrate Easter Sunday tomorrow, but the wider situation is fraught
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Churches will be unusually full tomorrow, attendances swollen by a key date in the religious calendar. But the everyday reality is that the Church of England is an institution in steady decline, with a 22% drop in attendances in the 1990s. Today, in the first of a two-part examination of the state of the church, we chart the demise of its traditional role.
fields.body:
Churches will be unusually full tomorrow, attendances swollen by a key date in the religious calendar. But the everyday reality is that the Church of England is an institution in steady decline, with a 22% drop in attendances in the 1990s. Today, in the first of a two-part examination of the state of the church, we chart the demise of its traditional role.

The Rev Bernard Rumbold is preparing for a busy Easter. He will spend it driving his ancient MG sports car along the winding lanes of his enormous rural parish in north Worcestershire, shuttling between the five churches - all once with their own vicars - which now make up his area.

As vicar of north Teme, his parish stretches from the Herefordshire border to Shropshire, an area of 50 square miles in which he is the only permanent man of religion, and where just 50 of the 1,500 residents attend church regularly.

For this he earns the standard clergy stipend of £16,500, plus the use of his modern vicarage at the foot of the garden of the old Georgian rectory, which is owned by a millionaire.

This is the pattern for many rural vicars these days - increasingly large parishes, filled with ancient, crumbling, even semi-derelict churches which remain a central part of England's heritage.

"I will probably be the last rector of north Teme. When I retire I'm sure they'll amalgamate the parish even more," said Mr Rumbold, pondering the possibility of parishes serving 10 or a dozen villages and churches.

He has two 11th century churches, mystic, quiet places set among fields of sheep where people have worshipped for more than 1,000 years; one 18th century church built by a squire, and two churches built in the 19th century for congregations of miners and farmworkers. Each could hold several times the combined number of worshippers that now attend church in the valley each Sunday.

Isolation and poverty

Along the valley there is rural isolation and poverty. The hop farms find even local breweries import cheaper crops from Poland, fruit from the damson orchards is no longer wanted to make the dye for khaki uniforms.

The elderly have difficulty getting to nearby towns such as Tenbury Wells and Kidderminster to shop. The incomers from Birmingham and the black country are being made redundant.

Does it mean that Mr Rumbold, who cannot possibly know all his flock, is an irrelevance? "In a parish like this, it is still very much about being the parson as well as the vicar, about being a figure in the community to whom people come for advice and help even if they don't come to church.

"It's not about getting bums on seats. As a bishop once told me, I am called to be faithful, not to be successful."

His declining congregations follow a nationwide pattern. The Bishop of Birmingham, Mark Santer, said: "One has to be frank, the number of people on Sunday is declining and it is dispiriting if the numbers are small."

Some claim this is partly due to the issues of women and homosexual clergy which have both preoccupied and split the church.

When the Bishop of Blackburn, Alan Chesters, supported the repeal of Section 28 outlawing the promotion of homosexuality in schools, he was denounced by evangelicals for betraying the nation's children.

A Synod lay member, Philip Gore, said: "The bishop has capitulated to the gay lobby. The vast majority of parents are opposed to this sort of stuff and looked to the established church to provide firm opposition. We feel betrayed."

Almost a decade after the first ordination of women priests, a recent survey found a quarter reporting they had experienced sexual harassment or abusive behaviour and 40% said congregations had walked out on them.

Ironically, gay clergymen are blamed for some of the most spiteful attacks on their new female colleagues.The result has been that both groups regard each other with suspicion, rather than making common cause as oppressed minorities.

The arrival of ordained women has also seen the departure of 400 of the church's leading Anglo-Catholic vicars and most vociferous lay people, such as the Tory MPs John Gummer and Ann Widdecombe, both of whom have taken refuge in Roman Catholicism.

Fractious flock

The church's leader, the Archbishop of Canterbury, is the focus of the most intense scrutiny. George Carey, appointed in 1991, is often compared to John Major - a social upstart subject to snobbish metropolitan sneers as he struggles to keep his fractious flock together and update the creaking mechanism of the institution.

"Actually, we're like the Labour party in the 1980s," one vicar said. "We believe in letting it all hang out and pretend the vibrancy of our debate is a virtue."

The church needs all the help it can get. The commissioners charged with looking after its money were found to have lost £500m through ill-advised property speculation in 1992, a crisis with profound effects on the church's burgeoning pensions bill and its organisation, which has led Dr Carey to adopt modern managerial methods to streamline the organisation and its decision-making.

Paradoxically, some of the lessons of New Labour have been learned, though cack-handedly. Power has been increasingly centralised through the setting up of the inner cabinet-like archbishops' council, taking real decision-making away from the General Synod, the church's parliament.

The church's press officers have also grown more spin doctor-like and aggressive in their promotion of the official line and rubbishing of anything that does not emanate from them.

To much eye-rolling at its Westminster headquarters, Church House, it has even resorted to focus groups. The first, in February, told the church its services were too long and its vestments offputting.

Its influence, too, in the life of the nation is declining. The government's reformed House of Lords will contain 10 fewer Anglican bishops - down to 16 - their places taken by representatives of other faiths.

When Dr Carey and other bishops talk of disestablishment or the Prince of Wales says he wants to be Defender of Faiths, rather than just the Church of England, no one even turns a hair. "I don't think it would be the end of the world," said Bishop Santer.

Even some within its own ranks cannot see the church surviving. A survey by the Scripture Union estimates that if things continue at their present rate the church will be dead in 40 years, its buildings abandoned, its congregation down to just one in 200 of the population.

Its author, Peter Brierley, is respected as the church's leading statistician but official spokesmen are already questioning his gloomy analysis, which is based on decline continuing along the same curve.

Dr Brierley said: "The basic doctrines of Christianity will be believed much less and there will be many who actively do not believe them. This is very sober stuff. Numbers of Christians will decrease and the ones who remain won't express their Christianity by going to church."

Many of the church's 24,000 vicars are now being forced to radically reassess their roles.The Rev Adrian Newman, vicar of St Martin's-in-the-Bullring, Birmingham, sees himself almost as much as a chief executive and full-time social worker as a clergyman.

"Ten million people go past our door every year - it will be 22m when the new shopping centre opens - and we reckon 82,000 stop to come in," he said. "We did a survey and estimate 10% of them have financial, emotional or psychological problems. That is a lot of people to help."

Among its 20 staff, St Martin's employs a full-time clinical psychologist and an assistant psychologist as well as a curate, chaplain, arts coordinator, finance and development officer, secretaries, vergers and musicians.

The stream of damaged people entering the church come even though most are not religious. They see the church as a place of help and advice, offering a meal, a listening and advisory service, a voucher for a bed in a hostel. But not necessarily, or even primarily, Christianity.

"We don't push the faith on them, but we make clear we will pray with them if they want. We don't jump on them or push them into a corner.

"They wouldn't come in if they thought they were going to be judged. We are not like the street preachers in the market every day - we just make sure we are here all the time."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mother charged with murder
fields.body:
Mother charged with murder

Taj Ali, 24, is to appear today before Blackburn magistrates charged with murdering her daughter, Natalia, three, and the attempted murder of her son, Darnish, one.

The children were taken to hospital from their home in the Lancashire town last Tuesday with a suspected drugs overdose, and the girl died that evening. Asad Mujahid, 27, is charged with manslaughter of his daughter and neglect of his son.

Boy found face down in pond

A boy aged two is "very poorly" on a life support machine after being found face down in a duck pond.

He had been playing on his parents' farm in Carnkie in Cornwall, where the shallow pond was fenced off. Police said he may have been in the water for 20 minutes. His brother, six, called their mother and she resuscitated the boy while an ambulance arrived.

The couple, who have one other child, were with their son in hospital but "extremely traumatised", said police. They moved in to the farm six weeks ago.

Runaway 'plans Gretna wedding'

A 15-year-old runaway, Abigail Wells from East Wittering in West Sussex, may be hoping to marry her boyfriend at Gretna Green, police said yesterday when appealing for anyone who might have seen the pair.

She is 5ft 2in, slim, with brown eyes and shoulder- length hair. Mark Miller, 25, who also uses the surnames McLeod and Kennedy, is 5ft 9in with glasses and dark hair.

Walker survives 40ft cliff drop

A woman, 40, was flown to hospital yesterday after falling 40ft down a cliff while walking her dog on Leckhampton hill in Gloucestershire.

A spokesman for the county air ambulance said the unnamed woman had been lucky to escape with her life, although she had suffered quite serious facial injuries and a lot of bumps and bruises.

Collie pulled back from brink

Tiny, a black collie, bolted out of a window yesterday while alone in a flat in a Bristol tower block and was left hanging with his paw caught in the window frame, 12 floors above ground.

Passers by called fire fighters who broke down the flat door and pulled Tiny back from the brink. "He was shocked but otherwise unhurt," said Avon fire brigade.

fields.headline: The great getaway
fields.standfirst: Gloomy forecast spurs 1.5m to fly abroad as stay-at-homes shiver
fields.trailText: Roads, ports and airports yesterday escaped major congestion as millions of Britons embarked on the traditional Easter getaway.
fields.body:
Roads, ports and airports yesterday escaped major congestion as millions of Britons embarked on the traditional Easter getaway.

Problems were, however, experienced in Wales on the M4 when the second Severn crossing was blockaded by around 20 lorries.

Drivers of recovery vehicles were protesting about Gwent police's policy of using a single breakdown firm to help motorists.

Police took half an hour to remove the blockade, while traffic was diverted to the other crossing.

An estimated 1.5m people were leaving the country, spurred on by forecasts of bank holiday rain.

Heathrow recorded its busiest day of the year with 176,000 passengers passing through its terminals.

A further 1.65m people were expected to take a break in England, spending around £200m, according to the English tourism council.

The heaviest congestion was on coastal routes but AA Roadwatch reported few major problems.

Meanwhile, the port of Dover described the holiday traffic as "incredibly busy" but said the day had gone smoothly overall.

webTitle: Murder trial jury nobbling row grows

fields.headline: Murder trial jury nobbling row grows
fields.trailText: Lawyers representing Tony Martin, the farmer jailed for murdering a teenage burglar, yesterday said a juror had contacted them amid allegations that the jury was intimidated.
fields.body:
Lawyers representing Tony Martin, the farmer jailed for murdering a teenage burglar, yesterday said a juror had contacted them amid allegations that the jury was intimidated.

It is understood that the juror said she had been warned to convict Martin, who was sentenced to life imprisonment at Norwich crown court on Wednesday.

A majority verdict found that Martin, 55, from Emneth Hungate in Norfolk, murdered Fred Barras, 16, of Newark, Nottinghamshire, after the teenager broke into his isolated farmhouse.

On Thursday a woman called a Norfolk radio station claiming to be a juror. It was reported that she said she had received threats. But yesterday a spokeswoman for the station said the caller had not spoken of being "intimidated, pressured or nobbled".

However, Martin's lawyer, Nick Makin, believes the same woman contacted him yesterday. The publicist Max Clifford, acting for Martin, said: "Nick Makin had a lengthy conversation with a juror today. He knows it is one of the jurors from their conversation.

"What they spoke about is extremely interesting and revealing and Nick Makin will be acting on that information. I think this was the person that phoned into the radio station."

Meanwhile Barras's uncle, Tony Joines, yesterday dismissed as "absolute rubbish" claims that anybody con nected with his family had intimidated jurors.

The anonymous call to Radio Broadland in Norwich was taped but not broadcast. Afterwards the presenter told listeners what the alleged juror had said.

A spokeswoman for Radio Broadland said: "We want to clarify what was said because we feel it has been misreported in some respects and want to set the record straight.

"I have read the transcript of what the alleged juror actually said and what was reported on air and at no point was the word intimidation or pressure or nobbled mentioned at all."

She said the tape of what the alleged juror said would be given to police if requested.

The presenter, Rob Chandler, told listeners: "I think the most powerful thing that this person said was that the last eight days had changed their life.

"This person now actually feels frightened to leave their house having heard some of the things they heard."

Norfolk police said they were aware of the call but would not mount any investigation until asked to do so by the Lord Chancellor's Department.

A spokesman for the department said no investigation into the allegations would start until Tuesday. "The issue is taken seriously. What we don't know is whether the issue is a genuine or false one."

Court officials will also meet on Tuesday to discuss the allegations and may call in police.

webTitle: Protherics breaks drugs test speed barrier

fields.headline: Protherics breaks drugs test speed barrier
fields.trailText: Protherics, the pharmaceuticals research company, claims it has developed software which can accurately identify useful chemical compounds at 15 times the speed of existing technology.
fields.body:
Protherics, the pharmaceuticals research company, claims it has developed software which can accurately identify useful chemical compounds at 15 times the speed of existing technology.

The Macclesfield-based group has completed a project called DockCrunch, which involved screening 1m compounds to see if they will dock (combine) with oestrogen, the hormone crucial in diseases such as breast cancer and osteoporosis.

Using a system called Prometheus, the company has completed the process in six days, screening more than 150,000 compounds a day. Protherics says existing technology can only work at a rate of 10,000 compounds a day.

The group, which is chaired by the former Fisons chief Stuart Wallis, has been showing the results of the project to large pharmaceuticals companies over the past few weeks.

Protherics maintains that the system correctly identified all the compounds known to dock with oestrogen, together with several new ones. By reducing time and wasted research, the company believes its technology could slash the cost of finding new targets for development.

A Protherics spokesman said: "This could send the cost of testing crashing down. It will create a virtual library of potential drugs."

Prometheus works on a high-powered computer platform developed by a US group, Silicon Graphics. It uses electronically simulated three-dimensional models of compounds and the target receptor to see if a useful link can take place.

Protherics was created seven months ago through a merger of Proteus, a computer-aided research specialist, and Therapeutic Antibodies, a struggling biotechnology company.

The group has battled to impress the City since the deal, hampered by delays in getting regulatory clearance for its most advanced drug, a rattlesnake antivenin. It has said it will need to embark on a further fundraising by the second half of this year.

Mr Wallis is a respected "company doctor" who also chairs the Durex condoms group SSL International. His other interests include John Mansfield, the stock market shell which recently took over Waddington, the packaging company.

fields.headline: Justice for all?
fields.standfirst:
Metallica sets trend with MP3 suit

www.napster.com
fields.trailText: Prominent recording artists are planning to follow the lead of heavy metal band Metallica in suing Napster, the online service that enables users to download and trade music recorded in MP3 format.
fields.body:
Prominent recording artists are planning to follow the lead of heavy metal band Metallica in suing Napster, the online service that enables users to download and trade music recorded in MP3 format.

"There are going to be more lawsuits filed in the next few weeks by prominent artists," said Howard King, who filed suit on behalf of Metallica but also represents Dr Dre, The Offspring, Smashing Pumpkins and the Goo Goo Dolls.

On Monday, the Los Angeles lawyer sent a letter on behalf of rapper Dr Dre, whose legal name is Andre Young, demanding that Napster delete all his tracks from the directory.

Lawyers for Napster responded by putting the onus on Dr Dre and his advisers to identify individual users of the system who were violating the rapper's copy rights. Mr King said the proposal was impracticable, given the thousands of Napster users downloading and sharing Dr Dre tracks.

Mr King said other artists had approached him about taking action. "The suits will be remarkably similar to Metallica."

The Recording Industry Association of America sued Napster in December on behalf of the record labels it represents, alleging "contributory and vicarious copyright infringement". Lawyers for Napster have asked for a summary judgement in that case, which could result in a fast-track ruling without a trial.

Mr King said that after he demonstrated Napster's capabilities to one artist, "the gentleman was astonished; every song he's ever recorded is up there".

Napster officials pointed out that the service merely directs users to websites holding songs. The company explains on its website: "Napster does not, and cannot, control what content is available to you using the Napster browser."

The Digital Millennium Copyright Act of 1998 says internet service providers are "dumb pipes" that merely conduct information but have no responsibility for it.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Harland & Wolff breaks even
fields.body:
Harland & Wolff breaks even

Troubled Belfast shipyard Harland and Wolff increased its turnover but failed to make a profit last year, according to figures released yesterday.

The company, which is facing closure if it fails to secure new contracts before June, announced that it had broken even in 1999, compared with a pre-tax profit of £5.1m in 1998.

Its turnover during 1999 was £406m, up from the 1998 level of £223m.

The figures do not reflect the impact of a dispute with the company's main customer, Global Marine, over a sum of more than £100m. The announcement comes as a Royal Navy order for warships offers a potential lifeline for the shipyard, which employs 1,700.

BA aims to sell Air Liberté

British Airways is negotiating to sell its 86% stake in Air Liberté, its loss-making French subsidiary, to Taitbout Antibes, a financial institution registered in the Netherlands, according to reports yesterday. Taitbout is controlled by the French concerns Groupe Alpha and Marine Wendel, close partners of SAir group, the Swissair parent.

A deal would strengthen the presence of the Swissair-led Qualiflyer airline alliance in the French domestic market in competition with Air France, which has also submitted a bid for Air Liberté.

Nomura profits bounce back

Nomura Securities, Japan's largest brokerage, rebounded from last year's heavy losses to report its highest profits for 10 years on Friday. The company said net profits were ¥144.18bn (£867m) for the year to March 31, compared with a loss of ¥241.58bn a year earlier. Profits were the highest since the strong growth of the late 1980s, when Japanese asset prices were at their peak.

The turnaround was attributed to stockbroking commissions, which nearly tripled to ¥215.4bn.

The company's share on the exchange, calculated by the value of deals executed, was 11.1% compared with 9.5% a year ago. The news gave Nomura shares a lift: they closed 4.64% higher at ¥2,820.

Renault buys Samsung

Renault yesterday became the first foreign car maker to break into the South Korean market, striking a deal for Samsung Motors after nearly four months of negotiations.

"Renault and representatives of [Samsung Motors'] creditors have reached a deal which will have to be ratified by a creditors committee next Monday," a spokesman for Renault said.

He declined to give any details of the financial terms of the accord, but recent reports in the Korean press have said the company has raised its offer for Samsung Motors to $540m (£342m).

Thomson 'not ready for talks'

Britain's largest holiday firm, Thomson Travel, believes a bid of 150p a share from Germany's C&N Touristic will not be enough to bring it to the table, a source close to Thomson said yesterday. Thomson, whose shares have struggled since flotation two years ago, closed on Thursday at 137p.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: South Shropshire
fields.trailText: Alfred Housman had the acutest sense of Shropshire as a border county and scene of ancient fighting. He often contrasted the old-time strife with the present peace, nowhere more perceptibly than in that part of A Shropshire Lad where he describes the quartet of villages beside the twisting and turning river Clun as it comes out of emptiest Wales. Here indeed are these little settlements in Housman's "country for easy livers", where the most impressive presence is the ruined Norman castle at Clun.
fields.body:
Alfred Housman had the acutest sense of Shropshire as a border county and scene of ancient fighting. He often contrasted the old-time strife with the present peace, nowhere more perceptibly than in that part of A Shropshire Lad where he describes the quartet of villages beside the twisting and turning river Clun as it comes out of emptiest Wales. Here indeed are these little settlements in Housman's "country for easy livers", where the most impressive presence is the ruined Norman castle at Clun.

On a recent April morning primroses were winking in the fitful sun on the grassy mound-side below the castle walls. It wasn't hard to imagine Edric the Wild throwing stones at us from across the river - as he did so often in his harrying of the Normans. Clun suffered greatly in those days; burned by the Welsh four times between 1195 and 1400. Calm now, almost silent under broad border skies, the rolling blue hills across Offa's Dyke give promise of greater hills over the next horizon.

To the north-east a clump of little "bread cake" hills separate the river Clun from its eventual tributary the Kemp. From the summit of Clunton hill we gazed across to Walcot Park, former seat of Clive of India and famous now for its wealth of mature confiers. Though we couldn't see them from our hilltop there are two outstanding Douglas firs in the park. One is a survivor from 1827, grown from the original seed brought to Britain: the other is almost as old and probably the finest specimen of the species in this country today.

The path drops, north-eastwards, to cross the swirling Kemp close by Kempton hamlet on the road to Lydbury North. The Norman church there seems to have been built with a bigger village in mind; the screen to the Plowden Chapel is almost five centuries old and brings to mind the timber-framed Plowden Hall a mile off to the east. You can catch a glimpse of this ancient black-and-white house from the road, a mansion erected for the illustrious Elizabethan lawyer Edmund Plowden and still occupied by his family - a continuity of which Housman would have wholeheartedly approved.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A column on page 21, April 19, Let us be the judge, stated that there were no senior members of Britain's judiciary who had not taken silk. In fact, there are just upwards of half a dozen judges who were not Queen's Counsel.
fields.body:
A column on page 21, April 19, Let us be the judge, stated that there were no senior members of Britain's judiciary who had not taken silk. In fact, there are just upwards of half a dozen judges who were not Queen's Counsel.

Huntingdon Life Sciences, a company being targeted by protesters for its work in testing drugs and other products on animals, has neither been taken to court nor heavily fined as reported in a G2 cover story, April 12. Two of its employees were convicted of "cruelly terrifying dogs"; the company was given a Home Office caution.

Yesterday's music feature, page 12, Friday Review, misspelled Jascha Heifetz. This is the correct version of the late violinist's name.

Bettino Craxi, a former Italian prime minister, belonged to the Socialist party, not the Christian Democrats as stated in a report, page 16, April 20.

webTitle: Hague secures his status with swing to right

fields.headline: Hague secures his status with swing to right
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague's latest swing to the right will win him enough seats at next month's local elections and the general election to consolidate his position as opposition leader, leftwing Conservative MPs are starting to predict.
fields.body:
William Hague's latest swing to the right will win him enough seats at next month's local elections and the general election to consolidate his position as opposition leader, leftwing Conservative MPs are starting to predict.

Not only are they resigned to Mr Hague leading them into an election they are doomed to lose in mid-2001, they fear that a post-election leadership challenge might trigger the ultimate nightmare for the Tory left: a second round contest between Michael Portillo and Ann Widdecombe which the shadow home secretary wins.

Senior Tories yesterday put a brave face on claims that party membership, now around 350,000, is at its lowest since the first world war, insisting that it is stable or rising - though nowhere near the "millennium 1m" Mr Hague spoke of after he succeeded John Major in 1997.

That was the figure in Margaret Thatcher's heyday. But the Tory problem is less numbers than age profile. Their membership is still ageing.

"We never kept national membership records until just over a year ago," the Tory deputy chairman, David Prior, said yesterday as grassroots radicals complained that the party is still too undemocratic to attract young people.

Mr Prior insisted: "Each Conservative association kept their own records. We now do have an accurate membership list and it is growing. All political parties are finding it difficult to attract new members, but we have, I think, turned the corner."

Mr Hague has been fighting hard in recent weeks to ensure that he can claim another "victory" in a series of elections on May 4, just as he did by shifting his Euro-rhetoric to the right during the 1999 European parliament elections, where PR voting and a very low 23% turnout proved a recipe for Tory gains.

If Mr Hague had not passed that test, some party plotters already had the names of 25 MPs prepared to trigger a leadership contest under Hague-imposed rules, Tory insiders admitted last week.

Liberal Democrats in Romsey, Hampshire, are so confident that they may just snatch victory in the May 4 byelection to pick a successor to Michael Colvin - burned to death in a fire at his home - that some senior Lib Dems are predicting "an anti-gay smear story" between now and polling day.

Conservative strategists are confident they will win and argue that their concerns on Europe - Mr Hague staged a "Save the £" rally in Romsey - on asylum seekers and the section 28 controversy on sex education reflect mounting concerns among voters.

A win for the Tory candidate, Tim Palmer, and a victory for Ken Livingstone as independent mayor of London, would be judged a good day's work. That should be enough to give Mr Hague some morale-boosting lines as he urges his troops towards a general election he has no chance of winning, according to Tory campaign data leaked last week.

But leftwing Tories, who believe their leader made a mistake in abandoning the more "inclusive" rhetoric of his first year in favour of consolidating his party's core vote, are already looking beyond that defeat.

Others on the moderate flank believe that Mr Portillo "is not behaving like a man who wants to be chancellor".

What they would like to see is Mr Clarke making one last bid if Mr Hague is dispatched after the 2001 defeat, failing that a run by Mr Ancram or by Sir Malcolm Rifkind, if the former foreign secretary gets back to Westminster.

In reality some of them are already adjusting to the prospect of a Portillo leadership, not least because he is meeting them halfway on key social policy issues.

The rules laid down by Mr Hague require a leader to stand down if they fail to win the support of half of party's MPs. But once MPs have voted to reduce applicants for the vacancy to two finalists, the rank and file make the choice.
