webTitle: Germany learns to party like there is a tomorrow

fields.headline: Germany learns to party like there is a tomorrow
fields.trailText: Mukti Rehrs has a problem. She wants to party. But, like a lot of people in Germany she takes her job seriously.
fields.body:
Mukti Rehrs has a problem. She wants to party. But, like a lot of people in Germany she takes her job seriously.

"I work for a private kindergarten. Tomorrow, I start at 8 o'clock and it's very important that I'm fit for work, because I don't want to be aggressive with the children."

Which is how she came to be in the Far Out club on the Kurfürstendamm last Tuesday, taking advantage of the latest craze to hit Berlin's ever-shifting club scene. As Mukti and her friend took to the dance floor, there was still daylight coming in through the windows.

The craze began last October when the first early evening rave was held in Hamburg. An agency called Inferno organised it.

"One day, we were wondering why good parties start so late, and why people have to feel rough the next day in the office," said the owner of Inferno, Alexander Schulz, who has copyrighted the word "after-work".

From there, the idea spread to Berlin. Next month, a dedicated after-work disco is due to open in Hanover

"Right now, this is the only club in the west of Berlin which is doing this," said the DJ at Far Out, Punyesh Schlüter. "We hold an after-work party once a week. It starts at seven and ends at 12. This is only our third. But so far, the number of people coming along has increased each time."

People have, of course, been pouring out of offices and into bars for decades. But this trend represents something different. The idea is not to get wasted, but to dance, chat, drink a little - but only a little - and leave in time to get a full night's sleep and wake up fresh the next morning.

The volume at the Far Out last Tuesday was kept low enough for an intelligible conversation and its three bars were doing a distinctly desultory trade.

There is a large insurance office nearby and the managers of the club seem to have expected an influx of neo-yuppies. There is a notice at the entrance banning mobile phones.

Some of the customers were still in business suits, among them Olaf von Koenemann, the managing director of a call centre. "I read all about it in Welt am Sonntag and just wanted to see what it was like," he said as he collected a foaming glass of Warsteiner from the bar.

Germany's consensus capitalism is not the sort to push men and women to the limits of their endurance by sundown, and Berlin is nowhere near as frenetic as, say, New York.

What seems to be driving the craze is not so much bottled-up stress as a hitherto unexploited demand for sensible raving which may, or may not, turn out to be uniquely German.

"I like to dance, but I don't like to wait half the night to do so," said Matthias Matuschka, an out of work software consultant. "Being unemployed I could wait. But why should I?"

On the other side of the club, five young mothers were sitting together round a table. "We were going to a parent-teachers meeting, but we decided to miss it and come here instead," said Ellen Scheffkler.

"It's great for us that it starts so early. The last time we went to a party, it didn't finish till 1.30 in the morning, and that's too late if you've got kids."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mahathir let off
fields.body:
Mahathir let off

A Malaysian judge ruled yesterday that prime minister Mahathir Mohamad does not have to testify at Anwar Ibrahim's sex trial, saying that there was "not an iota" of evidence that Dr Mahathir plotted against his ex-deputy.

Anwar is accused of sodomising his former driver, and if found guilty faces up to 20 years in jail and a whipping.
Reuters, Kuala Lumpur

Protests in Iran

At least 150 people were arrested yesterday as protests continued for a third consecutive day against the annulment of the election of a reform candiate in Sarvestan, southern Iran. A local journalist speaking on condition of anonymity said hundreds of riot police were patrolling the streets and had banned gatherings of more than three people in the town.
AP, Tehran

Nazi attack fails

Neo-Nazi arsonists failed in an attempt to set a synagogue on fire in the eastern German town of Erfurt, police said yesterday.

The would-be arsonists left a note at the scene that was signed with the name of a previously unknown radical group. The attack took place on the anniversary of Hitler's birthday.
AP, Erfurt, Germany

Census snub

Serbs have boycotted efforts to register Kosovo's population for elections later this year, the authorities said yesterday. Four villages were selected to begin a project to replace records lost during the 1998-99 conflict.
Reuters, Pristina

fields.headline: 'Dr Subtle' asked to save coalition
fields.trailText: Italy's finance minister, Giuliano Amato, has been nominated to form a new government that would keep the embattled centre-left coalition in power and avoid a snap general election.
fields.body:
Italy's finance minister, Giuliano Amato, has been nominated to form a new government that would keep the embattled centre-left coalition in power and avoid a snap general election.

Mr Amato, a former prime minister known as "Dr Subtle" for his discretion, was chosen by colleagues as the best bet to unite the fractious coalition for a confidence vote in parliament next week.

President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi was last night expected to accept the nomination despite furious protests from Silvio Berlusconi's centre-right opposition, which wants an election a year early.

Mr Amato, 61, fills a vacuum left by Massimo D'Alema, who quit as prime minister on Wednesday following a crushing defeat in regional elections.

Mr Amato will spend the weekend selecting cabinet ministers and trying to shore up the centre-left's razor-thin majority to form Italy's 58th government since the second world war. Most estimates put his support at 322 votes in the 630-member house.

The technocrat, respected but unloved for spending cuts, was accepted by suspicious leftwing colleagues as the price to be paid for buying another year in government.

Some members suggested yesterday that the new leader was a stop-gap who should step down within the year, a refrain which also dogged Mr D'Alema.

Mr Amato will also be plagued by the accusation that he has no democratic mandate.

Political analysts have warned that the coalition will be weak; it certainly will need to regroup before taking on an opposition which swept the north and key regions in the south with anti-immigration rhetoric in regional elections last weekend.

Avoiding an election also keeps alive a May 21 referendum on electoral reform to end chronic political instability in the country by abolishing the remnants of proportional representation in favour of a first-past-the-post system.

Determination to see the referendum passed deterred President Ciampi from dissolving parliament and calling an election, which infuriated Mr Berlusconi who opposes the referendum and wants to exploit his momentum.

His coalition of former neo-fascists and the autonomy-seeking Northern League scored more than 50% of the vote in the regional elections.

In his brief stint as prime minister in 1994, Mr Berlusconi praised Mr Amato as a potential ally; yesterday he branded him a "useful idiot".

Almost alone in the government, Mr Amato has spoken out in favour of politically explosive pension reforms. And although secular, he is supported by Catholics for questioning an abortion law that is allegedly skewed in favour of wealthier women.

Determination to see the referendum passed deterred President Ciampi from dissolving parliament and calling an election, which infuriated Mr Berlusconi who opposes the referendum and wants to exploit his momentum. His coalition of former neo-fascists and the autonomy-seeking Northern League scored more than 50% of the vote in the regional elections. In his brief stint as prime minister in 1994, Mr Berlusconi praised Mr Amato as a potential ally; yesterday he branded him a "useful idiot". Almost alone in the government, Mr Amato has spoken out in favour of politically explosive pension reforms. And although secular, he is supported by Catholics for questioning an abortion law that is allegedly skewed in favour of wealthier women.

webTitle: Poetic tribute to bard of the Lakes

fields.headline: Poetic tribute to bard of the Lakes
fields.standfirst: Plaque to Wordsworth unveiled on 150th anniversary of his deathBooks Unlimited
fields.trailText: Easter in the Lake District is when hosts of golden daffodils are in bloom and poetry lovers' thoughts turn to William Wordsworth. But this year is special: Easter Sunday coincides with the 150th anniversary of the poet's death at Rydal Mount, his home for 37 years.
fields.body:
Easter in the Lake District is when hosts of golden daffodils are in bloom and poetry lovers' thoughts turn to William Wordsworth.

But this year is special: Easter Sunday coincides with the 150th anniversary of the poet's death at Rydal Mount, his home for 37 years.

So tomorrow one of Britain's finest poets will pay tribute to one of her literary ancestors (and his sister, Dorothy) by unveiling a discreet sesquicentennial plaque at the house, a couple of miles down the road from the much humbler Dove Cottage, where Wordsworth lived during some of his most productive poetic years.

Fleur Adcock is well qualified for the job: more than 20 years ago she published a pamphlet of verse written during an 11-month stay as literary fellow at Charlotte Mason college in Ambleside.

"I was grudgingly given an unpaid year off from my job at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office," she said. "A lot of people there seemed then to talk about Wordsworth as if he had died only last week."

Born in New Zealand, Ms Adcock had previously spent only one weekend in the Lake District but during it discovered "the lost England of my childhood".

"To me it was an unpolluted landscape, and I thought I had to try to get back there. So when this fellowship came up, I saw my opportunity.

"I read a lot of Wordsworth's work, including The Prelude, and I used to sleep with Dorothy's journals by my bedside. When I got to the end, I went back to the beginning."

Poems written during that stay are included in her new book, out next Thursday, which gathers verse produced over the past 40 years. They describe how she went for walks, gazed out over Windermere and tried to come to terms with the landscape's presiding genius.

In The Spirit of the Place, she finishes a walk at dusk and hears dogs barking hysterically "and from the housing estate below/a deep mad voice bellows 'Wordsworth! Wordsworth!'".

In the Vale of Grasmere she writes ironically of poets on pilgrimage and adds: "Most of the rocks are wreathed by now/with faded rags of fluttering soul".

Ms Adcock will read those poems at tomorrow's ceremony, plus others by Wordsworth including lines writtens in 1802 about his pursuit of a butterfly.

He describes himself as a hunter tracking his prey, but Dorothy "God love her, feared to brush/The dust from off its wings".

Ms Adcock will also read The Glow-worm (1807), which Dorothy recorded reciting to herself as she went for a walk on Good Friday 1802.

"I wanted to include something by Dorothy herself and hoped I could find a passage from her journals for April 23, 1800," she said. "But there is nothing for that day, so I'll read from her entry for the same day in 1802."

Dorothy describes a walk with William and Samuel Taylor Coleridge towards Rydal. "Before we got to Tom Dawson's, we determined to go un der Nab Scar. Thither we went. The sun shone and we were lazy. Coleridge pitched upon several places to sit down, but we could not be all of one mind respecting sun and shade, so we pushed on to the foot of the scar."

Poems 1960-2000, by Fleur Adcock, is published by Bloodaxe.

The Vale of Grasmere
These coloured slopes ought to inspire,
as much as anything, discretion:
think of the egotisms laid bare,
the shy campaigns of self-projection
tricked out as visits to Dove Cottage
tellingly rendered. Every year
some poet comes on pilgrimage
along these valleys. Read his verses:
each bud of delicate perception
sprouts from a blossoming neurosis
too well watered by Grasmere - in which he sees his own reflection.
He sits beside a tarn or ghyll
sensitively eating chocolate
and eyes Helm Crag or Rydal Fell
plotting some novel way to use it.
Most of the rocks are wreathed by now
with faded rags of fluttering soul.
But the body finds another function
for crags and fells, as Wordsworth knew
himself: they offer hands and feet
their own creative works to do.
"I climb because I can't write"
one honest man said. Better so.
Fleur Adcock

webTitle: Brookside star dies of heart attack

fields.headline: Brookside star dies of heart attack
fields.trailText: Actor Bill Dean, who played Brookside's cantankerous Harry Cross, has died aged 78. The Merseyside comedian had a heart attack on Thursday while at Arrowe Park hospital, Wirral, undergoing tests.
fields.body:
Actor Bill Dean, who played Brookside's cantankerous Harry Cross, has died aged 78. The Merseyside comedian had a heart attack on Thursday while at Arrowe Park hospital, Wirral, undergoing tests.

Brookside's creator, Phil Redmond, said yesterday: "It is both a shock and a tragedy that another of Merseyside's gallery of stars has gone out. Bill was not just part of the family but part of the furniture at Mersey TV."

Mr Dean became a cult hero in the Channel 4 soap, playing a crotchety retired railwayman who was Brookside's original nosy neighbour.

In an interview last year he described his character as a "miserable old git" but claimed there was a Harry Cross in every street.

He left the programme in 1990 but made a poignant return last year in three episodes when a much frailer Harry Cross returned to his old home with Alzheimer's disease.

Mickey Starke, who plays Sinbad, joked that his friend, a fanatical Everton supporter, would be disappointed at missing yesterday's Merseyside derby against Liverpool.

"Everyone had a tale to tell about Bill. He was a sweet old man and it was a privilege to know him in his later years. I have nothing but happy memories of him."

fields.headline: Rock of ages
fields.standfirst: Quarry opens to visitors
fields.trailText: Wil Jones has resisted all pleas to fire a rock cannon to celebrate today's reopening of a quarry which has been buried in forest for half a century.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Wil Jones has resisted all pleas to fire a rock cannon to celebrate today's reopening of a quarry which has been buried in forest for half a century.

Rock cannons were part of the traditions of the quarry at Bryn Eglwys, north Wales, which supplied first-quality slate slabs for the likes of the Star Chamber of the Palace of Westminster.

The quarry will never cover a roof again. The buildings, which once included a splendid manager's house and a vast 19th century slate mill, lie buried under tons of shale.

Bryn Eglwys's only product now is tourism. "People get sentimental about the pits and quarries," Mr Jones said, "but it was a filthy, dangerous, horrible job."

He has worked all his life for the forestry commission, which bought the land when the quarry closed, and is an amateur industrial archaeologist.

He has researched the bizarre history of rock cannons in north Wales. They were fired for special occasions: coronations, diamond jubilees, VE Day, VIP weddings.

Shallow holes, connected by grooves, were drilled in rocks and filled with blasting powder, which was then lit - to spectacular effect.

Mr Jones has made and fired one, but has collected too many disaster stories to make one today.

One was once made for a wedding. The quarryman fired it on the hill above the church, and while waiting for the wedding party to emerge he took his pipe from his powder-spattered pocket - and lit it.

fields.headline: Two die in 'suspicious' house fire
fields.trailText: A house fire which claimed two lives is being treated as suspicious, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A house fire which claimed two lives is being treated as suspicious, police said yesterday.

The bodies of a man and a woman, thought to be in their 30s or 40s, were found in the burnt-out property in the village of Coxhoe, five miles south of Durham.

Detective Superintendent Ian Scott, of Durham police, said the blaze was being treated as suspicious and predicted the investigation would be painstaking and slow.

Police have begun sifting through the wreckage and a team of specialists from a forensic laboratory in West Yorkshire has been brought in.

The bodies will be examined by a Home Office pathologist before being moved to Dryburn hospital in Durham, where a post mortem examination is expected to be carried out.

The alarm was raised shortly after 6am but by the time firefighters arrived flames could seen be pouring out of downstairs windows.

The roof collapsed and neighbours reported hearing the windows blow out.

Assistant divisional officer Ian Davison, of Durham fire brigade, said: "The scene is one of utter devastation.

"The damage is such that it is likely to be some time before we know the cause. We do not know where it started and it is impossible at this stage to say whether it was accidental or deliberate."

Electricity and gas board officials have been called in to help the investigation.

Two dogs are also thought to have died in the blaze.

webTitle: How verse saved poet laureate from the IRA

fields.headline: How verse saved poet laureate from the IRA
fields.standfirst: Behind the bumbling exterior, poet was a successful secret agent who jokingly signed himself 'Sean O'Betjeman'Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The IRA plotted to kill the poet John Betjeman but called the gunmen off because they liked his poetry.
fields.body:
Gracious Lord, oh bomb the Germans
Spare their women for Thy sake
And if that is not too easy
We will pardon Thy mistake
But, gracious Lord, whate'er shall be
Don't let anyone bomb me
- from Lady's Cry (1940)

The IRA plotted to kill the poet John Betjeman but called the gunmen off because they liked his poetry.

Diarmuid Brennan, the IRA army council's head of civilian intelligence, later wrote to the poet laureate, who had been a spy in wartime Ireland, telling him how he had been spared.

"I came to the conclusion that a man who could give such pleasure with his pen couldn't be much of a secret agent. I may well be wrong," said Brennan.

He was very wrong. For newly discovered papers reveal that behind his bumbling tweedy front, Betjeman was an exceedingly good spy.

He in fact knew more about the inner workings of the IRA than many of its own members, and his take on Eamon de Valera's neutral Irish government was far more accurate and astute than that of his political masters.

Betjeman worked as a press attache in the British embassy in Dublin in the early years of the war planting British propaganda in newspapers and trying to counter the energetic efforts of his German opposite number, a man called Petersen.

But it was as a spy and political analyst with an understanding of De Valera's often convoluted attempts to maintain Irish neutrality, in the face of intense pressure from Churchill to join the allies, that Betjeman really shone.

His success eventually attracted the attention of IRA, which Betjeman had correctly deduced was more anti-De Valera than anti-British at the time because he had interned most their leaders without trial.

Brennan later wrote to the poet telling him how in 1941 two gunmen from the second battalion of the Dublin IRA had approached him looking for a photograph of "a fellow called Betjeman.

"These second battalion types were known to us as the Edward-Gees of the IRA, after Edward G Robinson [the actor who specialised in playing gangsters].

"I got communications describing you as 'dangerous' and a person of menace to all of us. In short, you were depicted in the blackest of colours."

But having read some of Betjeman work, Brennan decided to throw them off the scent. He waited 26 years before writing to the poet to tell him how close he came to death.

Betjeman's biographer Bevis Hillier believes Brennan was swayed by reading Continual Dew, a 1937 volume that contains several poems about Ireland and another about Oscar Wilde (Betjeman loved him), as well as his best-known verse, Slough, in which he implored the Luftwaffe: "Come, friendly bombs, and fall on Slough."

Hillier got his first inkling that Betjeman was a spy when he interviewed Professor Nicholas Mansergh, of St Johns College, Cambridge, who worked in the Colonial Office during the war and read many of the poet's reports from Dublin.

"As soon as I arrived in his room to talk to him he prefaced it by saying that he would not discuss whether Betjeman was a spy. I hadn't even raised it," said Hillier.

In a neat historical irony, Mansergh's son, Michael, is now the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern's historical adviser, and is credited with helping to persuade the Irish government to renounce its territorial claim to Northern Ireland.

Heresy

According to documents unearthed by a Channel 4 documentary to be shown tomorrow, Betjeman actually told London that the only way to lure the Irish into the war was to end partition.

He said a "defensive union of the whole of Ireland" should be made "indissoluble", and he urged them to stop attacking the Irish Free State.

This was heresy at the time given that De Valera was seen by Churchill as little short of a traitor, and had become a hate figure in the British press.

Betjeman recommended "the stopping of anti-Irish articles and cartoons". Instead, propaganda should concentrate on backing De Valera "and showing the tightrope he is walking".

Although De Valera was convinced Germany would win the war, the poet said: "There is no doubt that he and most of his ministers feel that the better interests of Eire will best be served by a British victory. For this reason Mr de Valera is Britain's best friend in Ireland."

He was also scathing about Unionist leaders of the devolved Northern Ireland government and their "stupid anti-Irish remarks".

His reports hint at several high-level contacts within the Irish government. That the English poet appeared to have struck up a very useful friendship with the minister for industry, Sean McEntee, among others, and his IRA informants was even more impressive.

His estimates of their strength and his accounts of their interminable internal feuds were very close to the mark. The depth and detail of his intelligence on their splits and activities point to the inside track, according to Michael O'Riordan, a Spanish civil war veteran active in the IRA at the time.

Betjeman somehow got hold of a hand written anti-fascist declaration signed by 140 leftwing IRA men, including O'Riordan, interned in the Curragh army camp in Kildare and reported it back to London complete with precise figures about how many prisoners were communist, pro-German and anti-British.

Although he was clearly no stranger to espionage, one of Betjeman's main sources of information were the wags and Irish Times journalists who gathered in the Palace bar, a Dublin watering hole where Brendan Behan - then in the IRA himself - sometimes held court and which the great satirist and novelist Flann O'Brien used like an office.

Tony Gray, an Irish Times journalist who met him then, said Betjeman was a very popular figure who endeared himself to the Irish. "He was very witty and very English and people loved him. He didn't at all seem to be a spy, which I suppose is a very good cover."

He got even more popular by persuading Laurence Olivier to shoot his ultra-patriotic Henry V - with its heavily symbolism of a beleaguered England vastly outnumbered by its European enemies - in Ireland. The doughty yeomen who faced the French in the Agincourt battle scenes were actually Irish farmers, paid extra if they brought their own horse.

"That was a huge propaganda coup," said Marion Milne, who directed the documentary. "The man was a consummate operator. Not only did it pump £80,000 into the Irish economy - a huge amount at the time - it won the British cause a lot of sympathy and goodwill."

As you would expect from a man who found hitherto unknown levels in light verse, Betjeman's dispatches back to his controller in London were often priceless. Weighing up the threat of a German invasion of England being launched from Ireland, he noted that Dublin pork butchers were almost all German and that the Irish army bandmaster was also one.

His insights into the Irish psyche were spot on. "The Irish are not at all ideological," he wrote in 1941, "and not really interested in totalitarianism versus democracy. They are, however, intensely interested in Irishmen." And in a final flourish he signed himself Sean O'Betjeman in Gaelic script.

There in pinnacled protection
One extinguished family waits
A Church of Ireland resurrection
By the broken, rusty gates
Sheepswool, straw and droppings cover
Graves of spinster, rake and lover
Whose fantastic mausoleum
Sings its own seablown Te Deum
In and out the slipping slates'
- from Ireland With Emily

fields.headline: The last word on   Paganism
fields.trailText: Easter has its origins in a pagan celebration of nature's resurrection. According to St Bede, the word is derived from Scandinavian "Ostra" or Teutonic "Ostern" or "Eastre," in either case the name of a goddess of northern mythology responsible for fertility and birth.
fields.body:
Men become superstitious not because they have too much imagination, but because they are not aware that they have any. - Santayana

Easter has its origins in a pagan celebration of nature's resurrection. According to St Bede, the word is derived from Scandinavian "Ostra" or Teutonic "Ostern" or "Eastre," in either case the name of a goddess of northern mythology responsible for fertility and birth.

The symbols of Easter are as ancient as the festival: rabbits to signify reproductive ebullience, eggs to symbolise new life. Like the phallus-worshipping May-day observance which closely follows it (and which contemporary self-styled "Pagans" regard as a more important feast, a "Greater Sabbat" as opposed to a "Lesser Sabbat"), Easter is therefore about sex. The contrast with the purely spiritual and other-worldly significance now attached to it is striking proof that propaganda and brutality (eg burnings at the stake) can make entire populations believe the very reverse of what their ancestors believed.

Christianity's appropriation of this age-old fertility festival is of a piece with its frequent adaptation of other once-pagan things. The quarter-days - including Christmas - are associated with moments of astronomical importance, namely the solstices of winter and summer and the equinoxes of spring and autumn, all of them major pagan feasts.

Many saints of the Christian calendar are pagan deities whose cult was so strong that the new religion could make headway only by incorporating them; two of many examples are St Vitus and St Hippolytus. JG Fraser in The Golden Bough famously begins by showing how worship of the Virgin Mary was grafted on to worship of the virgin goddess Diana, whose cult in Italy during the first centuries AD was very powerful. The Christians' technique was effective; the old faiths were simply incorporated wholesale into the new; Diana's worshippers were told that they could at last know her real name, which was Mary.

Indeed the very word "pagan", with its negative connotations, is a mark of Christianity's propaganda success. In Latin "paganus" means countryman, and by association "pagan" even then denoted the superstitions of uneducated folk. Worship of nature and its animating principles, together with knowledge of nature's healing and narcotic powers, and celebration of everything associated with its cycles of reproduction, birth, maturation and death, were outlawed by Christians as evil practices.

The beings associated with these superstitions - the Green Man, the nature goddesses, fairies and elves - were demonised. Nature, like the human body itself, was to be chastened and controlled, as merely functional and not only far less significant than the abstract spiritual truths of the next world, but actively hostile to them unless subjugated.

The nature beliefs characteristic of ancient paganism (and modern "Paganism") reflect the origins of religion as mankind's first attempt at science and technology. It was science because it offered an account of how the world works; it taught that the wind blows because invisible powers puff their cheeks and blow, and likewise that crops grow and rains fall at the will - or when otherwise, the whim - of the gods. It was therefore technology also because it offered a means of controlling the wind, rain and growth of crops, the means being prayer and sacrifice.

There was nothing arbitrary about these beliefs for our ancestors. They could see the gods in the sky - the sun and moon - and feel their strength in the earthquake and their anger in the drought. It is a mark of how entrenched that world-view remains that as its themes became increasingly abstract, belief in them appears to grow stronger.

Thus: the ancient Egyptians married a boy to their queen on the day of the winter solstice, then at the day's end killed and dismembered him to strew his body on the fields like fertiliser, the point being to encourage the sun to cease its southward winter journey and bring its life- giving warmth back again so that the crops would grow. This theme - of death being a necessary preliminary to renewed life - is repeated in many traditions; it has echoes in the tale of Orpheus's journey, and it makes Jesus's three days in hell a commonplace of mythology.

In western Christianity, Easter is the first Sunday after the full moon that follows the spring equinox of March 21. This is why it is a "moveable feast." In eastern Christianity it coincides with the Jewish observance of Passover, for the reason that the earliest Christians, who were Jews, appropriated the latter for their new rites. This Easter, votaries of both traditions will repeat the paradox that is so characteristic of human beings: they will watch Easter services on television, thereby using an instrument of science to replenish their faith in dim superstitions whose roots lie in the infancy of our species, and which we dreamed up then to fill the vacuum of our ignorance.

webTitle: Wind me up, watch me go

fields.headline: Wind me up, watch me go
fields.trailText: I'm going soon to California for the summer, and I'm worried about the language problem. It is by now a familiar idea, even if it came alarmingly from philosophers, that the words available to us affect, not just what we do, but how we think about what we do.
fields.body:
I'm going soon to California for the summer, and I'm worried about the language problem. It is by now a familiar idea, even if it came alarmingly from philosophers, that the words available to us affect, not just what we do, but how we think about what we do.

Wittgenstein's "language games" spur conversations about this, encouraging us to consider the play of behaviour around specific words. (On the birthday before his death, Wittgenstein's charwoman brought him a cake and wished him "many happy returns of the day". He turned from his desk and told her, "I want you to think precisely about what you have just said", whereupon she burst into tears and dropped the cake.)

The point is that we shape ourselves to the phrases that can be said about us. So what will I be newly liberated to do or feel in California? And what habits of mind or behaviour will I lose?

Humour may be the first victim. That is always the concern when I am heading west. It will no longer be possible to think of anyone as "po-faced" for sitting stonily through some entertainment - the phrase, which comes from poker-faced and means an impassive expression, has no real American equivalent.

Getting the joke or playing along is not as important a part of the social repertoire there. American phrases to describe people who are stiff, or take themselves too seriously, usually involve rods or pokers being uncomfortably somewhere near asses - altogether coarser phrases, so naturally I wouldn't use them. (Maybe because I'm too uptight; though uptight has mostly disappeared, sadly, except among ageing hippies.)

Californians have a reputation for tending to their psyches - much as the English have a reputation for tending to their gardens - and though I am comfortable with that attendance, the therapy-enhanced language that goes with it leaves me cold. People often use the phrase "pushing his buttons" to describe triggering angry reactions. As buttons suggests, the idea is that the reactions are pre- programmed; if you've had enough therapy you will know where your buttons are, and can recognise when someone is pushing them.

Here, the same phenomenon would be called "winding you up". You wind someone up when you play them along until they start to react with anger or impatience. It is a similar image, as it also involves setting off a mechanism, but in implying some kind of toy, it suggests something more prankish: wind him up and watch him go!

This is consistent with the way that people use the expression - winding someone up can be a more playful, and certainly more deliberate, thing to do. You can admit to someone, even affectionately, "I'm just winding you up", whereas you would never acknow-ledge "I'm pushing your buttons". Button-pushing is not something to play around with. It is serious. In all likelihood, thousands of dollars have been invested in learning how not to let others push your buttons, and no one wants to be faced with evidence that it was money down the drain.

An American friend recently said, of a young child in conflict with his mother, that the boy "pushes her buttons". It struck me that this problem would formerly and more simply have been described as "getting on her nerves", which might be a fact of mother-son, or indeed parent-child, life; this new phrase opens up the possibility that the situation might be susceptible to therapy. (In fact, in England, he might be said to be "getting on her tits", but those do seem to be loaded words to use about a young boy and his mother.)

What I most dread acquiring is what everyone in California seems to have: "issues". People used to have "baggage"; now they have issues, which sound lighter but cause at least as much trouble, as once you have discovered your issues, you have to "work through" them: it goes with the linguistic territory. The process is almost limitless, the choice of life-elements you can have issues with: parents or money or abandonment.

Do English people have issues? If not, what do they have instead? It is easy to have abandonment issues - all you need is a fear of being left. But if it is not possible for someone to describe their troubled interior in a particular way, they may not have the same experience of it, and will seek different solutions, other than therapy. Bridget Jones's response to her many issues is to have another glass of Chardonnay and light up a cigarette.

Of course, you can't smoke now in bars in California. That is not language: it is law. And there is no point in complaining, as Californians are quite po-faced about it.

fields.headline: First TV poet
fields.standfirst: An eccentric uncle to the nationBooks Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir John Betjeman, the most popular poet laureate of the last century, who came to embody everything English, was born into a family of Dutch furniture makers who may actually have been German.
fields.body:
Sir John Betjeman, the most popular poet laureate of the last century, who came to embody everything English, was born into a family of Dutch furniture makers who may actually have been German.

His selected poems sold more than 2m copies and made him a kind of colourful, eccentric uncle to the nation. He also became the first TV poet, with a reach and popularly his successors have yet to match.

His deceptively dark light verse won him a large audience. His most famous poem, Slough, in which he implored the bombers to destroy the town of "tinned milk, tinned beans/Tinned minds, tinned breath", is always thought of as a joke, but it was in fact a daring and controversial poem coming as it did in the wake of Guernica.

He idolised the aristocracy, and eventually married into it, though Penelope Chetwode's parents did not approve. When he first met her father, a field marshal, he turned up in a bow tie on an elastic band which he twanged right through lunch.

The marriage withered in middle age, but the couple stayed together by virtue of a "civilised arrangement" that allowed Betjeman time for his mistress, Lady Elizabeth Cavendish.

Asked near the end of his life if he had any regrets, he said: "Yes. Not enough sex."

webTitle: Veterans sue MoD for war trauma

fields.headline: Veterans sue MoD for war trauma
fields.trailText: A group of 280 ex-servicemen are suing the Ministry of Defence in the largest group action of its kind to seek compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder.
fields.body:
A group of 280 ex-servicemen are suing the Ministry of Defence in the largest group action of its kind to seek compensation for post-traumatic stress disorder.

The veterans, who between them have served in almost every recent military action involving British forces - including Bosnia, the Gulf, the Falkands and in Northern Ireland - claim the MoD failed to diagnose and treat those suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

The men say they were poorly trained for the effects of conflict, exposed to unnecessary danger and that afterwards the ministry failed to diagnose or treat their condition or to put adequate support systems in place.

The claimants include 40 Welsh Guardsmen who were trapped in the burning shell of the Sir Galahad warship after it was attacked by Argentine planes during the Falklands war.

Many of the survivors of that attack say they have since been unable to work as result of the psychological stress they suffered and some claim not to have had a full night's sleep since the attack in which 50 of their comrades died.

The 280 individual claims are to be brought in the High Court in two group actions next year, claiming medical negligence and seeking compensation for loss of earnings.

If these cases are successful, the government could face compensation claims from thousands more ex-servicemen totalling hundreds of millions of pounds.

John Mackenzie, a solicitor representing 50 of the claimants, said PTSD was a "deeply disabling" condition that had left many of the veterans emotionally scarred.

He told Radio 4's Today programme: "The basis of the action is that the MoD and services should have taken better steps to diagnose and treat the condition once they had acquired it.

"It is a condition that has been recognised in one form or another since the First World War, and probably before that."

The lawyer warned that the litigation could also have implications for emergency services whose employees face similar stresses.

Although the ex-servicemen's claims acknowledge that soldiers, sailors and airmen must accept being exposed to risk and danger during conflict, they are claiming the right to receive treatment for any resulting psychological problems in the same way as they would expect for physical injuries.

The MoD is expected to argue that it could not have predicted the problems as PTSD was little known until recently and was only recognised by the American Psychiatric Society in 1980.

Although 150 people were discharged from the forces for PTSD between1990 and 1998, there is still no single diagnostic test for the disorder, sufferers of which exhibit a range of physical and mental symptoms, including headaches, nightmares, an inability to concentrate and involuntary tics.

Shaun Rusling, chairman of the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association, said the MoD promised to put a system of diagnosis and treatment in place after the Falklands.

He said: "At the time that the troops were returning from the Gulf war in 1991, the MoD failed to keep that promise.

"The result of this failure led to an increase in serving soldiers and ex-servicemen committing suicide and a clear increase in the divorce rate in service families."

The British veterans claim that evidence collected by the Israeli authorities during the Six Day War in 1967 and the experience of American serviceman in Vietnam proved decades ago that servicemen can suffer PTSD as a result of their involvement in military action - yet the MoD did little to alleviate the suffering.

Israel, unlike Britain, has routinely screened and treated troops for PTSD since the 1970s.

An MoD spokesman insisted the ministry had behaved "in line with contemporary best practice in our treatment of service personnel with suspected PTSD".

He added: "We hope that the court's findings on these lead cases will set the scene for the resolution of the remainder of the outstanding claims. We have had measures in place to prevent stress related illness for a number of years.

"We take it very seriously. We are more sophisticated now than when the shell-shock victims of the Second World War were identified."

Bill Sutherland's nightmares began soon after the first bombs hit HMS Plymouth on June 8 1982 .

A chief petty officer in the Royal Navy, he was serving in the Falklands when the ship was attacked, suffering fire and bomb damage.

That day changed his life forever. "I started having disturbed sleep and nightmares, waking with cold sweats, and my personality completely changed."

Mr Sutherland, now 42 and living in Fife, saw action in the Gulf clearing mines off Kuwait in 1991, but he was not diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder until 1995.

As the officer in charge of his ship's fire party, he was asked to take his men to the fire training ground.

"It was absolute terror," he says. "I soiled myself and burst into tears. I had this terrible fear of getting trapped in a fire."

He spent a month in hospital and, after 21 years of service, he was medically discharged in May 1996.

He blames his divorce on the condition, while his fear of crowds means he has only worked for six months since.

"I lost my wife because I wasn't the same person she married. If something had been said or done earlier, my life would be different now."

fields.headline: Sheep: this year's hot accessory
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
Sometimes, just sometimes, radio tells the truth like no other medium. It can express human folly and tragedy better than Shakespeare (witness Neil in The Archers on Wednesday: "Getting rid of the pigs? But you had such plans!"). And it can ask the big questions with more gusto than Mr Paxman (Mark Tully to yoga guru BKS Iyengar: "How long are you going to stand on your head for?").

This has been a revelatory week. Maybe it's to do with the fact that tomorrow is a special day. No, not Easter Sunday, silly, but Shakespeare Day - and this on the same weekend that the phone numbers change. Radio 3 has been leading up to this frisky vortex of chocolate, poetry and dial codes in just the right way. If you've been tuning in, you will already be inhabiting a sonnet-sensitive, paranoid universe of sudden, strange declarations, all in tricksy rhyming schemes.

To lead up to the Bard's birthday, dozens of people have been recorded reciting a Shakespeare sonnet as far afield as Sydney and, er, Bournemouth. These have been cropping up mainly in Morning on 3 and In Tune (Radio 3) and they are lovely, kooky things.

An airline pilot read No 27 ("limbs with travel tired", "a zealous pilgrimage" - geddit?) at 33,000ft above the Atlantic. You want to know whether he let go of the steering wheel to do so, and whether it went out over the intercom. A dance teacher recited 128 ("nimble leap") to her class over soulless electronic music ("the wiry concord that mine ear confounds") and you could almost feel the sweat hanging in the air. Best of all was a farmer called Norman doing an earthy cover version of 130, "My mistress' eyes". His backing track was the putt-putt of his tractor; expect Fatboy Slim to sample this soon.

Agricultural matters were high on the agenda elsewhere. In The Archers, William worried himself silly about where to re-house Tess the dog and Baby Spice the cow in the Grundy move. Pets and lifestock were dropped off at every door in Ambridge. Some of the people in The Trouble with Sheep (Radio 4) sounded close to abandonment, but mostly they just ate their flock with lashings of mint sauce.

Exploring the trend for sheep being kept by townies-turned-rural-dwellers as "lifestyle accessories" and "pretty lawnmowers", here we learned that sheep "don't go off and do drugs and alcohol" (well, not unless the one in front of them does first). We discovered too that foot rot is a common but not pretty thing with sheep. "The combination of a little bit of blood, quite fetid, foul-smelling gunk and rotten flesh, topped off with half a dozen maggots - it's great dinner-party stuff," said one sheep-keeper. Especially if Gin or Tonic are on your plate in chop form at the time.

fields.headline: Great goddess
fields.standfirst: Mark Espiner  is an instant convert to the voice of Virginia Rodrigues
fields.trailText: Mark Espiner is an instant convert to the voice of Virginia Rodrigues
fields.body:
A Virginia Rodrigues performance is like a religious experience. Her evangelism may be unintentional, but something spiritual happens in the air she fills with her voice. And with a vocal range as broad as the band of emotions that she communicates in her songs, she seems to express the whole of Brazilian life.

Songs from her second album, Nos - her homage to Salvador and the saints (orixas) of the Afro-Brazilian religion Candomble - were the crux of her set at the Barbican. Allowing her six-piece band to take the stage ahead of her, each of them picking up percussion instruments and striking up a carnival procession rhythm, she emerged on stage swathed in golden silk that clung to her voluminous curves.

As the percussion subsided and melted in plaintive textures of flute, viola, guitar, saxophone, double bass and softly struck drum skins, she sang the beautifully haunting Uma Historia de Ifa - a Candomble incantation and story of lost fertility. The contrast in textures couldn't have been more marked, the transformation more masterfully smooth.

The performance continued in the same style. What was lost in a cracked or missed note in her voice or over-zealous playing in the band was made up for by her exuberance: she threw her arms out and mimed with theatrical gestures to the lyrics, her charismatic grin shaping the rich, dark sounds drawn from her heaving breast.

The band metamorphosed from song to song. A jazzy ensemble with honky saxophones for the carnivalesque Afrekete gave way to thumb pianos and rain sticks for a percussive interlude, before creating the lush orchestral backing for a deeply plaintive rendition of Manha de Carnaval, a song from Rodrigues's first album, Sol Negro.

At one point she gracefully dismissed the band but for the guitarist. And then, as a show piece, she stood alone to warble free-falling melodies.

The band returned to strike up carnival again. Rodrigues pulled up her skirts and started to dance. Tossing away her shawl and turning her back to the audience, she shimmied her expansive behind, graciously accepting the audience's cheers. An unorthodox preacher with a voice to nourish the soul.

fields.headline: Last Supper - the sequel
fields.standfirst: Harrison Birtwistle's new work contains some of his most intense and beautiful music, says  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: Harrison Birtwistle's new work contains some of his most intense and beautiful music, says Andrew Clements
fields.body:
When Harrison Birtwistle decides to call a theatre work The Last Supper, the last thing you would expect is a straight narration of the biblical events. Storytelling has never been the point of his theatre pieces, and in the "dramatic tableaux" unveiled on Tuesday at the Berlin Staatsoper, the events of the Passion are just the starting point. The piece is more concerned with exploring the dramatic possibilities of the rituals it implies than with delivering a commentary on its religious significance. In the same way, the priority in Birtwistle's 1984 The Mask of Orpheus was to examine the many facets of the myth rather than to tell the story of Orpheus and Eurydice pure and simple.

Robin Blaser has provided a libretto for The Last Supper that is both passionate and allusive, threaded through with theological references and some overripe imagery. The final message of his text is hard to pin down, and the ending, with the sound of a cock crowing, is perhaps deliberately ambiguous - would Christ be betrayed in the 21st century in just the way he was in the first, and who would play Judas this time around? The score, on the other hand, contains some of the most direct and immediate writing for voices and orchestra that Birtwistle has ever produced. The one thing that The Last Supper most decisively is not is a Christian celebration for Easter, despite the timing of the premiere.

The main action of The Last Supper takes place now, looking back "through the three zeros of the year 2000", as Blaser has one of the disciples say. The only female protagonist, a figure called Ghost, acts as the bridge between the past and the present. While a chorus in the pit comments and proclaims, she gathers the disciples - minus Judas - together once again, to relive the events of that fateful evening, and to take stock of the intervening 2,000 years. Each disciple gives a little vignette of his subsequent life, then they celebrate their reunion and build a table on which to re-enact their meal. When Judas finally appears to complete the group the mood darkens and becomes confrontational.

Christ's arrival is delayed until the second half of the work, and the mood then changes yet again as he renews his message. Around him history seems about to repeat itself, and he suggests, perhaps rather glibly, that a new Christianity can learn from the mistakes of the old.

It is Christ's appearance that also triggers the first of three "visions" which break the continuity of the second half of the work. Each time, the stage darkens, and to the sound of a pre-recorded chorus singing some of the most intense and rapturously beautiful music Birtwistle has ever written, the betrayal, the stations of the cross and the crucifixion are acted out in reverse order. In Martin Duncan's intelligent and effectively low-key production, with designs by Alison Chitty, these visions are played out in cliched, garishly realistic, biblical imagery, pointing up the contrast with the everyday clothes of the disciples, who are summoned back into the world through a brilliantly lit "time tunnel" into an impersonal, concrete space.

Birtwistle writes for a small orchestra - 35 players, with a minimum of percussion, but with an accordion that adds an astringent edge to the textures. The words from the soloists, sometimes set in sweeping melismas, sometimes incisively declaimed, come across very clearly. They are underpinned with long raking melodic lines or intricate webs of counterpoint, so that each of the disciples as well as Christ and Ghost can inhabit their own specific musical worlds.

The two-hour work unfolds in a seamless arc - what will audiences at Glyndebourne do about their own supper? - and is perhaps a little too long. The pacing of the first half, up until the appearance of Christ in fact, is perfect - intensely dramatic, gripping, exuberant. The disciples celebrate their return by dancing and clapping to some of Birtwistle's most unbuttoned music, while their questioning of Judas - "Who do you think He is?" - and the riddle with which he retaliates, create music drama of real power.

After that, though, the pace sometimes slackens; the long, very typically Birtwistlian section in which Christ washes the feet of each of his disciples, ridding them of the dust of 2,000 years of inhumanity, is a cyclic, too protracted structure. At the same time, Christ's own utterances finally lack the authority that the context seems to demand of them.

That might have had something to do with William Dazeley's performance in that role - his cream-suited portrayal (with an unfortunate resemblance to Monty Python's Brian) didn't project real confidence and charisma, though it might well be fleshed out when the production reaches Glyndebourne, first on the tour in the autumn and then in next summer's festival. (Glyndebourne, along with London's South Bank Centre, are co-commissioners of the work.) The rest of the cast is already superb. Susan Bickley as Ghost and Thomas Randle as Judas are outstanding. She is the pivot around which the whole work revolves, its conscience and its emotional heart; he is its dark side, hunted, remorseful, and strangely compelling. Daniel Barenboim conducted the first performance wonderfully; it was he who secured the premiere for Berlin, and his faith has been repaid with a fascinating work.

 Glyndebourne Touring Opera will give the British premiere of The Last Supper at Glyndebourne on October 18.

fields.headline: Passion runs high
fields.standfirst: This year's Oberammergau play has been revised to rid it of anti-semitism. But, says  Stephen Bates, nobody seems to be satisfied with the changes. What will happen when it opens next month?
fields.trailText: This year's Oberammergau play has been revised to rid it of anti-semitism. But, says Stephen Bates, nobody seems to be satisfied with the changes. What will happen when it opens next month?
fields.body:
It is given to few journalists, even from the Guardian, to interview the Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ before lunch, but as we sat in a Bavarian cafe supping cappuccinos, it did not seem ridiculous. This is Oberammergau, home of the famous passion play and scene of continuing controversy over the blaming of Jews for the crucifixion of Christ. Once again, charges of anti-semitism are reverberating through the Alps.

Outside the vast 4,700-seat theatre, you can watch hundreds of villagers reverently converging through a spring dusk. Heavily-bearded middle-aged farmers, businessmen, wood carvers, some wearing traditional hats, others driving up in BMWs, families in anoraks, young women in leather jackets, all congregating, as their ancestors have done for 360 years, to take part in a ritual that once every 10 years makes their village unique.

The play, performed only by villagers (you have to have been born locally or have lived here for at least 20 years) will this summer attract half a million visitors: the production has as many as 1,000 actors on stage, lasts for nine hours and is performed almost entirely in German. As 60% of the audience will be tourists from the US and Britain, many will have little idea of what is being said: they do not seem to care. The 112 performances, up to five times a week between May and October, were sold out two years ago.

The words do matter, however. After decades of argument, this year the play has been substantially rewritten in an attempt to be sensitive to long-standing Jewish complaints. But the rewrite has not satisfied Jewish-American groups. With only weeks before the first public performance, the New York-based Anti-Defamation League is demanding further script revisions to make clear that the high priests who condemned Christ were not bad just because they were Jewish.

The name of Judas is too close to Judaism; the word Pharisee is fraught with meaning; couldn't Oberammergau just put on Godspell instead, asks the League. It suggests that visitors should be reminded that the village is close to Dachau - the concentration camp site is almost 100 miles away. The mostly Catholic villagers resent that the changes they have made have not been appreciated. They do not like one Jewish critic's description of them as living in "the jungle of Bavaria". And the Jews feel that the villagers have ignored Germany's past.

"Sometimes I do believe they will not be satisfied until Jesus dies of influenza," sighs Otto Huber, a teacher who has rewritten the play. "We have a friendly, threatening relationship. With Dachau nearby, one should be more careful," says Rabbi Leon Klenicki from his League office in New York.

The play is close to the hearts of 5,000 villagers. It has been performed every decade since their ancestors swore in the church in 1634 that they would stage it regularly if God spared them from the plague; 83 villagers died that summer but after the oath, as winter approached, there were no more deaths. The village has kept its promise. Its inhabitants used to perform only for themselves, but for the last 130 years productions have been popular with visitors. In the early 1900s, the auditorium, dominating the village, was built to accommodate growing audiences. In 1934, Hitler was among them; he claimed the play was a precious tool of anti-semitism. Only in the last 10 years have things begun to change, slowly. Otto Huber and younger colleagues, now in control of the play, do acknowledge there was a problem, perhaps less with the current text (written by the parish priest Alois Daisenberger in the 1860s) than with its interpretation. Somehow in the late 19th century, a choral aria asking what God should do with sinners - implicitly Jews - concluded that they should be killed; it dropped Daisenberger's conciliatory lines,that it was God's purpose to rescue them.

Now pointed references to bad characters being Jewish, suggestions that the money-changers and the high priest Caiaphas, Christ's accusers, were motivated by their religion, have gone, as has the suggestion that Pontius Pilate was a good man facing Jewish pressure. . Out has gone Judas's yellow costume, with its echo of the colour of the stars Jews were forced to wear under the Nazis.

In have come references to Jesus's own Jewishness (the last supper will be a Passover feast with Christ reciting a Hebrew prayer); a change in the character of Pilate, who takes a cynically ruthless decision to order the execution; above all, new lines imply that those opposing Jesus are motivated by human wickedness, not Judaism.

These changes have taken time and effort. Ten years ago, Huber and the play's director, Christian Stückl, were defeated in a village referendum over revising the text (all decisions about the play are put to referendum). The revolutionary proposal that women who were married or over 35 should be allowed to take part was only reluctantly accepted, even though it ended the absurd convention that Jesus's mother should be played by a woman decades younger than the actor playing Christ. Other conventions - that the cast do not wear make-up (the men stop shaving a year before the show to achieve the requisite shagginess) and that no microphones are used, despite the huge auditorium - were left unchanged. This year, one of two women playing Mary, Andrea Hecht, 37, who runs a local art shop, is married with two children. The two men who take it in turn to play her son are both younger than she is, though only by a few years.

The theatre has been renovated at a cost of £5m to seat almost 5,000 people. In a cafe opposite, Hecht and Anton Burckhart, 29, a forestry worker who plays one of the Christs, explained the village's motivation to keep the play alive. It brings enormous revenue to the region since most visitors have to stay two nights to see it. But the cast themselves do not reap financial rewards.

"We would do this even if nobody came. It is a very important part of our life," said Hecht, who will work in her shop even on performance days, during the long periods when she is not required on stage. "This is important to the village and its unity. We are not professional actors, so normal life must go on. It would be dangerous if I started feeling holy. I believe in God but I don't go to church every week."

Burckhart, a man with a hint of Gérard Depardieu about him, said: "No Oberammergau actor has ever become a professional. I don't want to be famous; when this is over, I will go back to the forest."

Oberammergau is not a devout village. Only about 7% of locals regularly attend church. But attitudes are deeply conservative. Huber and Stückl, both from local families - Huber's has been there since 1670 - had to present their proposed revisions every three months to the town council and village meetings before they were accepted. Critics are at present silent, though one local has said the play is no longer pious enough. Some tickets, mainly those sold in Germany, are being returned.

"I think if you asked people in our audience whether Jesus was a Jew, they might be genuinely shocked," said Huber. Stückl, a professional director, whose father and grandfather are in the cast, said: "My actors are very good, but it is not possible to make great theatre, because many people who come here want to see the old story."

But, like the rest of Germany, Oberammergau is changing. On the way to the theatre, the director chatted with a shell-suited skateboarder. "He is the first Muslim ever to be in the play," Stückl said.

The revisions did not impress the Anti-Defamation League, which last week sent Huber nine further pages of changes it wants to see. While conceding the new script was a great improvement, Rabbi Klenicki said that passion plays are sources of anti-Judaism and do not improve the relationship between Christians and Jews; the play still projects a very negative view of Jewish leadership in the first century, implying community guilt and minimising Roman responsibility. Rabbi Klenicki suggests that tourist agencies alert visitors to the presentation of Judaism and its negative projections - centuries of contempt - which prepared the atmosphere for the Holocaust.

In an earlier letter, Rabbi Klenicki and his academic colleagues suggested that Jesus should greet his disciples by saying Shalom, adding : "Jesus is now always referred to as Jesus rather than Christ. This we see as a helpful step because Jesus is not so far removed from his Jewishness by his name _ we think that the Hebraic name Yeshua could occasionally be used _ it will add to the Jewish atmosphere "

Such suggestions make Huber, who believes he has genuinely tackled anti-semitism, sigh. "Everything we have done is the product of 100% reflection and humility, but they think we are just a gang of farmers. If, when you see the play you can still taste something anti-semitic, we will have to look further into ourselves."

Rabbi Klenicki will do just that. He has accepted an invitation from the mayor to attend, and will be in the front row on the first night.

It brings enormous revenue to the region since most visitors have to stay two nights to see it. But the cast themselves do not reap financial rewards. "We would do this even if nobody came. It is a very important part of our life," said Hecht, who will work in her shop even on performance days, during the long periods when she is not required on stage. "This is important to the village and its unity. We are not professional actors, so normal life must go on. It would be dangerous if I started feeling holy. I believe in God but I don't go to church every week." Burckhart, a man with a hint of Gérard Depardieu about him, said: "No Oberammergau actor has ever become a professional. I don't want to be famous; when this is over, I will go back to the forest." Oberammergau is not a devout village. Only about 7% of locals regularly attend church. But attitudes are deeply conservative. Huber and Stückl, both from local families - Huber's has been there since 1670 - had to present their proposed revisions every three months to the town council and village meetings before they were accepted. Critics are at present silent, though one local has said the play is no longer pious enough. Some tickets, mainly those sold in Germany, are being returned. "I think if you asked people in our audience whether Jesus was a Jew, they might be genuinely shocked," said Huber. Stückl, a professional director, whose father and grandfather are in the cast, said: "My actors are very good, but it is not possible to make great theatre, because many people who come here want to see the old story." But, like the rest of Germany, Oberammergau is changing. On the way to the theatre, the director chatted with a shell-suited skateboarder. "He is the first Muslim ever to be in the play," Stückl said. The revisions did not impress the Anti-Defamation League, which last week sent Huber nine further pages of changes it wants to see. While conceding the new script was a great improvement, Rabbi Klenicki said that passion plays are sources of anti-Judaism and do not improve the relationship between Christians and Jews; the play still projects a very negative view of Jewish leadership in the first century, implying community guilt and minimising Roman responsibility. Rabbi Klenicki suggests that tourist agencies alert visitors to the presentation of Judaism and its negative projections - centuries of contempt - which prepared the atmosphere for the Holocaust. In an earlier letter, Rabbi Klenicki and his academic colleagues suggested that Jesus should greet his disciples by saying Shalom, adding : "Jesus is now always referred to as Jesus rather than Christ. This we see as a helpful step because Jesus is not so far removed from his Jewishness by his name _ we think that the Hebraic name Yeshua could occasionally be used _ it will add to the Jewish atmosphere " Such suggestions make Huber, who believes he has genuinely tackled anti-semitism, sigh. "Everything we have done is the product of 100% reflection and humility, but they think we are just a gang of farmers. If, when you see the play you can still taste something anti-semitic, we will have to look further into ourselves." Rabbi Klenicki will do just that. He has accepted an invitation from the mayor to attend, and will be in the front row on the first night.

webTitle: Take a good look: that's you

fields.headline: Take a good look: that's you
fields.standfirst: Forced Entertainment's latest project presents imaginary cities reeling with violence.  Jonathan Jones  takes a look
fields.trailText: Forced Entertainment's latest project presents imaginary cities reeling with violence. Jonathan Jones takes a look
fields.body:
It's hard to imagine two more different worlds than contemporary British art, with its avant-garde white spaces and laconic gestures, and British theatre, with its continuing addiction to narrative and social critique. Since their formation in 1984, theatre group Forced Entertainment have tried everything to bridge this gap, from taking an audience on a coach tour of Sheffield to presenting a 24-hour "durational performance" at last year's London International Festival of Theatre. How about an arty computer game pro jected large as life at Sheffield's Site Gallery?

The city centre is empty, except for someone slumped under a lamp post in the street lights' amber glow. This is not a time and a place you want to be in. The only escape is by touching the body, which leads you to another city street at night, graphite, a wooden door daring you to open it... This is Nightwalks, an interactive art work on CD-rom, directed by Tim Etchells and photographed by Hugo Glendinning, in which members of Forced Entertainment act out some terrible yet unexplained scenario in desolate urban settings at dead of night.

Across the road from the gallery, the silver drum shapes of Nigel Coates's National Centre for Popular Music lend Sheffield's cultural quarter a... well, you wouldn't call it glitz. Coates's architecture is emblematic of a changing sense of the city: it seems to mime the excitements of virtual space. Meanwhile at the Site Gallery, virtual space imitates the desolation of a real British city. Nightwalks was photographed in London and Sheffield; the alleys, flats, graveyards and car parks are in some imaginary yet grittily authentic Britain. Sex, murder, dubious transactions - it's all happening down these hyperreal mean streets. But what makes Nightwalks - along with its sister pieces Frozen Palaces and Spin, shot respectively in a Georgian townhouse and a junkyard - so unhealthily entertaining is the way it implicates you.

Glendinning has shot a series of 360-degree panoramas in which people bleed, scream, hold seances. They are frozen like statues for you to move around, zoom in, move back for a better view. The actors play murderers, the murdered, and a pantomime horse. It's a game, and one in which they are setting you up as the Hitchcockian film director, or just a psychotic voyeur. The tableaux are full of narrative details that never gel into a "story" - there is an analogy with paintings such as Hogarth's Rake's Progress. They are also full of loaded iconography, but it's impossible to tell which scene comes first, what the story is. Your effort to do so becomes the narrative; your urge to see compels you from scene to scene. You are the sinister presence in these rooms and streets. It is your shadow glimpsed on a rainy street at 4am, your invisible presence moving silently and smoothly towards a weeping figure sitting alone in a midnight car park.

There's humour here too, a Grand Guignol quality to these scenarios. If the experimental theatre work dries up, Forced Entertainment have a great future as a kind of HammerStudios.com.

Artists who work with new media tend to be optimists, even utopians, like the Danish group Superflex who are gradually creating an exact double of the Swedish city of Karlskrona on the internet, arguing that in this virtual space Karlskrona's citizens will be able to negotiate new social relationships. By contrast the virtual world created by Forced Entertainment is not utopian at all; it is a murky replica of contemporary Britain and it chills your blood. Their exercises in video art are less interesting, because they seem to retreat to a more humanist, emotional style, but the fictional British city of Nightwalks is a dreadful, alluring place. You wouldn't want to live there but you probably do.

webTitle: A country of trust and friendliness

fields.headline: A country of trust and friendliness
fields.standfirst: When  Martin Wainwright taught in 60s Rhodesia, Deadly Hazards were just road signs
fields.trailText: When Martin Wainwright taught in 60s Rhodesia, Deadly Hazards were just road signs
fields.body:
The road sign was unforgettable for a boy on the loose in Zimbabwe. Pocked with a potshooter's slug-hole and topped with a thoroughly British red warning triangle, it read simply "Deadly Hazard". When you thumbed a lift - and everyone always stopped for you, black, white and a Chinese family in a Morris Traveller with fitted curtains - the big game was tease-the-English-teenager with macabre guesses as to what the DH was going to be. Gaboon vipers crossing the road? A tottering baobab tree waiting to keel over and squash the car?

In reality, the worst Deadly was a badly-engineered bend across the Umvumvumvu river; and that was as far as human agencies went towards threatening your life in the beautiful country now so gruesomely torn apart. Although civil war was not very far away - this was 1968 and sanctions were in force - there was an atmosphere of friendliness and trust.

Every third weekend, I would be dropped after midnight by a drowsy trucker or farmer who'd been visiting family in Harare, to walk 12 miles through the bush from Marandera to Bernard Mizeki college and the duties of gap-year "teaching", trying to find contemporary meaning in Buchan's Prester John, the set text.

Sometimes the moon turned the sandy track into silver powder; at others the night was so soot-warm and black that you almost had to feel your way along. But always there were murmurs of conversation from huts among the trees, and a cigarette end would glow orange, signalling a 2am chat in the middle of nowhere. "From England?" England was seen by black Zimbabweans as the great force for good which would come and rescue them from the "settlers".

Our frigates prowled the Beira Strait; we summoned Ian Smith to meetings on a cruiser called the Tiger. The imagery came from the days when a troop of Lifeguards in plumes and redcoats galloped up to Lobengula's kraal in Bulawayo with a message from Cecil Rhodes. Knowing the inadequacies of Harold Wilson's almost bankrupt country, you were torn between telling the truth or sustaining this Ladybird book image of the Motherland, because of the power it had to keep good people full of faith.

You were torn in a different way in a dreary pub at Enkelkdoorn, sparsely patronised by Afrikaner farmers and complete with a fake prison cell reserved for Wilson. To these men with colossally thick arms, we were a country of communist nancy-boys in love with kaffirs and Pakis; worse still, we were liberals. To have that word spat out with real venom was a tonic for a secret Young Liberal, used to being patted to death by opponents in Britain as well-meaning, ineffectual and too nice. But liberals in UDI Rhodesia were another matter.

The headmaster of Bernard Mizeki regarded getting a mildly satirical letter about Smith into the Herald newspaper as the equivalent of a Commando raid. It was frightening to see how a community's values had rotted in the sun, corroded by easy-living, bossing malleable servants around and pushing black pedestrians off the pavement. I saw that every time I hitched through.

It was Doris Lessing's stories come horribly to life. And the most painful thing, for a Quaker-edu cated boy working at a school named after a Shona Anglican martyr, was the way that Christianity had died among whites, so far as the black community was concerned. It wasn't just the failure of the churches, which meekly registered under the apartheid Land Tenure Act, which partly underlies today's tragedies. Scarcely any white Rhodesians wanted to meet, deal or share anything with blacks, however genuinely kind and friendly they all were to a young white visitor. The chill ran very deep and well into the next generation.

When the 15-tonne open truck carrying the Bernard Mizeki Debating Society rolled up at an all-white Catholic school in Harare, our eager kids in their pink blazers were patronised and sneered at by priest-taught teenagers who will now be in their mid-forties. The striking resemblances to England and English ways were a sham. It was like accounts of the wartime occupation of the Channel Islands. And yet the country was full of hope, not just because of its great beauty and obvious natural wealth, but because Christianity, the gift the whites had abandoned, had been taken up so eagerly by the blacks.

In my class register of Rejoices, Nelsons and Perserverances, you could check the Beatitudes and find in droves the meek, the hungering and thirsting after righteousness, and the forgiving.

One afternoon, I looked out from a clifftop on a sea of blue headscarves de-bussing in the valley road below. It was a visit by 6,000 members of the African Mothers Unions of Zimbabwe to the Bernard Mizeki shrine and within minutes the whole landscape shook with hymns. The 30 years since may have eroded this, with power corrupting the new rulers just as the loss of it has clearly reformed those young, white Zimbabweans who have thrown in their lot with a country they no longer control.

I keep in touch now only by letters full of sonorous English, such as one to my brother who also taught in Zimbabwe: "Dearest English Friend, how rolls life and actions with you on your journey towards death? Mine is simply enjoyable and comfortable." But such a powerful resource will still be there beneath the violent headlines. And like the Silent People of GK Chesterton (a poet the old white Rhodesians would mistakenly have believed to be on their side), when the elections come, it will speak.
