fields.headline: California, here I come
fields.standfirst: In the year of the 150th anniversary of the birth of Robert Louis Stevenson, right, fellow-Scot  Duncan Campbell  follows in the footsteps of his hero through the farthest west of America
fields.trailText: In the year of the 150th anniversary of the birth of Robert Louis Stevenson, right, fellow-Scot Duncan Campbell follows in the footsteps of his hero through the farthest west of America
fields.body:
There is the spiffy, Californian coastal golf course named after Spyglass Hill from Treasure Island, where each hole is called after a character from the book. There is the Louie Louie cafe in the Robert Louis Stevenson school at nearby Pebble Beach, full of busy, impossibly healthy-looking co-eds who will soon be de-constructing Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde in their English classes. And there is the galleon-topped monument in San Francisco's Chinatown, standing amid the skate-boarders and the elderly, dozing Chinamen, with its im- precation to the passer-by that he should "keep a few friends but these without capitulation; above all, on the same grim condition, (to) keep friends with himself".

But in this 150th anniversary year of the birth of RL Stevenson, it is perhaps not the plaques and the place-names that resonate with the time he spent in the United States, but the still contemporary issues on which he focused: on race and the fate of the American Indian; on sudden wealth at times of boom and bonanza and its ability to destroy and divide; on immigration and capital punishment; and, not least, on the joys of Californian wine and the perplexing nature of the telephone.

In 1879, Stevenson received a telegram in Edinburgh from Fanny Osbourne, the married American woman with whom he had fallen in love in France three years earlier. The telegram does not survive, but whatever it contained drove Stevenson to pack in haste, and within a week he was setting sail on the SS Devonia from Greenock. "I am in fair spirits but a little off my nut," he wrote from the ship.

He can only have been a little further off his nut by the time he arrived in New York. It is reassuring to learn that, even then, Britons about to arrive in America were full of stories of the dreadful things that might befall them. "You would have thought we were to land upon a cannibal island," he wrote. "You must speak to no one in the streets, as they would not leave you till you were rooked and beaten." Today, the vocabulary has changed rooked to mugged, but the sentiment is much the same: these Americans are a wild and violent people, so don't catch their eye in the subway in New York or drive with rent-a-car plates in Florida or you'll come back in a box. It is equally reassuring to discover that, in a land where there is now an (expensive) cure for everything, Stevenson, suffering from a terrible itch, parted with some of his limited funds to purchase a blue pill, a powder and a little bottle of medicine. "He might as well have given me a cricket bat and a copy of Johnson's dictionary," wrote Stevenson of the pharmacist.

There was more of the adventurer than the grumpy ex-pat in Stevenson and as he travelled by train across Nebraska, he could write: "The line of the railway stretched from horizon to horizon, like a cue across a billiard board; on either hand the green plain ran till it touched the skirts of heaven." What strikes the reader now is not so much the lyrical descriptions of the landscape, as the observations of his fellow-passengers whom he described in The Amateur Emigrant. Passengers on the train were split into three groups: the families, the single male immigrants and the Chinese. Stevenson wrote: "Of all stupid ill-feeling, the sentiment of my fellow-Caucasians towards our companions in the Chinese car was the most stupid and the worst _Their forefathers watched the stars before mine had begun to keep pigs."

In particular, the prevailing attitude to the American Indians struck Stevenson: "If oppression drives a wise man mad, what should be raging in the heart of these poor tribes, who have been driven back and back, step after step, their promised reservations torn from them one after another as the States extend westward, until at length they are shut up into these hideous mountain deserts of the centre." He saw Indian families at way-stations on the journey west much as you might today at some glum Greyhound station: "The silent stoicism of their conduct, and the pathetic degradation of their appearance, would have touched any thinking creature, but my fellow-passengers danced round them with a truly Cockney baseness. I was ashamed of the thing we call civilisation."

He was bound for Monterey in California, arriving there somewhat to Fanny's embarrassed surprise, since she was still married and uncertain how to proceed. Stevenson, unable to stay with her because of the conventions of the time, slipped away into the nearby Carmel hills where, always a sickly man, he lapsed into a delirium. He was rescued, as Frank McLynn tells it in his biography, by a bear hunter called Captain Smith and an Indian called Tom, who treated him with frontier remedies until he recovered.

He returned to a boarding house in Monterey - now Stevenson House, preserved with many of his artefacts on display. As an author with a local connection, he is somewhat overshadowed by John Steinbeck, since the original Cannery Row is in the town; but perhaps Stevenson would not envy him the tourist spin-offs and the Steinbeck Country insignias. Steinbeck paid gentle homage to Stevenson in his short story, How Edith McGillcuddy Met RLS.

I had always had a sneaking, vicarious attachment to Stevenson: we grew up in the same part of Edinburgh, went to the same school, studied in the same law faculty at the same university, edited the same student paper and hot-tailed it in our twenties to California. (Only one of us, at the last count, had become a world-renowned writer.) And so time to retrace a few of his footsteps, to Monterey and that French-Swiss boarding-house where he waited for Fanny to extricate herself finally from her husband, Sam.

The house itself is in beautiful condition, the datura and rhododendron in full bloom in the garden, and Stevenson could not have asked for a more devoted carrier of the flame than Monica Hudson, the Swiss woman who is the local RLS expert, co-founder of the new society there in his honour and one of the guides to the house.

"There is a lot of interest still," said Hudson, pointing out a family that had just visited the house because the boy had read Treasure Island and was curious to know more. Visitors come from all over the world, with a large contingent from Japan, where Stevenson's poems have all been translated. What they see is some of the strange, eclectic paraphernalia of the writer's life right up to his death in Samoa at the age of 44. There is the Buddha that sat on his desk as he worked; his elegant cigarette case - he was an inveterate smoker who would have been ostracised in California today; a head-hunter's knife. His bedroom in the boarding-house, or the room that seems likeliest to have been his, has in it the bed from his house in Bournemouth, with his velvet jacket lying in ghostly fashion upon it.

When Stevenson arrived in Monterey, the population there was "about that of a dissenting chapel on a wet Sunday in a strong church neighbourhood." Now Monterey flourishes, a wealthy, knick-knackered, tourist enclave with its own Path of History and jazz festival. Stevenson used to take his midday meal at a little French restaurant where he was the only Briton in a cosmopolitan crew.

The British presence there today is most obvious in two pubs, the Mucky Duck and the Britannia in Alvarado Street, where Stevenson collected his mail from the post office, and both are decorated with fox-hunting prints and copper plates.

In the Mucky Duck, some Englishmen with adopted American accents were telling each other a joke: "What's the definition of a loser? When you meet a nymphomaniac and she tells you she just wants to be friends." It had been a long day: I could think of another definition of a loser and started to feel as snooty as Stevenson did towards the Cockney immigrants he encountered on his journey. There was something deeply depressing about all this faux Englishness, the signs with "Keep your hands off the barmaid" and the retro poster of Bournemouth, which I am sure was not on the wall because Stevenson had once lived there.

In the Britannia later, ordering a McEwans Export in RLS's honour, I was told "You've made a good choice there" by the bleached blond young man who served me. His accent was a hybrid, Clyde lapping the Pacific, and it turned out that he was from Glasgow and "when I'm with my mum" his accent returned home, too. Yes, Stevenson still brought the tourists in, he said, as an Arsenal game flickered on the box, and his own girlfriend was a pupil at the local Robert Louis Stevenson school. There was a bottle of Treasure Island malt vinegar to put on my French fries.

The RL Stevenson school is private, founded in 1952 by a Stevenson admirer and scholar and known locally as the "Bob Louie". The director of alumni, Frank Stephenson, invited me to lunch in the Louie Louie cafe. The student literary magazine is called Vailima, after Stevenson's home in Samoa, and the student paper Tusitala, is the teller of tales name given to Stevenson there. The writer also provided the school prayer: "Lord - give us the strength to encounter that which is to come, that we may be brave in peril, constant in tribulation, temperate in wrath and in all change of fortune, and, down to the gates of death, loyal and loving to one another." The pupils sat on the lawns in the sun, one strumming a guitar.

Nearby is the Spyglass Hill golf course at Pebble Beach. Stevenson wrote in Treasure Island of the moon as something "broad and silvery" moving by the summit of Spyglass Hill, but the only broad and silvery things about the area these days are the golfers. RLS might have enjoyed the idea of people paying $225 a round so that they can tee off from a hole called Blind Pew. Stevenson made some slim pickings writing for the local, long-defunct Monterey Californian. "The United States Mint can coin many million more dollar pieces but not make a single Indian," he wrote. "No man's word can save the Indian from the fate that awaits them."

In San Francisco, where Stevenson eventually married Fanny in 1880, there are still traces of his adventurous life. There is a plaque by his old lodgings on Bush Street, now a barber shop with a pile of Playboys for waiting customers. The cafe where he took his morn ing coffees is long gone, but he could have his espresso at Uncle Vito's or tiger prawns Polynesian at Cafe Mozart at the same corner. The place where he and Fanny wed has been subsumed into the Zingari Italian restaurant.

The manager there, a Russian who had read Treasure Island in his youth, was anxious that I should try their menu ($85 for a wine extravaganza dinner). The RLS memorial is in Portsmouth Plaza, Chinatown and carries words from Stevenson's Christmas sermon, with his advice about friendship and honesty: "To be honest, to be kind - to earn a little more, to spend a little less - to make, upon the whole, a family happier for his presence - to renounce when that shall be necessary and not be embittered _ Here is a task for all that a man has of fortitude and delicacy."

What a rich city San Francisco, in the middle of the dot.com boom, would be for the man who wrote about "the millionaire vulgarians of the Big Bonanza".

One of his great concerns was capital punishment which he opposed, most tellingly in his novel, Weir of Hermiston. What would he have made of the execution of a Native American in California only last month, an execution finally carried out after the man had been refused permission to take part in a traditional sweat lodge ceremony in the prison grounds, a decision against which he appealed. On the day I was in San Francisco, the court of appeal reversed the decision. Too bad he had already been executed.

There are other landmarks of Stevenson's life in California. In Calistoga, north of San Francisco, he used a telephone for the first time. "So it goes in these young countries," he wrote. "Telephones, and telegraphs, and newspapers, and advertisements running far ahead among the Indians and the grizzly bears." God, what would he have made of the mobile phones in Silicon Valley? Californian wine was still "at the experimental stage" but Stevenson was spot on in predicting 120 years ago that "the smack of the Californian palate shall linger on the palate of your grandson".

The Everyman edition of The Silverado Squatters and Travels with a Donkey suggests that Stevenson was a "precursor of Jack Kerouac and Bruce Chatwin". He certainly reflected on the nature of nationality and travel. "The happiest lot on earth is to be born a Scotchman. You must pay for it in many ways as for all other advantages on earth _ the lights of home shine softer on the rainy street; the very names endeared in verse and music cling nearer round our heart. It is at least a curious thing_ that the races which wander widest, Jews and Scotch, should be the most clannish in the world. But perhaps these two are cause and effect: 'for ye were strangers in the land of Egypt'. "

And he could conjure up the strange emotions of travel that give the same frisson more than a century later. "There is wonderful callousness in human nature which enables us to live. I had no feeling one way or the other from New York to California until at Dutch Flat, a mining camp in the Sierra, I heard a cock crowing with a home voice; and then I fell to hope and regret both in the same moment."

It is often, too often, said that if Shakespeare were alive today, he would be working in Hollywood. Since most of his work has already been turned into film, he would more likely be counting his royalty cheques in Colorado. Stevenson seems better equipped for the film business. Bertolt Brecht, in his 1925 Notes on Stevenson, observ-ed that "with Stevenson events are quite clearly visually ordered". It would have been Stevenson for whom producers would have sent the limos, begging him to come up with another Dr J or a cracking action idea like Kidnapped.

Returning from his American journey in 1880, Stevenson entranced fellow-passengers on the boat across the Atlantic with his tales. One of them, James Cunningham, recalled that "to the accompaniment of endless cigarettes, or sometimes it might be a perilous cocktail which he compounded with such zest from a San Francisco recipe, the stream of romantic and genial talk flowed on."

Whether as a screenwriter with an adobe home in Twenty-Nine Palms, or as a commentator on all that is remarkable about California - the death penalty, the lingering separation of races, the casinos on the reservations, the wine industry - one trusts that Stevenson would have written with that same mixture of hope and regret, and "without capitulation" about the perilous cocktail of life.

fields.bodyText: There is the spiffy, Californian coastal golf course named after Spyglass Hill from Treasure Island, where each hole is called after a character from the book. There is the Louie Louie cafe in the Robert Louis Stevenson school at nearby Pebble Beach, full of busy, impossibly healthy-looking co-eds who will soon be de-constructing Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde in their English classes. And there is the galleon-topped monument in San Francisco's Chinatown, standing amid the skate-boarders and the elderly, dozing Chinamen, with its im- precation to the passer-by that he should "keep a few friends but these without capitulation; above all, on the same grim condition, (to) keep friends with himself". But in this 150th anniversary year of the birth of RL Stevenson, it is perhaps not the plaques and the place-names that resonate with the time he spent in the United States, but the still contemporary issues on which he focused: on race and the fate of the American Indian; on sudden wealth at times of boom and bonanza and its ability to destroy and divide; on immigration and capital punishment; and, not least, on the joys of Californian wine and the perplexing nature of the telephone. In 1879, Stevenson received a telegram in Edinburgh from Fanny Osbourne, the married American woman with whom he had fallen in love in France three years earlier. The telegram does not survive, but whatever it contained drove Stevenson to pack in haste, and within a week he was setting sail on the SS Devonia from Greenock. "I am in fair spirits but a little off my nut," he wrote from the ship. He can only have been a little further off his nut by the time he arrived in New York. It is reassuring to learn that, even then, Britons about to arrive in America were full of stories of the dreadful things that might befall them. "You would have thought we were to land upon a cannibal island," he wrote. "You must speak to no one in the streets, as they would not leave you till you were rooked and beaten." Today, the vocabulary has changed rooked to mugged, but the sentiment is much the same: these Americans are a wild and violent people, so don't catch their eye in the subway in New York or drive with rent-a-car plates in Florida or you'll come back in a box. It is equally reassuring to discover that, in a land where there is now an (expensive) cure for everything, Stevenson, suffering from a terrible itch, parted with some of his limited funds to purchase a blue pill, a powder and a little bottle of medicine. "He might as well have given me a cricket bat and a copy of Johnson's dictionary," wrote Stevenson of the pharmacist. There was more of the adventurer than the grumpy ex-pat in Stevenson and as he travelled by train across Nebraska, he could write: "The line of the railway stretched from horizon to horizon, like a cue across a billiard board; on either hand the green plain ran till it touched the skirts of heaven." What strikes the reader now is not so much the lyrical descriptions of the landscape, as the observations of his fellow-passengers whom he described in The Amateur Emigrant. Passengers on the train were split into three groups: the families, the single male immigrants and the Chinese. Stevenson wrote: "Of all stupid ill-feeling, the sentiment of my fellow-Caucasians towards our companions in the Chinese car was the most stupid and the worst _Their forefathers watched the stars before mine had begun to keep pigs." In particular, the prevailing attitude to the American Indians struck Stevenson: "If oppression drives a wise man mad, what should be raging in the heart of these poor tribes, who have been driven back and back, step after step, their promised reservations torn from them one after another as the States extend westward, until at length they are shut up into these hideous mountain deserts of the centre." He saw Indian families at way-stations on the journey west much as you might today at some glum Greyhound station: "The silent stoicism of their conduct, and the pathetic degradation of their appearance, would have touched any thinking creature, but my fellow-passengers danced round them with a truly Cockney baseness. I was ashamed of the thing we call civilisation." He was bound for Monterey in California, arriving there somewhat to Fanny's embarrassed surprise, since she was still married and uncertain how to proceed. Stevenson, unable to stay with her because of the conventions of the time, slipped away into the nearby Carmel hills where, always a sickly man, he lapsed into a delirium. He was rescued, as Frank McLynn tells it in his biography, by a bear hunter called Captain Smith and an Indian called Tom, who treated him with frontier remedies until he recovered. He returned to a boarding house in Monterey - now Stevenson House, preserved with many of his artefacts on display. As an author with a local connection, he is somewhat overshadowed by John Steinbeck, since the original Cannery Row is in the town; but perhaps Stevenson would not envy him the tourist spin-offs and the Steinbeck Country insignias. Steinbeck paid gentle homage to Stevenson in his short story, How Edith McGillcuddy Met RLS. I had always had a sneaking, vicarious attachment to Stevenson: we grew up in the same part of Edinburgh, went to the same school, studied in the same law faculty at the same university, edited the same student paper and hot-tailed it in our twenties to California. (Only one of us, at the last count, had become a world-renowned writer.) And so time to retrace a few of his footsteps, to Monterey and that French-Swiss boarding-house where he waited for Fanny to extricate herself finally from her husband, Sam. The house itself is in beautiful condition, the datura and rhododendron in full bloom in the garden, and Stevenson could not have asked for a more devoted carrier of the flame than Monica Hudson, the Swiss woman who is the local RLS expert, co-founder of the new society there in his honour and one of the guides to the house. "There is a lot of interest still," said Hudson, pointing out a family that had just visited the house because the boy had read Treasure Island and was curious to know more. Visitors come from all over the world, with a large contingent from Japan, where Stevenson's poems have all been translated. What they see is some of the strange, eclectic paraphernalia of the writer's life right up to his death in Samoa at the age of 44. There is the Buddha that sat on his desk as he worked; his elegant cigarette case - he was an inveterate smoker who would have been ostracised in California today; a head-hunter's knife. His bedroom in the boarding-house, or the room that seems likeliest to have been his, has in it the bed from his house in Bournemouth, with his velvet jacket lying in ghostly fashion upon it. When Stevenson arrived in Monterey, the population there was "about that of a dissenting chapel on a wet Sunday in a strong church neighbourhood." Now Monterey flourishes, a wealthy, knick-knackered, tourist enclave with its own Path of History and jazz festival. Stevenson used to take his midday meal at a little French restaurant where he was the only Briton in a cosmopolitan crew. The British presence there today is most obvious in two pubs, the Mucky Duck and the Britannia in Alvarado Street, where Stevenson collected his mail from the post office, and both are decorated with fox-hunting prints and copper plates. In the Mucky Duck, some Englishmen with adopted American accents were telling each other a joke: "What's the definition of a loser? It had been a long day: I could think of another definition of a loser and started to feel as snooty as Stevenson did towards the Cockney immigrants he encountered on his journey. fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck hails Somerfield, the master of absurd prices
fields.body:
Drinking an incredibly raunchy, organic Australian cabernet sauvignon/petit verdot - Temple Bruer 1998, 17 points out of 20, £9.99 at Asda when it appears in mid-May - with friends the other night, I noted a degree of animated discontent at the male end of the table (evening feeds at our house always seem to divide along these gender lines: don't ask me why).

One particular old fart called out, 'Don't you ever serve claret in this house, Malcolm?' and I responded that I had a bottle of Château Gruaud-Larose 1978, which I intended to serve with the cheese. The old fart's face lit up like a stop light. However, he was soon back swigging the Aussie after a glass of the claret, and when I tasted the latter it was apparent why. It was so darned dull; etiolated compared with the Temple Bruer.

I was disappointed, too (rating it barely 10 points), since it is one of the few single bottles of wine you can buy at Waitrose that the store will deliver anywhere in the country for free. This is because the wine costs £78, and that's £3 more than the minimum carriage order. Seventy-eight pounds? It beggars belief. More interesting, however, was how tactile and eruptive the Aussie was compared with the Gruaud-Larose, a so-called . . . um . . . 'second growth' Saint-Julien (sorry to laugh, but these blighters take matters such as perceived status so damned solemnly), which is also predominantly cabernet sauvignon, with some petit verdot along with merlot and cabernet franc. What does this prove? Don't eat at my place, if you take wine, or yourself, too seriously.

A wine calling itself Errazuriz, which derives from the Basque word for the matador bird of Patagonia that dives at bulls' hairy bits to snatch insects, cannot be expected to be taken seriously. Yet when I served two Errazuriz wines at another romp recently, both went down so well that guests contested at the end of the evening to take away the empties so they could remember the names. They were Errazuriz Sauvignon Blanc 1999 (£5.49) and Errazuriz Merlot 1999 (£5.99), and both are from Chile. The sauvignon is an elegantly mineralised specimen, showing compressed gooseberry, under-ripe apple fruit and a finish of some finesse. It is a sublime sauvignon with which no Sancerre is comparable. The merlot is composed of crushed blackcurrants and soft, silky leather. It's effortlessly rich and flowing. A remarkably eloquent wine, it falters only if the food is too pungent, but with risotto it was marvellous. Each wine rates 17 points, and you can buy them at Oddbins, Thresher, Bottoms Up, Wine Rack and Victoria Wine.

Oddbins, as it happens, has a terrific pair of Chilean reds. La Palmeria Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (16 points, £3.99) has that ineffable Chilean richness and smoothly textured finish, and, at the price, there can be very very few cabernets ahead of it. La Palmeria Merlot 1999 (16 points, around £4.50-£5.00, and also available at Unwins) is chutzpah vinified, being rich, aromatic and subtly spicy - and all this gushes from the bottle the second the cork is pulled. The eager, leathery, soft fruit is ripe yet not inelegant, in spite of the cheek of its immediacy. Neither is it so forward that the whole construct fails to be deeply and rewardingly palate-provoking. Earthier, and with great character and bite, is Chteau Depaule Cabardes 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99, Oddbins), from the Midi. It parades tobacco, coffee, plums - plus texture - and it has an exciting tension between the fruit and the acidity. A bold, complex wine at a fairly absurd price.

Somerfield is the master of absurd prices, and Santa Julia Sangiovese 1999 (15.5 points, £3.99), from Argentina, is a splendid example. It is a wonderful paradox of dryness and richness, vivacious, plummy fruitiness yet not vulgarity. Somerfield is also offering, until April 25, Gouts et Couleurs Chardonnay/Viognier 1998, from the south of France, for £3.49. It is deliciously apricot- and melon-scented and fruited, and it rates 15.5 points. The woman in the queue ahead of you with her trolley stacked to the top with this wine, by the way, will be my wife.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Cut to the chase: knife care
fields.trailText: Cut to the chase: knife care
fields.body:
The subject
Basic maintenance of your most important kitchen tools. Protection of your fingers.

The basics
At its thinnest point, the cutting edge of a well-sharpened knife measures a few molecules across. In other words, it's a fragile thing. It makes cutting easier and safer than a dull knife. This is why you have to protect your knives zealously, anally, fanatically. See if you can spot yourself in any of these knife-criminal profiles. Storage: you keep your knives in a drawer. Kitchen practice: you can't find the tin opener, so you use a knife instead; can't find a chopping board, so you use anything. Sharpening: what's that? If you recognise yourself on any count, check into rehab.

The details
Therapy 1, storage. Easy. Knives should be stored in something that protects their precious molecules of cutting prowess from anything that might ding or dull them. Such as: a knife block, where each knife sits safe in its own slot. But blocks = counter-clutter. That's why The Knowledge prefers wall-mounted, magnetic knife racks. Out of the way, but easily accessible.

Therapy 2, kitchen practice. Also easy. Use a wood or polypropylene board for chopping. Not the counter. Not a plate. Not the sink. Nothing. Zero. Good.

Therapy 3, sharpening, is not so easy - except with a Chantry Knife-Sharpener, widely available at around £20, which takes all the guesswork and all the anxiety and all the skill out of sharpening. If you like a challenge, however, buy a whetstone (best sharpener in town) or diamond-coated steel (second best) and learn how to use them from a butcher or fishmonger. And remember: the possessor of knife knowledge sharpens little but often, rather than rarely and brutally.

Where to buy
Any kitchen shop or department store.

The easy way out
Don't cook.

fields.headline: Make mine a...
fields.standfirst: Gordon's
fields.trailText: Gordon's
fields.body: Britain's oldest gin, still made to the same (deeply secret) recipe as when it was first produced by Alexander Gordon in 1769. Gordon's is huge. Mega, in fact: 6.9 million people drink it, which gives it a colossal 40% share of the UK gin market. Which doesn't necessarily mean it's Britain's best gin - gin connoisseurs have been a bit sniffy since the strength was cut to 37.5%. They may have a point: in many overseas markets, it's sold at 40%, or 43%, while duty-free is a whopping 47.3%. But that doesn't make it all bad. It's not the best gin for a Martini, say, but it makes a classic G&T, which is how 85% of its drinkers prefer it. Gordon's make great play of the refreshing quality of the brand, which owes its character to a high percentage of matured juniper berries (most gin manufacturers don't mature their juniper, apparently). The quintessential Gordon's drinkers are Jerry and Margot from TV's The Good Life - nice bit of real estate, plan their TV viewing a week in advance. Except in Greece, where Gordon's drinkers are wild and funky.

fields.headline: The Net Addict
fields.trailText: The Catholic Encyclopedia
fields.body:
Baggio, my personal trainer, is in a bad way. He invested in lastminute.com and then Arnie, his lover, left him (these events are unconnected). 'Do you think true love exists?' he asked anxiously while I was knotted into a figure of eight in a half-yoga, half-Pilates position he's devised to tighten my buttocks, so it took me a while to find the answer. 'Yes, I do,' I said assertively, 'look at the screen. There are 78 sites for "true love", but only a handful for Jonathan Aitken. Truth always wins.'

While Baggio was packing the exercise mat and the dumb-bells, I printed the St Thomas Aquinas text on love from the Catholic Encyclopaedia, and off he went in search of peace and self-knowledge.

As soon as he left, I rushed to the pearl among the 78 results: www.2ofakind.com ('100,000 profiles, two-way screening, match analysis, anonymous email, free-registration!').

They really are pretty thorough in their questionnaire, and I got into the spirit, but I hope I didn't blow my chances when I entered 'high sperm count required' in the box marked Additional Information. It's just that Mum is not having an easy time in Assisted Hatching, and we all know about the dangers of tap water, the pill, etc. It can't be that difficult to find a kind, but strong, good-looking man under 35 who earns high six-figures, is fertile, works out, and reads Alain de Botton. I'll let you know about any replies. Among the many e-mails I've received, I've been intrigued by the persistence of Alex from www.leapingsalmon.com:

'we deliver nationwide all the fresh ingredients you need, chopped and ready, to cook your own gourmet meal. No hassle - just fun.' I haven't tried them, but I'm all for fun and big pink things leaping about after dinner (or even before).

fields.headline: Eating out
fields.standfirst: The New End marks a new beginning for Hampstead's diners, says Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: The New End marks a new beginning for Hampstead's diners, says Matthew Fort
fields.body:
In my beginning is my end. In succession/Houses rise and fall, crumble, are extended,/Are removed, destroyed, restored, or in their place," and so on and so on and so on. East Coker, TS Eliot, just in case you can't put a title to a quote (I checked up on it in an idle moment). I never quite worked out what the old boy was on about, but it stuck in my mind; and, when you come across a restaurant with a name like the New End, it seems appropriate to drag it out and dust it off. Not that there's much about food in the Eliot canon. Had his mind set on higher things, I expect.

Still, there is an almost Eliot-ish, New England restraint about the design of the New End and its menu. In fact, I want to say a word about the design of the menu and the bill, because both seemed to me original and pleasing examples of these much abused art-forms. The bill, in particular, was a model of clarity, with each item consumed plainly set out, the quantity, the unit price and the total for each all in a neat line and underlined. It was easy to read, easy to understand, and made paying £102.05 at the end of the session a remarkably painless business. Someone at the New End has thought through the bill business very thoroughly, and other restaurants would do well to follow suit.

The menu was of a piece with the bill. The shell, as it were, is middleweight white card with a setting of cutlery elegantly embossed on it, and a block of subdued colour to draw your eye to the name in the bottom-right-hand corner. Inside is stuck the bill of fare, neatly and clearly laid out, with a total absence of menu poetry to irritate the sensibilities. Oxtail raviolo, lentil and cabbage - £7.50, read the menu; dressed hand-picked crab, artichokes and gazpacho - £9; roast loin of lamb, turnip confit, gnocchi and coriander - £15; baked fillet of brill, fennel, green olive and brown shrimps - £15. Short, to the point, and inspiring confidence. Actually, it inspired a bit more than that in Bunbury and I. Greed and high expectation, to be exact.

The expectation was not only generated by the nature of the dishes. There was enough originality about the proposed combinations to indicate the presence of properly developed culinary personality in the kitchen, and so there is - Tom Ilic, late of Searcy's at London's Barbican. From experience, I know that he knows how to deliver oompahpah flavours and how to balance them with trills of wit and imagination.

Take my first course, smoked haddock tortellini. It was delicate, light and fastidious. The pasta had the texture of suede. The smoked fish inside produced a solid impact, while the frothed-up sauce, made with the poaching liquid, was like a shadow of the fish itself. Buttered leeks added a minor-key earthy sweetness to the dish.

Bunbury's oxtail raviolo was up there on the rostrum alongside the tortellini: a single, great, fat bolster of sweetly succulent oxtail. The pasta had a slightly softer texture than mine, and was suited to the dish. The sauce was a beautifully-judged reduction of cooking liquids, which carried the flavours with limpid brilliance. The grainy lentils and soft cabbage added their own notes of contrast.

Bunbury was not so ecstatic about his main course, scallops with black-pudding crepinettes and asparagus. It wasn't the individual elements of the dish that put him off. Indeed, there was a lot to admire in the technical precision and finesse with which they were cooked. No, it was the fashion for combining scallops and black pudding, a notion that, if memory serves me, was slipped into the culinary mainstream by Bruno Loubet. There is something about the feel of the thing, and the clashing styles of sweetness.

But I was as chirpy as a flea with my veal cutlet with goat's cheese, anchovy and almond fondue. The fondue was contained inside an onion that sat on top of a small castle of veal slices. As I stuck my knife and fork into it, the contents gushed down over the meat, coating it with a refined richness. Oh me, oh my: it was nothing short of sensational.

Of course, we had puddings. What did you think? Poached rhubarb with ginger and lemongrass pannacotta in my case, and spiced pear tarte tatin with cinnamon ice cream for Bunbury. They were like the dishes that went before: individual affairs, with finely-defined flavours; civilised, cultured, assured. There aren't too many chefs cooking better than Tom Ilic in London at present.

As I said earlier, this all came to £102.05. From the bill, I have no problem in working out that, in the interests of science, we drank a bottle of ring-a-ding Altydgedacht Sauvignon Blanc from South Africa (£16.50) and a bottle of yo-heave-ho Yering Station Pinot Noir (£21), a litre of mineral water (£3.25) and a double espresso (£2.50). From this, I can work out that the food cost us £58.80, and that is not a lot for cooking of this quality.

Hampstead does not have a happy history of supporting quality restaurants. The New End was bustling on the night we went, and any restaurant that can play host to Bob Hoskins and Michael Lynagh on the same night, while welcoming Ken Livingstone the night before, must have a chance of flourishing. In The New End is a beginning, as you might say.

fields.headline: Ex-ham time
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: William woke up screaming in the night... I managed to glean that his nightmare included David Blunkett's guide dog and the gay Teletubbie. I didn't press him for details.
fields.body:
Monday, April 10, 2000, Arthur Askey Way

William woke up screaming in the night. He'd been having a nightmare about the exams he will be taking when he is seven. He was mostly incoherent, but I managed to glean that his nightmare included David Blunkett's guide dog and the gay Teletubbie. I didn't press him for details.

Pamela hasn't rung me since our weekend with her parents. I fear that beside the hirsute masculinity of her father I appear a poor specimen. My expert knowledge of the early poetry of Philip Larkin cannot compete with Porky Pigg's ability to roll a double kayak in white water. I could tell that my refusal to join Porky in his flimsy plastic boat sowed doubts in Pamela's mind.

Did some primeval instinct warn her that my spermatozoa and her eggs were incompatible and wouldn't add to the quality of the gene pool? Whatever - as they say on Jerry Springer - she was very quiet as we drove south and didn't offer her tongue when I kissed her goodnight. Ugh.

Tuesday, April 11

This morning, I handed William his usual carrier bag full of toilet rolls and squashed cereal packets and was amazed when he handed it straight back to me, saying, "We can't play at school any more, Dad, so don't collect 'em up."

At home time, I broke the rules and waited outside William's classroom. On looking through the glass panel in the door I saw that the children were sitting in rows being taught exam techniques by an "exam trainer". (Formerly known as a teaching assistant.) The weather chart and the nature table were nowhere to be seen. The hamster cage was empty.

There were various exhortations around the room. As I watched, the exam trainer wrote "Exams are good, play is bad" on the white board. The children dipped their pens in their inkwells and copied this slogan down. Since when has it been compulsory to write in ink? I fear that once again Mrs Parvez has misinterpreted education-department guidelines.

She won't be content until the children are wearing clogs.

Wednesday, April 12

I embarked on a new novel, Sty, today. Progress was slow. I only managed to write 104 words, including the title and my name.

Sty, by Adrian Mole.

The pig grunted in its sty. It was deeply sad. Somehow it felt different from the other pigs with which it shared a home.

"Look at them," thought the pig. "They are oblivious to the fact that they are merely part of the food chain." The pig had felt discontented since it had glimpsed Alain de Botton's TV programme, Philosophy: A Guide to Life, through a gap in the pig farmer's curtain. The wisdom of Socrates, Epicurus and Montaigne had brought home to the pigs that it was completely uneducated and knew nothing of the world beyond the sty.

Notes on new novel
1. Should the pig have a name?
2. Should the pig's thoughts be in quotes?
3. Has the story got legs? Or is the main protagonist (the pig) too restricting a character, ie, being (a) unable to communicate with the other pigs and (b) never leaving the sty?

Sunday, April 16

Pamela Pigg has just left this house after flying into a rage and accusing me of stealing her life and turning it into "fifth-rate art". She read my manuscript of Sty which I had foolishly left on the kitchen table under a copy of Men's Health. As she ran to her car, I shouted, "I'm an artist, we must forage where we can for our materials."

Pamela shouted back, "I'm a housing officer. We must cancel the artist's move to a maisonette as promised." I went inside and read page 124 of Men's Health - bed-busting sex, for my art, of course.

fields.headline: How to be safe
fields.trailText: It's a dangerous world out there and safety should be our number one priority. Always take a few moments to familiarise yourself with the nearest emergency exits, even when you are travelling by bicycle.
fields.body:
It's a dangerous world out there and safety should be our number one priority. Always take a few moments to familiarise yourself with the nearest emergency exits, even when you are travelling by bicycle.

Nature is a born killer - ice, floods and volcanoes are a continual threat. Even a stiff wind can dessicate you like a coconut. These risks can be much reduced by telling people where you're going and wearing a reflective band.

Stalkers are another modern danger. The person on the other side of this newspaper could have been following you around for years, going through your laundry and opening your letters (okay, they may be married to you, but that's just a good cover).

Driving is incredibly dangerous, as almost all deaths on the road involve a car. If you insist on driving, pre-inflate all airbags, wear a cycle helmet and drive defensively, preferably on the pavement. Whether you have a baby on board or not, have a sticker in the back window as these can substantially reduce the impact of being rear-ended by a 40-ton truck.

In safety terms, it is obviously extremely foolhardy to live on, or anywhere near, the edge. Life is a like a platform - if you get too close to the edge you're likely to be hit by someone opening their door. Stand well behind the yellow line of life, or preferably in the designated waiting area.

Ideally, wear a cycle helmet and adopt a brace position. Normally, you'd be better off staying at home were it not for the fact that most deaths occur in the home. Remember that water and electricity don't mix, so turn off the lights when you're in the bath and don't buy electricity from your water company. Wear a cycle helmet in the bath.

The average garden shed is chock full of instruments of death. If you buy a lawnmower, insist on airbags, roll-bars and side-impact protection. When mowing, wear a cycle helmet.

All domestic animals are stiff with rabies, tetanus and lasser fever. Keep them under observation for six months before letting them into the house. Remember, too, that animals are essentially savage, and in the wild a hamster is an attack animal. Before petting, wear a chain mail/biological warfare suit.

One of the main risks to life these days is death. By taking a few sensible precautions, this unnecessary risk can be avoided; check the nearest available exits, wear a cycle helmet, and assume the brace position.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: Shooting pains
fields.standfirst: 'I always vowed I wouldn't turn into a cantankerous old sod, and now I have'
fields.trailText: 'I always vowed I wouldn't turn into a cantankerous old sod, and now I have'
fields.body:
Still reeling from Elaine's bombshell: that, while still married to me, Spouse had affairs with Sally the 17th-century historian and Elly the bisexual. Determined to confront him immediately, but privacy rarely available in this house. Distracted from what ought to be my main task today: to think of ways of earning money via the internet.

"I do love Dad," Harriet confesses to me, with diabolical timing. "He tries his best, bless him!"

"Yes," I concede with a sigh. "He's only human." I do not want Henry and Harriet to hear me shout, "You Treacherous Philandering Bastard!" There should be a number you could dial to shout at a surrogate bastard instead. Wonder if this is a delirious fantasy or a sound business idea.

His adoring aunt is the next one to show concern for the bastard. "Dulcie! I'm a wee bit worrrried about Gorrrdon - these shooting pains in his chest." I suppose if we lived in Tennessee, I would have shot him long ago. Reassure aunt that shooting pains only indicate a wayward nerve. When he comes in asking for tea and feeling better, she looks so relieved and fond, I almost wish I was his aunt, too. Then his infidelities would just be picturesque peccadilloes. Perhaps I am just punishing myself by chewing over an ex-Spouse's ex-peccadilloes. I expect I should just spit out the bitterness and forget it, like a dodgy Brazil nut.

"Mum?" enquires Henry. "Did you, like, wash my rugby kit, or not?"

"No, I did not!" I scream with sudden fury. "You can wash your own clothes in future! You never put them in the washing basket! You just chuck them in a corner! Well, I'm not going to pick up anybody's dirty clothes off the floor again!"

Aunt Elspeth looks panicky. I have raised my voice. But she's escaped lightly. There's a lot dirtier linen I could have ranted about. Henry is startled into silence by this unmerited venom and everybody looks at me with distaste. If only I could retreat from the hurly-burly of family life and establish a virtual nunnery for wronged ex-wives seeking enlightenment. I would gladly devote hours to illuminating the letter S, but instead I must clean the windows, which I suddenly notice have become opaque with filth. Seizing the cleaning materials, I storm out. Everyone looks relieved at my exit.

Pause to admire the plants in my little front garden, which I have begun to cherish. Then start removing the grime of decades from the windows. If only one could introduce clarity as easily into one's personal relationships. My family thinks I am a bad-tempered old bitch suffering from post-menopausal tension. In fact, I am a paragon of tactful reticence.

Step back to admire my sparkling windows and realise what they need is a final buffing-up with loo roll. Run indoors and fetch some, then rub away until complete clarity is achieved, accompanied by almost Franciscan sense of order marred only by unpleasant smell. Suddenly realise that, some time earlier, I must have stepped in dogshit, and upon investigating further, discover I have trodden it in all across the hall, up the stairs and into the bathroom. Instead of incense- scented meditation, I crouch over the loo, scrubbing my shoe with an old toothbrush and cursing lavishly.

I always vowed I wouldn't turn into a cantankerous old sod obsessed with dogshit, and now I have. But it's the unspeakable poisons clinging to the sole of your soul that really drive you bonkers. You should be able to vent your bile on the internet by recording, for posterity, your husband's misdemeanours. The Wronged Woman's Webshite.

Spend the next half-hour vacuuming and scrubbing the violated carpet, which luckily is already dark brown. Harriet screws up her nose fastidiously.

"Oh Mum!" she exclaims. "You are really, like, gross!"

Protest that it was someone else's dog, not I, who is responsible for the offence. And, by gum, if I ever find out who it was, I'll go round to their house after dark and crap on their geraniums.

Ex-Spouse watches me as if from a high shelf, with faint, condescending amusement. He thinks this is just fate teaching me a lesson for my unreasonable outburst earlier. He'll laugh on the other side of his face when his own personal ordure hits the fan.

Then his infidelities would just be picturesque peccadilloes. Perhaps I am just punishing myself by chewing over an ex-Spouse's ex-peccadilloes. I expect I should just spit out the bitterness and forget it, like a dodgy Brazil nut. "Mum?" enquires Henry. "Did you, like, wash my rugby kit, or not?" "No, I did not!" I scream with sudden fury. "You can wash your own clothes in future! You never put them in the washing basket! You just chuck them in a corner! Well, I'm not going to pick up anybody's dirty clothes off the floor again!" Aunt Elspeth looks panicky. I have raised my voice. But she's escaped lightly. There's a lot dirtier linen I could have ranted about. Henry is startled into silence by this unmerited venom and everybody looks at me with distaste. If only I could retreat from the hurly-burly of family life and establish a virtual nunnery for wronged ex-wives seeking enlightenment. I would gladly devote hours to illuminating the letter S, but instead I must clean the windows, which I suddenly notice have become opaque with filth. Seizing the cleaning materials, I storm out. Everyone looks relieved at my exit. Pause to admire the plants in my little front garden, which I have begun to cherish. Then start removing the grime of decades from the windows. If only one could introduce clarity as easily into one's personal relationships. My family thinks I am a bad-tempered old bitch suffering from post-menopausal tension. In fact, I am a paragon of tactful reticence. Step back to admire my sparkling windows and realise what they need is a final buffing-up with loo roll. Run indoors and fetch some, then rub away until complete clarity is achieved, accompanied by almost Franciscan sense of order marred only by unpleasant smell. Suddenly realise that, some time earlier, I must have stepped in dogshit, and upon investigating further, discover I have trodden it in all across the hall, up the stairs and into the bathroom. Instead of incense- scented meditation, I crouch over the loo, scrubbing my shoe with an old toothbrush and cursing lavishly. I always vowed I wouldn't turn into a cantankerous old sod obsessed with dogshit, and now I have. But it's the unspeakable poisons clinging to the sole of your soul that really drive you bonkers. You should be able to vent your bile on the internet by recording, for posterity, your husband's misdemeanours. The Wronged Woman's Webshite. Spend the next half-hour vacuuming and scrubbing the violated carpet, which luckily is already dark brown. Harriet screws up her nose fastidiously. "Oh Mum!" she exclaims. "You are really, like, gross!" Protest that it was someone else's dog, not I, who is responsible for the offence. And, by gum, if I ever find out who it was, I'll go round to their house after dark and crap on their geraniums. Ex-Spouse watches me as if from a high shelf, with faint, condescending amusement. He thinks this is just fate teaching me a lesson for my unreasonable outburst earlier. He'll laugh on the other side of his face when his own personal ordure hits the fan.

fields.headline: Colour of memory
fields.standfirst: Now the last of the frosts are behind us, fingers crossed, perennials are coming into their own. By Christopher Lloyd
fields.trailText: Now the last of the frosts are behind us, fingers crossed, perennials are coming into their own. By Christopher Lloyd
fields.body:
Early magnolias gave a wonderful account of themselves last month, but - as also applies significantly to camellias and rhododendrons - their display runs severe risks from frost. May flowerers are in a far stronger position, especially if their flowering is spread over so many weeks that frost damage at some point can be shrugged off by later-opening flower buds.

One of the most forgiving in this respect, and one of the most suitable for the smaller garden, is Magnolia liliflora 'Nigra'. It makes a compact bush to 2.5m. The flowers are elegantly elongated, rich reddish-purple on the outside and pale within. It flowers from a baby, but does not like lime. As branches come freely down to the ground, they are easily layered. Layering can be done at almost any season, but is easiest when there is not so much foliage that you cannot see what you are doing.

Even more brightly coloured is the classy magnolia 'Galaxy' (5m) in a vivid shade of deep pink. You will be thrilled by this. Although it grows quite tall, its rather narrow, upright habit means that it does not occupy an embarrassing amount of lateral space. It often starts flowering before the end of March.

The bay laurel, Laurus nobilis (3m), makes a delightful, many-stemmed shrub/tree if you can allow it the space (see Spadework, right). Bays are usually clipped, which is all right as far at it goes, but the habit of an unpruned - or not obviously pruned - specimen has an engaging freedom and ebullience, which is especially pleasing at this moment when covered with blossom. This is yellowish, though not a bit showy, but you notice its abundance and it releases the bay aroma on its surroundings with an added sweetness. Bees love it. If you have to clip a bay, it will be subject to attack by some nasties, including scale insects and aphids, but an unpruned tree generally remains trouble-free.

Three closely-related species of geranium come into their own now and will be flowering for the next two months. They all have in common distinctly fleshy leaf stalks. Geranium rubescens is the smallest of them, and looks like a giant-sized herb robert ( G. robertianum ), which is a more or less welcome garden weed. G. rubescens (0.5m) is a self-seeding biennial, making handsome rosettes in winter with crimson leaf stalks. It has showy, pink flowers from now on, and we like it so much that it is quite a feature through some of our borders, although if not watched, it is a little inclined to overwhelm its neighbours. It is absolutely hardy.

The much larger-growing G. palmatum , on the other hand, is hardy only in a sunny, sheltered spot, but that, too, will self-sow. It makes a bulky plant, with a dense rosette of bright green, nicely dissected foliage, which nurses a widely spraying inflorescence (1m) of mauvy-pink flowers. This geranium does not develop a woody stem, which distinguishes it from another Madeiran species with which it is often confused, G. maderense . This latter is by far the largest-growing of all the cranesbills, and makes a very imposing rosette of deeply divided leaves, for which alone it is worth growing. For most of us, however, this needs to be under glass, unless we live right on a frost-free coast, as in the Ventnor Botanic Garden in the Isle of Wight, where there is a gorgeous self-sowing, self-perpetuating colony.

To flower (after which it seeds and dies), G. maderense needs plenty of root space, as in a very large container or planted out in a greenhouse bed. Alternatively, heavy feeding will do the trick, but remember that most of its growing is in winter, which is the season when we withold added nutrients from most of our plants. Not in this case. Flowering is dramatic, with a mass of light-magenta blossom, but by then the foliage is beginning to die off. Give it a run, and remember that if it disappoints, the fault is yours, not the plant's.

Among the perennials whose striking foliage looks its best in spring are members of the genus Ferula . They are the giant fennels, but must not be confused with the strongly aniseed-smelling fennel ( Foeniculum ) that we use in cooking and that will seed itself tenaciously all over the garden unless we watch out. Ferula does nothing like that. It can be grown from your own-saved seed after it has had a flowering. It does not flower every year, but here again matters can be greatly improved and speeded up by growing your giant fennels in rather good soil. Most of those available in this country are pretty hardy.

F. communis makes a few enormous leaves, but they are so finely and intricately divided that you would scarcely suspect that all that wonderful confection of fresh green mounds could come from perhaps only three or four leaves. If the plant does decide to flower, it will rapidly send a stem up to 3m, with branching platforms of yellow, parsnip-like flowers. Everything dies away from midsummer, and you can plant close to it with an annual.

There are glaucous-leaved types, and a bright green one with larger, shining leaflets, F. tingitana 'Cedric Morris' (2m), which flowers regularly and is showy.

The evergreen Fatsia japonica is just about the boldest-leaved shrub we can grow outdoors in Britain. It flowers in November, but its heads of ivy-like, black berries only ripen now. Collect the seed and sow it fresh, under glass. Even without heat, it will germinate in a few weeks and you can have a grove of fatsias in future years

fields.headline: Scale model
fields.standfirst: It is no coincidence that anchovy features in two of the most celebrated sauces of Italian cooking
fields.trailText: It is no coincidence that anchovy features in two of the most celebrated sauces of Italian cooking
fields.body:
The little silver dart of a fish - the genus Engraulis or, as it's more commonly known, the anchovy - is found in all manner of tiny, decorated tins and jars on supermarket and delicatessen shelves. Unlike the jarred variety, however, the tins - which are of roughly the same price - show nothing of their quality at all. While it is good news that these places stock such items at all, it is irritating in the extreme that what they have on offer, anchovy-wise, is generally the worst-tasting of that ilk. As with so many a choice ingredient, while the real thing is sublime, the cheapened variety inevitably turns out to be a grave disappointment.

Of course, top-notch ingredients are never cheap, but anchovies at their best are really very good - if price is a concern, remember that you need only a few fillets to pep up a salad or sauce, say. Preserved in salt, they keep splendidly in the fridge for some time. Those stored in oil, however, need swift consumption, irrespective of what the best-before date says.

So, what makes a "good" anchovy? These fish are found the world over, but it is the anchovy of the Mediterranean, Engraulis encrasicholus , that is the true anchovy, and which the locals know, love and use in huge quantities. Some are sold fresh in markets all along the Mediterranean coastline, to be eaten, just lightly grilled, with a little squeeze of lemon juice. But most are preserved, in one way or another.

Once, the anchovy was fished, filleted and layered in salt, then left for at least a month to cure in the vast amount of liquid it exudes during this process. Until recently, this was common practice, and had been so for a few thousand years - bought anchovies were always salted, and notable for the extraordinary brick-red colour they developed while salting. Nowadays, however, most anchovies are tinned - and therein lies a sorry tale. Compare the splendidly jolly, brightly-decorated tins of Spain with the dour packaging preferred by British companies, and you'll see who holds the anchovy closest to heart. (Unsurprisingly, the finest tinned anchovies I've ever eaten were Spanish.) As with salted, the only real visible proof of the quality of a tinned anchovy is its colour: embrace only plump, red fillets, and steer well clear of grey matter.

In the kitchen, the anchovy serves all manner of purposes. There are the great dishes that feature an abundance of these wonderful fish, and in a manner that is more akin to a homage to the little creatures - for example, the great Provençal pizza of onions and anchovy, the Pissaladière, so-called because of the crock, called a pissal , in which the anchovies were once cured; or anchoïade, a marvellous ointment made from anchovy, garlic and olive oil. Then, there are occasions in which they not are quite so prominent but nonetheless integral - in salsa verde, say, the heady, green sauce of anchovy, capers, garlic and olive oil that so perfectly accompanies poached fishes and meats; or in bagna cauda, the gorgeous anchovy, garlic and olive oil dipping sauce for vegetables. It is no coincidence that these are two of the most celebrated sauces in the cooking of Italy.

But, as mentioned above, the anchovy need not always be present in numbers. In fact, on many occasions, its very presence in a dish would go undetected were it not for the cook's ego, which just has to show off and explain the role of the anchovy in a dish's preparation as the first forkfuls are reaching the mouths of the hungry guests. The effect is all too often instantaneous: forks are returned, still laden, to plates and, several embarrassed coughs later, a chorus of high-pitched announcements rises up, claiming an inability to eat anchovies. Of course, it is sometimes wise to alert the unsuspecting diner that he or she is about to eat something that they genuinely abhor, but where anchovies are concerned, it is all too often not the fish itself that causes consternation, and rather the mouth-puckering sensation of eating something that tastes like a gobful of salt.

This may explain why many prefer cooking with anchovies that have been preserved in oil, believing them to be less salty than those preserved in, well, salt, and so more likely to allay any fears of assaulting a friend in such a way as to render their palate unconscious for days. But how many people, in these islands at least, have a lust for eating an anchovy straight from the tin? Very few, I'd hazard. Were you to use salted anchovy, on the other hand, you would need to taste the desalinated anchovy to ascertain what degree of salt remained within the fish, and whether further soaking were called for. A simple rule to follow is this: once infused within the structure of a dish, removal of anchovy is impossible; used wisely, however, and their removal is unnecessary.

All recipes serve six.

Sage and anchovy fritters

Aka involtini di salvia - inspired by the version in A Taste Of Tuscany, by Leslie Forbes.

Anchovy fillets

1 bunch fresh sage

Beaten egg

Flour, sifted and lightly seasoned

Taste the anchovies first, to check for saltiness - soak them in water for half-an-hour or so if they are too strong. Sandwich each anchovy fillet between two leaves of sage, thread a cocktail stick through to secure, then dip first in egg and then in flour. Lay the prepared bundles on a tray. Heat a fryer with clean, light oil and fry the involtini until they are puffed up and crisp. Serve immediately.

Montpellier butter

A great butter sauce that sits happily upon steamed or poached fish.

130g picked tarragon, flat-leaf parsley, chervil, chives, watercress and young spinach

30g shallots

3 small gherkins

2 tsp salted capers, well rinsed

2 small cloves garlic

6 anchovy fillets

1 raw egg yolk

3 hard-boiled egg yolks

125g unsalted butter, softened

90ml extra-virgin olive oil

The texture of this sauce when made in a pestle and mortar is sublime, but use a food processor by all means if you prefer an easier time. Put a pan of water on to boil. Wash all the herbs and spinach. Once the water is boiling, plunge in the leaves then remove after 30 seconds. Cool the leaves in iced water, and drain, squeezing out any excess of water.

Put all the ingredients, bar the olive oil, into a food processor or pestle, and whizz or grind away until the texture is smooth. Pour on the olive oil in a fine drizzle, and stir in. Pile the mix on to a sheet of cling-film, roll it into a tight sausage shape and refrigerate. The butter will keep for three or four days. To use, remove from the cling-film, cut into thin rounds and lay upon hot steamed or baked fish.

Ricotta and canapés

Aka crostini bianchi. If you can get it, use buffalo ricotta and salted anchovies to make these cheery pre-dinner snacks. The simple elegance of the pure, fresh flavours proves that the best ingredients treated with due respect make the best memories.

1 loaf crusty white bread

225g fresh ricotta

8 flat anchovy fillets

15g unsalted butter, softened

1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil

1 tbsp freshly-ground black pepper

Cut thin slices of bread, remove and discard the crusts, and cut the bread into 5-6cm squares or triangles (precision is unimportant here). Lay the pieces out on a tray and bake in a moderate oven until golden.

If the ricotta is moist, put it in a strainer to drain for half-an-hour or so. If using salted anchovies, rinse and divest them of bones first. (It's a good idea to desalinate a large batch, and layer any that you don't use in good olive oil, as they'll keep in the fridge for a week and make a perfect excuse to eat more anchovies.) Put the cheese, anchovies, butter, oil and pepper in a food processor, and chop to a creamy consistency. Transfer to a bowl and leave to sit for half-an-hour before spreading on the toast.

Tian of tuna and anchovy

2.5kg piece tuna loin

16-20 anchovy fillets

16-20 large lettuce leaves

1 medium-sized onion, thinly sliced

6 ripe tomatoes, thinly sliced

1 lemon

1 small sprig fresh thyme

1 small sprig fresh rosemary

2 handfuls picked sorrel

Sea salt and fresh black pepper

Olive oil

150ml white wine

Pre-heat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Choose a shallow dish that can be sealed easily and into which the tuna will fit snugly. Insert an anchony fillet between each ring of the tuna steak, spreading them out as evenly as possible.

Line the base of the tian with half the lettuce leaves. Lay half the onion and tomato on top. Peel and thinly slice the lemon, and lay half of it on the onion and tomato. Scatter a little thyme and rosemary over this. Wash and de-stalk the sorrel, shred the leaves, and place half on top of the lemon. Grind some black pepper over, sprinkle with a little sea salt, then dab with a few tablespoons of olive oil. Place the tuna on top, then repeat the layering backwards, up to and including the onion.

Wrap the remaining lettuce leaves around the tuna, enclosing it completely, and spoon over a little more oil. Pour the wine into the dish, and seal tightly with foil or a lid. Place in the heated oven and cook for an hour or so. This is at its best served just warm.

Abbacchio alla cacciatora

A celebrated Roman dish - month-old lamb pot-roasted with sage and rosemary, the flavours elevated by discreet quantities of anchovy and garlic.

1.4kg leg of top-quality spring lamb

25g lard

2 tbsp plain flour

1 sprig fresh rosemary

tsp chopped dried sage leaves

1 small clove garlic

8 tbsp red-wine vinegar

6 tbsp water

Sea salt

1 fully-charged pepper mill

4 large anchovy fillets

Remove the meat from the leg, and cut into 5-6cm cubes. Melt the lard over a medium flame in a heavy-bottomed pot. Put in enough lamb to cover the base of the pot, and brown thoroughly. Once browned, sift over a little flour and continue frying until the meat turns a rich, dark colour. Remove the browned meat, and repeat until all the lamb is done.

Return all the lamb to the pot, and add the herbs and garlic. Take care that it does not scorch at the bottom of the pan and so embitter the flavour. Add the vinegar and boil rapidly, then add the water. Season, cover tightly, lower the heat to the gentlest of murmurs and leave for an hour or so. Check the pot every 15-20 minutes, adding a spoonful or two of water if necessary. The lamb is cooked when the meat offers no resistance to a fork.

To finish, put two or three tablespoons of the cooking liquor into a bowl and mash the anchovies into it. Spoon this over the lamb, stir carefully, and simmer for a minute longer before serving

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

The simple elegance of the pure, fresh flavours proves that the best ingredients treated with due respect make the best memories. 1 loaf crusty white bread 225g fresh ricotta 8 flat anchovy fillets 15g unsalted butter, softened 1 tbsp extra-virgin olive oil 1 tbsp freshly-ground black pepper Cut thin slices of bread, remove and discard the crusts, and cut the bread into 5-6cm squares or triangles (precision is unimportant here). Lay the pieces out on a tray and bake in a moderate oven until golden. If the ricotta is moist, put it in a strainer to drain for half-an-hour or so. If using salted anchovies, rinse and divest them of bones first. (It's a good idea to desalinate a large batch, and layer any that you don't use in good olive oil, as they'll keep in the fridge for a week and make a perfect excuse to eat more anchovies.) Put the cheese, anchovies, butter, oil and pepper in a food processor, and chop to a creamy consistency. Transfer to a bowl and leave to sit for half-an-hour before spreading on the toast. Tian of tuna and anchovy 2.5kg piece tuna loin 16-20 anchovy fillets 16-20 large lettuce leaves 1 medium-sized onion, thinly sliced 6 ripe tomatoes, thinly sliced 1 lemon 1 small sprig fresh thyme 1 small sprig fresh rosemary 2 handfuls picked sorrel Sea salt and fresh black pepper Olive oil 150ml white wine Pre-heat the oven to 175C/350F/gas mark 4. Choose a shallow dish that can be sealed easily and into which the tuna will fit snugly. Insert an anchony fillet between each ring of the tuna steak, spreading them out as evenly as possible. Line the base of the tian with half the lettuce leaves. Lay half the onion and tomato on top. Peel and thinly slice the lemon, and lay half of it on the onion and tomato. Scatter a little thyme and rosemary over this. Wash and de-stalk the sorrel, shred the leaves, and place half on top of the lemon. Grind some black pepper over, sprinkle with a little sea salt, then dab with a few tablespoons of olive oil. Place the tuna on top, then repeat the layering backwards, up to and including the onion. Wrap the remaining lettuce leaves around the tuna, enclosing it completely, and spoon over a little more oil. Pour the wine into the dish, and seal tightly with foil or a lid. Place in the heated oven and cook for an hour or so. This is at its best served just warm. Abbacchio alla cacciatora A celebrated Roman dish - month-old lamb pot-roasted with sage and rosemary, the flavours elevated by discreet quantities of anchovy and garlic. 1.4kg leg of top-quality spring lamb 25g lard 2 tbsp plain flour 1 sprig fresh rosemary tsp chopped dried sage leaves 1 small clove garlic 8 tbsp red-wine vinegar 6 tbsp water Sea salt 1 fully-charged pepper mill 4 large anchovy fillets Remove the meat from the leg, and cut into 5-6cm cubes. Melt the lard over a medium flame in a heavy-bottomed pot. Put in enough lamb to cover the base of the pot, and brown thoroughly. Once browned, sift over a little flour and continue frying until the meat turns a rich, dark colour. Remove the browned meat, and repeat until all the lamb is done. Return all the lamb to the pot, and add the herbs and garlic. Take care that it does not scorch at the bottom of the pan and so embitter the flavour. Add the vinegar and boil rapidly, then add the water. Season, cover tightly, lower the heat to the gentlest of murmurs and leave for an hour or so. Check the pot every 15-20 minutes, adding a spoonful or two of water if necessary. The lamb is cooked when the meat offers no resistance to a fork. To finish, put two or three tablespoons of the cooking liquor into a bowl and mash the anchovies into it. Spoon this over the lamb, stir carefully, and simmer for a minute longer before serving  Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Joseph Shabalala
fields.trailText: Joseph Shabalala
fields.body:
In 1964, Joseph Shabalala formed Ladysmith Black Mambazo, one of South Africa's most popular vocal choirs. Controversially, they sung on Paul Simon's Graceland album in 1986 during the cultural ban by western nations of South Africa. They have since had hit records worldwide and have just finished a UK tour. Shabalala has nine children, and three houses in the KwaZulu Natal region of South Africa.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
All people living together in peace.

What is your greatest fear?
That the Zulu tradition will disappear.

With which historical figure do you most identify?
Jesus Christ.

Which living person do you most admire?
There are two - Nelson Mandela and Gatsha Buthelezi.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Hatred.

What objects do you always carry with you?
The Bible.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Yes, as a Christian. But different cultures have different ways. Zulus are not required to keep just one wife.

Where would you like to live?
My home is the perfect place for me to live. However, I do love California.

What makes you depressed?
Thinking about all the fighting and killing in this world.

What is your favourite smell?
Cooking in my kitchen after I have been away for a long time.

What is your favourite building?
The Zulu huts in my hometown of Ladysmith.

What, or who, is the greatest love of your life?
There are many. Jesus Christ, my wonderful wife, Nellie, my children and their children, my culture and tradition.

What is your greatest regret?
It would be if I didn't do enough to keep my Zulu culture alive. But I'm hoping that I will not have such a regret.

How do you relax?
I write new songs or read my Bible.

What would your motto be?
Love each other, respect each other, help each other.

What keeps you awake at night?
On tour, it's usually the sound of the bus driving us to the next city.

Do you believe in life after death?
There is certainly a heaven that we go to after we die.

How would you like to be remembered?
First as a good Christian, and second as a Zulu. I also hope that people will say, 'Shabalala was a man who spoke of peace. He tried to make people throw away the hatred that divides people and pushes away happiness.'

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText:
Once again, Roger Protz (Weekend, April 15) puts forward the myth that organic produce and products are 'chemical-free' (a completely nonsensical phrase, when you analyse it!). Virtually all organic produce is sprayed with pesticides (as defined by the Control of Pesticide Regulations 1986). It is just that they are the ones defined as organic by the UK Register of Organic Food Standards and certification bodies such as the Soil Association. These pesticides are principally 'natural' in origin, although how 'natural' sulphur and copper oxychloride sound to your readers, I leave for them to judge.
Jonathan Blackman
Hereford

Seeing the three pages of BMW advertising (Weekend, April 15), reminded me of a part in the Alfred Hitchcock film Psycho, where maybe it could have been said . . .'The most effective form of propulsion is from behind . . .' I think it's called stabbing in the back?
Norman Meyer
Goole, Yorkshire. Normingoole@tesco.net

Re Julie Burchill (April 15): '. . . with journalism and PR locked into some sort of infernally Dante-esque three-legged race of servility . . .' Oh, what poetry! A Sucker Upper I may be, but I still have to tell Julie Burchill how much she enriches my Saturday mornings.
Liz Palmer
Taunton, Devon Palmer-Harvey@tinyworld.co.uk

I can identify with Julie Burchill's inverse suck-up gene, as opposed to inverse snobbery. It expresses itself when in the presence of our social or work 'superiors' and makes us truculent and aggressive. If nothing else, this gene gets us noticed and sometimes it gets 'selected for', in the biologists' parlance, by people who think our 'truculence', or whatever, is of use to them. Like all genes, it is very selfish and only has our own interests at heart. You can disguise it any way you like, dress it up, if you need to, as subversion or rebellion - but at the end of the day you're just trying desperately to rise above the throng like the rest of them.
Mark Pulley
Handsworth, Birmingham
markpulley@email.com

Julie Burchill might pedantically call 'inverted snobbery' totally meaningless, but it doesn't stop her falling into the trap of all feminists, swapping one form of elitism for another. Why is it any better to eulogise the menial over that of the powerful?
Nigel Murphy
Halesowen, West Midlands
nigelmurphy@madasafish.com

Bullying, Jim? (Dear Weekend, April 15) Can't you recognise the art of gentle teasing and tongue-in-cheek humour when you read it? I, too, am a rambler and thought Guy Browning's How to Ramble article very amusing, although it did make me feel a trifle uncomfortable. So much comedy is based on making fun of others - perhaps Jim has chortled away at other similar articles/sketches and only objects to this one because it relates to him. I'm afraid it adds another description to ramblers - achingly dull, with no sense of humour.
Pam Fray
Faversham, Kent
pam.fray@tinyworld.co.uk

 Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
