fields.headline: Holy fools
fields.standfirst: Why, if a woman shows her sex organs to one stranger she is a prostitute, but if she shows them to millions, she is a superstar?
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill: Why, if a woman shows her sex organs to one stranger she is a prostitute, but if she shows them to millions, she is a superstar?
fields.body:
I know prejudice is a bad thing, and the last thing I'd want back in pubs and hotels are those signs that used to read No Blacks, No Irish, No Dogs. But "No Actors", as I believe was once a common sight? Mmm. Lead me to it. It's funny how other people who work in what are thought to be overpaid, parasitical occupations - estate agent, stockbroker, politician, hack - are routinely mocked and reviled. Yet I don't remember the last time I heard an Actor Joke - not since that old one about the out-of-work actor who comes home to find his wife raped and his dog dead. "Your agent did it," whimpers his wife. "Oh, God!" says the actor. "Did he leave a message?"

No, actors have done a damn good job presenting themselves as The People's Friend, and it's the best acting job any of them ever does. But the facts are somewhat different. Despite its outlaw credentials, acting is as conservative, selfish and reactionary a profession as you'll find; politically, they make prison officers look like social workers. The acting profession is snobbish (hence the continuing veneration of the useless Redgraves), racist (when did you last see a black actor playing anything but a mug or a thug?) and so sexist that women stop existing between the ages of 40 and 60, when they are allowed back in reduced numbers, so long as they play dotty old biddies.

Last week, one Jennifer Tuckett, a student at Cambridge, claimed that she had been kept out of the famous Footlights society by the boy's club that dominates drama there, and only allowed on stage when a young blonde stripped to her underwear was needed. "Everything was so male-dominated and incredibly intimidating. There are about 10 people on the Footlights committee; they all tend to be male. Women find it very intimidating, and friends tend to give their friends important roles." Sadly, some might say that if a woman is determined to be an actor, Footlights are only doing the decent thing in giving her a taste of how her working life is going to be, like it or lump it; surely only a woman with either a skin thicker than a rhino's or else a masochistic streak a mile wide would choose to continue in such a profession.

I never thought I'd have cause to agree with that big blethering perm-on-a-stick Michael Caine about anything, but he was totally right about this country's stuck-up thespians, as were Jane Horrocks, Bob Hoskins and Ray Winstone when they supported him. Though, of course, Caine himself, being an actor, is prey to all their vices; coming to fame during the heyday of British film-making, it didn't take him long to object to paying a decent level of tax and push off to America in order to stretch himself with such life-enhancing artefacts as The Swarm IV, The Hand and Blame It On Rio.

In fact, he is exactly the sort of actor - feet supposedly planted in the soil, hands grabbing at any fast buck floating by - who you'd expect to see in the new Barclays advert. In a brilliant example of our old friend socialism for the rich and capitalism for the poor, Barclays have paid Christ knows how much to a trio of actors - Anthony Hopkins, Tim Roth, Nick Moran, who have all made a great to-do about their alleged bucking of the system - to tout their slimy product while laying off workers and stranding clients by the hundreds of thousands. But then, allegedly left-wing British actors have always made me laugh - Roth and Gary Oldman come immediately to mind - because of their habit, during the reign of Mrs Thatcher, of leaving the country in a self-righteous strop about right-wing repression and then not moving to Cuba or Sweden, both of whose cinema is in good health and well subsidised by their governments. No, where did they go to escape Fatcher's Britain - why, Reagan's America, that famous bastion of freedom and equality! The new rash of British gangster films, wherein public-school directors exploit the real desperation and degradation of the working-class for comic effect, are yet another expression of this vicious hypocrisy; see Vinnie Jones as a Cockney Uncle Tom, dropping his aitches and swallowing his pride for the glory of well-born Guy Ritchie.

It is refreshing, then, when an actor makes no pretence whatsoever of caring about the greater good, but simply follows his heart and his nose to the place where he will find the greatest wealth and ease possible on this planet. Step forward Anthony Hopkins, who has finished what he started with the Barclays ad by becoming an American citizen. I found it particularly touching that one of the people from his home town of Port Talbot who put the boot in was the local postmaster, Asghar Ali, an Asian, who spat: "Sir Anthony is always harping on about his Welshness, but when the chips are down he goes away. To be honest, I think he is a hypocrite."

No, not a hypocrite, Mr Ali, but an actor ; a mercenary and a freebooter, if you want to be nasty about it, a citizen of the world if you buy their own brand. An Asian may easily become a Welshman within one generation, but an actor calls only the mirror home. A lifetime spent pretending that you are other people must surely distort your "real" emotions, till such concepts as loyalty and integrity seem quite . . . subjective , somehow, like pain and poverty in that Brecht song about Los Angeles doubling as Heaven for the rich and Hell for the poor.

As a child, I used to love films and film stars, but now find that the whole idea fills me with horror. Why? Why do we need to escape from our own lives so much that we will pay a few dozen people millions of dollars in order to waste their lives dressing up, spouting someone else's words and generally getting themselves well confused? Why do "serious" actors such as Richard Gere, Winona Ryder and Sean Penn make TV commercials that cannot be shown in America? Are they ashamed of themselves? Why, if a woman shows her sex organs to one stranger is she a prostitute, but if she shows them to millions, like Demi Moore and Sharon Stone, she is a superstar? Why are people paid a pittance for being real nurses, but a fortune for pretending to be nurses?

Ultimately, it is these and many other questions which will keep actors on the fronts of our newspapers and in the slipstreams of our subconscious; not, as they believe, for what they reveal to us about the human condition when they are practising their art, but for what they reveal when they are at their ease, or cutting that deal, or pulling up that skirt. They are our holy fools, and no money could ever be too much reward for the spectacles they make of themselves so that we may escape with at least a little dignity.

fields.headline: The angry icon
fields.standfirst: William Klein is an artist held in huge esteem for his pioneering photography, film-making and artworks. But he has never courted fame, and sometimes it rankles that he hasn't had more of it. Alix Sharkey sounds out an American in Paris
fields.trailText: William Klein is an artist held in huge esteem for his pioneering photography, film-making and artworks. But he has never courted fame, and sometimes it rankles that he hasn't had more of it. Alix Sharkey sounds out an American in Paris
fields.body:
As a young man, he believed his eyes frightened people, and he was probably right. Even now they have an owl-like quality; pale-green, a little too alert, cold and unblinking. Age has crumpled and softened the rest of him. The jowls sag, there are liver spots on his broad forehead, but he remains sturdy and handsome, unbowed by his 71 years. He wears faded jeans, battered black Reeboks, a blood-red bandana tucked inside his sweater. He feels a bit stiff because he played tennis last night.

The apartment is elegant and orderly, not plush. The living room, flooded with spring sunlight, looks out over the Jardin de Luxembourg. This has been home for half his life; he and his wife, Janine, raised their son Pierre here, and his office is upstairs.

We sit at the marble coffee table under bookshelves stacked with monographs - painters, photographers, African and Oceanic art - and reams of literature, classic and modern. His New York idiom is dated, contorted by decades of speaking French, and his English vocabulary is rusty: at one point he growls, "How do you say it now . . . people without jobs? Oh, yeah, unemployed."

Thirty years ago, William Klein was famous, even infamous. True, he's still relatively well known in Paris, but elsewhere, those who recognise the name think of him as a photographer who did his best work in the 50s and 60s. A few cinema buffs will know him as the director of several ground-breaking films. In fact, he's much more than that.

He says he wasn't really a photographer at all, and each of his four photographic monographs, on which much of his reputation is based, took an average of only three months to shoot, and a couple more for the design, typography, covers, text and layout - all of which he did himself. No, he sees himself as an multi-disciplinary avant-garde artist. Big shows in San Francisco, books flying out of the stores in Tokyo, that sort of thing. And certainly, over the past four-and-a-half decades he has moved freely between disciplines as diverse as abstract painting, graphic design, art and fashion photography, documentary and feature films, even TV commercials.

His latest film is a quasi-documentary interpretation of Handel's Messiah. "Beautiful, funny, tragic, scary, all at once," is his immodest description of a film depicting various amateur and ecclesiastical choirs in America, Russia, France and Spain performing the title work, as well as "a lot of ordinary life" - tattoo parlours, prisons, desert landscapes and political demonstrations. The Messiah, he says, is both homage to, and satire on, Handel's masterpiece. "For example, Christmas dinner at a homeless refuge here in Paris was one of the most frightening things that you can imagine. And during that sequence, you have this beautiful black singer, Nicole Heaston, singing, 'Rejoice, rejoice . . .' "

If Klein has been pigeonholed as a photographer and image-maker, it is because, 43 years ago, his first book changed the theory and practice of photography. New York, or to give it its full title, Life Is Good And Good For You In New York: Trance Witness Revels, was published in Paris in 1956. The $ is a means of expression, and the artists who have learned to work in this medium, who can produce money-making masterpieces, will become the real American Artists. And the day when Ugliness shall no longer profit will be Their Day, beauty will fill the banks, beauty will be a commodity, only beauty will sell, then shall dawn the Age Of The Beautiful Dollar and everything will be just gorgeous."

Though born into a petit-bourgeois orthodox Jewish family in 1928, Klein grew up poor, his father having lost everything in the Wall Street Crash, and the household moving to progressively rougher neighbourhoods. On graduating at 18, he let himself be drafted into the army, having realised he would be sent to occupied Germany, where he supplemented his pay as a poker shark. "Most of the other soldiers were older than me, and sent money back to their families, so they were more prudent. But I was young and didn't give a shit, so I would bluff and maybe win two, three hundred dollars." Klein emerged from one winning hand with a Rolleiflex camera, with which he took his first photos.

He and 25 other GIs were selected under a Franco-American cultural programme to study at the Sorbonne. "Léger was not only the first artist I ever met, but also the first pop artist, and he blew our minds. He told us to get out of our studios and go down into the streets and look at the life around us. He told us that what was happening was not in museums or galleries, but on the walls of the city, in its advertising and signs. And he told us to open ourselves to collaboration with other artists, and architects."

Klein took him at his word and, in 1952, aged 24, found himself in Milan, exhibiting linear black-and-white paintings which fore-shadowed the op-art of the 60s. This led to a job painting interior murals for an Italian architect, based on abstract designs that he had made in the darkroom working with light and photographic paper. These appeared in Domus art magazine, attracting the attention of Vogue art director, Alexander Liberman.

Liberman realised Klein was unsuited to office life, but offered him a contract anyway. Klein proposed a photographic journal of his return to New York; Liberman agreed Vogue would finance and publish it. But there was never much chance of that. Klein's attitude was diametrically opposed to the Cartier-Bresson school which insisted the photographer should never intrude or editorialise. Having felt excluded in his youth, Klein "had a score to settle" with New York. "Coming back from Paris, I saw it as hicksville, not the brilliant Big Apple that New Yorkers thought it was." He decided to give it "a kick in the balls".

The pictures were too strong for Vogue and Alexander Liberman, who suggested that Klein find another publisher. But no American house would touch New York: it was too grim, and would remain unpublished in the US for almost 40 years. Instead, it was published in Paris, and was an instant hit. Liberman next asked Klein to photograph the Paris collections for Vogue. According to the photography critic Martin Harrison, it was Klein who "introduced wide-angle and long focal-length lenses, the use of open-flash, multiple exposures, and surrounded models with swirling auras of moving light". He also used sets with distorted perspectives, creating surreal images that influenced the next generation of fashion photographers, in particular David Bailey and Helmut Newton. Nor was his innovation limited to technique. His view of women was challenging: he encouraged his models to play up for the camera rather than merely posing, and photographed top models with cigarettes hanging from their mouths,"smoking like sailors".

This blunt street aesthetic gave fashion photography a new edge which, paradoxically, made it seem even more glamorous. His move into film-making was inevitable. On seeing New York, Federico Fellini invited the American to assist him on Notti di Cabiria. Soon afterwards, Klein returned to New York to shoot his first short, Broadway By Light, which Orson Welles described as "the first film in which the colour is absolutely necessary". It was full of Pop images, opening on a giant Pepsi Cola sign. For Klein, the film is a response to critics who said New York was too black, too dirty. "I decided to do something very clean and beautiful, but just as frightening: the brain-washing electric lights and neon signs of Broadway . . . were ready-made movies."

Broadway By Light prompted nouvelle vague director Louis Malle to enlist Klein as "visual director" for Zazie Dans Le Metro. Next, in 1962, came a fashion documentary, to be followed by Cassius, The Great.

"I didn't really know who Cassius Clay was. I just wanted to show America through a heavyweight championship fight. Ever since my childhood, I'd been fascinated by the way the whole country becomes polarised around this event." Fate conspired to his advantage; an advertising executive friend put up the money, and on the flight from New York to Miami he found himself sitting next to Malcolm X, who told him all about the fiery young boxer who had the whole country talking about him - and half of it hating him.

Comparable to the best of Luis Buñuel, this surrealist satire on celebrity and the media anticipated the supermodel phenomenon by 25 years. Leading with his chin, Klein followed this with Mr Freedom, a feature-length political satire featuring a crypto-fascist Rambo-style superhero rampaging through a France in turmoil (Maoism was fashionable on the Left Bank at the time), to the accompaniment of a Serge Gainsbourg soundtrack. Mr Freedom was banned for nine months.

Weary of the amateurish French documentary crew following him around, Cleaver asked Klein to take over.

Klein became a cause célèbre in his adopted home: Roland Barthes wrote admiringly about his photography, Jean-Paul Sartre was among many intellectuals who signed a petition against the ban.

Klein is a shy and painfully reserved man, according to his wife, Janine. They married as soon as he left the army, at the age of 20. The daughter of a Belgian architect who modelled to finance Klein's painting, she too has pursued an artist's life, collaborating and designing costumes for many of Klein's films, and generally playing an enormous role in his working life. Intriguingly, she once described her husband as "someone who never really wants to reveal who he is. All the important people, he was never polite to them, even those he liked. Maybe to prove something . . . He shuts himself off, never talking about his own feelings. He hardly has any close friends. Maybe I'm the only one. He never played the game."

This refusal to make the most of his contacts, along with an almost pathological inability to repeat himself, a satirical edge that borders on slapstick, and his anarchistic political stance - not to mention his haughty demeanour and occasional rudeness - all these factors have probably deprived Klein of his place in the pantheon of modern artists: a place that, for all his supposed indifference, he undoubtedly believes he has earned.

Of course, he knows he is not a Picasso, but he likes to compare himself to Man Ray, and is not slow to point out parallels with another maverick who burned through more ideas in a decade than many of his peers managed in a lifetime. Neglected in his homeland for 40 years, Klein is keenly aware of how easily reputations are made or lost, and how critical recognition is often bestowed only after death - too late for the artist himself to benefit from his commercial resurrection. When I mention Easy Rider screenwriter Terry Southern he bristles: "He was ripped off, poor guy, he should have had a career that was recognised . . ." He pauses, before adding, "For example, Andy Warhol gets so much credit for a lot stuff that isn't that revolutionary . . ." The sentence trails off with a wave of the hand, but the implication is clear.

Klein still makes a living from photographs he took nearly half a century ago, like the picture from New York of a small boy pointing a toy gun at the camera. Every few weeks, a magazine will call for the rights, usually to accompany a feature on juvenile crime.

"And you always let them use it?"

"Well," he smiles,"I'm in business."

His affability remains intact as long as he's playing the patrician role. The wisecracking persona and couldn't-give-a-damn attitude evaporate when he's riled. A propos of nothing, he suddenly says of Paris-based designers Alexander McQueen and John Galliano, "They're both doing quite well, but a lot of that is bullshit, you know . . . The British Film Institute, having decided against a retrospective of Klein's films, is "what you'd call a bunch of wankers".

"And that's true on one level, but it works on many levels, and there's a lot of suspense. It tells the story that Handel illustrated - the Nativity, Passion, and the Resurrection. The room is suddenly ablaze with golden light, as the sun begins to set behind the trees outside. I unzip my bag, take out my latest purchase, and ask the big question.

"Will I take your photograph?" he repeats, as if I had asked for money. For a second he fixes me with those unblinking eyes. Then he says,"Yes, but don't move. The light's perfect."

I hand him a plastic disposable camera. He turns it around in his big, ruddy hands, looking puzzled. "What's this?"

I point out the viewfinder and the shutter release. He takes one, two, three, four snaps. The last, he mutters, is "perfect".

I don't have the heart to tell him about the trendy new restaurant that opened the night before, barely a mile from his apartment - a place designed for the new breed of instant celebrities he so brilliantly ridiculed in his films. The restaurant is called Man Ray

Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate Gallery since 1988, is the most powerful figure in the history of modern art in Britain, at a time when contemporary art has never been more culturally centre stage. Gallery visitor figures are on a spectacularly rising curve and press and public interest has never been greater. Serota chairs the judges for the Turner Prize and has become inextricably linked to its annual cavalcade of dead sharks, unmade beds and the accompanying controversy. It has become a major annual fixture that every year swells the audience for modern art while simultaneously providing ammunition for sceptics to fulminate about its waste and absurdity.

Next month sees the culmination of Serota's career so far with the opening of Tate Modern, the vast new £130m temple to contemporary art at Bankside. It joins Tate Britain - the new name for the original gallery on Millbank - Tate Liverpool, and Tate St Ives as part of the most comprehensive presentation of modern art ever seen in this country.

Having worked for 30 years at that explosive junction where public money meets contemporary art, Serota has become accustomed to operating under heavy bombardment. But more recently it has begun to seem that he can do no wrong. Unlike the fiascos of other millennium projects, Bankside is on time, within budget and Swiss architects Herzog & de Mueron's stunning conversion of Giles Gilbert Scott's power station on the south side of the Thames is getting rave reviews. So perhaps now comes the really difficult part for Serota. In an unorthodox development it seems that traditional British cynicism has given way to naked enthusiasm. The expectations of Bankside couldn't be higher.

"It is an enormously important moment", says Culture Secretary Chris Smith. "This is the first major new gallery to open in this country in over 100 years and it is also a landmark piece of architecture. It will mean that London and the UK have for the first time a world-class contemporary art gallery." The artist and influential art teacher Michael Craig Martin makes an even larger claim. "It is difficult to overstate its importance. There has always been a hesitancy about modernism throughout this century in Britain. This building announces that the hesitancy is over."

Glen Lowry is director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, traditionally seen as the world leader in contemporary art. Even he acknowledges that Tate Modern, "has vaulted Britain to the forefront of the international art scene. We are all looking forward to it with incredible interest and anticipation, but of course ultimately the displays and programming will decide its true impact."

So Serota, having already achieved so much, will remain under scrutiny for some time yet. There are few who doubt he has the artistic vision and mental toughness to succeed. He is variously described as "intense", "cold" and "unnervingly inscrutable". The Turner prize-winning artist Gillian Wearing, recently made a trustee of the Tate, says Serota's position and reputation make him an intimidating man to meet. "He's the overseer of everything, isn't he?"

His ascetic demeanour, along with a taste for understated dark suits and white shirts, prompted one gallery owner to describe him as, "a Jansenist dressed by Comme des Garçons". But while he is undoubtedly a formidable man to do business with and a world-class political and administrative operator, the question remains - with the global surge in interest in contemporary art over the last decade - whether Bankside would ever have happened if Nick Serota had never been involved.

Chris Smith thinks not. "Probably more than anyone it was his idea that Bankside could be transformed into something special, and he has been very much the driving force. Without him there would have been a serious question as to whether it happened at all." Norman Rosenthal, exhibitions secretary at the Royal Academy agrees. "The moment finds the man and the man finds the moment. And Nick has very much been a man for this particular moment." Rosenthal says that Tate Modern will permanently alter "the cultural ecology of London".

Shaping the body politic of London seems to be in the blood. Serota was born in 1946 in middle-class Hampstead to Stanley and Beatrice Serota. He has one sister, Judith, two years younger, who is festival manager of the Spitalfields arts festival in east London. His father was a civil engineer. His mother was a leading Labour Party figure in local government. After serving on Hampstead Borough Council and the London County Council, where she chaired the education committee, in 1967 she became a life peer and served as a minister of state at the department of health in Harold Wilson's government. Later she became deputy speaker of the Lords and a governor of the BBC.

Serota recalls a few cabinet ministers coming in and out of the house but says his mother was never at the heart of the Labour Party in that sense, "although she was active in the Hampstead party in the 50s, so she did know people like Gaitskell and Greenwood".

The family is Jewish and the name Russian but Serota says his aunts and uncles were far more observant on religion than his parents. "But just because they weren't observant doesn't mean they didn't feel part of the Jewish community. My parents respected rather than actively observed Jewishness." He adopts the same approach.

After attending the local primary school Serota won an LCC scholarship to the direct grant Haberdashers Askes. He was made head boy and captained the first XV rugby team. "I was a forward, although I don't look like one now." He says he wasn't engaged in the arts at school but was more interested in social and political questions. He never joined the Labour Party but did go on a few Alder maston anti-nuclear marches and thought he would probably end up working somewhere in social administration.

His parents were not academically pushy but he says they were "surprised" when, at Cambridge University, after a gap year in India, he changed his course from economics to history of art. The family had occasionally visited galleries but there was no strong visual presence in the home, apart from a few reproductions of paintings by Christopher Wood, several of whose colourful depictions of inter-war provincial France are in the Tate collection. "I think I decided that if I wasn't going to be a great economist, I might as well spend two years learning about something that would stay with me for the rest of my life. Once I started, it felt natural to be doing it."

In the early 60s Serota saw exhibitions of Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg at the Whitechapel Gallery, but says if there was a moment when he decided that he was interested in the visual arts it was after seeing a big survey show of European and American art at the Tate in 1964 called Painting and Sculpture of the Decade. "I saw British artists in an international context. It didn't feel like little England." His main enthusiasm remained 20th century art, but at Cambridge he mostly studied the Italian renaissance. So, after university, he spent a year in France doing a series of hand-to-mouth jobs, and self-consciously catching up on the 18th and 19th centuries to reinforce his interest in the modern.

When he returned from France, Serota took an MA at the Courtauld Institute. He was taught by Anita Brookner - "an incredible teacher, really brilliant" - and wrote his thesis on Turner in Switzerland. He then applied to the Arts Council for a job as a garden technician at the recently opened Serpentine Gallery but was turned down for being over qualified. He was, however, offered another job - looking after the grants made to artists and managing exhibitions touring around the country. His patch was the north east, which extended from Southend to Berwick - "It was a very metropolitan view," he says, "but it was a really good job." His predecessor at the Tate, Alan Bowness, had done the same job 15 years earlier.

Serota began to learn the business of arts administration. Michael Craig Martin first met him at this time and remembers him as serious, shy and quiet - "although his essential shyness is often taken for coldness, when in fact he has a very wry humour" - but always very well informed. Serota identifies a key moment in 1970 when he worked with the art critic and curator David Sylvester on putting together an exhibition of Miró sculpture at the Hayward Gallery. "I learned a huge amount in about 48 hours; how you deal with works of art, how you install it and make exhibitions," says Serota. Sylvester remembers thinking even then that, "one day this man will be director of the Tate. And he has been the best director the Tate has ever had. Both in terms of his acquisitions and his presentations."

Serota's taste was forged at this time. "We can now see it was a pretty key moment in the development of art in the 20th century," he says. "People like Richard Long and Bruce McLean in this country and Carl André and Joseph Beuys and others overseas were making art that was more conceptually based and directly related to things in life around them. It was everything Brian Sewell hates and it was new and challenging and felt very much of the moment."

It is this type of art that he has most closely been associated with and he acknowledges that, "you come into contact with contemporary art at a certain moment in your life and that art and those groups of artists remain important to you. The question is then whether you can move forward and engage with other types of art. I think my taste has become much more catholic than many people might believe. I'm certainly more interested in a wider range of contemporary art than I was in the 70s."

He was criticised not long after joining the Tate for spending £700,000 on a Joseph Beuys installation of rocks with felt-lined sockets. But he also bought paintings by Joseph Wright of Derby and Gainsborough, along with more mainstream modern painters like Freud, Heron and Kitaj.

The Courtauld lecturer Julian Stallabrass feels that the Tate's buying policy can be too conservative. "They tend to deal with a small number of established dealers and they stick to works that has received endorsement from the commercial sector first. It is not a leader. I think it could be a bit more pro-active in helping to set trends as well as follow them." Serota counters by saying the Tate does buy early. "We rarely go into a studio and buy works by artists who have not had commercial shows of any kind. But we do buy early and sometimes get very good margins. For instance in 1993 we bought a work by an American artist called Matthew Barney for $30,000 which is probably worth close to $500,000 now."

In 1973 Serota was given his first director's job when he was asked to run the Oxford Museum of Modern Art. Despite the small budget he set out to create a programme that had some international dimension, and he formed a series of alliances with similar small galleries in the Netherlands and in Germany and began to exchange work.

He got married the same year to the ballet dancer Angela Beveridge. They have two daughters, Anya, 24, who works on the online edition of the Macmillan Dictionary of Art and Beth, 23, at Edinburgh University studying sociology and anthropology. The marriage broke up in 1993. Serota married Teresa Gleadowe, a friend from Cambridge and former head of information at the Tate, in 1997. Gleadowe, who has two daughters, is director of the MA course in curating and visual arts administration at the Royal College of Art.

After three years in Oxford he moved to the Whitechapel Gallery. Joanna Drew, who as director of art at the Arts Council has nurtured a whole generation of gallery curators, remembers him as a brilliant figure in a very bright generation. "When he went to Oxford he put the whole museum on its feet. It was struggling and he established the nature of the place and its pro gramme. He had the same effect on the Whitechapel. He was associated with minimalism but he also put on a remarkable exhibition of Max Beckmann and one on Hawksmoor. He re-established its credibility as a serious venue for serious exhibitions."

Under Bryan Robertson's regime in the 50s and 60s, Whitechapel had been the premier gallery for showing contemporary art in Britain. By the time Serota arrived it was suffering the consequences of a turf war between the Hayward, the Tate and the ICA, its grant had been cut and it had had three directors in five years. Serota, however, saw a sleeping giant, particularly as it was so well placed to tap into the geographical shift of artists moving to east London. One of the first things he did was appoint a community education worker who promoted contact with local schools and hospitals, a revolutionary appointment in those days, and began to attract a new audience to the gallery.

He staged some extremely controversial shows featuring work by Baselitz, Richard Long and, in 1978, Carl André. The Tate had been vilified for acquiring André's sculpture, Equivalent VIII, two years earlier, when the neatly arranged collection of bricks became a by-word for the absurdity of modern art. "That was one of the reasons for doing an André show," he says. "I didn't think he had been given a fair crack of the whip after the Tate bricks row."

By the time the Tate job became vacant in 1988, Serota was the obvious candidate. Michael Craig Martin says, "from the minute he arrived he did two things that were significant. He physically transformed the gallery by stripping the building back to its original architectural framework. And then he completely reorganised the hanging of the collection. Those two acts carry over to what you will see in Bankside."

Denis Stevenson, chair of the trustees throughout most of the 90s, says people don't remember how contentious re-hanging the collection was. Rodin's The Thinker was removed, and hasn't been seen since, as were other favourites. "The first re-hang was extraordinarily controversial. Rather like the re-hang at Millbank is now. But it was clearly strategically correct. The audience doubled. You don't go back to the cinema to see the same film every week, and it's the same with paintings."

Having worked for nearly 20 years on temporary exhibitions Serota was relishing the opportunities offered by the Tate. Since he arrived, visitor numbers have increased from 1.1m to 2.6m a year. It is anticipated that Tate Modern will attract 2m visitors on its own. "The moments when the Tate has authority in the contemporary world is when it is respected by artists, putting on interesting shows and buying good work," he says. "I wanted to create one of those moment. I was also increasingly interested in building a collection."

He remembers that when he arrived, people at the Tate were apprehensive because he had never run an organisation with more than 20 people. "Looking back I can see why they were apprehensive." Stevenson, also chairman of Pearson and the Halifax, says Serota is a natural: "he is the manager from central casting. He has natural authority and can just do it. If he wanted to and was available, I wouldn't hesitate to give him a great chunk of Pearson or the Halifax."

Serota says he wasn't apprehensive in artistic terms. "Not because I thought I was infallible, but I had become used to making choices and statements through the art I showed. I knew I would be criticised and occasionally praised but I had served an apprenticeship in being roasted by the press and by artists and sometimes by other colleagues. It doesn't mean that you are impervious to criticism, but you get used to the notion that you can't please all the people all the time."

His most persistent critic has been Brian Sewell who used a show held last year, Abracadabra, to illustrate all that is wrong with Serota's Tate. "It was a prime example of the hocus-pocus and mumbo jumbo by which the false intellectuals of the art world are able to 'hey presto!' anything into art, be it the dung of elephants, the video of a medical camera's examination of an artist's uterus, anus and digestive tract, an erect cucumber projecting from a stained mattress, or a dead horse suspended from a dome."

In calling for Serota to be sacked he said that, "the curators of this exhibition know nothing of empathy, catharsis or the elevation of the spirit, nothing of intellectual nourishment, nothing of awe and wonder, nothing of what is to be derived from, for example, the great Titians in the National Gallery."

The director of the National Gallery, Neil MacGregor, may agree with Sewell about the glory of Titian, but he is also a firm supporter of Serota. MacGregor sees Serota's key achievement as at last solving the historical compromise of the Tate. The gallery was founded by sugar magnate Henry Tate in 1897 as The National Gallery of British Art. Following a major bequest of modern French art in 1916, including many important impressionist paintings, it formally took on the remit for international modern art the following year.

"The huge task at the Tate was always to clarify that split," says MacGregor. "Nick's achievement has been a lucidity of analysis in sorting out the different roles and then an astonishing capacity to make it a reality. London will benefit from the huge gain in clarity. Everyone will know where the 20th century collection is." In making the split Serota has been conscious that Tate Britain might be overshadowed by its bright new sister space. Symbolically he has decided to keep his office at Millbank and the annual Turner Prize show will still be based there.

The prize has been the single most significant element in raising the profile of contemporary art in Britain. It was founded in 1984 but by 1990 it was dead on its feet and was suspended. Five of the first six winners had appeared on the very first shortlist and the public had lost interest. In 1991 Channel 4 stepped in and the prize was limited to artists under 50. "Which meant it was on live television and artists in their 30s started to win it," recalls Michael Craig Martin. "Now a young audience thinks of contemporary art in the same way as previous generations thought about the cinema, the theatre or literature. Art has become another central component of cultural life."

But Serota knows that simply basing the prize at Millbank won't in itself generate interest in Tate Britain. "I do need to give some tender loving care to a few places that have missed out over the last year or so. They will get it. The challenge now is make Tate Britain a place where British artists really want to see their work shown."

Turner prize short-listed artist Cornelia Parker will have a piece of her work in the opening collection at Tate Modern but is enthusiastic about Tate Britain. "Now is a good time to change how we think about Britain and the idea that there will be a museum for art made in Britain reflects the confidence and changes in British art over the last decade or so. It will show how British art is not such an exclusive club any more."

As part of the effort to balance the different arms of the Tate, each gallery has its own director. Stephen Deuchar, formally at the National Maritime Museum, is in charge at Tate Britain and the Swedish curator Lars Nittve will run Tate Modern. One industry observer notes that, "Serota has a reputation for wanting to control things and there are potential problems with the two directors beneath him. When looking at Bankside one of the most interesting things will be to see how much Serota allows the new director to do the work and who will make the big decisions. Intellectually I'm sure he wants to allow the two directors a reasonable degree of latitude. But I suspect in practice the temptation of wanting to control things will continue. After all it was his idea and he raised the money."

Serota says his job is to, "encourage, support and act as a second pair of eyes. But I would find it difficult to walk away from the hands-on side of the job and not be directly involved. In the last few weeks I have spent some time hanging works at Tate Modern with Lars. But clearly it is his gallery."

In fact one of Serota's triumphs has been how few rows he has had despite pushing the organisation so quickly forward. The history of the Tate is littered with stories of carnage as directors and trustees continually fell out. But in Serota's time there seem to have been remarkably few rows. He laughs that there were bad periods in the 50s, the late 70s and the mid 80s. "So we're just about due for another one now." A former member of staff confirms the effectiveness of his personal skills. "Quite often major donors want to impose conditions on gifts. Nick is very good at finessing things so that they fit in with the Tate's strategy. And he uses his aura and mystique to add to the attractiveness. Equally he is very approachable to his staff, and you don't need to pussyfoot around him."

People close to him say that his apparently buttoned up on-duty persona is only part of the story. His Who's Who entry used to rather depressingly list his recreation as "hanging paintings". Now it makes no mention of recreation at all, but he enjoys sailing dinghies and there are stories of him as an energetic dancer at the office party - with a fondness for the music of Little Richard. He says that while he works hard, he's no workaholic. "I still take holidays, I have a few friends. I tremendously enjoy the company of artists," he laughs. "I have spent my working life working with them and I wouldn't be in this job if it didn't include talking about art and talking to artists."

This feeds into an evangelical enthusiasm for what galleries can do. "Here is something that by its very nature should be interesting to huge numbers of people and we want to make it available to them. But in the end there is little point in encouraging people to come to the Tate unless they find something that interests them or irritates them or that they find beautiful. It's not a question of liking everything. I don't like everything in the Tate.

"But it's not an industry. It's a form of educational experience and of self discovery. It's the reason one can justify using taxpayers money to support and sustain a great institution." People speak of Serota's sense of moral duty in accounting for the way public money is spent. He has been a passionate advocate of increased accessibility and a recently announced joint web-site project with New York's Museum of Modern Art is part of that agenda. He has also been prominent in the campaign to reject admission charges to museums.

Neil MacGregor says Serota's role in changing the perception of modern art has been enormous. "He has made it into something that a very large number of people are interested in and want to come and look at. It is no longer a minority or fringe interest. And that is true right across the country. I suspect he has played the leading part in that. He has almost stopped Britain being afraid of contemporary art."

The "almost" is important. As chairman of the Turner prize judges, Serota is well aware that annual displays of outrage at the shortlist and periodic personal attacks on him are a sign that there remains much more hand-holding of the public to be done. "Occasionally I get irritated with the criticism," he says, "but I probably also have myself to blame for being seen as someone who will support new developments in contemporary art. If you do that you will be regarded as only being interested in those things. But that's the life of the director of the Tate. I've got no complaints."

Life at a glance

Nicholas Andrew Serota

Born: April 27 1946, London.

Education: Haberdasher's Aske's school; Christ's College, Cambridge; Courtauld Institute.

Married: 1973 Angela Beveridge (two daughters, Anya and Beth), divorced 1995; 1997 Teresa Gleadowe.

Career: Exhibition director, Arts Council1970-73; director, Oxford Museum of Modern Art 1973-76; director, Whitechapel Art Gallery 1976-88; director, Tate Gallery 1988-.

Other posts: member, visual arts advisory committee of the British Council 1976-98, chairman 1992-98; trustee, Architecture Foundation 1991-99; Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment.

Publications: 1997, Walter Neurath Lecture, Experience or Interpretation; The Dilemma of Museums of Modern Art.

Honours: Knighted in 1999; honorary fellow, Royal Institute of British Architects, 1992.

 Tate Modern opens on May 12

For instance in 1993 we bought a work by an American artist called Matthew Barney for $30,000 which is probably worth close to $500,000 now." In 1973 Serota was given his first director's job when he was asked to run the Oxford Museum of Modern Art. Despite the small budget he set out to create a programme that had some international dimension, and he formed a series of alliances with similar small galleries in the Netherlands and in Germany and began to exchange work. He got married the same year to the ballet dancer Angela Beveridge. They have two daughters, Anya, 24, who works on the online edition of the Macmillan Dictionary of Art and Beth, 23, at Edinburgh University studying sociology and anthropology. The marriage broke up in 1993. Serota married Teresa Gleadowe, a friend from Cambridge and former head of information at the Tate, in 1997. Gleadowe, who has two daughters, is director of the MA course in curating and visual arts administration at the Royal College of Art. After three years in Oxford he moved to the Whitechapel Gallery. Joanna Drew, who as director of art at the Arts Council has nurtured a whole generation of gallery curators, remembers him as a brilliant figure in a very bright generation. "When he went to Oxford he put the whole museum on its feet. It was struggling and he established the nature of the place and its pro gramme. He had the same effect on the Whitechapel. He was associated with minimalism but he also put on a remarkable exhibition of Max Beckmann and one on Hawksmoor. He re-established its credibility as a serious venue for serious exhibitions." Under Bryan Robertson's regime in the 50s and 60s, Whitechapel had been the premier gallery for showing contemporary art in Britain. By the time Serota arrived it was suffering the consequences of a turf war between the Hayward, the Tate and the ICA, its grant had been cut and it had had three directors in five years. Serota, however, saw a sleeping giant, particularly as it was so well placed to tap into the geographical shift of artists moving to east London. One of the first things he did was appoint a community education worker who promoted contact with local schools and hospitals, a revolutionary appointment in those days, and began to attract a new audience to the gallery. He staged some extremely controversial shows featuring work by Baselitz, Richard Long and, in 1978, Carl André. The Tate had been vilified for acquiring André's sculpture, Equivalent VIII, two years earlier, when the neatly arranged collection of bricks became a by-word for the absurdity of modern art. "That was one of the reasons for doing an André show," he says. "I didn't think he had been given a fair crack of the whip after the Tate bricks row." By the time the Tate job became vacant in 1988, Serota was the obvious candidate. Michael Craig Martin says, "from the minute he arrived he did two things that were significant. He physically transformed the gallery by stripping the building back to its original architectural framework. And then he completely reorganised the hanging of the collection. Those two acts carry over to what you will see in Bankside." Denis Stevenson, chair of the trustees throughout most of the 90s, says people don't remember how contentious re-hanging the collection was. Rodin's The Thinker was removed, and hasn't been seen since, as were other favourites. "The first re-hang was extraordinarily controversial. Rather like the re-hang at Millbank is now. But it was clearly strategically correct. The audience doubled. You don't go back to the cinema to see the same film every week, and it's the same with paintings." Having worked for nearly 20 years on temporary exhibitions Serota was relishing the opportunities offered by the Tate. Since he arrived, visitor numbers have increased from 1.1m to 2.6m a year. It is anticipated that Tate Modern will attract 2m visitors on its own. "The moments when the Tate has authority in the contemporary world is when it is respected by artists, putting on interesting shows and buying good work," he says. "I wanted to create one of those moment. I was also increasingly interested in building a collection." He remembers that when he arrived, people at the Tate were apprehensive because he had never run an organisation with more than 20 people. "Looking back I can see why they were apprehensive." Stevenson, also chairman of Pearson and the Halifax, says Serota is a natural: "he is the manager from central casting. He has natural authority and can just do it. If he wanted to and was available, I wouldn't hesitate to give him a great chunk of Pearson or the Halifax." Serota says he wasn't apprehensive in artistic terms. "Not because I thought I was infallible, but I had become used to making choices and statements through the art I showed. I knew I would be criticised and occasionally praised but I had served an apprenticeship in being roasted by the press and by artists and sometimes by other colleagues. It doesn't mean that you are impervious to criticism, but you get used to the notion that you can't please all the people all the time." His most persistent critic has been Brian Sewell who used a show held last year, Abracadabra, to illustrate all that is wrong with Serota's Tate. "It was a prime example of the hocus-pocus and mumbo jumbo by which the false intellectuals of the art world are able to 'hey presto!' anything into art, be it the dung of elephants, the video of a medical camera's examination of an artist's uterus, anus and digestive tract, an erect cucumber projecting from a stained mattress, or a dead horse suspended from a dome." In calling for Serota to be sacked he said that, "the curators of this exhibition know nothing of empathy, catharsis or the elevation of the spirit, nothing of intellectual nourishment, nothing of awe and wonder, nothing of what is to be derived from, for example, the great Titians in the National Gallery." The director of the National Gallery, Neil MacGregor, may agree with Sewell about the glory of Titian, but he is also a firm supporter of Serota. MacGregor sees Serota's key achievement as at last solving the historical compromise of the Tate. The gallery was founded by sugar magnate Henry Tate in 1897 as The National Gallery of British Art. Following a major bequest of modern French art in 1916, including many important impressionist paintings, it formally took on the remit for international modern art the following year. "The huge task at the Tate was always to clarify that split," says MacGregor. "Nick's achievement has been a lucidity of analysis in sorting out the different roles and then an astonishing capacity to make it a reality. London will benefit from the huge gain in clarity. Everyone will know where the 20th century collection is." In making the split Serota has been conscious that Tate Britain might be overshadowed by its bright new sister space. Symbolically he has decided to keep his office at Millbank and the annual Turner Prize show will still be based there. The prize has been the single most significant element in raising the profile of contemporary art in Britain. It was founded in 1984 but by 1990 it was dead on its feet and was suspended. Five of the first six winners had appeared on the very first shortlist and the public had lost interest. In 1991 Channel 4 stepped in and the prize was limited to artists under 50. "Which meant it was on live television and artists in their 30s started to win it," recalls Michael Craig Martin. "Now a young audience thinks of contemporary art in the same way as previous generations thought about the cinema, the theatre or literature. Art has become another central component of cultural life." But Serota knows that simply basing the prize at Millbank won't in itself generate interest in Tate Britain. "I do need to give some tender loving care to a few places that have missed out over the last year or so. They will get it. The challenge now is make Tate Britain a place where British artists really want to see their work shown." Turner prize short-listed artist Cornelia Parker will have a piece of her work in the opening collection at Tate Modern but is enthusiastic about Tate Britain. "Now is a good time to change how we think about Britain and the idea that there will be a museum for art made in Britain reflects the confidence and changes in British art over the last decade or so. It will show how British art is not such an exclusive club any more." As part of the effort to balance the different arms of the Tate, each gallery has its own director. Stephen Deuchar, formally at the National Maritime Museum, is in charge at Tate Britain and the Swedish curator Lars Nittve will run Tate Modern. One industry observer notes that, "Serota has a reputation for wanting to control things and there are potential problems with the two directors beneath him. When looking at Bankside one of the most interesting things will be to see how much Serota allows the new director to do the work and who will make the big decisions. Intellectually I'm sure he wants to allow the two directors a reasonable degree of latitude. But I suspect in practice the temptation of wanting to control things will continue. After all it was his idea and he raised the money." Serota says his job is to, "encourage, support and act as a second pair of eyes. But I would find it difficult to walk away from the hands-on side of the job and not be directly involved. In the last few weeks I have spent some time hanging works at Tate Modern with Lars. But clearly it is his gallery." In fact one of Serota's triumphs has been how few rows he has had despite pushing the organisation so quickly forward. The history of the Tate is littered with stories of carnage as directors and trustees continually fell out. But in Serota's time there seem to have been remarkably few rows. He laughs that there were bad periods in the 50s, the late 70s and the mid 80s. "So we're just about due for another one now." A former member of staff confirms the effectiveness of his personal skills. "Quite often major donors want to impose conditions on gifts. Nick is very good at finessing things so that they fit in with the Tate's strategy. And he uses his aura and mystique to add to the attractiveness. Equally he is very approachable to his staff, and you don't need to pussyfoot around him." People close to him say that his apparently buttoned up on-duty persona is only part of the story. His Who's Who entry used to rather depressingly list his recreation as "hanging paintings". Now it makes no mention of recreation at all, but he enjoys sailing dinghies and there are stories of him as an energetic dancer at the office party - with a fondness for the music of Little Richard. He says that while he works hard, he's no workaholic. "I still take holidays, I have a few friends. I tremendously enjoy the company of artists," he laughs. "I have spent my working life working with them and I wouldn't be in this job if it didn't include talking about art and talking to artists." This feeds into an evangelical enthusiasm for what galleries can do. "Here is something that by its very nature should be interesting to huge numbers of people and we want to make it available to them. But in the end there is little point in encouraging people to come to the Tate unless they find something that interests them or irritates them or that they find beautiful. It's not a question of liking everything. I don't like everything in the Tate. "But it's not an industry. It's a form of educational experience and of self discovery. It's the reason one can justify using taxpayers money to support and sustain a great institution." People speak of Serota's sense of moral duty in accounting for the way public money is spent. He has been a passionate advocate of increased accessibility and a recently announced joint web-site project with New York's Museum of Modern Art is part of that agenda. He has also been prominent in the campaign to reject admission charges to museums. Neil MacGregor says Serota's role in changing the perception of modern art has been enormous. "He has made it into something that a very large number of people are interested in and want to come and look at. It is no longer a minority or fringe interest. And that is true right across the country. I suspect he has played the leading part in that. He has almost stopped Britain being afraid of contemporary art." The "almost" is important. As chairman of the Turner prize judges, Serota is well aware that annual displays of outrage at the shortlist and periodic personal attacks on him are a sign that there remains much more hand-holding of the public to be done. "Occasionally I get irritated with the criticism," he says, "but I probably also have myself to blame for being seen as someone who will support new developments in contemporary art. If you do that you will be regarded as only being interested in those things. But that's the life of the director of the Tate. I've got no complaints." Life at a glance Nicholas Andrew Serota Born: April 27 1946, London. Education: Haberdasher's Aske's school; Christ's College, Cambridge; Courtauld Institute. Married: 1973 Angela Beveridge (two daughters, Anya and Beth), divorced 1995; 1997 Teresa Gleadowe. Career: Exhibition director, Arts Council1970-73; director, Oxford Museum of Modern Art 1973-76; director, Whitechapel Art Gallery 1976-88; director, Tate Gallery 1988-. Other posts: member, visual arts advisory committee of the British Council 1976-98, chairman 1992-98; trustee, Architecture Foundation 1991-99; Commission for Architecture and the Built Environment. Publications: 1997, Walter Neurath Lecture, Experience or Interpretation; The Dilemma of Museums of Modern Art. Honours: Knighted in 1999; honorary fellow, Royal Institute of British Architects, 1992.  Tate Modern opens on May 12

fields.headline: Mortal fins
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark on the moody menaces in and out of the water that pervade Robert Drewes' The Shark Net
fields.trailText: Alex Clark on the moody menaces in and out of the water that pervade Robert Drewes' The Shark Net
fields.body:
The Shark Net: Memories and Murder
Robert Drewe Hamish Hamilton, £9.99, 358pp
Buy it at BOL

Oddly, given its title, sharks do not dominate Robert Drewe's memoir of his west Australian boyhood. There is a relatively harmless carpet shark that the 16-year-old narrator pierces through the brain and then drags, as it leaks foul-smelling blood and distintegrating guts all over him, to the front doorstep of the girl he fancies. Her father alerts her thus: "Mr High Society's here wearing a fish." (She, as one might expect, is faintly repelled by this peculiar trophy, and makes her excuses.)

Then there are the requiem sharks that, during his stint as a cadet reporter, Drewe attempts to drum up into a reputation-building feature, only to be thwarted by the bathetic pronouncements of a sanguine ichthyologist. Alas: you've several hundred thousand times more chance of dying in a car crash on the way to the beach than in the jaws of a shark.

Despite this lack of real-life piscine danger, the book is suffused with a wonderfully achieved sense of menace. Events are quietly encircled by a mysterious malice, most obviously suggested by the "murder" of the subtitle, which refers to a serial killer who terrorises suburban Perth during the 1950s, chopping up women as they lie sleeping, shooting teenage boys through the head, peering in through steamed-up car windows to catch couples necking and mowing down young women who are innocently crossing the road.

Drewe was closer to the murderer, Eric Cooke, than many (although he points out that once he was apprehended, everyone rushed to claim some sort of link with him: in gossipy small-town society, there is little division between celebrity and notoriety). The hare-lipped, speech-impaired Cooke had delivered dining-room chairs to the Drewe family house (delivering in the process a gnomic utterance about bicycle pumps giving you warts), and had killed one of Robert's chums. And then, in his cub reporting days, Drewe found himself on the receiving end of a chilling wink from Cooke in the dock - an unwanted gesture of complicity that he automatically returned.

Cooke's misdeeds feature sporadically in the book, alongside separate sections attempting to imagine what was going on in his head. It's no surprise to find out that he was an ugly, resentful man, knocked about as a kid by his drunken father, not much of a dad to his own seven children, and obsessed with women. There is a powerful moment towards the end when Drewe interviews Cooke's widow and asks her how she felt during the final moments before her husband's execution. She had been getting the children ready for school, and hadn't noticed the appointed hour come and go. Her next-door neighbour came over and asked her if she felt like crying. "No, no," she replied, "maybe later."

This macabre drama frames the book but, despite its headline-grabbing horror, it is not its life and breath. Far more sustaining is the other half of the subtitle - the memories, largely concerned with childhood. Drewe had been transplanted from Melbourne to Perth at the age of six, tracking his father's trajectory as a rising star in the mighty Dunlop corporation. Rubber products dominated his youth, from the unfashionable Bumper leisure shoes that made an appearance under every Christmas tree to tyres, hoses and novelty ashtrays. Drewe Sr was fond of reminding his wife that when he proposed to her, he warned her that she was marrying the company as well as him. Ever the perfect consort, she took her somewhat acid comfort in teaching the budgerigar to say "Today You'll Use a Dunlop Product."

Drewe captures perfectly the way businessmen like his father colonised the alien landscape of west Australia, braving the shifting sand dunes and treacherous coastline to educate the suburbs in the ways of company cocktail parties, tennis tournaments and factory visits. Their children, of course, marvelled at the freedom of the wild, and much amusing, poignant tension derives from the older generation's nervous attempts to inhibit the excesses of juvenile enthusiasm. The Drewe children were continually being lectured on the perils of the undertow and of sun-broiled brains, all the while marvelling at the bravado of the native kids, who were known to peel strips of desiccated skin from shoulder to shoulder and eat them.

In this sensitive and delicately realised memoir, these local details accumulate to give a much wider picture, not only of 1950s Australia, but of the fragile ecology of a family. On the surface young Robert's relationship with his parents is fairly straightforward, a recognisable mixture of affection, embarrassment and covert rebellion. Yet Drewe himself is a master of the undertow, and his subtle, suggestive recollections transform boyish tales into a far more original, affecting meditation on the nature of childhood itself.

There is a tremendous tenderness in his depiction of the comedies of family life, but those comedies exist alongside a welter of unreconciled differences and outbreaks of ungovernable tragedy. The apprehension of the murderer and the revelation of his proximity to the Drewe family is a beautifully turned counterpoint to domestic events: the frisson of excitement and the accompanying shame, the sense of random, irrevocable actions, propel Robert into adulthood as surely and as fast as his shotgun wedding to his girlfriend.

Drewe grew up to become a writer of novels, short stories and plays, and this book is as much about the development of a writer's sensibility, the ability to make connections and to become alive to mood and atmosphere, as it is about sharks and murders and Dunlop tyres - although I'll never attempt to ride a bicycle with a dead shark strapped to my back.

fields.headline: Travel books
fields.trailText: What the punters want is a book that will tell them where to find the loo in the Louvre
fields.body:
Some little while ago, mostly when Bruce Chatwin was wandering about the Australian outback, travel writing was the new rock'n'roll. But take a look at this little listing, and you'll see that the Rabans, Thubrons and Moorhouses can do their worst, but they'll never compete with a book telling you how to find the lav in Montmartre or where to get the best spliff in Amsterdam.

Straightforward guides are where it's at, unless your bag is ogling the homes of the super-rich, in which case Judith Miller's Great Escapes will give you a bad case of pelmet envy. The top two, by the way, are an interiors boffin's guide to never staying anywhere that hasn't been designed by Anouska Hempel, Philippe Starck or Karl Lagerfeld. But if none of this strikes you as very horizon-broadening, turn to the inner journey instead: in possibly the oddest definition of the travel book, the Dalai Lama tells it like it is, with handy meditation tips.

Herbert Ypma
(Thames & Hudson, £18.95)
Buy it at BOL

Herbert Ypma
(Thames & Hudson, £18.95)

fields.headline: Would we know Lenin today?
fields.standfirst: Gary Younge on Robert Service's biography of Lenin and why the revolutionary remains an enigma
fields.trailText: Gary Younge on Robert Service's biography of Lenin and why the revolutionary remains an enigma
fields.body:
Lenin
Robert Service
Macmillan, £25, 592pp
Buy it at BOL

For several years a faction of the Kurdish liberation movement, the PKK, used to meet twice a week in a McDonald's in Hackney. Over coffee and McNuggets they would discuss, with great intensity, the situation back home, berating the PKK leadership and each other for their vacillations and/or deviations from whatever line they had adopted on the struggle. Occasionally they would develop strategy for their comrades in "the field".

It was a curious but inspiring sight: here were people who lived, ate and slept liberation. Their dedication to the cause was in no way diminished by their exile and in many ways enhanced by it. East London is a long way from the battlefields of what remains eastern Turkey and yet, if they had doubts about their purpose, they were not apparent. True, their bodies were in a fast-food chain in Hackney, but all their hopes and their passions were for Kurdistan.

Whenever I saw them I thought of Lenin. We know him as the leader of the Bolshevik revolution; one of a handful of politicians who shaped 20th-century history. But for almost two decades before the revolution he would have looked like just one more Russian emigré sitting among many of his kind in a Swiss, British, French or German cafe. Here was a man who had scarcely held down a full-time job, who was almost completely unheard-of in his native land, but who pledged: "Give us an organisation of revolutionaries and we'll turn all of Russia upside down."

Herein lies the strength of Robert Service's biography. With the help of previously unpublished documents recently released from central party archives, he has managed skilfully to depict the surreal life of an obsessive, brilliant and stubborn individual who usually found himself the champion of the minority opinion within a minority of just a small number of revolutionaries - who, for most of their lives, did not have a revolution in sight.

A man whose perspective (or lack of it) was such that during the most brutal period of the first world war, when the trenches were filling up with corpses and an uprising looked possible in Germany, he turned to the philosophy of Hegel and Aristotle in a search for essential truth. An ideologue who, like the Kurds in McDonald's, had to concentrate on doctrine because his ultimate goal remained so remote in so many ways.

Service explains how Lenin was sustained by his Marxist faith: "Through Marx and Engels he 'knew' that the future would bring about a final and wonderful stage in world history. His life had purpose. Lenin clung to a rock of attitudes and assumptions, and on it he was able to construct almost any notions of politics and economics he wanted."

Where Service is weakest is in analysing the value of these political and economic notions when the goal - revolution - became more attainable. Like many Russian historians and biographers of Lenin, he demands far higher moral, economic and political standards of the system that the revolution brought in than of the one it replaced. He continually describes Lenin as "amoral" because his key priority during the turbulent years of the revolution was not fairness but defence of the revolution itself - as though any other state, then or since, has had moral ideals that transcend self-preservation. He criticises Lenin for his dictatorial tendencies as though he were ruling an established democracy in peacetime rather than a ravaged nation emerging from autocracy, at war first with itself and then with foreign powers.

Not that there are not severe criticisms to be made. Lenin in particular and the Bolsheviks in general made many mistakes, some of them unforgivable, which set the tone for dictatorship and repression for the rest of the century. Given that, at least in theory, they were attempting something nobody had ever tried before - to build a country based not on profit but on the collective power of the poor - this is not surprising. But they did not find themselves at the helm by chance. The Bolsheviks promised peace when nobody else would and seized power when nobody else dared. One may argue about what they did with it when they arrived, but it is impossible to ignore the reasons why they got there and the insurrectionary route they had to take to achieve it.

Biographies of Lenin tend to canonise or demonise him; Service, to his credit, does neither, although his assertion in the introduction that too many works "give him the benefit of too many doubts" leaves one in little doubt that he approaches his subject with more than just a critical historical eye.

In The Age of Extremes Eric Hobsbawm argues that, compared with the move from agricultural to industrial labour, "the history of the confrontation between 'capitalism' and 'socialism'... will probably seem of more limited historical interest - comparable in the long run to the 16th- and 17th-century wars of religion or the Crusades". Occasionally they would develop strategy for their comrades in "the field". It was a curious but inspiring sight: here were people who lived, ate and slept liberation. Their dedication to the cause was in no way diminished by their exile and in many ways enhanced by it. East London is a long way from the battlefields of what remains eastern Turkey and yet, if they had doubts about their purpose, they were not apparent. True, their bodies were in a fast-food chain in Hackney, but all their hopes and their passions were for Kurdistan. Whenever I saw them I thought of Lenin. We know him as the leader of the Bolshevik revolution; one of a handful of politicians who shaped 20th-century history. But for almost two decades before the revolution he would have looked like just one more Russian emigré sitting among many of his kind in a Swiss, British, French or German cafe. fields.headline: The Cookham Resurrection and Simpleton
fields.trailText:
A boatload of the resurrected
trailing amazement,
cast off, second-chancing
from a Berkshire village...
fields.body:
The Cookham Resurrection

A boatload of the resurrected
trailing amazement,
cast off, second-chancing
from a Berkshire village.

See how hesitantly
they renew acquaintance,
dipping earth-stained fingers
in the holy Thames.

Then home to homeliness,
a step up from the tow-path,
sure of their ground
and all they left behind.

To resume in the rinsed
clarity of vision what before
seemed daily, good bread
risen to angel food.

Going once more about
their business, love's
transfiguration of each trade
or sturdy labour

in a field of praise
contiguous with heaven
where the gate stands open
and they pass between.

Simpleton

They stopped him on his way to the fair
and asked impossible questions.
I don't know he answered, one by one,
but with a simple grin they might
find fetching. Not a bit of it. Their laughter
thundered overhead, a dark cloud
gathering impatience. Then there rained
such blows on him he knew for sure
he'd never get there. We could tell you
everything, they said, but this is better
and was worth the wait. At that
he lay face down and took it, weeping
earthwards. One by one
the stars came out, and then the moon
was there, by now too late
for anything but shining vacantly
on all of them. The road ahead
returned a distant music and the pulse
of love until whatever started this
was over. Now if he doesn't know
he heard them say, he'll never, as they
left him, as he rose and stood there
shrouded in the certainty of pain,
remembering the questions. Then
towards him, innocently decked
with ribbons from the fair, a girl
came dancing and she broke his heart.
