fields.headline: Here be monsters
fields.standfirst: Andrew Rissik  finds the true stories behind  Moby Dick as enthralling as the novel
fields.trailText: Andrew Rissik finds the true stories behind Moby Dick as enthralling as the novel
fields.body:
In the Heart of the Sea
Nathaniel Philbrick
HarperCollins, £16.99, 292pp

Buy it at BOL

Shipwreck of the Whaleship Essex
Owen Chase Pimlico, £8, 160pp
Buy it at BOL

Great literature always internalises its landscapes: it turns the physical world into a mirror of the mind's private affliction. Of no natural phenomenon is this truer than of the sea, that eternal metaphor for psychological isolation and self-reliance. Seafaring is what happens to the human soul when it cuts itself free of the moorings of society and its stabilising codes of permitted behaviour. Out there, upon a wilderness of ocean, the human psyche makes a reckoning with its own essential loneliness.

All the great sailors of literature - from Odysseus and the Anglo-Saxon Seafarer to Coleridge's Ancient Mariner, Melville's Ahab, Tennyson's Ulysses and Conrad's Lord Jim - are fleeing insanity, yet heading into it at the same time. The sea, eternally changing and eternally the same, reflects back at them some circularity in their own nature, a longing for fulfilment which recedes further the more they try to achieve it. Exiled from peace of mind and their own hearts by a lust or curse that they cannot expiate, they break deep and ancient taboos.

Few writers have felt this superstition more deeply, or handled it with a more self-conscious and driven intensity, than Herman Melville. Melville's extraordinary prose - with its restless struggle for a metaphysics of meaning lying deeper than words - makes every action of the human and natural world into a revelation of the battle between heaven and the demonic.

His most famous stories are parables of the sea's power to realise a dammed-up, primitive evil which then spreads like a stain. In Billy Budd an angelic-seeming young sailor accidentally kills the ship's evil master-at-arms and is then executed by the queasy, temporising Captain Vere - who claims to believe in Budd's innocence, or beauty of soul, but also (as Melville unflinchingly recognises) wants to see him die. In Moby Dick the albino sperm whale on which the Nantucket whaling vessel Pequod 's Captain Ahab is seeking revenge for the loss of his leg becomes a living, breathing monster from the id, the embodiment of what Ahab, for all his profane fury, cannot resolve - his ruinous, corrupt, self-maiming ambition.

Because literature thrives on metaphor, it is easy to forget that it begins elsewhere, in the real, tangible and self-evident. Nathaniel Philbrick's superbly readable new work of popular maritime history, In The Heart Of The Sea, gives us, in fascinating detail, the stark, bloodstained true story which Melville raided and then rebuilt to his own grandiose poetical specifications in Moby Dick, yet it never ignores the wider imaginative context - the ingrained, inexplicable superstitions of sea folklore that lend Melville's work its atmosphere of predestined moral tragedy.

In November 1820 the whaling ship Essex, from the New England island of Nantucket, was shattered and sunk, far out in the Pacific, by an 85ft sperm whale. The bloodiness of the whaling expeditions was notorious, comparable to anything which befell the bison of the American plains. The kill - in which the whalers circled the doomed creature in rowing boats, striking at it with harpoons like Lilliputian matadors - was protracted and revoltingly inefficient.

Worse still was the stench and gore which washed over the ship as the dead mammal was winched alongside, its blubber ripped from its carcass in a huge, dripping strip - Philbrick likens this process to the peeling of a gigantic orange - and approximately 500 gallons of valuable spermaceti oil, which would later be used to light the streetlamps of London, drained from the brain cavity of its decapitated head.

It was filthy work, but full of atavistic excitement and the promise of high financial reward. It was also, under normal circumstances, free of any serious risk that the quarry would fight back. What astonished the crew of the Essex was their particular whale's mystifying belligerence. According to the ship's first mate, 23-year-old Owen Chase, it attacked at an angle ominously "calculated to do us the most injury" and, by repeatedly ramming the hull, left the vessel mortally damaged.

The crew of the Essex were now in what Captain Scott might have described as a very tight place, dispersed in three small whaleboats in the middle of the Pacific with desperately limited supplies. Chase, normally a resourceful man, was temporarily broken by the experience. In the journal he wrote afterwards - and which is now republished by Pimlico - all the old sea superstitions come boiling to the surface. "Unaccountable destiny" is to blame, perhaps God Himself; "anything but chance".

In the days that followed, Chase suffered joltingly vivid flashbacks as "the horrid aspect and revenge of the whale wholly engrossed my reflections". What Coleridge, coming at annihilating psychic trauma through the allegories of art, had described figuratively in The Ancient Mariner, Chase underwent literally, in an open boat 1,000 miles from land. From these recurrent, plaguing memories Melville created not merely Ahab and the drama of the Pequod, but an idea of the sea as an ocean of the mind where our darkest impulses assume vengeful physical life. He knew that ultimately, human beings are wounded worst by their own imaginations.

In the end, unable to find their way out of the arid wastes of the sea after months of scorching thirst and emaciating starvation, the survivors of the Essex resorted to cannibalism. In Chase's boat they fed only upon the flesh of those who had already died; but in another the Essex 's captain, George Pollard, permitted lots to be drawn and his own cousin to be shot in the head, dismembered and eaten. One of the strengths of Philbrick's book is that incidents like this - which are only glanced at in Chase's journal, partly because he did not personally witness them and partly because they offended his Quaker conscience - are reinvestigated and given proper context and weight.

Pollard emerges as a well-meaning but weak man, too easily swayed by the headstrong opinions of others and morally unequal to the "sinister violence of intention", the unforgiving fickleness of fortune, which Joseph Conrad later thought was the supreme test of the sea against human nature. After the ordeal was over, he was given command of another whaling ship, which was promptly wrecked on a coral reef off the Hawaiian Islands. After this Pollard was never again trusted with a ship, and he ended his days on shore, low down the social scale, as Nantucket's night-watchman. "I was lost on an infinite sea," sings the guilt-stricken captain Vere in Benjamin Britten's opera of Billy Budd. So too were Pollard, Chase and the men of the Essex.

What's impressive about In the Heart of the Sea is its power to suggest that tragedy is what happens when men cannot rise above themselves. Neither the group of sailors Bligh had famously led across the Pacific without charts after being cast adrift from the Bounty, nor the crew Shackleton miraculously rescued from death in the Weddell Sea by crossing South Georgia on foot, finished up the way the survivors of the Essex did - in blood-blackened boats, gnawing human bones.

Literature feeds on something uncontainable in such stories. Beginning in adventure and ending on the shores of hell, they stand for all lives in which everything goes wrong, where men are powerless to halt their slide into moral squalor. Probably it was this lack of heroism that obsessed Melville most, and that ultimately prefigured Conrad's unblinking stare into "the heart of an immense darkness". Philbrick's book is more than a piece of elegantly written maritime history or an illuminating addition to the story of Melville's artistic development. It is a compelling study of the infinite human meanings of the sea itself.

fields.headline: Warrior of the Trojan horse
fields.standfirst: Child-abuse campaigner Andrew Vachss tells Nick Hasted of fiction's power
fields.trailText: Child-abuse campaigner Andrew Vachss tells Nick Hasted of fiction's power
fields.body:
When Andrew Vachss was seven, a teenage stranger in his New York neighbourhood attacked him with a chain, damaging an eye so badly that he has ever since had to wear a patch. He felt so loved growing up in his tough little world that he told himself it was an aberration.

Then, when he was 21 and working as a Federal Investigator in sexual diseases, he met a baby-rapist; when he found out there were more, his focus tightened on what he saw as a curable plague. With ferocious purpose, he directed himself to removing predatory paedophiles from society. He also became involved with the campaign to save children in Biafra and ran a prison for murderous juveniles. Finally, he settled as a lawyer, who would take only child cases, and as a writer.

Vachss's crime novels are set in a New York recast as hell, a literal underworld of icy wasteground etched in red flame, where his hero, abuse victim Burke, lives an outcast existence with his chosen "family" - a mute giant, a dwarf genius, a transsexual - preying on predators, on the human capacity for cruel pleasure that Vachss calls "the Beast". Shella (1993), his only non-Burke novel, saw a sociopath search for his soul, finding it in love for a woman skeletal from Aids, caught by sucking the blood of murdered paedophiles. The prose was not so much lurid as desolate.

Vachss has written comics and non-fiction, too. His appearance on the Oprah Winfrey Show was instrumental in Bill Clinton signing the National Child Protection Act. But the Burke books, spare and angry, intended to document their hero's numb decline, remain his convictions' major outlet (in the new Safe House, stalkers and Nazis are fought).

The greatest threat to his campaign loomed the day it began - when Vachss met that baby-rapist and nearly lost it. "My first reaction was literally seeing myself snapping this person's neck like you'd kill a chicken," he remembers, "I had never felt such rage. And I realised in the same moment that if I were not completely calm, I would lose every opportunity to ever do anything about this. That desperate calm, and the subsequent experiences with which I was bombarded, cauterised my nerve endings. So not much affects me. I don't get extremely happy or extremely sad. That was the price I paid."

In Safe House, Burke reaches for "the ice inside me" - much as his creator does in his law work. "If you think about what a child's been through, about how someone can torture something they gave birth to, you'll be lost," says Vacchs. "Getting control of my temperament as a teenager was the key to everything I've been able to do. I was already engaged in a process of self-control. I'd seen too many people in my neighbourhood end badly. But my only purpose back then was to shoot pool, chase girls. After I met that baby-rapist, everything took the same path."

Did he feel he had a choice ? "No. The way religious people talk about getting a call - that's what it felt like to me. It was a message I couldn't ignore. I couldn't have lived with myself." Vachss's first response was to enter Biafra's tribal inferno. Stung by seeing "waves of children starving on TV, at an age where the grandiose idea I could save them overwhelmed me," he took vast risks to set up supply lines.

The chaos of the Nigerian civil war doomed his efforts, but as he struggled, defining images seared him: of a child asking why he was running during an air-raid, when the bombs couldn't see him, and he'd die anyway. And of a hungry, hunted woman snatching up an abandoned baby hours from inevitable, starved death, and holding it to her breast, so it would die loved. "I've seen the best of people as well as the worst," Vachss says.

The Burke books have been criticised for their zero-tolerance of sexual predators. But when Vachss talks of his own chance to administer rough justice, taking over a maximum-security prison for juveniles, his desire to save as many as possible, rather than simply punish them, is clear. The textbook he wrote on his methods is still used. The fiction followed, influenced by pulp writers like David Goodis and Paul Cain, as well as by Iceberg Slim and blues records.

He has always seen his novels not so much as art as like "Trojan horses" - a way of smuggling his views into the popular consciousness. The brutal beauty of a book like Hard Candy (1989) is, he claims, "fortuitous". Writing causes him pain not pleasure, unearthing bad memories. His work as a whole has left him physically and emotionally injured, under permanent threat from the enemies he has made along the way. The way he tells it, it sounds a sacrificial life.

"It gives me too much credit to call it sacrifice," he says. "I don't do what I do because I love children, I do it because I hate those who prey on them. So the sacrifice is to my hatred, not my love. It hasn't affected my life that much. I have good security on numerous levels." He also has what he calls his "brothers and sisters - warriors who are my family of choice". It makes him sound like Burke, living in his safe house. Does that mean that, at 57, he's subject to his character's exhaustion?

No, he says. "I don't ever feel exhausted by the struggle, because the victories have been higher than I fantasised. I've seen a kid who by every measure was fated to be a serial killer rescued, and become a loving parent. Public attitudes have changed. Any cost I've paid seems fair. I have a cardiogram on my website, to show my heart still beating. But my life is my work, and I expect that to go on, long after I'm dead."

Did he feel he had a choice ? "No. The way religious people talk about getting a call - that's what it felt like to me. It was a message I couldn't ignore. I couldn't have lived with myself." Vachss's first response was to enter Biafra's tribal inferno. Stung by seeing "waves of children starving on TV, at an age where the grandiose idea I could save them overwhelmed me," he took vast risks to set up supply lines. The chaos of the Nigerian civil war doomed his efforts, but as he struggled, defining images seared him: of a child asking why he was running during an air-raid, when the bombs couldn't see him, and he'd die anyway. And of a hungry, hunted woman snatching up an abandoned baby hours from inevitable, starved death, and holding it to her breast, so it would die loved. "I've seen the best of people as well as the worst," Vachss says. The Burke books have been criticised for their zero-tolerance of sexual predators. But when Vachss talks of his own chance to administer rough justice, taking over a maximum-security prison for juveniles, his desire to save as many as possible, rather than simply punish them, is clear. The textbook he wrote on his methods is still used. The fiction followed, influenced by pulp writers like David Goodis and Paul Cain, as well as by Iceberg Slim and blues records. He has always seen his novels not so much as art as like "Trojan horses" - a way of smuggling his views into the popular consciousness. The brutal beauty of a book like Hard Candy (1989) is, he claims, "fortuitous". Writing causes him pain not pleasure, unearthing bad memories. His work as a whole has left him physically and emotionally injured, under permanent threat from the enemies he has made along the way. The way he tells it, it sounds a sacrificial life. "It gives me too much credit to call it sacrifice," he says. "I don't do what I do because I love children, I do it because I hate those who prey on them. So the sacrifice is to my hatred, not my love. It hasn't affected my life that much. I have good security on numerous levels." He also has what he calls his "brothers and sisters - warriors who are my family of choice". It makes him sound like Burke, living in his safe house. Does that mean that, at 57, he's subject to his character's exhaustion? No, he says. "I don't ever feel exhausted by the struggle, because the victories have been higher than I fantasised. I've seen a kid who by every measure was fated to be a serial killer rescued, and become a loving parent. Public attitudes have changed. Any cost I've paid seems fair. I have a cardiogram on my website, to show my heart still beating. But my life is my work, and I expect that to go on, long after I'm dead."

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: What the women in the bible were really like, plus Alone of All Her Sex and The Alphabet and the Goddess
fields.body:
The Word According to Eve
Cullen Murphy
(Penguin, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

All about Eve and her Biblical sisters, and about the scholars, mostly female, who have lately inquired of potsherd, scroll and cuneiform-tablet prime sources whether the women of the scriptures really were what we have made of them. Or rather, what 2,000 years of all-male interpretation made them: supine, servile, sexual or sexless objects - trouble anyway, ever since that incident with the apple, and never the chosen norm. Rigorous, vigorous, and wide in reference: quotes a study on Hollywood's Bible titled "Throw Them to the Lions, Sire", as well as the wise who hope at most to glimpse the female past through a crack in the door, clearly.

Alone of All Her Sex
Marina Warner
(Vintage, £9.99)
Buy it at BOL

Warner's 1976 study of the Virgin Mary cult: art and social history rather than religion, and less novel in approach than on first publication; we are all used now to the personal passing painfully into the Vatican political. But Warner's new preface confessing why she did it surprises - on a Vietnamese road to a Marian shrine, she and the hackpack met the napalmed (recall the famous photograph), and she felt compelled to investigate Mary's consoling powers. Her research remains unequalled, though the style is irritatingly winsome, as if written with head tilted and eyes looking up from under: gosh, God, it's only little me. You've come a long way, Warner.

The Alphabet and the Goddess
Leonard Shlain
(Penguin, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

Amateur scholarship by an eminent San Franciscan professor of surgery. He excitedly proposes that the stimulation of the masculine, abstract functions of the left-brain hemisphere by the invention of the first alphabet (he is certain it was Hebrew) ended the worship of the Mediterranean Great Goddesses. Literacy led to patriarchy, female repression and butchissimo madnesses including witch-burning and the Russian revolution. Euro- and US-centric, with a concept of primeval hunter-gatherers based on early Tarzan movies, and for all the New Agey phrases about balancing yin and yang, patronising of women. Barking, frankly. But with infrequent acute insights.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A subversive take on the historical novel, plus Ink, Old Soldiers and The Mercy Boys
fields.body:
Manly Pursuits
Ann Harries
(Bloomsbury, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Autumn 1874, and Francis Lewis takes his camera out of Oxford to record the building of John Ruskin's Hinksey Road. He happens to get a shot of Oscar Wilde, Cecil Rhodes and Alfred Milner toiling for the sake of art, and then bumps into fellow amateur photographer Charles Dodgson, who invites him in for tea. Other eminent Victorians cross paths with almost comic regularity in Harries's farce, which sweeps across the intellectual debates and scandals of the day. Lewis, the fastidious Oxford botanist around whom history revolves, is a beautifully comic creation in the vein of Stoppard. Harries has subverted the genre of historical faction with admirable restraint.

Ink
John Preston
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

In a stroll down Fleet Street in the days when presses thundered, typewriters clattered and journos drank for a living, Preston stirs up nostalgia for hot metal with affection. His hero, Hugh, is an unhappy hack with writer's block when the news editor sends him out to write up the story of a Thames suicide. Tracking down the true identity of the body is only part of the story; mostly we get a Dickensesque picture of London circa 1989 in a pea-souper of times past, and a comic meditation on the discontents of being a male of a certain age. Preston's evocation of the newspaper is high gothic fantasy, heavy on colour and entertaining in a weekend-supplement way.

 Isobel Montgomery

Old Soldiers
Paul Bailey
(Fourth Estate, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

This tiny gem of a novel was first published 20 years ago, and its reissue is cause for much celebration. Bailey is an almost unbearably elegant writer, his wit and humanity electrifying this tale of two Somme veterans and their unlikely meeting in the harsh streets of 1970s London. Victor Harker, a man near-paralysed by the death of his wife, is befriended by the eccentric tour guide and bludger Captain Harold Standish. But Standish is a master of disguise - sometimes Tommy the tramp, sometimes Julian, a poet in a purple fedora. Deception and self-delusion mask agonising pain, leading to a haunting and beautifully realised climax.

The Mercy Boys
John Burnside
(Vintage, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Opening with an all too recognisable hangover ("a huge, invisible bruise"), this grimly attentive novel sits us down in the boozer - the Mercy of the title - with four hard-drinking men from Dundee. But the result, delivered in Burnside's powerful prose, avoids both glib bar-room wisecracking and burned-out nihilism. Rather, it is a brutal study of alcoholism and of the inarticulacy of male friendship, in which only a hideous act of violence can break the stasis. This modern morality tale is compelling in its refusal to find easy answers, and Burnside, author of the much-praised novel The Dumb House, is clearly one to watch.

 Alex Clark

fields.headline: The wow-factor
fields.standfirst: Victor Pelevin's fantastical Russian satire, Babylon, impresses  Steven Poole
fields.trailText: Victor Pelevin's fantastical Russian satire, Babylon, impresses Steven Poole
fields.body:
Babylon
Victor Pelevin
Faber, £9.99, 250pp
Buy it at BOL

Victor Pelevin's new novel, a simmering ragout of modern satire, Buddhism and Egyptology, was originally published in Russia as Generation P. The book's arch opening chapter explains the nomenclature: the Soviet teenagers of the 1970s chose Pepsi as their preferred soft drink, signifying the taste of freedom. Faith in Communism had vanished, to be replaced by sugary brown water.

Exemplary of this rootless generation is the novel's hero, Babylen Tatarsky. He grows up and dabbles in poetry, but eventually the collapse of Soviet power renders his verses impotent and pointless in the face of the new order's absurdity. He can't understand "why it was worth exchanging an evil empire for an evil banana republic that imported its bananas from Finland".

This artistic dilemma is also by implication that of Pelevin himself: how to respond to a Russia, and a wider postmodern world, that is so barking as to be almost beyond satire. Pelevin has chosen the fantastic as a suitable analogue, and become a cult literary bad-boy in his homeland. Babylen Takarsky, on the other hand, is saved from life in a cigarette kiosk by a mysterious friend and sucked into the world of advertising. Same difference.

The first few chapters of Babylon have a great deal of fun with Takarsky's work. All the television commercials he works on are for Western products, which need a specific cultural twist to play well in the Russian imagination. One of the hero's masterpieces runs thus: "Russia was always notorious for the gap between culture and civilisation. Now there is no more culture. No more civilisation. The only thing that remains is the Gap. The way they see you." A terser effort is Tatarsky's speculative concept for Reebok, finessing the Nike slogan with "Do it yourself, motherfucker".

One of the greatest pleasures of Pelevin's writing is the perfectly pitched irony of his narrative voice, which pokes fun at his characters but never abandons sympathy for them. When Tatarsky enjoys a mushroom-induced revelation, for example, we are told that "he was filled with happiness at having managed to formulate the answer to a question that had tormented humanity for the last several thousand years in terms so simple anyone could understand them".

Soon enough, however, it becomes clear that ad-slapstick is not enough to power a whole novel, and Pelevin veers off into his trademark philosophical phantasmagoria. From the evidence of Babylon and his previous, brilliant The Clay Machine-Gun, the one thing that Pelevin takes seriously is Buddhism: this anchors his fiery imagination, giving it a species of moral authority. Drunk Russians in bars or on the battlefield hold sophisticated conversations about whether or not the world really exists, and what the meaning of death might be.

In this novel the metaphysics is woven into a startlingly clever and only slightly tongue-in-cheek neo-Marxist theory of television, which is dictated to the hero through a ouija-board by the boisterous spirit of Che Guevara. To summarise the argument, which seems so central to Babylon as to make one suspect the novel was written around it, is to traduce its dazzling sophistry, but at base it turns out that all human life is determined by the simple transmission of three impulses through the media: the oral, anal and displacing wow-factors. The oral induces a powerful yearning for money to bring happiness; the anal induces the subject to excrete money to attain happiness; and the displacing wow-factor causes the subject to dismiss as irrelevant to the pursuit of happiness anything that does not concern money.

Tatarsky receives this revelation dubiously. Meanwhile, events are getting curiouser and curiouser: an old samizdat text on the goddess Ishtar has been infecting the real world, and an ancient dragon appears during an acid trip. "You're a copywriter, aren't you?" it accuses Tatarsky. "That means you are one of those who force people to gaze into the consuming fire."

Pelevin likes to imitate the form of detective fiction, although the search is more important than the destination. In the last third of the novel Tatarsky is initiated into a huge politico-cultural conspiracy - but it is so delightfully realised that to reveal it would be an act of gibbering critical sabotage. And even if Babylon sputters out, finding its fuel tanks too rapidly emptied, and crashes off the road rather than executing a perfect stop, the ride has been so deliciously inventive that you don't mind at all.

fields.headline: Astor la vista, baby
fields.standfirst: Julie Burchill on Peter Stanford's life of bit-player Bronwen Astor
fields.trailText: Julie Burchill Peter Stanford's life of bit-player Bronwen Astor
fields.body:
Bronwen Astor: Her Life and Times
Peter Stanford
HarperCollins, £19.99, 365pp
Buy it at BOL

Before I read this extremely big book I knew only one thing about Bronwen Astor. Which is, rather fabulously, that when she was a model under the name of Bronwen Pugh, someone once described her as "that Welsh girl who slinks along the runway with a fur over her shoulder looking as though she's just killed it and is taking it home to her mate". Well, they say less is more, and this hefty effort makes a pretty good case for leaving the audience unsatisfied whenever possible, rather than risk hearing the bitter cry "Enough!"

Peter Stanford is a bit of an old God-botherer, to judge from his track record; his books include the dirty-sounding but intriguing The She-Pope, Catholics and Sex (bet that's a short one) and biographies of Lord Longford and Cardinal Hume. He's also a former editor of the Catholic Herald - whooah! Do we detect a common theme here? Did Astor, by any chance, convert to Catholicism after she received the nasty shock concerning her husband's association with the Profumo affair? Yes, on page 302. (Don't all rush at once.)

The puzzle is why anyone, even such a shameless promoter of Catholicism as Stanford, would wish to write such a book, let alone read it. True, the Profumo affair has a resonant and bitter beauty, even down to the culprit's name - I often wonder if it would have lived on in legend had the minister in question been called Bloggs, say, or Parsons. That the savagely working-class Christine Keeler (born in Staines, moved to Slough, brought up in a converted railway carriage in a gravel pit - it really is like that prolier-than-thou Monty Python sketch about being dragged up in a shoebox in the middle of the M1) could bring down the last government of Tory patricians - well, it makes Robin Cook's dopey bint and Portillo's fruit-salad days look a bit limp.

But of all the players, Bronwen Astor - wife of a friend of Stephen Ward, the society osteopath who introduced Keeler to Profumo at the Astors' country seat, Cliveden - would seem to be one of the least interesting. She didn't have the one-liners of cheeky cherub Mandy Rice-Davies ("He would, wouldn't he?"), the sphinx-like beauty of Keeler or the enigmatic glamour of Ward - Professor Higgins with whips and chains.

Barrister's daughter Bronwen Pugh was privately educated, then worked as a model in Paris in the late 1950s, becoming Balmain's muse. Of course ideals of beauty do change from decade to decade, but the best that can be said of the photographic evidence of her glory days is that line of Hedy Lamarr's: "Any girl can be glamorous; all you have to do is stand still and look stupid." By 1961 her looks were passé, and she stares out here from a Bailey "Faces of the 1960s" photo looking like nothing so much as an anxious chaperone.

There isn't a single photograph of Keeler, probably the most fascinating woman of her time; but what is a Madonna without a whore, especially for a Catholic? Consequently, references to her litter the book, counterpointing Bronwen's saintliness. The scared teenager who found herself singled out as a whore in the eyes of the media at a time when a promiscuous woman was generally considered to be something less than human is the recipient of very little Christian charity; she appears only as "lying", "luring" and "threatening".

There is an exquisite piece of pomposity on the part of Astor when she says, "Keeler used to call herself a model, and I think at the time some people, some of our friends even, didn't know the difference between a model and a model girl." I'm not surprised: they both lived by selling their beauty, after all, though Astor attracted a higher bidder for hers. Whether this makes her a "better" person rather than simply a more prudent one is hard to say.

Though Stanford makes much of the Cinderella aspect of Astor's story, it is difficult to feel sorry for, or get excited about, an upper-middle-class girl who makes the short jété up into the aristocracy when one considers the achievement of a girl from a gravel pit who brought down a government. Despite Stanford's best efforts to elevate her ("Bronwen has made me think, stretched me. I like that, her capacity to say startling things, her involvement in exploring the frontiers between body, mind and spirit"), Bronwen remains one of life's bit-players, unwisely tempted into a spotlight that does not become her. It is Christine - tricky, tragic, almost incredibly lovely Christine - who remains the one endless fascinator in this whole sorry affair.

fields.headline: Gene genies
fields.standfirst: Andrew Brown wades through the complexities of molecular biology
fields.trailText: Andrew Brown wades through the complexities of molecular biology
fields.body:
The Second Creation
Ian Wilmut, Keith Campbell and Colin Tudge
Headline, £18.99, 362pp
Buy it at BOL

Life Without Genes
Adrian Woolfson
HarperCollins, £17.99, 420pp
Buy it at BOL

Lucy's Legacy
Alison Jolly
Harvard, £18.95, 416pp
Buy it at BOL

The central task of popular-science writing is to explain a great mystery: how is it that science now means dramatic, accurate and profound explanations of almost everything in the world, yet when we tried it in school it meant deadly boredom?

The Second Creation reminds us that science remains a grind even when it is dealing with the fundamentals of life. This book is as close as the general reader will get to science writing the way scientists think it ought to be.

You will, for instance, learn from it an immense amount about the extremely complicated processes involved in the fertilisation of an egg. Some of this has much wider implications: it is not until a fertilised human egg has divided three times, to make an eight-celled embryo, that all its genes from both father and mother start working together to make a new, unique individual. So much for the doctrine that life begins at conception!

But this, perhaps the most memorable news in the whole book - for there can be no one who does not already know that Dolly was cloned by the authors - does not emerge until page 193, and though the authors notice in passing that it "surely has significance for theologians and moral philosophers", they at once plunge back into densely detailed jargon. "Now we come to the part that really matters: how the cell cycle is controlled. There is mitosis. There is DNA replications (S phase). The DNA must replicate completely, once and only once. Mitosis must not begin before S is complete."

But why, and from what perspective, must one suppose that these technical details are "the part that really matters"? This is wilfully unpopular science writing but, paradoxically perhaps, it has produced something unusually valuable. There are hundreds of popular-science books which can teach us a great deal about the world around us; but the gift of an unpopular science book is that it shows the real workings of a scientist's mind and its utter refusal to consider the wider perspective. It tells a story as a professional journal would, with only two aims: to enable other scientists to copy what the authors have done, and to establish that they did it first. But there is a value to the general reader as well in being reminded at such length of the fiendish complications of cells: a certain immunity against the disease of supposing that we understand genes very well.

Different sorts of biologists mean rather different things by the word "gene". Perhaps it would be fairer to say that they are interested in different aspects of what genes do; and one of these aspects is much better understood than the other. What is understood, because it is mostly mathematics, is the way in which genes can spread and shrink through a population when they are considered as units of heredity: genes "for" something or other. But when you ask how all these various genes combine to build bodies, the answer is that almost nothing is known. We do not even know exactly how many genes a human body has.

We will find out, but until then the soaring mathematical splendours of theoretical biology have almost no connection with the gooey detail through which a cloner must trudge. Life Without Genes exhibits opposite failings to The Second Creation by being almost entirely theoretical: it ends up every bit as tedious, but without actually conveying much knowledge about the real world. It may just be me, but when I read hundreds of pages of argument in such style as "Let us now imagine a binding site shape space called Catalystic Shape Space. This is the theoretical Shape of all Possible Three-dimensional Molecular Shapes able to catalyse the chemical reactions that comprise the complete catalytic repertoire housed within the Space of all possible Metabolisms", I enter the space of all possible migraines.

From the point of view of popular-science writing, what is needed are authors who can understand both the theories of evolutionary biology and the ways in which these insights fit into the unscientific but no less valuable knowledge and beliefs that we have about ourselves. The most level-headed and successful shot at this I have read for years is Alison Jolly's Lucy's Legacy. This is a book which deals with "genes" in their third and most popular sense, which is not scientific at all, but is encouraged by almost all the pop science you can read about them: genes understood as the shadowy divinities that shape our ends.

You can see how this understanding derives from Darwinian theory. We have no trouble imagining how it is good for an animal to have eyes, or a sense of touch; these are produced by evolution. But at the same time as evolution works on the outward organs with which we understand the world, it also works on the inward understanding, so that a fish will flee from any shadow passing above, which might be a predatory bird, and a baby will recognise a human face before any other object in the world.

Such adaptations also apply to our social reflexes: a duckling will follow Konrad Lorenz around, a baby will smile at a crudely drawn face before it reacts noticeably to anything else - and a human being will fall in love, often as incongruously as any duckling. Selfish-gene theory shows how the most successful genes are sometimes those which promote unselfish behaviour and selfless feelings.

It's easy to say that genes condition our nature rather than determining our fate, but it's not very satisfying. In this perspective, genes become the medium for all sorts of discussions about fate, predestination and freedom which are predominantly philosophical and not scientific at all; you end up a very long way from the S phase of DNA replication in an embryonic sheep. But these discussions are here to stay: genes are now part of our understanding of ourselves. They affect the most intimate areas of our self-understanding, such as gender, with which Lucy's Legacy is greatly concerned.

One of the things that makes this book so satisfying is the way it clearly and cleverly gets around the whole nature/nurture question by looking at the complex interplay between a mother and baby, in which each is programmed to learn from the other. This is not what anyone would call headline science: it's just well-written, witty, thought-provoking and full of fascinating detail. You don't learn from it how to do primatology, but you do learn what sort of primate you are, which is, for most people, more valuable.

fields.headline: No honour among authors
fields.trailText: Dishing the dirt on Prescott, plus unreliable witnesses and the wages of sin
fields.body:
 A call from former bottle-top factory worker Ian Newton alerts us to the success of an unlikely author team. Dustbingate: The Plot to Rubbish Prescott is an account of how five night-shift workers from Hull joined forces with a team from the World In Action programme to dig the dirt on Blair's limo-loving side-kick. Then they sat down to produce a book. Now,"wads of cash from the royalties" having been divvied up in the canteen, all but one has left the factory - two heading permanently for the beaches of Goa. All of which goes to show how far the spirit of enterprise can get you.

 Naughty Paul Theroux, according to C K Stead in the current issue of the London Review of Books. Stead's Diary is a lengthy, if belated, reaction to Theroux's unflattering portrait of V S Naipaul, Sir Vidia's Shadow.

The gist is that one episode in the book is a thoroughly inaccurate recollection of a lunch held by Naipaul, at which Theroux hob-nobbed with Antonia Fraser (whom he randily imagined in a see-through dress on a Caribbean island) and a couple of New Zealanders, whom he rather disliked. In Theroux's version, "Malcolm" has a bit of a ruck with Lady Antonia, grates on the company's nerves with his non-U accent and has to be studiously avoided on the train back to London. In Stead's view, "Malcolm" was his former colleague Michael Neill, a rather well-spoken chap who claims they all got on famously. To add insult to injury, he maintains that he and his partner gave Theroux a lift back to the smoke.

 Those folks at hip publishers Canongate are always trying to do things differently - this time they've decided to take the staid world of literary prizes to task. Out goes the strict rubric, enormous prize money and single winner. All you've got to do is write 2,000 words in any style and any genre, send it off to Canongate, and they'll pick the best 15, who will share a total of £30,000. The only proviso is that your piece is loosely themed around the idea of Sin. What a perfect distraction at Easter-time.

fields.headline: Corridors of hell
fields.standfirst: Helen Falconer on a doomed and brilliant lust for life revealed by Stuart Browne in Dangerous Parking
fields.trailText: Helen Falconer on a doomed and brilliant lust for life revealed by Stuart Browne in Dangerous Parking
fields.body:
Dangerous Parking
Stuart Browne
Bloomsbury £9.99, 402pp

Noah, precocious film director and narrator of this outstanding novel, has been dangerously parked for a long, long time - going nowhere yet heading for a fatal crash, like a car rolled to a standstill in the fast lane. His alcoholic life is half a death, full of frozen moments and walking blackouts; he hangs out in the corridors of hell. Yet even in that hell he yearns for heaven. He can't help seeing rainbows everywhere; they appear to him in the Lake District, Kenya, Cornwall; in the arching spray of the hosepipe under which his infant daughter runs to greet him.

He craves the chance to live. With the dogged and frequently unwelcome help of some pretty bizarre friends he breaks free from the bottle, gives up on corrupt sexual marathons involving identical twins, and finally even ditches drugs. He works on his films; he obsessively courts the love of his beautiful, provocative wife; he fathers two little girls.

He battles the bitter destruction of his soul by alcohol, as though while wallowing in the corrosive filth at the bottom of the pit he has uncovered a dream of purity bigger and brighter and more important than boring day-to-day people can imagine. He fixes his eyes on the sky; he fantasises and hallucinates; he runs limping and clumsily lurching from the Grim Reaper. He puts us all to shame.

Too late. Death hunts him down through the leaves of his book, in the shape of a terrible cancer of the bladder. Noah pisses red on every page - clots the size of sparrows' eggs then of lambs' livers burst from his penis, washed out in agonising fountains of his blood. Again and again he goes under the consultant's knife. How much pain can one man take and still choose life? We wait for his surrender - but he is a Trojan, a hero, a moral soldier, a Job. (When he fears he is losing his wife, however, he drenches his dour AA meeting with a bottle of bubbly.)

This sounds like a story not for the squeamish, but it is so well written, so cinematic, so compulsively structured, that it carried me through from start to finish like a modern thriller - a genuine page-turner. Somehow it avoids the irredeemably grim, and Noah always likes to parade what he insists on calling his "sense of tumour" (an appalling pun that only his starchy consultant could claim to laugh at).

Noah is still standing in the upbeat final chapter - and there he parts company with his creator. Stuart Browne, a playwright and theatre director whose first and only book this is, died just before last Christmas. The alcoholism and cancer were autobiographical material woven into Noah's fictitious life.

The publishers rushed to get Dangerous Parking into print before Browne died, but death got there before them. If it makes up for it at all, he has built his own unforgettable memorial. There won't be a better novel out this year.

webTitle: Write me up when I'm gone

fields.headline: Write me up when I'm gone
fields.standfirst: John Mullan  sees Saul Bellow refuse to let an old friend die unheralded in Ravelstein
fields.trailText: John Mullan sees Saul Bellow refuse to let an old friend die unheralded in Ravelstein
fields.body:
Ravelstein
Saul Bellow
Viking, £16.99, 233pp
Buy it at BOL

Is this fiction, exactly? Abe Ravelstein, the brilliant, self-mocking, high-living, ever-opinionated hero of Saul Bellow's new work, has asked the narrator, Chick, a favour. "I'd like you to write me up after I'm gone." As Bellow let it be known long before the book was published, Ravelstein memorialises his friend and mentor Allan Bloom, and the request was Bloom's.

Bellow's novels have often been rooted in memoir - most strikingly, his sad comedy Humboldt's Gift (1974) was based on his recollections of doomed poet and alcoholic Delmore Schwartz. But this is something more. "I'm laying this on you as an obligation," Ravelstein tells the hesitant narrator. Here is the obligation's fulfilment.

Bloom, who died in 1992, was a Chicago professor who became famous, or notorious, with his surprise bestseller The Closing of the American Mind (1987). This elegant conservative polemic, with an introduction by Bellow, argued that Disney and Derrida had done for liberal culture in America.

Higher education in the humanities taught the young to find reflected in books merely their own senses of grievance or self-worth, and put anything difficult off limits. "The popular success of his book drove the academics mad," writes Chick. It also enabled his friend to fund his expansive enjoyment of life, caught in a series of vivid, half-ludicrous vignettes. Thanks to a book saying that students should learn Ancient Greek, he can now stay in a Paris hotel in the suite next to Michael Jackson's.

The appeal to Bellow of Ravelstein's extravagance and excitement is characteristic: the "big-souled" intellectual meeting up with the material world is the situation of most Bellow comedy. Ravelstein, whose hands tremble over small tasks with "a tremendous eager energy that shook him when it was discharged", tips the strongest French coffee down the most expensive jacket in Paris. He wants to be stylish, but his enthusiasm trips him up. He sets himself to lecture, but keeps turning to gossip. His wisdom is taken for wisecracks. Bellow may have lifted the details from his observation of Bloom, but they belong happily in a novel, and Ravelstein is the latest in his long line of flamboyant sages.

Bellow's hero (and it is obvious that Bloom truly was Bellow's hero) is as large and vociferous as life, full of appetites and arguments. "Ravelstein, with his bald, powerful head, was at ease with large statements, big issues and famous men, with decades, eras, centuries." An intellectual millionaire, enjoying the trappings of belated wealth, he is an overpowering presence, and a wrestler rather than a guru. "I was not about to get in the ring with this Sumo champion representing Platonic metaphysics," says Chick, as he ducks one of the intellectual debates that Ravelstein likes to provoke.

Obituaries of Bloom were silent about his sexuality: not so Bellow. Ravelstein is dying of Aids, but finding death "such a weird aphrodisiac"; still cruising, still paying off the rent boys. Though he is dead when the novel begins, we keep returning to his life and its last months - his time "in the end-zone". "When he coughed you heard the sump at the bottom of a mine-shaft echoing." He is brought alive unsentimentally by the energy of Bellow's still-inventive prose, with its mixtures of the elevated and the brutally jokey. Chatty and improvisatory, it is still thick with mostly unacknowledged quotation and misquotation (the pleasures of allusion for those who have read the great books that Bloom pressed on Americans).

Even more than Bellow's other novels, its narrative is structureless, digressive, almost whimsical. It circles around the character - the sayings and the idiosyncrasies - of its protagonist. When it loses him it loses its way, and its other main characters are pale. Ravelstein's lover, Nikki, is a silent functionary. The narrator's - ie Bellow's - wife is too good, and too often complimented, to have any life at all, though Bellow does a characteristically sardonic turn with his ex-wife (an astrophysicist in life and in this book). A serene lunar presence in Bellow's eloquently sombre novel The Dean's December (1982), her cold delicacy is now cruelly portrayed. As ever, these great male American novelists, with all those marriages behind them, cannot help putting their ex-wives in their books.

Intriguingly, Bellow cannot even do his own dramas of the soul without Ravelstein to reflect them. This, his first full-length work for 14 years, produced in his mid-80s, is much drawn to death, yet the personal element is curiously flat. The narrator's account of his own near-death experience after an exotic form of food-poisoning (based closely on Bellow's own recent brush with the reaper) seems pointless and utterly without drama: mere autobiographical data, unchanged into fiction.

Bellow needs his Ravelstein, his re-imagined version of his friend, to look at death in the face. He may be doing his duty to Allan Bloom, but he is also, by the quality of his writing rather than any weight of ideas, winning a fictional space to talk of last things - to wonder unabashed about the hungers of "the soul" while biology sucks at the narrator and at his favourite character. "We don't easily give up a creature like Ravelstein to death." Such not-giving-up is what this novel manages, by an achievement of style as much as of affection: a character is saved from death. An effort of fiction-making after all.

"We don't easily give up a creature like Ravelstein to death." Such not-giving-up is what this novel manages, by an achievement of style as much as of affection: a character is saved from death. An effort of fiction-making after all.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: An Englishman who can do a passable American, plus Umbrella Man, Zelda's Cut, Aftermath and The Other Daughter
fields.body:
In three novels Lee Child has established a successful franchise with his maverick drifter, ex-US military cop Jack Reacher, and shown that, for an Englishman, he can produce passable American. His fourth, The Visitor (Bantam, £9.99), offers a professional, efficient mix of hard-boiled style with lots of lip and a revival of the classic locked-room mystery.

How and why are several ex-US servicewomen, all previous victims of army sexual harrassment, persuaded to lie naked in a bath of khaki paint - and then wind up dead with no post-mortem evidence? Stumped, FBI profilers resort via blackmail to Reacher, a bolshie at odds with any organisation. If the denouement disappoints, Child rewards curiosity along the way with tight, well-worked plotting, pace and high mileage.

Doug J Swanson's Umbrella Man (No Exit, £6.99) is the real thing, and demonstrates that eccentricity is no longer the privilege of the English. The laugh-out-loud story collides the merely odd with the mad, the bad, the dangerously thick and the genuinely psychotic in a lively wild-goose chase that inevitably kicks back from contemporary Dallas to that big date at the grassy knoll in 1963. Rumours surface of a second amateur cameraman's film of the Kennedy assassination showing a second umbrella man doing the shooting. Swanson knows his conspiracy theories, and his portrait of Dallas, mainly rancid, saves you the trip.

In Zelda's Cut (HarperCollins, £16.99) by Philippa Gregory, a mousy, award-winning literary novelist, unable to meet bills because of a sick husband, performs an astonishing volte face by secretly blossoming as a brash, sexy author of lurid trash fiction, with advances and outfits to match. The words gush out of her - in marked contrast to her previous, constipated morality fables - but Gregory never quite overcomes the problem of having a foot in both camps: is she writing a good book badly or a bad book well? The better part of the story is Gregory's portrait of a creepy middle-class marriage of guilt, resentment and silent greed, with a ghastly husband worthy of Patricia Highsmith.

Jaded post-cold war CIA agents are reduced in Simon Gandolfi's Aftermath (Orion, £9.99) to conducting quasi-black operations in the paddling pool of Central America. The hero, head of the Guatemala station, is world-weary to the point of auditioning for Greene; his only plum is the prospect of enticing Cuba's terrorist mastermind into a carefully sprung trap. Gandolfi works his way with persuasive ease through the clandestine moves that tie together the realpolitik of bust-up third-world economies and smooth first-world business interests.

Lisa Gardner does good capital punishment in the teaser opening to The Other Daughter (Orion, £16.99) - electrocution courtesy of the State of Texas - but after she throws the big switch, her style turns breathless and the story takes too long to pick up. There's a jump of 20 years to the dead man's daughter, who is about to discover that her ragingly dysfunctional adopted parents - a wealthy, cheating doctor and his dipso wife - were also the parents of the little girl who Daddy got fried forand killing. Wearisome complications include an FBI man posing as a waiter and a sleaze journalist nudgingly named Digger.
