fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: On the slippery slope towards Europe's soccer soap
fields.trailText: So that's that. Having entered holy week on a wing and a prayer, the seasonal aspirations of English clubs in Europe have been all but demolished in the space of 72 hours by the combined efforts of a Brazilian, a Portuguese, a Romanian, a Spaniard and an old Liverpool Spice Boy.
fields.body:
So that's that. Having entered holy week on a wing and a prayer, the seasonal aspirations of English clubs in Europe have been all but demolished in the space of 72 hours by the combined efforts of a Brazilian, a Portuguese, a Romanian, a Spaniard and an old Liverpool Spice Boy.

No doubt Arsenal and their followers will relish the prospect of meeting Galatasaray in the Uefa Cup final but since both teams entered the tournament on the back of their failures in the Champions League this hardly represents an excuse for national rejoicing, although Turkey may be permitted a few handstands at the thought of winning their first European trophy.

Manchester United's response to losing their hold on the Champions Cup has been that of a wealthy wife waking up feeling depressed. Sir Alex Ferguson has followed Mrs Beckham's remedy for curing the blues: go shopping like crazy.

PSV Eindhoven must be hoping that United do not do well in Europe too often, since the £19m that Ferguson is spending on Ruud van Nistelrooy, added to the £10.75m he paid PSV for Jaap Stam two years ago, has surely added caviar to the menu in the Philips works canteen.

This is an awesome demonstration of United's ability to raise the stakes. In paying £6.4m more for a striker than they did for Dwight Yorke, their previous record signing, the club have upped the ante while their present busted flush in the Champions League is still lying on the table.

English football must now be fully aware of the way the cookie is going to crumble once the next television deal, estimated by some to be worth £2bn, has been finalised: it will not be United hunting for crumbs.

Van Nistelrooy is set to earn around £42,000 a week at Old Trafford, which is £10,000 less than Roy Keane is getting. Presumably the club will make it up to the Dutchman in luncheon vouchers. Those handling the affairs of David Beckham and Ryan Giggs, whose contracts still have some time to run, must even now be checking their gold- mining equipment.

These ever-spiralling fees and salaries are being paid out largely to preserve and protect the wealthiest clubs' annual entry into the Champions League. There is, however, always the chance of being eliminated unexpectedly, as United were by Real Madrid on Wednesday night, being knocked out with no guarantee of a place in the following season's tournament, Chelsea's fate against Barcelona the previous evening, or, like Arsenal, ending up in a plate competition.

Small wonder that Rupert Murdoch and other pay- television moguls would prefer a 16-club European league with no relegation. Enough of this knockout nonsense, it leaves too much to chance: an Irishman puts the ball into his own net and the team most likely to keep viewers glued to their screens disappears.

Far better, surely, to get Manchester United and Real Madrid meeting on a regular basis while giving each club £15m a season plus £750,000 a point. That way you avoid trying to sell semi-finals in which all but one of the participants are Spanish.

It is to be hoped, of course, that the clubs to whom such proposals are regularly made decide to stick with the present Uefa formula which, despite a prolonged and painful gestation period, tends to return to the European Cup ideal eventually.

The danger with leagues is that they regularly fail to produce a climax. Whether or not United win the Premiership over Easter, the moment will hardly hold the nation in thrall because all reasonable doubts about their retaining the title had disappeared by the end of January.

Though the failure of United and Chelsea to progress beyond the quarter-finals in the Champions League this time has been disappointing, the manner of their departures was memorable because of the way their conquerors, Raul and McManaman for Real Madrid, Luis Figo and Rivaldo for Barcelona, raised their performances for the occasion. And was not United's quirky progress to last season's triumph far preferable to winning the thing on points?

T he danger is that Uefa has already gone as far as it can in acceding to club pressure for regular appearances in its tournaments without actually setting up a European League pure and simple. The idea of a European pay-TV soccer soap which would upstage the national leagues even more than the Champions League does now is appalling, but so long as the leading clubs are intent on paying players ever-increasing sums in order to appear in a competition which will enable the best talents to demand even higher salaries it will not go away.

This week a survey in the Independent revealed that even the Premiership's spear- carriers are on an average of £400,000 a year. True, an NBA player, asked to appear for such a sum, would regard his prospective employers as basket cases but this is not America and if the next television windfall is simply going to produce more wage inflation then clubs whose turnovers are already struggling to keep pace will be no better off.

And those in the Nationwide will need even bigger telescopes to measure the void between themselves and the nearest star.

There is, however, always the chance of being eliminated unexpectedly, as United were by Real Madrid on Wednesday night, being knocked out with no guarantee of a place in the following season's tournament, Chelsea's fate against Barcelona the previous evening, or, like Arsenal, ending up in a plate competition. Small wonder that Rupert Murdoch and other pay- television moguls would prefer a 16-club European league with no relegation. Enough of this knockout nonsense, it leaves too much to chance: an Irishman puts the ball into his own net and the team most likely to keep viewers glued to their screens disappears. Far better, surely, to get Manchester United and Real Madrid meeting on a regular basis while giving each club £15m a season plus £750,000 a point. That way you avoid trying to sell semi-finals in which all but one of the participants are Spanish. It is to be hoped, of course, that the clubs to whom such proposals are regularly made decide to stick with the present Uefa formula which, despite a prolonged and painful gestation period, tends to return to the European Cup ideal eventually. The danger with leagues is that they regularly fail to produce a climax. Whether or not United win the Premiership over Easter, the moment will hardly hold the nation in thrall because all reasonable doubts about their retaining the title had disappeared by the end of January. Though the failure of United and Chelsea to progress beyond the quarter-finals in the Champions League this time has been disappointing, the manner of their departures was memorable because of the way their conquerors, Raul and McManaman for Real Madrid, Luis Figo and Rivaldo for Barcelona, raised their performances for the occasion. And was not United's quirky progress to last season's triumph far preferable to winning the thing on points? T he danger is that Uefa has already gone as far as it can in acceding to club pressure for regular appearances in its tournaments without actually setting up a European League pure and simple. The idea of a European pay-TV soccer soap which would upstage the national leagues even more than the Champions League does now is appalling, but so long as the leading clubs are intent on paying players ever-increasing sums in order to appear in a competition which will enable the best talents to demand even higher salaries it will not go away. This week a survey in the Independent revealed that even the Premiership's spear- carriers are on an average of £400,000 a year. True, an NBA player, asked to appear for such a sum, would regard his prospective employers as basket cases but this is not America and if the next television windfall is simply going to produce more wage inflation then clubs whose turnovers are already struggling to keep pace will be no better off. And those in the Nationwide will need even bigger telescopes to measure the void between themselves and the nearest star.

webTitle: Charlton determined to do it the hard way

fields.headline: Charlton determined to do it the hard way
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 1 Portsmouth
fields.body:
When Charlton clinched promotion two years ago the drama lasted 120 minutes, included a prolonged penalty shootout, and left every one of their supporters at Wembley wrung dry of emotion. It was nothing compared with this. For three games Charlton have prepared to breast the tape, only to come up short each time.

Still, they lived to celebrate another day. It may come this afternoon, because if either Manchester City or Ipswich do not win then this disappointment will have been forgotten, along with the inability to beat Huddersfield the previous Friday and Nottingham Forest the week before that.

Otherwise it all moves on to Blackburn on Monday when a draw would be enough to uncork Charlton's champagne, on ice so long there must be a danger that it has gone flat.

Alan Curbishley, forced to explain a third failure to take the final step into the Premiership, says it is a question of anxiety rather than nerves. Once again he could have no real complaints with the performance; once again a visiting team responded positively to the party atmosphere and the television cameras.

"Because of the time we have spent at the top and the lead we have established people think we can just turn up and it will happen for us but we have still got to make it happen," said Curbishley.

His team, so weary by the end and yet still seeking that elusive winning goal, could hardly do any more to make it happen. Yesterday they had 19 attempts on goal to put alongside the 25 against Huddersfield, but over two games they had only a single goal to show for all that domination. Never has it proved so difficult to dot the "i" and cross the "t" in promotion.

"We have not won for four games and I think our performances warrant better than that," added the Charlton manager. "But it's not all about the last four. Our run over 23 games shows 15 wins, six draws and only two defeats and that is a fantastic set of results."

From the start Portsmouth looked capable of preying on Charlton's nerves, even though injury after only four minutes deprived them of Steve Claridge, the striker responsible for the shock wins at both Huddersfield and Ipswich.

They looked ready to go ahead when Lee Bradbury moved instinctively on to an opening, only to see Dean Kiely save with his legs. Shortly afterwards Justin Edinburgh's right-foot centre found Bradbury pulling away from his marker Steve Brown before tucking away a neat header. Kiely had been hoping to set a club record for clean sheets but he too must wait for another day.

In the other goal Russell Hoult was demonstrating his value to Tony Pulis's team, parrying an early half-volley from John Robinson and fielding a low, firm drive from Mathias Svensson with assurance.

With a first-half goal against them and a keeper breathing outright defiance, this had all the makings of another frustrating Friday for the London club, a Groundhog Day for the champions elect. At least they managed to score this time, Graham Stuart scooping the ball high into the net after first slipping as he seized on Svensson's fast cross 20 minutes into the second half.

Before that Robinson came agonisingly close as he cut the ball back across Hoult, and in the final minute the Welshman sensed another chance and made room for the finish, only to find Thomas Thogersen blocking the way with a superbly timed challenge.

"What I am trying to do at Portsmouth is ensure that if anyone is to beat us they are going to have to work really hard for it," said Pulis. Charlton will testify that his message is getting through, and he also had sympathy for Curbishley. "I was here for the Huddersfield fixture and with a bit more luck Charlton could easily have had six points out of the two games. Sometimes that's all the dividing line is."

fields.headline: Space cadets
fields.standfirst: Galaxy Quest is the comic tale of  has-been actors unwittingly thrust  into in a real-life battle. An all-too familiar story, says Joe Queenan
fields.trailText: Galaxy Quest is the comic tale of has-been actors unwittingly thrust into in a real-life battle. An all-too familiar story, says Joe Queenan
fields.body:
Fourteen years ago, Steve Martin, Chevy Chase and Martin Short appeared in a clever, funny, heavily promoted film that performed dismally at the box-office. The Three Amigos was the tale of three unemployed silent film stars who had long specialised in playing virtuous Mexican cowboys sporting garish costumes and big hats. But their time had come and gone, and now they were looking for work. Any kind of work. One day, the amigos receive a tersely worded telegram from a tiny Mexican village requesting that they trundle down and help rid the peasants of their oppressor, the dreaded bandito "El Guapo". The compadres naturally assume that they have been invited south of the border to put on a show and regale the entertainment-starved paeons with their winning antics. So off they go. Alas, they soon discover that El Guapo is a genuine murderer, that the peasants are truly expecting salvation, and that the imbroglio they have entered involves real guns and real bullets. So they decide to run away.

But then, much like the gunslingers with hearts of gold in The Magnificent Seven, the film that The Three Amigos ingeniously parodies, Martin, Chase and Short rise to the occasion and defeat El Guapo, thereby attaining a heroic stature they have heretofore only simulated. Yet despite this original plot, hilarious musical production numbers, crackling dialogue, wonderful work by Martin and Short, and a surprisingly animated performance from the usually AWOL Chase, The Three Amigos was a bomb. Were those of us who adored this cheerfully inane film completely out of our minds? Or was The Three Amigos a film that was ahead of its time?

To make a long story short, The Three Amigos was simply a film that was ahead of its time. But now that it has been re-released as Galaxy Quest, those who missed it the first time around can atone for this oversight. In Galaxy Quest, Tim Allen, Sigourney Weaver and Alan Rickman play pathetic, ageing veterans of a TV show not unlike Star Trek that was cancelled a generation ago, not unlike Star Trek, but has since spawned a huge cult following, not unlike Star Trek. To keep their creditors at bay, the trio of hams, accompanied by several even less glamorous chums, must make an endless series of personal appearances at conventions, department store-openings, etc. They are tragic little has-beens, and they despise one another. Whether this accurately describes the relationship between the survivors of Star Trek, I have no way of knowing. But I would certainly hope so.

One day, Allen hooks up with a quartet of star-struck space bozos who escort him to what he believes is yet another promotional appearance. In fact, the four visitors are genuine extraterrestrials who have seen Allen's antics on TV but who have no way of knowing that his mighty deeds are fake. The space dorks, who bear a definite facial resemblance to the Teletubbies, want Allen and his crew to venture deep into space and rescue them from a cruel, voluble reptile who seems determined to reduce their civilisation to rubble.
It takes Allen quite a long time to realise what is happening here, and his crew members are not much faster on the uptake. But eventually, having taken a genuine liking to their hosts, they realise what is expected of them and rise to the occasion. They rise to the occasion the way Toshiro Mifune did in the Seven Samurai, and the way Yul Bryner did in The Magnificent Seven, and the way Steve Martin and Martin Short and Chevy Chase did in The Three Amigos, because these are all the same movie.

People who dislike the tomfoolery Star Trek has unleashed on society should not be put off by the forgoing paragraphs. When I first asked my 13-year-old son if he would like to see Galaxy Quest, he asked me what kind of a jerk I thought he was, since wholesome teenage boys loathe Star Trek, and have occasionally been known to put overbearing Trekkies to the sword. But when I assured my son that Galaxy Quest would be a merciless attack on the Star Trek cult - and here I was only guessing - he finally agreed to attend. To our relief, we found that most of the people in the audience would never be mistaken for Star Trek aficionados, because they were normal, good-looking, suitably attired, and in some cases, female - a gender never seen at any Star Trek convention I know of. And, yes, a good time was had by all, since what is bad for Trekkies - movies like Galaxy Quest - is good for humans.

A few caveats. Until I saw Galaxy Quest, I had not been a big fan of Tim Allen as a movie star. Reliably amusing as the tool guy on TV's Home Improvement, Allen seemed to phone in his performances in films such as The Santa Clause. But perhaps because Galaxy Quest is about an ageing star of the tiny screen who is suddenly asked to perform truly heroic feats, Allen seemed perfect for the role of William Shatner/Captain Kirk, pompous ass. Meanwhile, Alan Rickman, who seems like a strange chap anyway, was impeccably cast in the role of the drab, emotionless Doctor Spock.

But the biggest surprise of all was Sigourney Weaver, in an uncharacteristically voluptuous performance as Allen's gorgeous, pointless Space Sidekick. It's been years since Weaver appeared in anything that was even vaguely funny, and Galaxy Quest affords her a brief respite from her official role as the Baby Boomer Joan Crawford. It cannot be an accident that Weaver, obstreperously bald in Alien III, herein sports the most bellicose wig since Mary-Elizabeth Mastrantonio donned that Pam Grier Afro in Scarface. No, it is not an accident; it is, in fact, one of the best jokes in a very funny film. Not as funny as The Three Amigos, of course. But then again, what is?

 Galaxy Quest is out on Friday

fields.headline: Bradford ride Easter roller-coaster
fields.standfirst: Windass grabs hat-trick in extraordinary game of four penalties
fields.trailText: Bradford 4 - 4 Derby
fields.body:
Bradford City's faint hopes of Premiership survival virtually disappeared here yesterday and their involvement in an epic match against a Derby side still threatened with relegation will have provided few crumbs of comfort.

Although the cause looks all but lost City's manager Paul Jewell, who guided them up last spring, said: "We've got four games left and we might have to win all four, but another seven points might be enough to keep us up so even though we've made our job harder we're not going to throw the towel in yet.

"The game could have finished anything each, it was that sort of game. But we can't dwell on it and we've got to move on now to Sunderland on Monday."

The referee Alan Wilkie played his part in the drama by sending off Derby's Rory Delap and awarding four penalties, three of them to the visitors. Derby's third, 10 minutes from time, would have sealed a 5-4 victory and given Craig Burley a hat-trick from the spot but for Matthew Clarke's stunning save.

Asked to comment on the referee's performance Derby's manager Jim Smith said: "I've got my views but I can't say much can I, because he gave us three penalties."

In a topsy-turvey game Bradford recovered after conceding two early goals to lead 4-3 at the interval largely thanks to a hat-trick from Dean Windass.

It took Delap 22 seconds to open the scoring when he tapped home from a yard and when Branko Strupar added the second in the seventh minute, Bradford looked like to suffer the kind of beating handed out by Everton at Goodison Park last Saturday.

But in the next 20 minutes the game turned on its head, Bradford led and Derby were down to 10 men. Windass struck first from 10 yards and then from 30 to level matters. Then Robbie Blake found the net with a lob but the referee had awarded a penalty against Delap for shirt pulling. He was sent off and Peter Beagrie duly obliged from the spot.

Soon after Delap's departure Derby quickly won their first penalty after a trip by Ashley Westwood on Malcolm Christie. Burley punished the indiscretion but just before the break, Windass put City ahead again with a smart left-foot finish.

Within seven minutes of the restart Derby were on terms, Burley converting a hotly disputed spot kick. Derby then wasted two great chances when Christie and Seth Johnson both failed to score with only Clarke to beat.

In a last desperate gamble to gain maximum points Jewell sent on Isiah Rankin and Dean Saunders, and it fell to the former Derby striker to miss their best chance.

When he took the field the visiting fans had chanted his name and in the last seconds of stoppage time he was once again their hero as he wasted a glorious chance to win the match as he shot straight at Mart Poom.

The whistle went, the home players sunk to their knees and hopes of survival became ever more distant.

Both managers appeared exhausted and Smith said: "That was the good, the bad and the ugly. But there was too much ugly for me," he said. "At the end of the day I'm disappointed that we only drew. We set off with two goals in seven minutes to defend like we defended in the first half was crap really. But I think all we need is one more win and we will be safe."

That could come at Pride Park on Monday where they play a Southampton side free of their normal relegation worries.

Meanwhile Jewell must now rally his exhausted troops for the difficult trip to the Stadium of Light.

 Derby fans who had paid to watch the game on a giant television at Pride Pride invaded the pitch after a technical left them looking at a blank screen. Around 200 of the 1000 fans staged the protest befiore being cleared by stewards. The club has promised to issue a full refund to the fans, who eventually had to settle for commentary from BBC Radio Derby.

webTitle: Vialli must shop to get Blues shipshape

fields.headline: Vialli must shop to get Blues shipshape
fields.trailText: Clearly Gianluca Vialli's policy of trying to squeeze a last drop from the tanks of once great players has not been a winner. The gulf in class between his side and Barcelona could not be disguised even by the fact that Chelsea were just seven minutes away from victory.
fields.body:
On Monday the Spanish armada's two English victims meet at Old Trafford, equally determined to show that they have not been holed below the waterline.

Manchester United, with the Premiership title all but theirs, retain most buoyancy despite the Real Madrid defeat, and have already moved to plug a hole upfront by signing Ruud van Nistelrooy for next season.

But at Chelsea there is much more of a sinking feeling. Thrashed 5-1 by Barcelona and struggling to qualify for a European place via the Premiership, the manager Gianluca Vialli knows he faces a huge task to turn the once so promising Chelsea ship round.

Clearly Vialli's policy of trying to squeeze a last drop from the tanks of once great players has not been a winner. The gulf in class between his side and Barcelona could not be disguised even by the fact that Chelsea were just seven minutes away from victory.

In between catching the odd European Championship game this summer, Vialli must also take a look at his own players: who stays, who goes, and most crucially who arrives. Because if Chelsea fail to overcome Aston Villa in next month's FA Cup final, the likeable Italian will have gone two seasons without getting his hands on a major trophy. And that is not the return Ken Bates was expecting on Vialli's huge investment in the transfer market.

Several fault-lines run through the Chelsea squad. For a start, six of the Nou Camp starting line-up and two of the subsitutes were over 30. Players normally only get worse from that age.

Roberto di Matteo seems to have lost it at 29, Frank Leboeuf's defensive weaknesses are increasingly being exposed and Gianfranco Zola cannot go on for ever.

And of Chelsea's lavish squad, only four players have arguably enhanced their reputations this season: Dennis Wise, Ed de Goey, Jon Harley and Jody Morris.

Marcel Desailly, Tore Andre Flo and Gustavo Poyet are on level par but Didier Deschamps, Chris Sutton and Gabriele Ambrosetti have proved expensive flops, Jes Hogh an inexpensive flop. Bernard Lambourde is not top class. Those five, plus Di Matteo, are the most likely candidates to be elsewhere next season.

Chelsea require three fresh ingredients: width, midfield invention and pace up front. So Vialli must improve his shopping skills.

With transfer funds less abundant than at Old Trafford, Vialli cannot afford more Suttonesque bad calls. Club rumours also hint at more of a role for Morris, Harley, John Terry and the promising youngster Robert Wolleaston next season. Which makes sense.

Ironically, there is one upside to the downside of losing in Barcelona. If, as looks likely, Chelsea also fail to qualify for next season's Champions League via the Premiership, the reduction in fixture pressure of playing in the Uefa Cup, or not in Europe at all, next season could help them concentrate on winning the league title. Vialli just has to assemble a capable enough squad.

 Newcastle face a fresh injury crisis as they prepare for the visit of Leeds tomorrow. Their goalkeepers Shay Given and Steve Harper are struggling with ankle and knee injuries respectively, and Duncan Ferguson, Temuri Ketsbaia, Nikos Dabizas, Kevin Gallacher, Paul Robinson and Alain Goma are all out, while Nolberto Solano is on World Cup duty with Peru.

The Paraguayan midfielder Diego Gavilan is set for his first start, and the Spanish defender Marcelino is back in contention after playing for the reserves in mid week.

Internazionale's seemingly jinxed Brazilian striker Ronaldo returned to Italy yesterday, nine days after undergoing surgery on his right knee in Paris. Inter said last week that Ronaldo would need seven or eight months to recover before making a return to full-time competition, although the operation on his knee-cap tendon went well.

Ronaldo, 23, first tore the tendon in what looked to be a minor injury in an Italian league match last November. His comeback during Inter's Italian Cup match against Lazio last week lasted just six minutes before his knee gave way again.

Manchester United, with the Premiership title all but theirs, retain most buoyancy despite the Real Madrid defeat, and have already moved to plug a hole upfront by signing Ruud van Nistelrooy for next season. But at Chelsea there is much more of a sinking feeling. Thrashed 5-1 by Barcelona and struggling to qualify for a European place via the Premiership, the manager Gianluca Vialli knows he faces a huge task to turn the once so promising Chelsea ship round. Clearly Vialli's policy of trying to squeeze a last drop from the tanks of once great players has not been a winner. The gulf in class between his side and Barcelona could not be disguised even by the fact that Chelsea were just seven minutes away from victory. In between catching the odd European Championship game this summer, Vialli must also take a look at his own players: who stays, who goes, and most crucially who arrives. Because if Chelsea fail to overcome Aston Villa in next month's FA Cup final, the likeable Italian will have gone two seasons without getting his hands on a major trophy. And that is not the return Ken Bates was expecting on Vialli's huge investment in the transfer market. Several fault-lines run through the Chelsea squad. For a start, six of the Nou Camp starting line-up and two of the subsitutes were over 30. Players normally only get worse from that age. Roberto di Matteo seems to have lost it at 29, Frank Leboeuf's defensive weaknesses are increasingly being exposed and Gianfranco Zola cannot go on for ever. And of Chelsea's lavish squad, only four players have arguably enhanced their reputations this season: Dennis Wise, Ed de Goey, Jon Harley and Jody Morris. Marcel Desailly, Tore Andre Flo and Gustavo Poyet are on level par but Didier Deschamps, Chris Sutton and Gabriele Ambrosetti have proved expensive flops, Jes Hogh an inexpensive flop. Bernard Lambourde is not top class. Those five, plus Di Matteo, are the most likely candidates to be elsewhere next season. Chelsea require three fresh ingredients: width, midfield invention and pace up front. So Vialli must improve his shopping skills. With transfer funds less abundant than at Old Trafford, Vialli cannot afford more Suttonesque bad calls. Club rumours also hint at more of a role for Morris, Harley, John Terry and the promising youngster Robert Wolleaston next season. Which makes sense. Ironically, there is one upside to the downside of losing in Barcelona. If, as looks likely, Chelsea also fail to qualify for next season's Champions League via the Premiership, the reduction in fixture pressure of playing in the Uefa Cup, or not in Europe at all, next season could help them concentrate on winning the league title. Vialli just has to assemble a capable enough squad.  Newcastle face a fresh injury crisis as they prepare for the visit of Leeds tomorrow. Their goalkeepers Shay Given and Steve Harper are struggling with ankle and knee injuries respectively, and Duncan Ferguson, Temuri Ketsbaia, Nikos Dabizas, Kevin Gallacher, Paul Robinson and Alain Goma are all out, while Nolberto Solano is on World Cup duty with Peru. The Paraguayan midfielder Diego Gavilan is set for his first start, and the Spanish defender Marcelino is back in contention after playing for the reserves in mid week. Internazionale's seemingly jinxed Brazilian striker Ronaldo returned to Italy yesterday, nine days after undergoing surgery on his right knee in Paris. Inter said last week that Ronaldo would need seven or eight months to recover before making a return to full-time competition, although the operation on his knee-cap tendon went well. Ronaldo, 23, first tore the tendon in what looked to be a minor injury in an Italian league match last November. His comeback during Inter's Italian Cup match against Lazio last week lasted just six minutes before his knee gave way again.

webTitle: Oldest referee plans years of extra time

fields.headline: Oldest referee plans years of extra time
fields.trailText: • Now here's a glutton for punishment. Richard McCormack from Lichfield has refereed 1,237 games during his career and he plans still to be showing red cards when he is 80.
fields.body:
 Now here's a glutton for punishment. Richard McCormack from Lichfield has refereed 1,237 games during his career and he plans still to be showing red cards when he is 80.

McCormack, officially Britain's oldest man in the middle, is a mere 73 and has notched up 44 seasons as a ref after qualifying with the Football Association in 1956. He has also run the line in another 294 matches.

Mac, as he is known, enjoyed the perfect training to be a referee. He was a sergeant major in the Royal Welch Fusiliers during a 22-year stint in the army that saw him officiate in games around the world.

Now he is content to takes charge at matches in the West Midlands Services and Lichfield Recreational leagues, where he referees two games a week on average but is honest enough to admit: "I'm not as fit as I used to be."

However, he hopes to add on seven years of extra-time before blowing the final whistle. "I love the game and if I'm fit enough to still referee at 80 then I will."

 To those of you who wrote in querying whether Bury's Baichung Bhutia last weekend really was the first Indian to score in the English league, we would like to point out that Crazy Horse was only Emlyn Hughes's nickname.

 Just for the record, here is the full quote from Sir Alex Ferguson on Wednesday (see main story on opposite page) denying that United were about to splash out on Ruud van Nistelrooy.

"We've drawn up a list of priorities and at the moment Ruud van Nistelrooy is, in all honesty, not on it," the knight of the realm told the Dutch daily De Telegraaf. "We've watched him just the once and gathered bits of information about him, but that is what we do all the time, with players who are in the forefront of the game.

"It is simply a question of doing our homework and nothing more. I will only know in two weeks' time which players will be leaving us and as a result what types of player we need to bring in."

 "It does give my starting platform a better lift-off situation" - Sheffield Wednesday's caretaker manager Peter Shreeves gets carried away with the English language as much as last weekend's victory over Chelsea.

 And you think that your team's bad. Hebburn Wardles of the Dumsford Business Supplies Tyne and Wear League have conceded 166 goals in 20 games and could end the season pointless.

The side have managed two draws but Wardles have since been docked two points for being unable to field enough players for a match earlier this season.

Their worst defeat was 16-0 against table-topping Wavendon. But their manager John Simpson is convinced better times are round the corner despite suffering an 8-0 defeat at the hands of Sunderland's Ivy House last weekend. "We have improved of late and recently only lost a game 1-0."

There are two games to go this season for Wardles to break their duck though the evidence is against them. "Four or five of the lads are not really footballers," the manager admits.

 After Tony Adams's highly publicised visit to the dentist, a reader asks whether it is actually possible to extract a wisdom tooth from a footballer.

webTitle: Edwards:we will go on smashing records

fields.headline: Edwards:we will go on smashing records
fields.standfirst: Ferguson fumes over Dutch leak on £19m United deal
fields.trailText: Manchester United's chairman Martin Edwards, buoyed by his British-record £19m deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy, insisted yesterday that his club would top even that fee for the right player in their quest to become European champions again next year.
fields.body:
Manchester United's chairman Martin Edwards, buoyed by his British-record £19m deal for Ruud van Nistelrooy, insisted yesterday that his club would top even that fee for the right player in their quest to become European champions again next year.

Underlining United's awesome spending power and the reaction to Wednesday's European dethronement, Edwards said: "We're in a good position, are probably going to win the league again and we're in a position of strengthening. If a player is better, then we will always try and strengthen.

"We've always broken records in my time; going back to Bryan Robson we have broken British records. You then go to Gary Pallister, Roy Keane and Andy Cole. We paid a record for a defender when we signed Jaap Stam - and now this."

Despite his club's coup for the PSV Eindhoven striker, the manager seemingly least happy yesterday at the news was, bizarrely, Sir Alex Ferguson.

While PSV, Van Nistelrooy himself and United's spokesman Ken Ramsden were openly discussing the breaking of the British transfer record, Ferguson was furious that the Dutch club had broken what he saw as a confidentiality agreement.

"No, you can't ask me about it, I've nothing to tell you," he responded to an innocent query about the transfer.

When told that the 23-year-old Dutch striker was holding a press conference in Eindhoven yesterday, suggesting that the deal was complete, Ferguson snapped: "That's your opinion."

Reluctantly, he said later: "Nothing will be decided until next week. The boy will be over next week, Tuesday I would imagine. Until the medical has been agreed, and certain other things have been sorted out, I'm not saying anything. He's injured at the moment, knee ligaments."

Van Nistelrooy, who hopes to play in Euro 2000 this summer, said: "My knee has recovered but I am not fit yet." He is expected to sign a five-year deal worth at least £2m a year.

The United strikers most likely to be affected are Teddy Sheringham, who will shortly become a free agent and is likely to join Charlton, and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer. Ferguson may sell Solskjaer to the highest bidder, possibly the Leeds manager David O'Leary.

webTitle: Arsenal seek inquiry into Lens debacle

fields.headline: Arsenal seek inquiry into Lens debacle
fields.trailText: Arsenal are seeking a Uefa inquiry after nine of the north London club's fans were arrested following clashes with police as they attempted to enter Felix Bollaert stadium for the match against Lens amid claims that Lens had resold blocks of tickets allocated to the visitors.
fields.body:
Arsenal are seeking a Uefa inquiry into the French authorities' organisation of Thursday's semi-final return at Lens when nine of the north London club's fans were arrested after clashes with police as they attempted to enter the ground amid claims that Lens had resold blocks of tickets allocated to the visitors.

A 2-1 victory assured a place in next month's Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen for Arsenal, who said that nine of their supporters also suffered minor injuries in the clashes.

Arsenal, who sold out their 2,500 allocation, will want to establish how many of the fans involved in the trouble actually possessed tickets and listen to the grievances of supporters who have complained they were handcuffed and beaten by police.

The club's managing director Ken Friar said Arsenal wanted to avoid a repeat of the problem at the final on May 17, a game of the highest profile because it again pits English opposition against Galatasaray of Turkey.

So far Arsenal and the Istanbul club have each been allocated 12,000 tickets for the 42,000-capacity Parken Stadium, although this is expected to increase to around 16,000 apiece.

One of the principal worries is that troublemakers will go to Copenhagen masquerading as Gunners fans to seek a confrontation with Galatasaray followers in retaliation for the fatal stabbing of two Leeds fans in Istanbul two weeks ago.

The Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale has promised to ban for life the fan responsible for hitting Galatasaray's striker Hakan Sukur with a missile at Elland Road.

Sukur was struck on the back of the head, believed to be by a coin, late in the second half on Thursday. It may lead to disciplinary action by Uefa.

Celebrations of Galatasaray's success in Turkay were marred when stray bullets, fired into the air by revellers, wounded five people across the country. A man was seriously injured in the head by a ricocheting bullet in the south-east city of Mus.

Leicester's midfielder Muzzy Izzet has been named in a Turkish squad for Euro 2000 preparations. The players will have a two-day training session in Istanbul.

fields.headline: Washout has Bensons hedging it
fields.trailText: So much for the beautiful south. The abandonment of both of yesterday's Benson & Hedges ties, here and at Southgate, means that between them the south and west (all right, midlands/west/Wales) divisions have suffered 15 wash-outs in 22 scheduled starts.
fields.body:
So much for the beautiful south. The abandonment of both of yesterday's Benson & Hedges ties, here and at Southgate, means that between them the south and west (all right, midlands/west/Wales) divisions have suffered 15 wash-outs in 22 scheduled starts, rendering the qualifying process about as straightforward as a game of twister with an ambidextrous octopus.

Middlesex, whose previous three outings had all fallen prey to the weather, were eager to brave the swamps of north London, having switched the match against Surrey to Southgate from Lord's, which on Thursday had borne more than a passing resemblance to the Great Lakes. Having won their only complete fixture, their visitors were bent on another day off, and duly prevailed around midday.

Thanks to the Taunton torrents, Glenn McGrath's hotly anticipated debut for Worcestershire will have to wait until Monday's trip to Edgbaston, the scene of his maiden test on English soil in 1997.

Still, Australia's new-ball maestro found consolation in the pavilion as he watched his compatriots beat New Zealand at rugby league, as well as in the group table where the New Roadsters have drawn level with Northamptonshire at the top, leaving today's tussle between Glamorgan and Warwickshire at Sofia Gardens as a must-win for both.

The south division's sole game this weekend, tomorrow's enticing Michael Bevan-Shane Warne showdown at Hove, can settle only Sussex's elimination. Matters in the north division, where only one game, remarkably, has failed to produce a result, are appreciably more clear-cut. A home victory for Derbyshire against Yorkshire today will ensure their passage, and defeat for Leicestershire against pointless Nottinghamshire at Grace Road would all but eliminate the club who claimed the first B&H title 28 summers ago. The much put-upon Chris Lewis is expected to end his strike and face one of his less admiring exes.

Jagmohan Dalmiya, the president of the International Cricket Council, yesterday embarked on something of a war of words with Dr Ali Bacher, the South African cricket board's chief executive who this week claimed that two games in last year's World Cup were fixed.

Speaking on a television phone-in program in Calcutta, Dalmiya said: "A few days back Ali alleged that it was in this subcontinent only where match-fixing was done. Then, within 24 hours, he disowned his allegations. I am now waiting for another denial."

Saber Hossain Chowdhury, president of the Bangladesh Cricket Board, has reacted angrily to the specific allegations concerning his national team's World Cup victory over Pakistan. "We showed our mettle in every department of that game and beat Pakistan," he said. "Such an allegation will demoralise our cricket."

Indian police have said they are in no hurry to launch a formal prosecution of Hansie Cronje and the Indian bookmakers involved in match-fixing. Pradeep Srivastava of the Delhi police said: "It will be two to three months before we start the prosecutions."

The Australian Cricket Board, meanwhile, is to wait for the outcome of the emergency ICC meeting next month before committing itself to any future one-day tournaments.

fields.headline: The fast revolution
fields.trailText: Young fast bowlers are like buses: you can wait ages for one and then suddenly several arrive at once. If the 1990s saw a worldwide renaissance in spin bowling, the 2000s look set to provide a speedfest, with young fast bowlers springing up all over the place.
fields.body:
Young fast bowlers are like buses: you can wait ages for one and then suddenly several arrive at once. If the 1990s saw a worldwide renaissance in spin bowling, the 2000s look set to provide a speedfest, with young fast bowlers springing up all over the place.

There can be few cricket supporters anywhere who are still unaware of the talents of the Big Three - Shoaib Akhtar (24), Nantie Hayward (23) and Brett Lee (22), who look set to continue terrorising batsmen for years to come.

However, they are not the only young bowlers emerging around the world. Think of the West Indies and you tend to think of Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh steaming in. But nobody who saw the recent matches against Zimbabwe can have failed to be impressed by the 24-year-old Reon King, who seems ready and willing to step into their shoes: he also has Franklyn Rose and Merv Dillon forming a queue behind him. Zimbabwe, of course, have their own exciting young bowler in the shape of 23-year-old Henry Olonga.

The Asian sub-continent also boasts several talented young bowlers, who may well step out of Shoaib's shadow. Ajit Agarkar of India (22) is currently most renowned for making five consecutive ducks in the recent series against Australia, but this unfortunate notoriety should not obscure the fact that he is a fine, brisk, fast-medium bowler. Sri Lanka have the towering form of Nuwan Zoysa, only 21 and already with a Test hat-trick to his name. If he can avoid the injuries which his height and build will inevitably generate, he too should have a great future.

The only two countries which lack young fast bowlers are New Zealand and England. New Zealand do have a prodigiously talented young left-arm spinner in Daniel Vettori, but the pace ranks look a bit thin among the younger generation. Shayne O'Connor, at 26, has almost gone beyond the 'promising' stage now, and Darryl Tuffey, 21, did not have the best of Test debuts against the Aussies recently,even if that isn't always the best guide to future form.

England, of course, have 22-year-old Alex Tudor, but he will need careful nurturing if he is eventually to become the cornerstone of their attack. He hasn't played a Test since last year, and was not among those players awarded a central contract. If the ECB don't look after him now they may well have cause to regret it. After all, with fast bowling taking off again all around the world, England wouldn't want to miss the bus.

Catherine Hanley is a postgraduate student in medieval French literature at the Sheffield University

webTitle: Splash of orange to light up Reds

fields.headline: Splash of orange to light up Reds
fields.standfirst: Spending £19m on the Dutch striker will be good business if the goals continue to flow
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson's mastery of bluff was confirmed when Manchester United agreed terms for the 23-year-old Dutch striker Ruud Van Nistelrooy less than 24 hours after he dismissed his interest in the player.
fields.body:
"We've drawn up a list of priorities and at the moment Ruud van Nistelrooy is, in all honesty, not on it."

This was Sir Alex Ferguson, speaking on Wednesday afternoon, in response to a Dutch journalist's question. No wonder they say you should never believe everything you read in the newspapers.

Ferguson's mastery of bluff was confirmed when Manchester United agreed terms for the 23-year-old striker less than 24 hours later. More than that, during this week's talks with PSV, United produced no fewer than 40 scouting reports on Van Nistelrooy, going back four years to his days playing for Den Bosch and Heerenveen.

Thankfully months of newspaper speculation on whether the 6ft 2in goalscorer was going to United, Arsenal and Chelsea has given everyone a chance to master his mouthful of a name.

Van Nistelrooy will arrive in this country with his regularly repeated CV imprinted in the collective mind: 31 goals in 34 games last season and 29 so far this are impressive figures to match his British-record fee.

Though little else about the Dutch international is common knowledge, United fans should be well pleased with what they discover. He laughs a lot, lives with his girlfriend, is down to earth, prefers a slow pace to fast cars and in terms of lifestyle is more like his international room-mate Jaap Stam than his new provider David Beckham.

Born in the rural village of Oss, Van Nistelrooy began his career in the lower leagues with Noolt Gedacht and Margriet before joining Den Bosch. In 1997 he moved to Heerenveen and notched 13 goals in 30 games in his first season, offering a hint of things to come.

The following year he moved to PSV for a record fee between Dutch clubs of £4.2m. United's long-standing interest plus the stature of his mentor prove that Van Nistelrooy is the real thing.

The person he credits with his metamorphosis from a 13-goals-a-season man to scoring addict is someone more than familiar with praise this season, Bobby Robson, who arrived as coach at PSV just as Van Nistelrooy joined.

"Bobby was fantastic for me from day one," he says of the Newcastle manager. "The feeling I have with him, well you can't describe it. He got the best out of me, with good motivation and tips on how to play as a striker, how to play with a good mentality.

"He was a big factor in wanting to play in England. His stories about the Premier League, about the way of playing the game in England, have inspired me.

"He also told me about his experiences in Spain and Portugal, but the way he spoke about England - well, I never forgot that. It made a big impact."

Van Nistelrooy also received his own scouting report on United from Stam. "He said nice things. And, when we talked, I also got a sense of whether players are happy or not. I wanted a good atmosphere to play in."

It says a lot for his fine relationship with PSV that the chairman Harry van Raay agreed not to stand in the way of his ambitions and in return Van Nistelrooy agreed to stay another year if no decisive bid for him arrived by May 1, just so PSV could plan for the following season.

Arsenal had made an inquiry for him in February but never followed it up. Chelsea ruled themselves out of the running on grounds of cost. That left United. When Ferguson told Van Nistelrooy that, despite his stature as a player, he would have to accept being rotated with Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole, the United manager was not put off.

"If those are the club rules I am happy to accept them," he says. "It's an honour for every player to play for that side. They are all big names at the club, so when you play alongside them you become a better player.

"Of course every big club in Europe has two or three players in every position and at United they play so many games that maybe you have to take a rest.

"My knee has recovered from a recent injury but I am not fully match fit yet. In a few weeks I hope to be playing games. To the United fans I say I hope I can give them good times."

If Van Nistelrooy is more Stam than Beckham off the pitch, he is more Cole than Yorke on it. With a deft first touch, fast and strong, he owns a powerful shot with each foot and is very direct going for goal, sometimes to the frustration of better-placed team-mates.

There are other weaknesses. His heading could improve and he has been known to lose his temper on the pitch resulting in some silly bookings. In that respect at least Van Nistelrooy should fit in with his team-mates at Old Trafford.

What Ferguson has done is to increase his chances of scoring against the tight defences United will meet as they attempt to win back their European crown next season.

"With the number of games we have got nowadays, the strikers are the players who really need sharpness all the time," says the United manager. "They're the ones who really decide games for you."

And Ferguson reckons that Van's the man.

webTitle: Shreeves believes in the Wednesday miracle: from the bottom to Europe in one bound

fields.headline: Shreeves believes in the Wednesday miracle: from the bottom to Europe in one bound
fields.trailText: Only a few weeks into his tenure at Sheffield Wednesday the one-time London cabbie Peter Shreeves is winning over the natives. He talks to Daniel Taylor.
fields.body:
Not long after Danny Wilson had been summoned for one final tete-a-tete with Sheffield Wednesday's chairman, a local radio phone-in offered fans the opportunity to air their views on the club's choice of short-term successor.

"I suppose Peter Shreeves is an all-right kind of bloke," began one caller, somewhat half-heartedly. "It's just, well, isn't he a bit Steptoe and Son?"

Presumably when Wednesday disclosed they were bringing back a familiar face who had been around the block a few times, dripped with gold and harboured a dewy-eyed fondness for Frank Sinatra, most supporters were hoping for Ron Atkinson, orchestrator of their great escape circa 1998, rather than his nasal sidekick.

For all his experience and know-how, Shreeves was hardly expected to provide a suitable antidote for long-suffering supporters overdosing on despair. Yet only a few weeks into his tenure the one-time London cabbie is winning over the natives. He has presided over something that most Wednesdayites had long forgotten about, back-to-back wins, and another three points at home to Sunderland today would see them lurching further towards the safety hatch.

"I don't think I've ever been stopped in the street more in my life," he says. "It's known for me to go into a pub and not be noticed but now there are people wanting autographs and passing on their best wishes everywhere I go.

"When I arrived here I was the only crusader who thought we could survive. There were not many people who believed what I was preaching but I've picked up a few converts along the way. We've lifted the public of Sheffield and put ourselves in a fighting position. More and more people are believing we can get out of this predicament."

Until now it has been a sombre campaign. Wednesday propped up the Premiership for six long months but are finally showing signs of life. They have moved to within five points of free-falling Wimbledon and have conceded only two goals in four games as well as mugging Chelsea in the week that Gianluca Vialli's players were tentatively eyeing a European Cup semi-final.

"We need to keep clean sheets," Shreeves says, "because we hardly score buckets of goals, do we? It has been a good week and it has been easy taking training when everyone is buoyed like this.

"There was a depression about the place a couple of weeks back but there are nine or 10 players of international calibre here. On paper we should never have been in this position." Unfortunately for Wednesday, football is still played on grass.

Hillsborough's centenary season has been memorable more for its boardroom back-biting and political meddling than anything achieved on the playing field. And with Leeds and Arsenal still to come, they remain favourites to take the plunge. So it was bordering on the absurd for the subject of European football to be raised with the manager yesterday.

Apparently, when it comes to discipline the Owls are actually pussycats. They have had fewer bookings and sendings-off than any other Premiership side and if they cling to the top of the Fair Play League they will be entered into a draw for next season's Uefa Cup. It could be a pub- quiz question for years to come: Which side were relegated to the First Division but still merited a place in Europe?

"If our good conduct means we could be pitting our wits in Europe next season, then let's take advantage," says Shreeves. "I seem to remember that West Ham had a good run in Europe this season after getting in through unconventional means.

"We're a well disciplined side, we don't get many yellow or red cards and I won't tolerate anyone back-chatting referees. I'm a big supporter of the job they do."

For the time being, however, it is the progress of Wimbledon rather than Milan which dominates thoughts and minds inside Hillsborough.

Shreeves would relish taking the job on a permanent basis and Wednesday would surely not risk an umpteenth public relations disaster by looking elsewhere should he complete a remarkable feat of escapology. Furthermore, he can be guaranteed a glowing reference from Atkinson after their spells together at Wednesday and Nottingham Forest.

"I'm positive they will stay up, convinced of it," volunteers Big Ron. "And if they do, I would make Shreevesy chairman. Get that other lot out.

"He's worked with the likes of myself, Terry Venables, Keith Burkinshaw and several others and he's one of the most dedicated, organised people you will ever meet.

"I've been saying Wednesday will survive ever since he was appointed. In fact I'm cursing myself for not having a few quid on it. They looked dead and buried at one stage but the best odds I got were 10-1. But mark my words, Wednesday will be all right with this guy in charge."

Premiership survival and European qualification? It could yet be a summer of celebration in the old steel city.

webTitle: Pirates drift into a storm in the port

fields.headline: Pirates drift into a storm in the port
fields.standfirst: Rovers are in need but they can expect no charity in the Bristol derby
fields.trailText: Russell Thomas on Bristol's opposing blue and red camps have regrouped this week for today's derby between City and Rovers at the Memorial stadium.
fields.body:
Ian Holloway said his Bristol Rovers team had been mugged after Preston stole away with victory last Saturday. He might as easily have been describing Rovers' bitter rivals' fate the next day, when Bristol City were "robbed" of Wembley silverware by a debatable Stoke winner.

Bristol's opposing blue and red camps have regrouped this week for today's derby at the Memorial stadium. The greater pressure is on fourth-placed Rovers: they dare not surrender further promotion ground as well as local pride.

Scott Davidson, the chairman of City (ninth), attempts to pile on the pressure. "Rovers have everything to lose," he says. "This derby is make-or-break for them in terms of the two automatic promotion places. And since I've been in charge I've not lost a derby and Ian Holloway hasn't won one."

This will be a red rag to Holloway, a Bristolian who has always nailed his colours to the Pirates' mast. "I probably take our results too personally because Rovers are my club and I am a supporter as well."

They have led the Second Division four times this season and were in the top two for 2 months until April Fool's Day. On that day a thrilling 3-3 draw with Stoke was sullied by an alleged attack on the visitors' goalkeeper Gavin Ward which could bring the two pitch invaders life bans. With only two points from their past six matches, Holloway appreciates the need to remain cool. "I won't need to motivate anyone," he says. "I just have to keep them calm, to play with their heads rather than their hearts."

Rovers urgently need further goal explosions from the division's most prolific striking partnership - 23 goals each - of Jamie Cureton and Jason Roberts, the latter a powerful, pacy 22-year-old who nearly joined City two years ago. But the side's balance has been badly affected by injuries that have claimed four midfielders since Christmas.

The team's recent slide has prompted local cynics to claim Rovers do not want to go up, suggesting the club cannot cope on and off the field with the demands of a higher division. But in last Saturday's match programme Holloway insisted: "We can afford to go up, we want to go up and we are trying our hardest to go up."

Rovers have projected a more confident and vibrant image since returning to the city in 1996 after 10 years' exile in Bath and, crucially in terms of going forward, they own the stadium they share with Bristol rugby club. Their success this season has been rewarded by their highest average crowd for more than 20 years. "There's a good new mood about it," says the commercial manager Ralph Ellis. "The club is very ambitious."

As the face of the city changes, Rovers are eagerly exploring opportunities to attract and retain support in one of Britain's biggest conurbations. "It's a huge city," Ellis says, "and a new city in the sense that a large population has moved to the area because of new technologies and business. We know there are Arsenal, Tottenham and Man United fans out there; what we've got to do is convince them to have a look at Bristol Rovers." The club "has the third or fourth biggest community scheme in the country".

City and Davidson, meanwhile, are looking to a new generation of players from their admired academy. The presence of four players between 17 and 20 at Wembley last Sunday points to the strategy they will pursue to return to the First Division

"The club is too big and unwieldy to break even in the Second Division," Davidson says. "The profit [£600,000-plus] from our Auto Windscreens run has rescued our season financially. We have to be in the First."

Whether Tony Fawthrop, in caretaker charge of the team, is given the job permanently in the summer remains to be seen. City have shown impressive form under him, their fourth manager in 18 months. But Peter Taylor is reportedly still "very interested" in the job after missing out last summer, and Davidson hints that the former England Under-21 coach, who is without a contract at Gillingham, is Fawthrop's principal rival.

"The shortlist is a very short one," he says, "and there is a candidate who would be available and who has the credentials the club is looking for."

fields.headline: Advocaat is ready to party
fields.trailText: Rangers manager Dick Advocaat talks about winning the Scottish Premiership, Ruud Van Nistelrooy, the Gers' fans and Europe.
fields.body:
Dick Advocaat never gives the impression that he would be first on his feet at a Friday night karaoke session but one could only assume yesterday that he was dressed up for a party. There could be no other excuse for wearing a jacket that was a cross between a Day-Glo top and a genuine Harris Tweed.

The Rangers manager has never been a dedicated follower of fashion. Business is done quickly and most times politely. What he does away from Ibrox has escaped the tabloids, apart from a fairly serious scrape in his car and a sighting at a Neil Sedaka concert.

But this afternoon or tomorrow night, when Rangers are at St Johnstone, he should claim his second Scottish championship. That is all that matters to the fans, who accord the Dutchman a kind of respect that they do not always show to their own.

"The expectations here are so high - from the club, the fans and the media," Advocaat said. "People expected us to be challenged harder by Celtic because they have a new manager and have spent over £16m on new players and they are a club that likes to talk about money. "But we had three wins and a draw against them - I admit with bits of luck going our way - and we are 18 points ahead of them with six games left. The best I did with PSV Eindhoven was to win a Dutch league losing five games and so far this season Rangers have lost only one."

Advocaat's mastery of the English language is now sufficiently sophisticated that he can clearly give the impression that putting Celtic to the sword is a highly enjoyable experience, even if he does not precisely say so. And his record this season is all the more impressive for the difficulties he overcame without continual recourse to the cheque-book.

"We were talking about this the other day," said the striker Rod Wallace. "Do you know that every one of the first team was out injured for at least a part of the season but we all pulled together and got the job done."

Advocaat lost Michael Mols from the start of November and has been without Craig Moore for the past month. In fairness, as he would say, the injuries to the Celtic pair of Paul Lambert and Henrik Larsson were probably more damaging but Rangers were not without their own problems.

He was forced to use 31 players in the league, including five goalkeepers. Of course most of the rest of the league are sparring partners but it is still a considerable feat of logistics to keep that number of men happy with their lot and ready to make a contribution when needed.

Eventually it will count for nothing because, although this will be Rangers' 49th championship and their 12th in the past 14 years, they will ultimately be judged on making advances in Europe.

Even before the title had been won, the agenda had moved on to next season's Champions League. Advocaat had been hoping to persuade Ruud van Nistelrooy, the PSV striker who agreed yesterday to join Manchester United, to come to Scotland.

"For Rangers it would have been too big a risk even if he had been prepared to go along with it," he said, "but £19m isn't a risk for them.

"I don't quite understand why everyone compares us to United. We outclassed Bayern Munich over two games and had good spells against Valencia in our group and those are the clubs who might contest the final.

"Manchester United have spent about £100m on transfer fees and salaries to get where they are and that is not possible for us to do all of a sudden. But we are a good team at that level as well."

fields.headline: Book of the week
fields.trailText: Motya - Unearthing a Lost Civilisation | Lost White Tribes - Journeys Among the Forgotten | The Pharaoh's Shadow
fields.body:
Motya - Unearthing a Lost Civilisation, by Gaia Servadio
(Victor Gollancz, £16.99)
A civilised bunch, the ancient Greeks. When they stormed Motya, a tiny Phoenician outpost off the coast of Sicily, they burned and raped like the barbarians they despised. So sudden was the massacre that the inhabitants barely had time to bury their valuables.

Calamity, of course, is the mother of romance. Imagine. An island in the Med, veined with buried walls, stuffed with hidden riches. A beach where every boulder is a stone sarcophagus. A paradise of figs and grilled fish where the sun sets behind ruined watchtowers, 2,500 years old. Servadio skips none of the romance as she tells the story of Motya from its heyday as a daughter of Carthage to its rediscovery in the heroic age of archaeology.

But romantics beware. This is Mafia country - a place where the present can be almost as nasty as the past.

Lost White Tribes - Journeys Among the Forgotten, by Riccardo Orizio
(Secker & Warburg, £15.99)
"Perhaps, although they're trash, they think they're better than we are." That was the author's Sinhalese friend, giving his verdict on a young white waiter in a small hotel in Sri Lanka. "He's only a Dutch Burgher. Don't bother your head about them."

But Orizio did bother. In fact he became quite fascinated with these "lost white tribes" - Germans, French, Dutch, Poles - poor descendants of the rich white colonists who couldn't afford to take a steamer home when the colonial dream ended. Too white for some, too native for others, their society, says Orizio, is often "a closed, incestuous microcosm". And for many, the future holds nothing but extinction.

The Pharaoh's Shadow, by Anthony Sattin
(Victor Gollancz, £20)
What could be more dead and gone than the customs and beliefs of Ancient Egypt? Pharoahs, priests, cults and gods, all are done and dusted, swept aside by Christianity and Islam, buried in sand and mobile phones. Or are they? In the 1920s, the anthropologist Winifred Jackman suggested that many of the ancient ways had in fact survived the passing millennia, and could be traced in the manners and rituals of ordinary Egyptians.

Could it be true? Sattin's curiosity was awakened when he witnessed a woman in a remote temple calling on one of the old gods to bless her with a child. Sure enough, when he began looking - whether in the streets of Cairo or the cemeteries of Alexandria - he found evidence that paganism is alive and well. But how much longer can it hold out against the modernisers and the fundamentalists?

A Shopper's Guide to Paris Fashion, by Alicia Drake
(Metro, £9.99)
As somebody who buys his clothes at M&S, and will continue to do so until media pressure forces them to cater exclusively for people with more money than tummy, I have little interest in where Jeff Goldblum buys his relaxed, chic menswear (Marcel Lassance, Rue du Vieux Colombier). Nor do I care where Hillary Clinton buys Chelsea's ballet gear (Repetto, Rue de la Paix) or Mick Hucknall takes a steam bath when shopping in the 3rd and 4th Arrondissements (Les Bains du Marais, Rue des Blancs Manteaux).

If I did (and I don't), then this book, with its "insider secrets" about sales that aren't really sales and designer clothes that aren't really designer clothes (they just look like them) would be perfect for me. Now where was I? Ah yes. M&S.

Home Truths, by Bill Murphy
(Mainstream, £7.99)
Forget John Peel's optimistic Radio 4 programme of the same name. Murphy spent eight months touring ordinary English towns and cities and concludes that, with the possible exception of Norwich ("I suppose Norwich really is the least objection able place outside London"), the country and all who sail in her have gone to the dogs.

To give him credit, he went where few travel writers venture - places such as Woking, Macclesfield, Huntingdon and Romford - and spent his time in the town-centre pubs and cheap Chinese restaurants, the 1960s housing estates and the 1980s shopping malls that are home to most of the English most of the time.

In Braintree, he noted that all the women have tattoos. In Stoke, he reckoned that only the prostitutes were having a good time. But although some of this needed saying, more of it didn't. And John Peel would have said it with more compassion.

Hungry for Home, by Cole Moreton
(Viking, £14.99)
Five years ago, I stood on the edge of Kerry - the most westerly point of the European mainland - and gazed across the sea at a distant mountain. It was a sunny day, and I couldn't for the life of me see why, half a century ago, an entire community had begged to be evacuated from what looked to my town-weary eyes like some island paradise.

But as I wandered around the modern "interpretation centre", read the newspaper cuttings and studied the stormy black-and-white photos, I began to understand something of what life must have been like for those last inhabitants of the Blasket Islands.

Blasket. The very name smells of wet stone. So where did they end up, those sur vivors of an ancient race who had lived as medieval peasants within my own lifetime? Moreton set out to trace the exiled families and found many of them living now in the most modern country in the world.

The Independent Hostel Guide, edited by Sam Dalley
(The Backpackers Press, £4.95)
Mrs Wilkins has a vacancy. In here, see? It's a delightful room, right at the front of the bungalow, and overlooking the cul-de-sac. The bedspread is pink and peach candlewick, although you can hardly see it. For this is where Mrs Wilkins keeps the 83 soft toys that she knitted in between embroidering the frilled pillow cases and making the dried-flower pictures of woodland scenes that adorn the dressing table.

Breakfast is between seven and eight, the bathroom (more embroidery) is across the landing, and Mrs Wilkins sleeps in here (taps plaster-board partition wall) with Mr Wilkins, who is a part-time fireman with a fine baritone snore.

Bed and breakfast - don't you love it? But in this country, where a night's shelter is rated a luxury item, what are the alternatives? There's a room above the main refrigeration unit at The Westbrook (residents' bar, parking at rear, all cards accepted), but that will set you back £65 - and plenty more if you so much as look at the mini-bar or the bedside telephone.

Perhaps it's time to think about a backpackers' hostel. They seem to be everywhere these days, from Snowdon to Hadrian's Wall, and you'll even find a handful in central London. There are nearly 300 listed here, and for the first time this guide includes a selection in Europe. Many are worth visiting for the names alone (try the Barn at the Back of Beyond, Stronsay Fish Mart and Shitlington Crag Bunkhouse) and prices start at around £8 per night. Facilities range from a simple sleeping platform to single room with bedding. But don't panic. Candlewick is simply not an option.

Catfish & Mandala, by Andrew X Pham
(Flamingo, £10.99)
A young man takes a year out to cycle alone around the Pacific Rim to Vietnam . . . comes home and writes a book about his adventures . . . haven't we read it a thousand times before? But wait. This is different.

Pham's family were "boat people". A young child when Saigon fell, he grew up as a Vietnamese-American in California. He was neither Vietnamese nor American, and he wondered what the hyphen meant. His father had been in a Viet-Cong prison camp, and his sister wanted to be a boy. On the street, war vets would tell him, "I was in Nam and I'm really sorry."

Sooner or later, he had to make that painful trip, to see for himself the fat American tourists squeezing themselves into narrow VC dug-outs, or buying model helicopter gunships fashioned from Coke tins. At the end of it all, he wrote the book - not about himself, but about two war-scarred countries, separated by a hyphen.
