fields.headline: European cities of culture: Bergen
fields.standfirst: This year there are nine European Cities of Culture, and they are not the ones you might expect.  Jonathan Glancey starts his artistic trawl in Bergen
fields.trailText: This year there are nine European Cities of Culture, and they are not the ones you might expect. Jonathan Glancey starts his artistic trawl in Bergen.
fields.body:
Fish. There's no getting away from the word, the smell or the slippery things themselves. Fish, fish and fish again. That's Bergen for you on a plate. It also happens to be one of the several European cities of culture this year and, as its tourist season is just beginning (too cold for most non-Vikings before Easter), it was a must on my itinerary of world cities yet to be visited.

If there was an I-Spy Book of Bergen, fish would feature largely but score few points because our scaly friends inform the Norwegian city as surely as lace does Bruges, the baroque does Salzburg and pork pies Melton Mowbray. As for culture, it's not as thin on the ground as I thought it would be. This isn't meant to be patronising. It's just that Bergenis not the first city to swim into the mind when the word culture, with its art-world ramifications, surfaces.

Fish, I thought, my gills gaping. It can't be that bad. It was and it wasn't. I arrived on a cheap flight from Stansted. It was raining cats and dogfish. Bergen is famous for its rain. Still, the Grand Hotel Terminus by the imposing railway station was impressively old fashioned. With its stained glass, chandeliers and pre-war atmosphere, I felt abashed not arriving in tweeds, titfer, plus-fours and fishing tackle ready in search of a hearty breakfast (poached cod perhaps) before a trip along the fjords in search of Nordic beauty, the northern lights and some sport with the local fish.

As it was, I went to a friend's all-night party. I can't bear to tell you what we ate because you know already. We drank lager and aquavit (potato whisky) because that's all anyone could afford. The price of drink is as high in Bergen as the smell of the you know what.

The morning came, and I set off in search of culture. Mist hung low over a city that sprawls in long fingers away from the natural tidal inlets. The scale of Norway's second city - which I discovered largely by efficient local buses with a flat fare of about £1 - is on the large side, not because of a big population (Norway's whole population could fit into half of London; Bergen's is about 250,000), but because Norwegians tend to live in suburban-style homes.

Such low-density living does little for city life, which is why Bergen can feel a bit like a Baltic sea port of the Communist era. Museums and shops close early. A Sunday morning walk can seem dauntingly lonely. Small wonder Edvard Munch is, by general agreement, thought to be Norway's finest and most revealing painter. You can see some of the tortured master's work in the Bergen Art Museum housed in two buildings beside a lake on Rasmus Meyers Alle.

Still, Sunday is as a good a day for museum browsing as it is anywhere in Europe. And, as befits a City of Culture, there are plenty of them. The Hanseatic Museum is housed in one of the city's distinctive 16th- and 17th-century clapboard harbourfront houses. Many of these have burned down over the centuries; fires were once banned even in the depths of freezing winter.

I enjoyed the sight of the museum's impressive fish press. I learned that the historic fish storage room once processed a million pounds of fish a month and tried, without success, to imagine what those million pounds of salmon, trout, cod and herring looked like. An installation by a piscine artist high on aquavit perhaps.

In 1890, the traveller Lilian Leland wrote of Bergen, "Everything is fishy. You eat and drink fish and smell fish and breathe fish." I breathed a sigh of relief that I had missed the Monday-to-Saturday fish market at Torget. But there is no wriggling off the hook so easily. My Sunday stroll took me, in search of Bergen culture, to the Norges Fiskerimuseum where you can discover more than you will ever need to know about a certain Norwegian industry.

Ole Bulls, however, is a meaty sounding name. Or so I thought when I first saw it on written on a sign. "Hello to the mighty matador" perhaps. Or just "hello male cattle". No, it turned out to be the decidedly unhispanic name (even though Norwegian Vikings once raided Seville in their rape'n'pillage heyday) of a 19th-century virtuoso whose wonderfully camp island villa nearby is a popular Sunday afternoon excursion for local families.

Local women swooned apparently as Ole struck up on his fiddle. A mainstay of local culture, he looks harmless enough in the guise of a rather daft statue erected to his memory on my walk from the old town to the Kulturhuset USF (surely the heart, I thought, of Bergen, City of Culture 2000) via the Akvariet, the impressive city aquarium devoted to the culture of our finny friends. It is an educational place and perhaps the plaice are educated too: one of the most popular features of the aquarium is a school of herrings.

Guess what the USF in Kulturhuset USF means? Oh go on. Please. Yes, the United Sardines Factory. This has now been converted into a fjordside contemporary arts complex. It's pretty good and one of the groovy places to hang out in Bergen (of which there are few). The café, bustling with young Vikings, is, I am pleased to say, called Kafe Kippers and there's a jazz festival here next month.

The Kafe Permanenten in the basement of the downtown West Norway Applied Arts Museum is an open-sandwich kind of place during the day, but a fun dance club by night with all the usual thumpa-whumpa-whoompa sounds, dress and attitudes.

For lunch, however, my party-going gang of Celts and Vikings repaired to the Enhjorniengen restaurant, back in Bryggen, the old Hanseatic merchant town which, although the heart of tourist town and with more than enough souvenir stalls selling trolls (for Thor's sake), is ruggedly pretty. The restaurant, set in an upper floor of an 18th- century's merchant house, was very good at about £30 a head. I can hardly bare to tell you what sort of food it specialises in, but let me put it this way; if you don't like fish, try elsewhere.

The heart of Bergen's culture quarter comprises the two city art museums with plenty of Munch, and a small shoal of Toulouse- Lautrec, Picasso, Miró and Klee, but little in the way of fish. The nearby Vestlande Kunstindustrie Museum, housed in a Gothic pile (designed by a madman by the look of it), has a changing programme of contemporary design and craft exhibitions. Oh, and one of Ole Bulls' violins for the ladies in your party to swoon over. Or not.

There was just time to drop in at the intriguing Lepramuseet, housed near the cathedral in the 18th-century buildings of St Jorgens Hospital. I do not know how many leprosy museums there are in the world, but this one is a gem, pretty much untouched since it was abandoned in 1946.

Oh, and for fans of the baroque, do not miss the glorious pulpit in the Mariakirche in the centre of town. This was the church of the Hanseatic League merchants and it's easy to see them cloaked in fur praying for a fine harvest. One of their major exports to other Hanseatic cities was dried cod, a nourishing meal in wintertime.

I wanted to see Gamle Bergen (Old Bergen), a kind of troll town or open-air village displaying local architecture in the city's northern suburbs, but this was closed (until May). I went instead to see the stave church at Fantoft, three miles south of the city centre. This wonderfully spiky and animalistic Viking church dates from 1992. The identical original church, which burnt down, had been moved here from Sognefjord, elsewhere in Norway in the 1880s. This was during the heyday of the National Romantic movements that swept through Scandinavia as these countries, usually under the yoke of another, struggled through culture to find themselves. To look to their roots.

Nearby the church is Troldhaugen ("Hill of the Trolls" would you believe), the home of Bergen's other famous musician, Edvard Grieg as in the Peer Gynt Suites, Piano Concerto in A minor and Classic FM. "I make no pretensions," he said, "of being in the class with Bach, Mozart and Beethoven."

The house is a pretty enough villa, the compulsory guided tour annoying, and the sense of it being left alone since the composer's death in 1907 rather moving. Down by the shore and next to the hut where Grieg composed, stirred by the sight and sound of the sea, is the Trolshalden (oh, for pity's sake) where you can attend recitals of Grieg's music for Classic FM. (Sorry, but this troll culture was beginning to get wearing.)

Grieg and his wife, the singer Nina Hagerup, are buried in a romantic rock tomb overlooking the sea. I stood here and imagined a tall ship sailing by, just as the one did at the beginning of The Onedin Line TV series with the sweeping strings of Grieg willing it on its zephyred way. Except, it wasn't Grieg after all, but Katchachurian. Oh well. I had got the wrong song for Norway as it were. No points for me, just like Norway itself in the Eurovision Song Contest. The Song of Norway, by the way, was a rotten film about Grieg made in 1970.

I'm sorry again. I'm trying to stretch the culture I discovered in Bergen, when the truth is that I couldn't bear all this troll stuff and National Romantic 19th-century sentimentality. I was fascinated by Bergen's Hanseatic history, but captivated by its devoted allegiance to fish and all their watery ways. To an extent these two interests came together in the cobbled streets of Bryggen, where German merchants kept alive the city's Hanseatic trading tradition long after its sibling cities - London, Rostock, Riga, Aberdeen, Bruges and Novgorod among them - had abandoned this forerunner of the EU.

The Germans, in fact, kept themselves apart: fraternising with Norwegians was a punishable offence. A few hundred years later, the Germans were keen on Norway again. This time, however - the 1940s - the Norwegians, save for "quislings" (collaborators named after the decidedly fishy Vidkun Quisling who put Hitler and the Nazis above Norway and the Norwegians), weren't exactly too keen to collaborate with their southern guests.

No, the story of life and death, of culture in fact, in Bergen swims around fish. If I was an artist I would seize not on the trolls or Grieg or the legend of Ole Bulls, but on the fact that the fish market is connected directly by ferry boat to the aquarium. Life and death intimately connected.

By the time I left Bergen, I was soaked to the gills and smelling oddly of fish. I slept on the plane and dreamt I was a fish. Very Dali, very surrealist. I had had, you see, my fill of culture after all.

The practicals

Two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 777 4445) at the three-star Augustin Hotel from May 1 to August 31 (excluding bank holidays) cost £359pp based on two sharing, B&B and including return flights from Stansted. Two nights at the same hotel from Jan 4 to April 30 2001 (excluding bank holidays) cost £309pp. For further information, contact the Norwegian Tourist Office on 020 7839 6255.

The café, bustling with young Vikings, is, I am pleased to say, called Kafe Kippers and there's a jazz festival here next month. The Kafe Permanenten in the basement of the downtown West Norway Applied Arts Museum is an open-sandwich kind of place during the day, but a fun dance club by night with all the usual thumpa-whumpa-whoompa sounds, dress and attitudes. For lunch, however, my party-going gang of Celts and Vikings repaired to the Enhjorniengen restaurant, back in Bryggen, the old Hanseatic merchant town which, although the heart of tourist town and with more than enough souvenir stalls selling trolls (for Thor's sake), is ruggedly pretty. The restaurant, set in an upper floor of an 18th- century's merchant house, was very good at about £30 a head. I can hardly bare to tell you what sort of food it specialises in, but let me put it this way; if you don't like fish, try elsewhere. The heart of Bergen's culture quarter comprises the two city art museums with plenty of Munch, and a small shoal of Toulouse- Lautrec, Picasso, Miró and Klee, but little in the way of fish. The nearby Vestlande Kunstindustrie Museum, housed in a Gothic pile (designed by a madman by the look of it), has a changing programme of contemporary design and craft exhibitions. Oh, and one of Ole Bulls' violins for the ladies in your party to swoon over. Or not. There was just time to drop in at the intriguing Lepramuseet, housed near the cathedral in the 18th-century buildings of St Jorgens Hospital. I do not know how many leprosy museums there are in the world, but this one is a gem, pretty much untouched since it was abandoned in 1946. Oh, and for fans of the baroque, do not miss the glorious pulpit in the Mariakirche in the centre of town. This was the church of the Hanseatic League merchants and it's easy to see them cloaked in fur praying for a fine harvest. One of their major exports to other Hanseatic cities was dried cod, a nourishing meal in wintertime. I wanted to see Gamle Bergen (Old Bergen), a kind of troll town or open-air village displaying local architecture in the city's northern suburbs, but this was closed (until May). I went instead to see the stave church at Fantoft, three miles south of the city centre. This wonderfully spiky and animalistic Viking church dates from 1992. The identical original church, which burnt down, had been moved here from Sognefjord, elsewhere in Norway in the 1880s. This was during the heyday of the National Romantic movements that swept through Scandinavia as these countries, usually under the yoke of another, struggled through culture to find themselves. To look to their roots. Nearby the church is Troldhaugen ("Hill of the Trolls" would you believe), the home of Bergen's other famous musician, Edvard Grieg as in the Peer Gynt Suites, Piano Concerto in A minor and Classic FM. "I make no pretensions," he said, "of being in the class with Bach, Mozart and Beethoven." The house is a pretty enough villa, the compulsory guided tour annoying, and the sense of it being left alone since the composer's death in 1907 rather moving. Down by the shore and next to the hut where Grieg composed, stirred by the sight and sound of the sea, is the Trolshalden (oh, for pity's sake) where you can attend recitals of Grieg's music for Classic FM. (Sorry, but this troll culture was beginning to get wearing.) Grieg and his wife, the singer Nina Hagerup, are buried in a romantic rock tomb overlooking the sea. I stood here and imagined a tall ship sailing by, just as the one did at the beginning of The Onedin Line TV series with the sweeping strings of Grieg willing it on its zephyred way. Except, it wasn't Grieg after all, but Katchachurian. Oh well. I had got the wrong song for Norway as it were. No points for me, just like Norway itself in the Eurovision Song Contest. The Song of Norway, by the way, was a rotten film about Grieg made in 1970. I'm sorry again. I'm trying to stretch the culture I discovered in Bergen, when the truth is that I couldn't bear all this troll stuff and National Romantic 19th-century sentimentality. I was fascinated by Bergen's Hanseatic history, but captivated by its devoted allegiance to fish and all their watery ways. To an extent these two interests came together in the cobbled streets of Bryggen, where German merchants kept alive the city's Hanseatic trading tradition long after its sibling cities - London, Rostock, Riga, Aberdeen, Bruges and Novgorod among them - had abandoned this forerunner of the EU. The Germans, in fact, kept themselves apart: fraternising with Norwegians was a punishable offence. A few hundred years later, the Germans were keen on Norway again. This time, however - the 1940s - the Norwegians, save for "quislings" (collaborators named after the decidedly fishy Vidkun Quisling who put Hitler and the Nazis above Norway and the Norwegians), weren't exactly too keen to collaborate with their southern guests. No, the story of life and death, of culture in fact, in Bergen swims around fish. If I was an artist I would seize not on the trolls or Grieg or the legend of Ole Bulls, but on the fact that the fish market is connected directly by ferry boat to the aquarium. Life and death intimately connected. By the time I left Bergen, I was soaked to the gills and smelling oddly of fish. I slept on the plane and dreamt I was a fish. Very Dali, very surrealist. I had had, you see, my fill of culture after all. Two nights at the same hotel from Jan 4 to April 30 2001 (excluding bank holidays) cost £309pp. For further information, contact the Norwegian Tourist Office on 020 7839 6255.

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Krakow
fields.trailText: Poland's third city contains 2.3 million recorded artworks. In 1978, it was included in Unesco's list of world cultural heritage sites.
fields.body:
Poland's third city was largely undamaged by either the Nazis or the Red Army during the second world war. The city contains 2.3 million recorded artworks. In 1978, it was included in Unesco's list of world cultural heritage sites. The old city is densely packed and all the major cultural sites and venues are within easy walking distance of one another. It is quite magical, some of its mystery caught well in Andzrej Wyslocksi's haunting film The Double Life of Veronique. Food is smart these day, the old Communist milk bars having all but gone (sadly), but the Bar Mleczny Barcelona on ul Straszewskiego survives. Museums, churches, wonderful squares and alleys at every turn. Hard to beat for a long weekend.

Highlights: huge programme of annual events includes Organ Music days in April, Student Song Festival in May, International Festival of Short Films in May/June, Jewish Culture Festival in June, the International Festival of Street Theatre (aagh) in July and plenty more this year, the cultural theme of which is "Spirituality". A prayer will be sung every day of this year in seven different religious traditions in the city.

June: Polish descendants of the Tartars will stage a peaceable raid on the city.

Further information: Polish National Tourist Office (020-7291 9920)

Getting there: two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 777 4445) at the two-star Hotel Pollera, Krakow, now to June 30 2000 (excluding Bank Holidays) cost £341pp, based on two sharing, B&B and including return flights from Gatwick. Autoplan Holidays (01543 257777) has two nights from £260.

fields.headline: The way of the Whitaker
fields.standfirst: Jim Jarmusch's hip-hop samurai thriller Ghost Dog has provided Forest Whitaker with his coolest role to date, plus the chance to explore his spiritual side
fields.trailText: Jim Jarmusch's hip-hop samurai thriller Ghost Dog has provided Forest Whitaker with his coolest role to date, plus the chance to explore his spiritual side
fields.body:
In Ghost Dog: The Way Of The Samurai, Forest Whitaker plays a modern-day urban warrior whose loyalty to a mafia underling is as unswerving as it is fateful. Written especially for the actor by maverick director Jim Jarmusch, the role is Whitaker's most emblematic to date, one that trades on both his formidable physical presence and his abiding, contemplative air. That contrast is manifest in almost all of Whitaker's acting work, a repertoire that includes Jody, the doomed soldier in The Crying Game, and jazz great Charlie Parker in Bird. Whitaker is also the director of such high-profile "women's films" as Waiting To Exhale and Hope Floats, and head of his own film and music production company.

You're known for really inhabiting your characters and thus they influence you personally. How did this character affect you?

The notion of silence. I always thought I understood silence, but while working on this movie I spent a lot of time completely alone and solitary, and it's a powerful thing. As an actor, I walked away with more confidence about conveying my feelings without doing anything other than "keep having the thought".

To prepare, you studied hagakure, the ancient way of the samurai. Did you internalise any of that?

Yeah, I actually think some of the principles are really strong. There's one that I've been trying to apply, which is about a person considering themselves as dead. There's a meditation, and in this meditation, you inhale for 15 seconds, you hold that for 15 seconds, you exhale for 15 seconds and then you hold that for 15 seconds. So for a minute, you don't really breathe. And it's not that long, really - in the bottom of a pool I could do it, no problem - but when I do that meditation, a fear overcomes me, even though I know I'm gonna breathe no matter what. So I know that's one of those meditations that I need to figure out.

Having worked with some of cinema's great directors, like Martin Scorsese, Oliver Stone and Clint Eastwood, what would you say is unique about Jim Jarmusch?

[Smiles] Well, what's definitely unique is that nobody's telling him anything to do. It's all his money. He got it from overseas, and he shoots the movie, then he sells it, and that really is unique. I mean, even Scorsese, and even, well, I think Clint can kinda do what he wants, know what I mean? But on the whole, they still have to have conversations behind the scenes. Jarmusch doesn't have to have them. But I think the thing that's most unique about him is his way of looking at the world. And that I could never get from him, cause it's his spirit, it's the way he thinks. It's very meditative in its own way. I think most of his movies are meditative, don't you? They have a very poetic flow.

In the past, you've talked about how you used to be very shy, that you would spend a lot of time alone. How is that different from your solitude on this film?

Before I was afraid. I was like the monk who can't leave the temple. If I went to parties, if I had too many interviews, I would feel ill, physically depleted. This solitude with Ghost Dog is totally different. There was no worry or fear. Now, it's more like a dream, now I walk the streets, I can deal with people, I can go sit in Starbucks, no problem.

So, the death meditation's working then?

[Laughs ] I wish!

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Bologna
fields.trailText: This impressive city is as famous for its left-wing politics as its cooking. A McDonald's, however, has been provided for tourists and snappily-dressed teenagers doing their best to be rebellious.
fields.body:
Impressive city as famous for its left-wing politics as its cooking. A McDonald's, however, has been provided for tourists and snappily-dressed teenagers doing their best to be rebellious. The centre is marked by the twin leaning towers of the Asinelli and Garisenda families. The former is worth climbing 498 steps for a commanding view of the city. As much culture as you want: try the Pinacoteca Nazionale (Giotto, Raphael), the Capella di San Domenico (Michelangelo), the restored anatomy theatre where Rossini first performed his glorious Stabat Mater in 1842 and, of course, the courtyard of the Chiesa del San Sepolcro where you will find the basin in which Pilate washed his hands at the end of his cross-examination of Christ. Oh, all right, its only 1,200 years old really, but it's a good story all the same.

Highlights: Exhibitions of visual and performing arts in The Palace of King Enzo, and music exhibitions in the Sanguinetti Palace.

Further information: www.bologna2000.it

Getting there: Two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 777 4445) at the two-star San Giorgio Hotel, Bologna, from April 25 to July 15 2000 (excluding Bank Holidays) is £307pp based on two sharing, B&B and including return flights from Gatwick.

fields.headline: The inside story
fields.standfirst: This week, Britain and Spain signed a deal over the Rock. Deep underground in the military labyrinth,  Nigel Fountain feels the weight of history above his head
fields.trailText: This week, Britain and Spain signed a deal over the Rock. Deep underground in the military labyrinth, Nigel Fountain feels the weight of history above his head.
fields.body:
My queasiness about the underworld flickered on somewhere just off the Great North Road, past the Peterborough stop. I was 100 feet under Gibraltar's Rock Hotel, on the periphery of the 30 miles of second world war tunnels. The Great North Road and Fosse Way are two main thoroughfares within that system. They are breathtaking; vast arches into the void, stone manifestations of curious conceits, the Rock Drill, Whitehall's secret states of the mind.

In the other world, we had driven up the west side of the cliff-face, past the hotel and parked by an anonymous, gated opening into the Rock. We walked inside, and a few hundred yards on, a series of narrow tunnels culminated in a Nissen hut inside a man-made cave, the stuff of post-bomb Bed Sitting Room surrealism. The British have not only scattered the planetary crust with Nissen huts but sandwiched them under it as well. The hut had windows, an antidote to the claustrophobia, my submariner guide observed, homely reassurance to soldierly troglodytes.

I was not reassured. The damp heat enveloped me.

"In time, the Rockies may crumble, Gibraltar may tumble," I thought, "they're only made of clay." But Ira Gershwin got it wrong. Gibraltar, the Moors' Djebel Tarik (the mountain of Tarik) is not clay but bedded limestone, good tunnelling material. And the military in general, and the British armed forces in particular, like few things more than a good burrow.

During the second world war, the Royal Engineers were digging up to 180ft a week. Under the Rock, the material was accumulated for Operation Torch, the 1943 allied invasion of North Africa. Here, they resolved that, if Gibraltar finally fell after two and half centuries of British occupation, some dogged band would remain, walled inside some tunnel, pedalling up bike- powered electricity, padding across cork-insulated floors, keeping an eye out, waiting for something to turn up.

We strolled on, past Maunsell's Wind joint-operations centre, the Admiralty Tunnel, and the "Durham Adit". There, someone had left a heap of anti-submarine netting. Later, we came across a spectacular shopping mall for the military; a cavern space devoted to ventilation equipment, sucking in the oxygen supply for the stone machine; a vast 1950s diesel-turbine engine - suitable for Alien's prehistoric spacecraft; the sickly smell from a drained wartime sea of oil and an underground hospital. This had its showers and baths and Vulcania lavatories and a mortuary slab as the centrepiece of the nurses' dormitory.

Beyond were more skeletal Nissen huts, down alleys, up stairs, with crazy lurching bedsteads where once squaddies slept and dreamed of Barnsley and Chatham.

In that urgent present of the 1940s, the Royal Engineers dug back into several pasts. Occasionally, they broke into the cave system that was a home to our ancestors and to the last survivors of our rivals, the Neanderthals.

The second world war sappers extended the tunnel system of their predecessors from the Spanish-French siege of 1779-82. The British and the Dutch had taken Gibraltar in 1704 and the British held it. The legal battle with Spain has dragged on until this week.

The men of the 18th century constructed emplacements in the North Face from which they had showered La Linea (the line of the Spanish border) with cannon balls and "hot potatoes" - red-hot shot. Looking up at the North Face today, what seem to be blots on the landscape are those 18th-century emplacements and their successors from the 20th century.

There is about Gibraltar a sense of frozen time, frozen history, unfinished business from lost empires, Roman, Moorish, Spanish, British.

Its Main Street follows the line set down by the Moors 700 years ago. As for La Linea, it is now is a border town, huddled at the foot of the Rock, ludicrously near, an unresolved siege turned into mundane bricks and mortar and sharing its EuroDisney modern architecture and council high-rise style with the Rock.

One sunny evening, I floated on the funicular to the ridge, above orange-tiled houses, birds, and barbary apes and looked out across the Mediterranean, the Atlantic, Europe and Africa. Below, along the line of Charles V's 16th-century Spanish defensive wall - built on a Moorish wall - a 19th-century English cemetery provided a last resting place for casualties from the nearby Battle of Trafalgar.

West across the bay was Spain's Algeciras; just to its north was an oil refinery, built on the site of a 3,000-year-old Phoenican trading town; 14 miles south was Mons Abila on the African mainland which, with Gibraltar (Mons Calpe) comprised the Pillars of Hercules two millennia ago.

When the Moors arrived 1,300 years ago, they placed a mosque down at Europa point. When the Spanish began their forays, the mosque was sacked and transformed into Our Lady of Europa, a warning to the Moslem world. When the protestant Anglo-Dutch arrived they threw Our Lady into the Bay, a warning that north Europeans - and booze has been a scourge of the British presence - don't mix with alcohol. Salvaged, Our Lady was returned to her elegant white church. Three years ago, the Saudis funded the construction of the "Mosque of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques" nearby, a calling card in marble.

Meanwhile, the Spanish and Gibraltarians fret about the children of the Moors across the straits and their dreams of Europe's industrial paradise. On the Rock, within the Rock, the British still track the passing traffic.

Anyway "Mammon is the God of Gibraltar," according to Richard Ford in his great Handbook for Travellers in Spain (1845). Gibraltar was an "arid and torrid rock" where "all creeds are free and all agree in exclusive money worship" and where the traveller was tormented with "cads and touters". The town, he went on, "is stuffy and sea-coaly, the houses wooden and druggetted and built on Liverpool pattern, under a tropical climate, but transport an Englishman where you will, like a snail he takes his home and his habits with him."

The fleet was the core of that world, and it has gone. The Gibraltarians, more British than the British, are now self-governing - unrecognised by Madrid and ignored by British public opinion. Yet 300 years as dinner lady to RN has taken its toll. The Gibraltarians derive from a splendid mixture of races - Genoans, Arabs, Jews, Spanish, et al - but the British tunnelled into their soul. Take a walk down Main Street and count the pubs threatening steak pie and chips and a pint of Websters. Stand in the 18th-century Casemates Square and con template California Real English fish 'n' chips and adjacent Burger King. Then retire, as I did, to a blue-tiled Kosher restaurant, out of the 1930s, up Bomb House Lane and over the road from the ruins of the wonderful 14th-century Moorish baths.

I stared at the North Face as I flew out of that curious fortress-cum-tiny city state. Long ago, the ancients had another belief about Gibraltar. On it was the gate to Pluto's land of the dead, Hades lay within the Rock. They were right of course. They just got the timing wrong - and forgot about the Nissen huts.

The practicals

Nigel Foiunatin flew from Luton by Monarch Airlines Crown Service (07800 405040), £114-£228 return. BA (0345 222111) from Gatwick return £136-£299 plus taxes. He stayed at the Elliot Hotel (00350 70500). Cadogan, Cresta, Crystal Holidays First Choice and Prestige Holidays offer three-night packages includongfligts and accomodation from £249-£416 per head. Hercules Travel (00350 76070) arranges transfers, accomodation and excursions for independent travellers. the 18th century tunnels are open daily. To visit the second world war tunnels, contact the Tourist Board in Gibraltar (00350 74982) giving at leats 48 hours notice. Admission is £2 per head.

Three years ago, the Saudis funded the construction of the "Mosque of the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques" nearby, a calling card in marble. Meanwhile, the Spanish and Gibraltarians fret about the children of the Moors across the straits and their dreams of Europe's industrial paradise. On the Rock, within the Rock, the British still track the passing traffic. Anyway "Mammon is the God of Gibraltar," according to Richard Ford in his great Handbook for Travellers in Spain (1845). Gibraltar was an "arid and torrid rock" where "all creeds are free and all agree in exclusive money worship" and where the traveller was tormented with "cads and touters". The town, he went on, "is stuffy and sea-coaly, the houses wooden and druggetted and built on Liverpool pattern, under a tropical climate, but transport an Englishman where you will, like a snail he takes his home and his habits with him." The fleet was the core of that world, and it has gone. The Gibraltarians, more British than the British, are now self-governing - unrecognised by Madrid and ignored by British public opinion. Yet 300 years as dinner lady to RN has taken its toll. The Gibraltarians derive from a splendid mixture of races - Genoans, Arabs, Jews, Spanish, et al - but the British tunnelled into their soul. Take a walk down Main Street and count the pubs threatening steak pie and chips and a pint of Websters. Stand in the 18th-century Casemates Square and con template California Real English fish 'n' chips and adjacent Burger King. Then retire, as I did, to a blue-tiled Kosher restaurant, out of the 1930s, up Bomb House Lane and over the road from the ruins of the wonderful 14th-century Moorish baths. I stared at the North Face as I flew out of that curious fortress-cum-tiny city state. Long ago, the ancients had another belief about Gibraltar. On it was the gate to Pluto's land of the dead, Hades lay within the Rock. They were right of course. They just got the timing wrong - and forgot about the Nissen huts. He stayed at the Elliot Hotel (00350 70500). Cadogan, Cresta, Crystal Holidays First Choice and Prestige Holidays offer three-night packages includongfligts and accomodation from £249-£416 per head. Hercules Travel (00350 76070) arranges transfers, accomodation and excursions for independent travellers. the 18th century tunnels are open daily. To visit the second world war tunnels, contact the Tourist Board in Gibraltar (00350 74982) giving at leats 48 hours notice. Admission is £2 per head.

fields.headline: Scotland's open policy
fields.trailText: Access to the countryside in Scotland is about to go through a revolution that will give people wider rights than in most European countries and could set a radical precedent for the future in the rest of the United Kingdom.
fields.body:
Access to the countryside in Scotland is about to go through a revolution that will give people wider rights than in most European countries and could set a radical precedent for the future in the rest of the United Kingdom.

While people in England and Wales will soon have legal right of access to open and uncultivated land - the so-called right to roam - the Scots are looking forward to being granted access everywhere, including cultivated farmland, forests, riverbanks and the coast.

A draft bill proposing these rights will be introduced to the Scottish Parliament in the next few weeks, and the backing of the Executive - a Labour-Liberal coalition - and the Scottish National Party makes it virtually certain it will become law.

What is perhaps most surprising is that the main representatives of land owners support the legislation, which is based on the unanimous recommendations of an Access Forum which brought relevant bodies together and deliberated for 18 months.

The legislation creates a mirror-image of the situation in England and Wales, where there is no access to private land unless a right of way is established or conceded. In Scotland, it's expected that that access will be limited only for reasons of privacy and environ mental protection, and the challenge will be to manage it successfully.

A vital part of the new bill will require local councils to establish and maintain a "core network" of paths, especially near towns and cities in the Lowlands, where it is felt that comparatively few routes for walking, cycling and riding are available.

"The effect is likely to be a huge change in attitude," says Dave Morris, director of the Ramblers' Association Scotland. "Users will be a lot more confident once they have this right to go anywhere, providing they don't do any damage, while landowners will have the responsibility of accepting that freedom and welcoming people.

"It shouldn't be too difficult - the Duke of Buccleuch is the biggest landowner in Scotland and he's been operating on that basis for years.

"People coming to Scotland with loads of money to buy up land will be told that people will have access to that land and this is something they'll have to deal with."

Meanwhile, pressure groups in England and Wales are looking beyond the imminent "right to roam" legislation and preparing to push for right of access to riverbanks and woodland as well. Many recognise, however, that access to the heavily-cultivated farmland in parts of England might prove more difficult.

fields.headline: Early risers
fields.standfirst: Steve Chamberlain gets the chance to play Richard Branson, hitching a lift with the hot-air heroes of the balloon world
fields.trailText: Steve Chamberlain gets the chance to play Richard Branson, hitching a lift with the hot-air heroes of the balloon world.
fields.body:
There is only one problem with ballooning. The hours. In order to catch the perfect weather conditions, the ideal time of day is somewhere between dawn and 11 o'clock. Which means you have to be up well before sunrise to lick a finger, stick it in the air and decide if today is going to be a goer or not.

Consequently, on this mad, week-long dash the length of Portugal by balloon, I spend a lot of time when I should be sleeping, worrying about being left behind. On the first morning, I have overcompensated and am up while it is still dark, shivering in the pre-dawn chill. And to think I had expected warm, blue skies.

Nineteen teams from all over Europe and one from the US have gathered in Bragança for the fourth annual race. As the pilots test their gas burners, everyone gathers round and holds up their hands gratefully to the heat.

The sun comes up, and the crews (usually three or four people including the pilot) begin a well-rehearsed process for inflating the balloons. Ropes and wires are checked, fixed and double-checked, baskets are equipped with gas bottles, maps and satellite-navigation equipment and big portable fans blow air into the envelopes which start to take on more recognisable shapes. One of them, in pink, yellow and blue, which is starting to strain for the sky, belongs to Willy Wuetrich and is to be my ride for the day.

Willy has a brand-new envelope, and today will be its first flight. As four of us struggle to hold down the lurching monster, he gives a final blast on the burner and tells us to jump in quick. Then we are shooting skywards at a surprisingly fast rate.

Looking down into the stadium, I see we are among the first off. Does this mean we are looking good for the race? Willy smiles: "It is not so much a race as a social event. Yes, we get points for how far we go, but not many of us are worrying about positions. We just want to fly."

So, unconcerned about competition, we drift a few thousand feet above red-tiled roofs and rolling hills. Already, one or two balloons that have found the right winds have become vague, ghostly shapes in the distance.

As the sun warms up the land, it creates pockets of rising air. The more of these you get, the more unsteady the ride becomes. "You don't want fast winds in a balloon," says Willy.

The landing is softer than anything I've ever experienced in a passenger jet. The recovery team are with us pretty quickly and Willy breaks out the wine to celebrate the safe inaugural flight of the new balloon.

He doesn't tell me until now that he destroyed his old one at this same race last year, crashing into trees in high winds.

The next stage for the race is Vila Nova de Foz Ca. By now, I have a practised eye and can tell as soon as we get to the take-off point - another football stadium - that today is a good day. Bright and fresh with hardly any wind.

At first, all the balloons hover in the stadium, clustered together like fruit in a bowl. But, gradually, different breezes pull them apart. Suspicious farmers give us sharp looks at the prospect of an impromptu landing on their cabbages.

At each stage, we are welcomed by the host town and treated to a huge meal. The crowds of spectators are also becoming larger the further south we travel. Each day brings a little more sleep deprivation - which makes it harder and harder to get out of bed while it's still dark.

Tuesday morning is very windy and, as we hang around the local airfield, someone puts up a kite. A pessimist points out: "It's always bad news when they fly a kite." Another voice adds: "Kites will be the only things flying today."

By the time we arrive in the walled Roman town of Évora, the wind is calm enough for an evening flight. I join Pedro Cotovia, a Portuguese pilot flying on his home turf. This evening's mission is to take off outside town, fly in low and attempt to drop a marker on a target.

We are up fast and high into the gathering dusk. By now it is hard to spot which area we are heading for, and after 20 minutes it's clear we are slightly off course, and we eventually pass about 300 yards off target.

Over clearer country on the other side of Évora, we begin our descent, but the wind has picked up and we are travelling at quite a lick by now. Heading for a field which looks clear, Pedro dumps the remaining gas in the balloon by pulling on a rope which opens a hole in the top. We plummet fast and hit the ground hard.

For a couple of seconds, we bounce along and the three of us in the basket roll around and get better acquainted, but eventually we are down. We look up and see that we have landed neatly between two barbed-wire fences that were hardly visible from the air. "Skill," says Pedro confidently.

On Thursday, I am grounded again, so I join the recovery team for Rob Bayley's balloon. Rob crossed the Atlantic by balloon in 1992, so as he takes off into a misty morning I anticipate a long drive to find him.

Despite modern communications technology, you still have to rely on the naked eye and good old map reading to follow a balloon - and satel lite navigation doesn't help if there's no gate in a field or no road over a hill.

When we eventually catch up with Rob, there's a slightly tense moment when the farmer arrives, but he could not be happier that Rob has chosen his field to land in.

Rob says this is often the best part about ballooning: "It's the ultimate way to travel off the beaten track - and dropping in on someone with a balloon is a great calling card - I've even had people throwing parties for me."

Our next stage begins at Serpa, a picturesque town of white houses built around a castle. On Friday morning, the whole town turns out to see the balloons off on the penultimate leg of the journey. But too many late nights enjoying the hospitality followed by early starts have taken their toll, and I finally oversleep and miss my flight. I arrive just in time to see the last one lift off over the roofs and a group of children chasing after a fluttering mini-Stars and Stripes, which American pilot Brian Bolland has dropped for them.

For the final flight on Saturday from a small village near Tavira, the object is to see who can cover the minimum distance in half an hour. I fly with Michel Benoit from France, who eventually wins this leg after deftly holding us no more than 10ft above back gardens and TV aerials while we drift less than half a mile from the take-off point.

Once our win is verified, Michel hits the gas and we head for the hills at 1,000ft - eventually landing with three other balloons. Among the crowd, I see Willy, my pilot on the first day. He breaks out a huge picnic and I begin to wonder whether I should have stuck with him for the whole week.

The practicals

Steve Chamberlain flew to Porto and back from Faro with TAP Air Portugal (0845 601 0932) for £150. He stayed at Residencia Tulipa, Braganca (00 351 2273 331 748), £11.25 a night; Centro de Formacao Agricola, Villa Nova de Foz Coa (00 351 275 774 145) £13.70; Albergaria Vitoria, Evora (00 351 266 707 174) £16.50; Casa da Muralha, Serpa (00 351 284 543 150) £16; Pedras D'El Rei, Tavira (00 351 281 325 532) £34 for a four-person apartment. For detila of the balloon race, see http://www.realizar.com.

fields.headline: Carry on up the Khyber
fields.standfirst: When he was last here, as a callow reporter, war and politics obstructed the view. Now, as a tourist,  Peter Preston finds he has become an honoured guest
fields.trailText: When he was last here, as a callow reporter, war and politics obstructed the view. Now, as a tourist, Peter Preston finds he has become an honoured guest.
fields.body:
The dowdy white bungalows of Flashman's hotel still squat where they did 35 years ago, half hidden among a coolness of trees, but the land behind is a derelict building site. Mrs Davies' boarding house, where once they served porridge, eggs and limp toast in sweet parody of British Raj breakfasts remembered, has gone the way of old Mrs Davies herself. Rawalpindi has moved on.

I first came to Pakistan in 1965, a callow Guardian reporter sent to war, and was duly strafed by Indian jets before suffering the permanent injury of teeth broken on a metal bolt which had somehow infiltrated Flashman's ravioli. It's a full three decades since I passed this way. And now I am a tourist. Now I can see more than bombs dropping from a night sky lit by tracer flares and tanks grinding through the streets.

What's changed? Everything and nothing. Another general rules down the road in Islamabad; the drumbeats of more war and Kashmir strife are never silenced; the teeming bazaars of the cities and the shacks of the countryside seem locked in immutable poverty. A peasant is a peasant is a peasant.

And yet this is a marvellous place to travel. A culture of deep-pile history; a landscape of deserts and mountains and lush plains full of fruit, the vistas shifting without end; a country of Buddhist temples, mosques built with Saudi millions, C of E churches strayed from some Cotswold village, and Moghul magnificences. But first, and always, there are the people.

A foreign visitor to Pakistan is an honoured guest, to be welcomed and protected. There's no crude hassling in the bazaars, no babble of importuning.

The problem of the people is their proliferation. They grow inexhaustibly. When I arrived in the long ago, the population of the then West Pakistan was 60million or so; now it's 150 million, and doubling every 25 years. That's an insupportable weight of humanity. It means that the cities burgeon in chaos and that even the most remote mountain valleys are cultivated on narrow terraces as far as the eye can see. Deserts apart, you're rarely alone in Pakistan.

Every problem, though, has its compensations - and here they are in abundance. This sometimes seems a nation of children in unnaturally smart blazers pouring from establishments called the Bright Future Grammar School and the College of Advanced Excellence. Toddlers with huge eyes chant "Sunday, Monday, Tuesday . . ." (English is Pakistan's second official language, devoutly learned as the passport to better things).

There's a natural charm to the shyness of the greetings, an innocent curiosity. They don't, in the backwater lands, seem to have seen many foreign faces. A truly young country welcomes you.

I wanted, from parallel curiosity, to retrace old steps, to view again the sights glimpsed only fleetingly through a prism of conflict. Call it, in essence, the Gandhara trek, after the great Buddhist civilisation which brought peace and prosperity to much of north-western Pakistan in the 1,000 years after 400BC. North from Rawalpindi and Islamabad to the Murree Hills, then north again along the string of hill stations called the Galis to Abbotabad and the Karakoram Highway; up the sinuous, amazing road that ends in China, then west through the Shangla Pass to Swat and a valley 160km long; south to Peshawar, west to the Khyber, east to Taxila, and south to one of the great cities of the world, Lahore.

Islamabad: a sub-continental Brasilia cum Milton Keynes designed by Greeks to meet the whims of a military dictator who went to Sandhurst. In 1965, it was already peeling and cracking, but decades of grandiose spending have dealt with that. The prime minister's new office looks like Sun City: you could fit Downing Street into the lobby. The boulevards are wide and gracious. The Shah Faisal Mosque, a giant concrete Bedouin tent, is the biggest on earth: 100,000 can worship together.

Murree: it's a brief morning drive to the green slopes and tin-roofed colonial mansions lounging along the most favoured ridges as though transplanted from the Malvern Hills. Who are the rulers now? Tycoons from Karachi, government officials from Lahore, the top brass of the army. They live as once we lived, in slightly-decayed splendour.

The old Murree brewery lies in ruins. The new Murree brewery is export only. This is a damned difficult country to get a drink in, Sergeant Major.

Wind on to Ayub Khan's own surrogate Malvern, called, blushingly, Ayubia and pause at the top of the pass, 10,000ft up, for green tea at the Daisy Dot Hotel, in which a former governor of the North West Frontier Province (NWFP) has invested not quite enough of his life savings. One day, this will be Crans-Montana.

The Karakoram Highway: Near Besham, four or so hours from Abbottabad, there's a plaque to the Chinese and Pakistani army men who, over 20 years, built this awesome road: 1,284km long, one dead every 1.5km in the blastings, the slidings, the endless rock falls. The Americans said it couldn't be done. The Chinese just got on and did it.

A military artery for Beijing? Hardly. Even Alexander the Great would have muttered about the ambush potential. This is the ancient Silk Route made modern trading reality. The Indus roars through grey gorges on its life-giving journey to the Arabian Sea. Turn left to Swat down a painful, rutted apology for a road. Pick-up vans playing ad-hoc buses keep overtaking you, full to the brim, with thin brown bodies sprawled on top, stuffed inside, hanging from the back. It's a tough, spare life in the hills of the frontier - but the people, wire-muscled, climb like goats: over the peaks and not so far away to the front lines of Kashmir.

Swat: almost a day's drive from top to bottom, from the red fortress at the Malakand Pass and the lonely outpost called Churchill's Picket where besieging tribesmen almost did Hitler a favour, to the pine forests and campsites of the Utrot. Some 1.5m people live here, growing apricots, onions and wheat and rice; learning to be hotel waiters and chefs at the grand new Austrian catering college; running the funfairs beside the Swat River; farming trout from the mountain streams and embroidering the finest shawls for Mingora's bazaars. The fast-food shop in Kalam high street never closes, crisp-frying great mounds of chopped mutton and spices and wrapping them in nan: true burger kings.

What do tender Western stomachs make of the feasts? I ate in five-star Pearl hotels and roadside transport cafés. If freshly-cooked, the food is uniformly delicious and safe. The most I paid for a top-end Moghul feast was £12 for two, the least was 70p. Pakistan - at 80-plus rupees to the pound - is a total eating and shopping bargain. Western-standard hotels, like the Pearls, aren't cheap, but make a cossetting break. The motels approved by the Pakistan Tourist Development Corporation are clean and comfortable and eager to please. Hotel builders are everywhere busy at work. You get what you pay for: but you can get almost anything you need.

History. The conquerings and re-conquerings through the millenniums are too complex to precis. But Takht-e-Bahi, high above Charsadda, is something simple: a Buddhist monastery nearly 2,000 years old and preserved in remote tranquillity. Stupas, the great burial beehives of Buddha, dot the countryside.

Taxila, its museum heaving with Gandharan art, is a treasure trove. And when you stand on the walls of the Bala Hisar Fort in Peshawar and look out for mile upon mile across the plains towards the mountains, time seems suspended. Not in Peshawar's tumultuous old bazaar, of course, fighting your way down the Street of the Sewing Machines to the Street of Leather Slippers - but there is a sense of continuum here.

I met (or perhaps was hijacked) by Abdel Ali, salesman supreme at his own Carpet Palace and watched open-mouthed as the master worked. Selling carpets is an operatic ritual spun across patient hours, an art form in itself. Mr Ali is fifth-generation in the game. His dad sold one British governor of the NWFP a 400-rupee carpet. Delighted, the governor recommended him to a chum - who bought an identical rug for 293 rupees. Ructions on discovery.

"But why did you charge me more?"

"Because you are a great man, sir. Because you are the governor."

Carry on up the Khyber. Two policemen toting kalashnikovs sit in the van. The mudhut slums where millions of Afghan refugees came to rest stretch interminably to the edge of the tribal areas (which invented devolution down the barrel of a rifle). And then you climb, beside the railway track, through arid hills, past forts and scattered villages, to Landi Kotal, the original smugglers' paradise with its underground shopping emporiums.

Stinger missiles on special offer; washing machines; hash mountains. Small boys on Chinese bikes toil up the slopes, cycling the 40km to Peshawar in supposed innocence for 60 rupees before getting the bus back, picking up another bike, and doing it all over again.

Lahore: which is, for me, the sub-continent's shining star. Thirty-five years ago, I barely glimpsed the fort, let alone the fountains of the Shalimar gardens or Jahangir's Tomb. The Indian Army, then, was just down the road, trying to cut Pakistan in half. But now the supreme Moghul past is there in peace, to wander and absorb. Lahore is culture and bustle and noise.

The town doesn't sleep till two in the morning. Its inhabitants walk the huge parklands and shop and ride - dad, mum and two toddlers - upon a single motorbike. Silver Mercs and bullock carts. Asia's Barcelona. They point out of the palaces of Colonel Sanders and Ronald McDonald with pride. They are citizens of a modern, vibrant world as well as rocks of ages.

Thirty-five years ago, I never dreamed this could be a nirvana among destinations: and politics, damned politics, keeps getting in the way. But, one fine day, the dream is there. Gandhara never dies.

The practicals

Peter Preston travelled to Pakistan with Steppes East (01285 810267, http://www.steppeseast.co.uk) who can custom build similar 14 day itineraries from £1650pp (based on two sharing, inc flights, transfers, accomodation, guides, entrance fees, taxes and most meals). Visas cost £40.
fields.bodyText: The dowdy white bungalows of Flashman's hotel still squat where they did 35 years ago, half hidden among a coolness of trees, but the land behind is a derelict building site. Mrs Davies' boarding house, where once they served porridge, eggs and limp toast in sweet parody of British Raj breakfasts remembered, has gone the way of old Mrs Davies herself. Rawalpindi has moved on. I first came to Pakistan in 1965, a callow Guardian reporter sent to war, and was duly strafed by Indian jets before suffering the permanent injury of teeth broken on a metal bolt which had somehow infiltrated Flashman's ravioli. It's a full three decades since I passed this way. And now I am a tourist. Now I can see more than bombs dropping from a night sky lit by tracer flares and tanks grinding through the streets. What's changed? Everything and nothing. Another general rules down the road in Islamabad; the drumbeats of more war and Kashmir strife are never silenced; the teeming bazaars of the cities and the shacks of the countryside seem locked in immutable poverty. A peasant is a peasant is a peasant. And yet this is a marvellous place to travel. A culture of deep-pile history; a landscape of deserts and mountains and lush plains full of fruit, the vistas shifting without end; a country of Buddhist temples, mosques built with Saudi millions, C of E churches strayed from some Cotswold village, and Moghul magnificences. But first, and always, there are the people. A foreign visitor to Pakistan is an honoured guest, to be welcomed and protected. There's no crude hassling in the bazaars, no babble of importuning. The problem of the people is their proliferation. They grow inexhaustibly. When I arrived in the long ago, the population of the then West Pakistan was 60million or so; now it's 150 million, and doubling every 25 years. That's an insupportable weight of humanity. It means that the cities burgeon in chaos and that even the most remote mountain valleys are cultivated on narrow terraces as far as the eye can see. Deserts apart, you're rarely alone in Pakistan. Every problem, though, has its compensations - and here they are in abundance. This sometimes seems a nation of children in unnaturally smart blazers pouring from establishments called the Bright Future Grammar School and the College of Advanced Excellence. Toddlers with huge eyes chant "Sunday, Monday, Tuesday . . ." (English is Pakistan's second official language, devoutly learned as the passport to better things). There's a natural charm to the shyness of the greetings, an innocent curiosity. They don't, in the backwater lands, seem to have seen many foreign faces. A truly young country welcomes you. I wanted, from parallel curiosity, to retrace old steps, to view again the sights glimpsed only fleetingly through a prism of conflict. Call it, in essence, the Gandhara trek, after the great Buddhist civilisation which brought peace and prosperity to much of north-western Pakistan in the 1,000 years after 400BC. North from Rawalpindi and Islamabad to the Murree Hills, then north again along the string of hill stations called the Galis to Abbotabad and the Karakoram Highway; up the sinuous, amazing road that ends in China, then west through the Shangla Pass to Swat and a valley 160km long; south to Peshawar, west to the Khyber, east to Taxila, and south to one of the great cities of the world, Lahore. Islamabad: a sub-continental Brasilia cum Milton Keynes designed by Greeks to meet the whims of a military dictator who went to Sandhurst. In 1965, it was already peeling and cracking, but decades of grandiose spending have dealt with that. The prime minister's new office looks like Sun City: you could fit Downing Street into the lobby. The boulevards are wide and gracious. The Shah Faisal Mosque, a giant concrete Bedouin tent, is the biggest on earth: 100,000 can worship together. Murree: it's a brief morning drive to the green slopes and tin-roofed colonial mansions lounging along the most favoured ridges as though transplanted from the Malvern Hills. Who are the rulers now? Tycoons from Karachi, government officials from Lahore, the top brass of the army. They live as once we lived, in slightly-decayed splendour. The old Murree brewery lies in ruins. The new Murree brewery is export only. This is a damned difficult country to get a drink in, Sergeant Major. Wind on to Ayub Khan's own surrogate Malvern, called, blushingly, Ayubia and pause at the top of the pass, 10,000ft up, for green tea at the Daisy Dot Hotel, in which a former governor of the North West Frontier Province (NWFP) has invested not quite enough of his life savings. One day, this will be Crans-Montana. The Karakoram Highway: Near Besham, four or so hours from Abbottabad, there's a plaque to the Chinese and Pakistani army men who, over 20 years, built this awesome road: 1,284km long, one dead every 1.5km in the blastings, the slidings, the endless rock falls. The Americans said it couldn't be done. The Chinese just got on and did it. A military artery for Beijing? Hardly. Even Alexander the Great would have muttered about the ambush potential. This is the ancient Silk Route made modern trading reality. The Indus roars through grey gorges on its life-giving journey to the Arabian Sea. Turn left to Swat down a painful, rutted apology for a road. Pick-up vans playing ad-hoc buses keep overtaking you, full to the brim, with thin brown bodies sprawled on top, stuffed inside, hanging from the back. It's a tough, spare life in the hills of the frontier - but the people, wire-muscled, climb like goats: over the peaks and not so far away to the front lines of Kashmir. Swat: almost a day's drive from top to bottom, from the red fortress at the Malakand Pass and the lonely outpost called Churchill's Picket where besieging tribesmen almost did Hitler a favour, to the pine forests and campsites of the Utrot. Some 1.5m people live here, growing apricots, onions and wheat and rice; learning to be hotel waiters and chefs at the grand new Austrian catering college; running the funfairs beside the Swat River; farming trout from the mountain streams and embroidering the finest shawls for Mingora's bazaars. The fast-food shop in Kalam high street never closes, crisp-frying great mounds of chopped mutton and spices and wrapping them in nan: true burger kings. What do tender Western stomachs make of the feasts? I ate in five-star Pearl hotels and roadside transport cafés. If freshly-cooked, the food is uniformly delicious and safe. The most I paid for a top-end Moghul feast was £12 for two, the least was 70p. Pakistan - at 80-plus rupees to the pound - is a total eating and shopping bargain. Western-standard hotels, like the Pearls, aren't cheap, but make a cossetting break. The motels approved by the Pakistan Tourist Development Corporation are clean and comfortable and eager to please. Hotel builders are everywhere busy at work. You get what you pay for: but you can get almost anything you need. History. The conquerings and re-conquerings through the millenniums are too complex to precis. But Takht-e-Bahi, high above Charsadda, is something simple: a Buddhist monastery nearly 2,000 years old and preserved in remote tranquillity. Stupas, the great burial beehives of Buddha, dot the countryside. Taxila, its museum heaving with Gandharan art, is a treasure trove. And when you stand on the walls of the Bala Hisar Fort in Peshawar and look out for mile upon mile across the plains towards the mountains, time seems suspended. Not in Peshawar's tumultuous old bazaar, of course, fighting your way down the Street of the Sewing Machines to the Street of Leather Slippers - but there is a sense of continuum here. I met (or perhaps was hijacked) by Abdel Ali, salesman supreme at his own Carpet Palace and watched open-mouthed as the master worked. Selling carpets is an operatic ritual spun across patient hours, an art form in itself. Mr Ali is fifth-generation in the game. His dad sold one British governor of the NWFP a 400-rupee carpet. Delighted, the governor recommended him to a chum - who bought an identical rug for 293 rupees. Ructions on discovery. "But why did you charge me more?" "Because you are a great man, sir. Because you are the governor." Carry on up the Khyber. Two policemen toting kalashnikovs sit in the van. The mudhut slums where millions of Afghan refugees came to rest stretch interminably to the edge of the tribal areas (which invented devolution down the barrel of a rifle). And then you climb, beside the railway track, through arid hills, past forts and scattered villages, to Landi Kotal, the original smugglers' paradise with its underground shopping emporiums. Stinger missiles on special offer; washing machines; hash mountains. Small boys on Chinese bikes toil up the slopes, cycling the 40km to Peshawar in supposed innocence for 60 rupees before getting the bus back, picking up another bike, and doing it all over again. Lahore: which is, for me, the sub-continent's shining star. Thirty-five years ago, I barely glimpsed the fort, let alone the fountains of the Shalimar gardens or Jahangir's Tomb. The Indian Army, then, was just down the road, trying to cut Pakistan in half. But now the supreme Moghul past is there in peace, to wander and absorb. Lahore is culture and bustle and noise. The town doesn't sleep till two in the morning. Its inhabitants walk the huge parklands and shop and ride - dad, mum and two toddlers - upon a single motorbike. Silver Mercs and bullock carts. Asia's Barcelona. They point out of the palaces of Colonel Sanders and Ronald McDonald with pride. They are citizens of a modern, vibrant world as well as rocks of ages. Thirty-five years ago, I never dreamed this could be a nirvana among destinations: and politics, damned politics, keeps getting in the way. But, one fine day, the dream is there. Gandhara never dies. fields.headline: European cities of culture: Helsinki
fields.trailText: Helsinki is a small, intense city built on a peninsula and a pretty tough place to be physically for much of the year. That said, it's easy to fall for the Finnish capital.
fields.body:
A miniature version of St Petersburg as seen from its impressive seafront, Helsinki is a small, intense city built on a peninsula and a pretty tough place to be physically for much of the year. That said, it's easy to fall for the Finnish capital, much of which was blasted to pieces in the second world war. Senate Square, with its stately Grecian public buildings designed by Carl Gustav Engel, a Berliner who made his name in St Petersburg, is overlooked by Orthodox (Byzantine style, 1868) and Lutheran (neo-classical, 1852) cathedrals and animated by a daily fish market. Modern architecture is often excellent - Alvar Aalto's Finlandia Concert Hall (1971) and Steven Holl's Kiasma Museum of Contemporary Art (1998). Most visitors' favourite is the beautiful Temppeliauko church hewn from solid rock, dating from 1969 and designed by Timo and Tuomo Suomalainen. Otherwise, very many museums, great Russian restaurants, very boozy bars (there's even a tram that doubles as a pub).

Highlights: The city's 450th anniversary will be celebrated by a cornucopia of events, including exhibitions of art and photography and a Festival of Film.

Summer: Culinary Concerts combining food and music.

Further information: Finnish Tourist Office (020-7839 4048).

Getting there: Crystal Holidays (0870 8880022) offers two-nights at the three-star Hotel Helka from £325pp, based on B&B, return flights from Heathrow and Gatwick and city guide. BA Holidays (0870 2424243) offers two nights in the three-star Cloister Inn from £305pp, based on B&B, return flights from Heathrow and transfers.

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Brussels
fields.trailText: Beer. Moules-frite. Chocolate. Trams. Great fashion. As much art-nouveau architecture as you can take. Brussels hasn't been boring for a long while.
fields.body:
Beer. Moules-frite. Chocolate. Trams. Great fashion. As much art-nouveau architecture as you can take. Brussels hasn't been boring for a long while, although if you find yourself in the Alphaville-like Parc du Cinquantenaire, home of the EU and other definitive Euro-bureaucracy, you might find this hard to believe. Much more entertaining is the Atomium, a giant steel and aluminium molecule composed of nine atoms you can climb through via a sequence of escalators. Designed for the 1958 World Fair by Andre Waterkeyn, it is the stuff of cultural nostalgia today. Wonderful old squares - the Grand Place is one of the world's finest. Fast trains direct from Waterloo.

Highlights: masses of museums. Don't miss the Musée Horta (25 rue Americaine, 2-5.30pm Tues-Sun), the home and studio of the art-nouveau architect Victor Horta. Photography and literary exhibitions year round.

June: opening of the Belgium Comic Strip Centre and the Museum of Musical Instruments.

Further information: Belgian Tourist Office (0800 9545 245)

Getting there: Eurostar Holidays (0870 1676767) offers two nights in a two-star hotel for £200 to five-star for £247. Two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 777 4445) at the three-star Hotel Colonies, Brussels, from now to March 28 2001 (excluding Bank Holidays) cost from £158pp.

webTitle: David Hamilton: Magazines | Business class ticket | Perfume

fields.headline: David Hamilton never travels without...
fields.trailText: Magazines | Business class ticket | Perfume
fields.body:
A necessity: A good supply of magazines. Hanging around in airports can be very boring so I read a lot to pass the time. I prefer a good laugh with Punch and Private Eye as well as trade papers such as Broadcast and The Stage.

A luxury: A business class ticket. It's definitely not for the champagne because drinking and flying is not a good idea. What I really appreciate is not having someone's knees in your back during a long flight.

A memento: I always bring back a bottle of perfume for my wife.

If only: Airlines did not overbook. If you've paid for a ticket, you should be entitled to a seat.

 David Hamilton presents the drivetime show on Radio Liberty 963 & 972 AM from 2pm-6pm weekdays.

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: SPURS IN NEW BID TO NET SOLSKJAER
fields.body:
SPURS IN NEW BID TO NET SOLSKJAER

George Graham has made a fresh £10m move for Ole Gunnar Solskjaer: United are ready to talk - but only if Graham agrees to release Sol Campbell.

NOW NIC'S OFF TO PARIS FOR £16m

Nicolas Anelka is set to sign for Paris St Germain after Arsenal rejected the chance to take him back. A £16m deal will go through this summer.

AND THE REST

Arsenal are ready to splash out in the battle to keep up with Alex Ferguson's transfer spending: Celta Vigo striker Benni McCarthy and ex- Everton midfielder Olivier Dacourt will be first in; Fiorentina are favourites to sign Allan Nielsen from Spurs ; Chelsea have lined-up a swoop for Inter striker Adrian Mutu - Vialli has also agreed a deal to keep Marcel Desailly at Stamford Bridge; Liverpool's Titi Camara is chasing a move to Celtic: 'I believe I could do a job for them' - Celtic also want Swindon teenagers Bryan Smith and Alan Young; Derby have denied preparing a bid for Coventry skipper Gary McAllister; Everton are ready to sell Thomas Myhre to Birmingham for £2m - Danny Cadamarteri is also up for grabs; Tottenham are set to up their bid for Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher - a £6.5m offer is being discussed; Teddy Sheringham is a top summer target for Fulham and Charlton ; West Ham have put Marc Vivien Foe, Javier Margas, Mark Keller and Neil Ruddock up for sale, and plan to sign Rushden & Diamonds starlet Andy Burgess; Newcastle boss Bobby Robson says he'll have to wait for transfer funds until July - he's chasing Portugese trio Fernando Meira, Sa Pinto and Jose Calado; and Glenn Hoddle has denied trying to tempt David Seaman to Southampton : 'This is the first I've heard of the story - there's nothing in it at all.'

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Avignon
fields.trailText: From 1309-77, the Holy See was based here. Rival popes co-existed in Avignon and Rome from 1378-1417. The seven Avignon popes blew a lot of money on grand architectural gestures.
fields.body:
From 1309-77, the Holy See was based here. Rival popes co-existed in Avignon and Rome from 1378-1417. The seven Avignon popes blew a lot of money on grand architectural gestures. The annual Avignon theatre festival has been held in the grandiose Cours d'Honneur of the Palais des Papes since 1947. The famous "pont", as in "sur le pont d'Avignon" was rebuilt in stone by Pope Clement VI who was as famous for what he ate as for what he built. At his coronation in 1342, his party scoffed 7,428 chickens, 3,043 fowl, 1,500 capon, 1,195 geese, 1,023 sheep, 914 kids, 180 oxen, 101 calves, 60 pigs, 10 tons of sugar, 50,000 tarts and 95,000 loaves of bread. Not quite the miracle of the loaves and fishes, but this was France after all. The food's still impressive: try Le Grand Café behind the Palais des Papes. Cote du Rhone is the local tipple.

Highlights: Art, photography and theatre in the Palais des Papes and l'Eglise des Celestines year round.

July: Festival of Avignon.

Further information: French Tourist Office (0906 8244 123)

Getting there: Cresta Holidays (0870 1610910) offers two nights B&B in the two-star Clairine Hotel from £282pp including return flights from Gatwick to Marseille. The four-star Clotre Saint Louis is £315pp.

fields.headline: Delayed  reactions
fields.standfirst: Emily Barr suffered a nightmare journey home from Kathmandu. Should the airline make amends?
fields.trailText: Emily Barr suffered a nightmare journey home from Kathmandu. Should the airline make amends?
fields.body:
I've often heard stories about people being delayed on long-haul flights. These always seem to have cheery endings, with the airline forking out a handsome sum so you don't blacken its name to your friends. But as I discovered, this is not always the case. In our household, Gulf Air not the flavour of the month.

Thursday January 6, Kathmandu airport

My boyfriend, James, and I are returning home after spending the new year in Nepal. At 6pm, we get to the airport for the 8.30pm flight to Heathrow, via Bahrain. Immediately, we are told the flight has been cancelled "for technical reasons". We are sent to the Annapurna hotel, and told that we will be flying at 5pm tomorrow.

Friday January 7

At 2pm a bus takes us to the airport. The check-in process is slow: there are two Gulf Air staff, hundreds of passengers, and no computers. Eventually, we check our bags through to London and go through immigration, where we are stamped out of Nepal. We spend our last 90 rupees in the departure lounge.

Ominously, the flight is not on the departure board, and, sure enough, at 4.45am it is cancelled again. The immigration men smile as they scribble out our exit stamps. At the Gulf Air desk, the defensive customer services manager is besieged.

Saturday January 8

We change a £5 note and so manage to avoid a sixth consecutive hotel buffet. Five pounds goes a long way in Kathmandu. However, we spend most of the day sitting in the hotel foyer, waiting for Gulf to decide to take us back to the airport. The familiar journey to the airport reminds us of Groundhog Day.

After several hours, astonishingly, we board a plane. It is a scheduled flight, and half the passengers have been bumped off in our honour. At take-off, a resounding cheer goes up. At 11pm we land in Abu Dhabi. Although we were assured of a connection to London, the staff here know nothing about us, and the London flight is already overbooked. The Gulf staff go out of their way not to make eye contact. The London flight leaves with none of us aboard.

The staff at the airport transfer desk try to get us onto other flights, although they are booked up throughout the next day. We try to buy first-class tickets, but even these are unavailable. By our body clocks it is about five in the morning, but Gulf does not break its silence to offer accommodation. Several passengers are crying with exhaustion. One woman is on her way to London for a kidney operation; she can barely stand up.

KLM has some spare seats on a flight to Amsterdam. A smiling woman takes eight passports. Ours are not among them. As James is holding them out in desperation, her walkie-talkie tells her to take two more. Thus we are among the lucky few, and board the 2.30am flight to Holland. The captain makes an announcement. "You may have noticed," he says, "that we are nine minutes late. We will take off in a further seven minutes." We are relieved, and go to sleep.

Sunday January 9

8.30am: At Schiphol Airport, KLM says it can't take us on to London without authorisation from Gulf Air. There is no one from Gulf here. All we want to do is to go home: there is clearly no option but to buy our own tickets, for £115 each, and get the money back later. We catch the next flight to Heathrow and arrive home 51 hours late to face a backlog of work and missed appointments.

But at least, we thought, we're in line for a compensation payment. I wrote to Mrs Patel, Gulf's customer service manager in London, outlining the entire miserable fiasco. A letter came back from Mohammed Al Shafie of the customer relations and quality standards department in Bahrain, agreeing to refund the cost of the tickets from Amsterdam, but overlooking my suggestions that a refund of the entire £735 each we paid for the Gulf flights might be in order.

Now, three months on, we have yet to be repaid even for the KLM tickets. James has spoken on a weekly basis to Mrs Patel, who has decided that KLM, not Gulf, must refund the cost, and tells us that we should not have bought these tickets in the first place (should we have set up home in Amsterdam, perhaps?) and has now explicitly told us that she doesn't care and washed her hands of us entirely.

"I can't understand what else you want me to do for you," she told James last week, before giving him KLM's number in Amsterdam and leaving us to it.

When I flew to Boston recently, Virgin had overbooked the plane, and offered £300 cash, or a Virgin ticket to anywhere, to anyone who would stay at a hotel and fly the following day.

"We sincerely hope," the letter from Gulf Air's Mr Al Shafie concluded cheerfully, "you will find our services entirely satisfactory when you next travel with us." Does he honestly believe there will be a next time?

 The following airlines also fly from London to Kathmandu: Qatar, Austrian Airlines, Thai Air, Eva Air, British Airways, Qantas and SAS.
