We try to buy first-class tickets, but even these are unavailable. By our body clocks it is about five in the morning, but Gulf does not break its silence to offer accommodation. Several passengers are crying with exhaustion. One woman is on her way to London for a kidney operation; she can barely stand up. KLM has some spare seats on a flight to Amsterdam. A smiling woman takes eight passports. Ours are not among them. As James is holding them out in desperation, her walkie-talkie tells her to take two more. Thus we are among the lucky few, and board the 2.30am flight to Holland. The captain makes an announcement. "You may have noticed," he says, "that we are nine minutes late. We will take off in a further seven minutes." We are relieved, and go to sleep. Sunday January 9 8.30am: At Schiphol Airport, KLM says it can't take us on to London without authorisation from Gulf Air. There is no one from Gulf here. All we want to do is to go home: there is clearly no option but to buy our own tickets, for £115 each, and get the money back later. We catch the next flight to Heathrow and arrive home 51 hours late to face a backlog of work and missed appointments. But at least, we thought, we're in line for a compensation payment. I wrote to Mrs Patel, Gulf's customer service manager in London, outlining the entire miserable fiasco. A letter came back from Mohammed Al Shafie of the customer relations and quality standards department in Bahrain, agreeing to refund the cost of the tickets from Amsterdam, but overlooking my suggestions that a refund of the entire £735 each we paid for the Gulf flights might be in order. Now, three months on, we have yet to be repaid even for the KLM tickets. James has spoken on a weekly basis to Mrs Patel, who has decided that KLM, not Gulf, must refund the cost, and tells us that we should not have bought these tickets in the first place (should we have set up home in Amsterdam, perhaps?) and has now explicitly told us that she doesn't care and washed her hands of us entirely. "I can't understand what else you want me to do for you," she told James last week, before giving him KLM's number in Amsterdam and leaving us to it. When I flew to Boston recently, Virgin had overbooked the plane, and offered £300 cash, or a Virgin ticket to anywhere, to anyone who would stay at a hotel and fly the following day. "We sincerely hope," the letter from Gulf Air's Mr Al Shafie concluded cheerfully, "you will find our services entirely satisfactory when you next travel with us." Does he honestly believe there will be a next time?  The following airlines also fly from London to Kathmandu: Qatar, Austrian Airlines, Thai Air, Eva Air, British Airways, Qantas and SAS.

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Reykjavik
fields.trailText: The world's northernmost capital city is a tiny place, just 170,000 largely wealthy and fashionably-clad people hemmed in by an icy sea and more late-night bars (more early morning, really) than can possibly be good for them.
fields.body:
The world's northernmost capital city is a tiny place, just 170,000 largely wealthy and fashionably-clad people hemmed in by an icy sea and more late-night bars (more early morning, really) than can possibly be good for them. Architecturally undistinguished, although the buildings tend to be colourful, chic and reelingly expensive. Food includes puffin, guillemot and hot dogs. It has the highest literacy rate in the world (so Icelanders claim) with more books published per capita than any other country. Visit Arni Magnusson Institute for Icelandic sagas on vellum, the National Gallery for bleak landscapes beyond Reykjavik's landscape of Prada and Armani and the Icelandic Institute of Phallology for, erm, penises. Largest belonged to a Blue Whale, smallest to a field mouse. Enough said.

Highlights: Cultural celebrations are based on the elemental themes of earth, air, fire and water.

August: Fireworks and displays of the ancient arts of smithying and ceramic firing. 26 and 27 August: pop diva Bjork sings with The Voices of Europe choir in Hallgrimskirkju.

Further information: www.reykjavik2000.is

Getting there: Icelandair (020-7874 1000), offers three-night packages at the Hotel Borg from May to September for £409pp on a B&B basis and including return flights from Heathrow, transfers, a Reykjavik tourist card and club pass. Three nights at the Hotel Esja cost £379pp.

fields.headline: 3 minute guide
fields.standfirst: Spanish steps
fields.trailText: Spanish steps
fields.body:
When in Rome..?

...do as tourists have done for centuries. Drape yourself down the Spanish Steps and watch the world go by.

A glorified rest stop?

Heaps of foreign bodies turn them into a vertical beach at the first hint of sunshine.

Is that their raison d' être?

Constant visitors to the sophisticated Piazza di Spagna needed somewhere to park their weary sightseeing thighs. The Pope obliged in 1725.

Are the steps as beautiful as the square?

Being supremely Baroque, they have served as the backdrop to countless artists' models.

What's at the top?

The lovely if simple Trinita dei Monti church, paid for by the King of France.

What was he doing here?

The steps originally linked the French quarter above with the Spanish embassy to the Holy See in the piazza below.

How romantic.

With a capital R when Keats, Byron, Shelley and their cronies arrived in the 19th century. The poets made the Piazza di Spagna their Italian HQ.

Have they left mementoes?

Locks of hair, death masks and more than 9,000 volumes of their works lie in the Keats-Shelley Memorial House at number 26.

A significant address?

It's the pink house next to the steps where John Keats spent the last three months of his life and died in 1821.

Do artists and writers still hang out here?

Nowadays you're just as likely to step over lolling backpackers waiting for a table to become free at the enormous McDonald's on the square - the first in Rome.

Hardly something to write home about?

But preferable, perhaps, to running up huge bills round the corner in Caffe Greco, haunt of the literati since the time of Goethe.

I'll count the steps instead.

Why climb to 138 when you can sit on Bernini's Barcaccia fountain, rinse your feet and gaze up.

Sounds an apt place to begin a spring break?

Particularly in May when the steps are awash with pots of azaleas.

Who will take me?

Most city-break tour operators can oblige. Two nights with Time Off (0870 5846363), for example, start at £275pp.

fields.headline: Highway patrol
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor serves up an online guide to the best sites on travelling in America
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor serves up an online guide to the best sites on travelling in America
fields.body:
What has Anthony Hopkins got in common with Jack Kerouac? Both have explored the long US highways. Hopkins, who lives in Los Angeles and took American citizenship last week, gets rid of excess energy by getting in his car and driving "thousands of miles"; Kerouac claimed to have written On the Road in three weeks.

American Express
According to the American Express online route planner, the distance between New York and LA is just over 2,821 miles. Given that it's unlikely that anyone would want to take the most direct route, you should count on plenty of time to complete any journey. Coast to coast is a very long haul - you will need to book flights separately for the beginning and end of the trip - and even a tour of New England demands at least 10 days.

USA Tourist and Yahoo travel
Unfortunately fly-drive holidays are not easy to find online, with Florida the only option on most of the bigger sites. However, it is relatively easy to research a route and plan stops. USA Tourist offers an overview of every state, and Yahoo travel has comprehensive links for each.

Rough guides
If you haven't driven in North America before, Rough Guides provides some basic advice at Rough guides. Bear in mind that you don't have to book in advance (although that's perfectly possible via a site such as Holiday autos) and haggling for a lower price on the spot may save you money. However, there is usually a premium for dropping off a car somewhere other than the pick-up point. Drivers under 25 should expect to pay more for insurance.

Motels.com
Motels.com is a portal that lets you book a place to stay in advance. Even if you don't intend to plan the journey in that much detail, it gives an indication of typical prices and the relative ease of finding accommodation in a particular area.

Route 66
The iconic Route 66 from Chicago to LA has its own site. It isn't entirely clear whether the diners, motels and attractions featured in each state have paid to be on this site, or whether a Route 66 enthusiast has lovingly compiled them all; but they do give a flavour of the country.

Roadside America
In a somewhat more ironic vein, Roadside America, the "online guide to offbeat tourist attractions", locates such jewels as "muffler men" (giant statues of upstanding American citizens that can be spotted on highways) and "adorable statements of understated Christianity".

fields.headline: West world
fields.standfirst: Ever wonder what keeps small-town America ticking over?  Michael Brooks  heads west to Flagstaff, a place once serviced by the traffic of Route 66 and where Hollywood stars came to play
fields.trailText: Ever wonder what keeps small-town America ticking over? Michael Brooks heads west to Flagstaff, a place once serviced by the traffic of Route 66 and where Hollywood stars came to play.
fields.body:
The handwritten sign on the shop door got straight to the point. "Tibetan prayer flags stolen. Bad karma. Please return." It was initially alarming, but I soon calmed down. It certainly didn't feel like there was much bad karma around.

A cool mountain breeze was keeping the air almost virginal. The café across the street sold the best espressos I had tasted since I was last in Portugal. As far as I could tell, no one else could sense the impending doom either: native American couples with bouncing children were wandering up and down the streets, pausing and pointing at every other shop window. Students from the University of Northern Arizona were lounging around tables outside the microbrewery. No, it seemed that Flagstaff was still OK, despite the theft.

It would take more than an insensitive new-age shoplifter to shake this town. It lies 270 miles east of Las Vegas, 143 miles north of Phoenix, perched on the ribbon of what used to be called Route 66. Alongside the highway runs the Santa Fe railroad: every half-hour or so, a train hoots from the town outskirts and then crawls into view. The engine, with its 70-plus wagons, takes a good few minutes to amble through the station. Nothing rushes through Flagstaff.

It has the feel of Brighton, forced into a diet to shed excess weight, and then sent to camp in the mountains. The central core is only a few blocks across, but contains the kinds of restaurants, bars and shops that would sit happily in any student or seaside town. And at the centre stands Flagstaff's Grand Hotel: the Monte Vista.

In case you can't find it, look up: its illuminated sign perches 20ft above the roof. But, unlike many things in America, it perches tastefully: this is a hotel with old-fashioned class. Scenes from Casablanca were filmed in its rooms, and a host of stars -Humphrey Bogart, Clark Gable and Spencer Tracy, to namedrop three - have slept there. And President Truman had his hair cut here.

But, however long you might be tempted to stay at the Monte Vista, don't take too many bags. The elevator is charming, if charming means cramped, rickety and prone to failure. But at least its seizures are predictable: the receptionist (who wore the Flagstaff uniform of faded T-shirt and baggy shorts) cautioned us that it was just about to break down when we arrived. Sure enough, we had to walk three floors down to breakfast the following day.

The hotel's coffee shop was closed, but Flagstaff is not short on places to eat and drink. Within a hundred yards of the Monte Vista you can find a pile of blueberry and banana pancakes (even better than they sound) or a plate of fried sausage and potatoes (strictly for the hard of arteries) to be washed down with fruit smoothies and coffee. Then, if you can get up from your chair, you can go and explore.

Twelve miles north is Sunset Crater, a dormant volcano that performed its last ablutions in 1065, burying its environment in hot rock. It is still surrounded by fields of oddly un-crumbled lava, a vast black skirt of bubbly rock slabs. The crater itself is rimmed with oxidised minerals that glow red in the last light of day.

Further north, the Painted Desert stretches across the horizon, indescribably beautiful on a clear day: the desert floor is coated with minerals that gleam with delicate pinks and mauves that Monet would have liked.

The view is even more spectacular from the Wupatki ruins, an ancient Indian settlement abandoned during the 13th century. Here, there is a hole in the ground through which the earth breathes. Sometimes the earth inhales, and sometimes it exhales. Or that's what the Indians thought: geologists have since come up with rather dreary ideas of temperature affecting the air pressure in the underground caverns.

There is a lot to be said for the Indian angle on the world. The impatient antics of the coyote, for instance, are apparently responsible for the plethora of stars in the sky. First Woman was carefully writing the moral laws for everyone to read when the frustrated coyote took her bowl of stars and flung them all into the blackness. Hence the random patterns in the sky, and the chaotic behaviour of Man. You won't find lessons in moral philosophy in the Big Bang theories.

The local Indian population were probably stunned by their first encounter with modern stargazing. The effort involved in getting "a good look" at the sky must have seemed absurd. In 1894, Percival Lowell, a wealthy Bostonian with an interest in extra-terrestrials, borrowed a huge telescope from Harvard university and somehow got it up into the mountains above Flagstaff. He was looking for life on Mars, probably a little too optimistically. By 1906 he had declared that he could clearly see Martian canals, which proved the existence of intelligent life. He was mistaken. Lowell was not an astronomical washout, though: by his observations he predicted the existence of Pluto, confirmed at the Lowell Observatory in 1930 - 14 years after his death. Sadly, Lowell had actually seen Pluto, though he never recognised it. Once it had been pinpointed, astrono mers went back to his photographs and found the tiny planet gazing out from a myriad of stars.

It's easy to see how Lowell missed it. A tour of the observatory gives visitors the opportunity to compare the two photographs of the sky the astronomers used to spot Pluto. The only difference between the two messes of bright dots is that Pluto has moved by about a centimetre. Fortunately, for the sake of tourists with less than a few weeks to spare, someone has indicated the planet's position with a big white arrow.

Flagstaff could advertise itself as a cosmic experience: within a few days you can hear the earth breathe, see the discovery of a new planet and sleep in the hotel of the stars. Instead, in the winter at least, it prides itself as a ski resort: the doorway to the Arizona Snowbowl. You could ski, if you fancied it. But I'd check that the prayer flags have been returned first. With all that bad karma around, I'd really rather not trust my life to the goodwill of the San Francisco peaks.

The practicals

BA Holidays (0870 2424243) has seven night fly/drive holidays to Phoenix, Arizona from £509pp for departures up to June 30. Price includes return scheduled flights with BA and car hire. Double rooms at the Hotel Monte Vista, Flagstaff (http://www.hotelmontevista.com, 001 520 779 6971) from $40 per night inc continental breakfast.

Reading and riding
Sustrans has launched the National Cycle Network Magazine and a catalogue of more than 150 maps and guides, as well as merchandise. By June, the Network will include 5,000 miles of safe routes for cyclists. Copies are available by calling Sustrans on 0117 9290888, e-mail: info@sustrans.org.uk

City slickers
It's springtime, when thoughts naturally turn to Paris. According to city-break specialist Crystal, the French capital continues to be the favourite destination for a short getaway. Other perennials in the top 10 are Amsterdam, Rome, Venice and Prague, with the only long-haul destination being New York.

Burning issue
More than 40% of us still believe it's important to return from our holidays with a suntan. The Sun Sense survey for Imperial Cancer Research Fund reveals that one in five of us don't bother using sunscreen despite the fact that a two-week holiday in the Med gives the equivalent of a whole year's sun exposure in the UK. One in four people still think the risks of skin cancer are exaggerated. The best way to enjoy the sun but stay safe is to avoid the hottest hours, between 11am and 3pm, cover up with loose cotton clothes and a hat and wear sunscreen of at least factor 15 on exposed skin areas.

Feeling supersonic?
Want to see the world, but can't spare the year off? Where there's a wallet, there's a way. In 26 days, you could see eight cities, dine with a sheikh in Dubai and be serenaded by fado musicians in Lisbon to boot. All courtesy of that supersonic charger Concorde. And all for the small consideration of £39,000. Call Abercrombie & Kent on 020-7559 8777 for further luxurious details.

Cruising in style
You don't need a royal budget to sail on the QE2. In fact, you could cruise in style for just £71 a day. The seven-night British Isles and France cruise calls at St Peter Port, Guernsey, Liverpool, Invergordon and Le Havre and costs £499, based on two people sharing, departing Southampton on July 11. The 10-night Fjords and Castles cruise costs £799 and leaves Southampton on August 18, featuring Oslo, Hellesylt, Geirangerfjord and Trondheim. For details, call Cunard Seaburn on 023-8071 6500.

Cellular light
Travellers with a WAP mobile phone will have access to late-availability deals online in the next couple of weeks via independent web travel agent The FirstResort.com (www. thefirstresort.com). Customers simply highlight a deal on their WAP phone, click "buy me" and are then transferred to the call centre to complete their transaction. There will be 70,000 offers available and all deals will be updated hourly.

webTitle: European cities of culture: Santiago de Compostela

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Santiago de Compostela
fields.trailText: The end of the Camino de Santiago - the great pilgrimage route still trodden by many today - is the superb stone city of Santiago de Compostela (St James of the Field of Stars).
fields.body:
The end of the Camino de Santiago - the great pilgrimage route still trodden by many today - is the superb stone city of Santiago de Compostela (St James of the Field of Stars). The saint's feast falls on July 25 and, if you can stand the crowds, remains one of the great surviving medieval public rituals. The city boasts a magnificent cathedral square, dramatic Sunday masses, and glorious stone streets, as well as one of Spain's best paradors by the cathedral walls. Galician Celtic music is played in small bars (try Café das Crechas, Via Sacra 3). A weekend of jamón, fino, Catholicism and rain. Caramba!

Highlights: May - Codex Calaxitus (a medieval liturgy sung in the Cathedral of Santiago de Compostela).

Further information: Spanish Tourist Office (020-7499 4593).

Getting there: two-night Travelscene weekend breaks (0870 7774445) at the three-star Hotel Congreso, Santiago, from now to August 31 2000 (excluding Bank Holidays) is £448pp based on two sharing, B&B, including return flights from Heathrow Airport.

fields.headline: Transported back in time
fields.standfirst: Transport minister  Lord MacDonald relieves the pressure of political life by walking the rugged West Highland Way
fields.trailText: Transport minister Lord MacDonald relieves the pressure of political life by walking the rugged West Highland Way.
fields.body:
It's no real surprise that the Scotsman whose job it is to produce a coherent strategy for Britain's struggling transport system has an escape route northwards, along an ancient drovers' road in the Highlands.

Lord MacDonald of Tradeston, or Gus to his friends, used to walk the 11 miles from Bridge of Orchy to Kingshouse in Glencoe when he was a teenager in Glasgow. He and his fellow apprentices would go up there to stretch their legs after another week in the shipyards.

Forty years on, the minister of transport likes to make it his first big walk of the season, starting at the ancient Inveroran Hotel, where walkers and climbers have replaced the cattle drovers of the old days. This route was also used by General George Wade for his military road into the Highlands in the 1720s, and is now part of the West Highland Way.

You start among the old Caledonian pine trees around Loch Tulla and its islets, then strike uphill across the shoulder of the 3,250ft mountain of Stob Ghabhar.

"The path is quite gentle, but you have the great bowl of the mountains all around you and it's very bleak - no shelter for six or eight miles, not even a tree, so if you get caught out it can be pretty miserable," says MacDonald.

"But on a good day, it's beautiful, and at the right time of year you can hear the deer in the corries. You can't see them, but they make this strange, deep braying noise, which can sound quite eerie. In the 1620s, James VI used to go hunting here for the rare white deer."

This area, called Black Mount, is connected to the Fleming family whose most famous member was the creator of James Bond.

"Then you come to the highest part with a great view of the mountains, and you can see as far as Schiehallion, a great pyramidal shape over in Perthshire. And after that, you begin to drop down into Glencoe which, if you're a MacDonald, has a special and sombre significance.

Glencoe is Scotland's most doom-laden valley where 37 of MacDonald's own clan were massacred by the Campbells and English troops in 1692.

"Sometimes, when it's raining and cloudy, there can be nowhere sadder and more gloomy than Glencoe. As you come down, you see the White Corries, where they have the ski-lift to take you to the tops, and beyond them is Buchaille Etive Mor, which I think translates as the great shepherd of Glen Etive."

It's a moderate walk of four to five hours ending at an inn, which claims to be the oldest in Scotland, in Kingshouse at the head of Glencoe.

MacDonald likes to go with his wife and old friends from Glasgow: "I just enjoy the physical effort of it, and I love the hills and mountains with which Scotland is particularly blessed.

"I lived in London from the 1960s to the 1980s and when I went back to work for Scottish TV in 1985, being near the mountains again was one of the best things about it. And you get so many changes in the weather, four seasons in a day sometimes, and such wonderful skies rolling across from the west."

Scotland's open policy

Access to the countryside in Scotland is about to go through a revolution that will give people wider rights than in most European countries and could set a radical precedent for the future in the rest of the United Kingdom.

While people in England and Wales will soon have legal right of access to open and uncultivated land - the so-called right to roam - the Scots are looking forward to being granted access everywhere, including cultivated farmland, forests, riverbanks and the coast.

A draft bill proposing these rights will be introduced to the Scottish Parliament in the next few weeks, and the backing of the Executive - a Labour-Liberal coalition - and the Scottish National Party makes it virtually certain it will become law.

What is perhaps most surprising is that the main representatives of land owners support the legislation, which is based on the unanimous recommendations of an Access Forum which brought relevant bodies together and deliberated for 18 months.

The legislation creates a mirror-image of the situation in England and Wales, where there is no access to private land unless a right of way is established or conceded. In Scotland, it's expected that that access will be limited only for reasons of privacy and environ mental protection, and the challenge will be to manage it successfully.

A vital part of the new bill will require local councils to establish and maintain a "core network" of paths, especially near towns and cities in the Lowlands, where it is felt that comparatively few routes for walking, cycling and riding are available.

"The effect is likely to be a huge change in attitude," says Dave Morris, director of the Ramblers' Associa tion Scotland. "Users will be a lot more confident once they have this right to go anywhere, providing they don't do any damage, while landowners will have the responsibility of accepting that freedom and welcoming people.

"It shouldn't be too difficult - the Duke of Buccleuch is the biggest landowner in Scotland and he's been operating on that basis for years.

"People coming to Scotland with loads of money to buy up land will be told that people will have access to that land and this is something they'll have to deal with."

Meanwhile, pressure groups in England and Wales are looking beyond the imminent "right to roam" legislation and preparing to push for right of access to riverbanks and woodland as well. Many recognise, however, that access to the heavily-cultivated farmland in parts of England might prove more difficult.

The practicals

For general information, call the Scottish Tourist Board brochure hotline on 08705 511511, www.visitscotland.net. For detailed travel factsheets, call 0131 332 2433. OS Landranger maps numbers 50 (Glen Orchy and Lcoh Etive) and 41 (Ben Nevis and Glencoe) and 39 (Loch Lormond). Recreational Path Guide: The West Highland Way, Anthony Burton, Aurum Press, £12.99.

fields.headline: Whistlejacket, George Stubbs (1762)
fields.trailText: · View the work online
fields.body:
· View the work online

Subject:
Whistlejacket foaled in 1749, was the star racehorse of his day, famous for winning £2,000 in a race at York in 1759 for his owner, the second Marquess of Rockingham, who commissioned this painting.

Distinguishing features
Stubbs's colossal, almost three-metre-high painting depicts a horse as a solitary and splendid individual, with no people in the picture, no landscape, just a surrounding void that focuses our attention on the rearing racehorse - his shiny flanks, flying mane, brown eye looking back at us.

This painting fascinated contemporaries who hypothesised that it was really an unfinished equestrian portrait of George III. A landscape painter was supposed to have filled in the background and a portrait artist was going to do the king, but then political differences between the Marquess of Rockingham and the monarch meant that the picture was left unfinished. There's no proof of this story. The way Stubbs has painted the shadows under Whistlejacket's back feet suggests on the contrary that this painting looks the way he wanted it to. It is a romantic study in solitude and liberty, freeing Whistlejacket from the bridles and whips that sur rounded him in life to gallop in unlimited abstract space.

Stubbs's picture is a portrait of an animal on the scale usually reserved for kings. A portrait is a study in individuality, at its most primitive an attempt to discover what makes someone recognisable as themselves. This might be a blemish or - as in Rembrandt's portraits - a consciousness. Stubbs specialised in painting horses in one of the great ages of the horse. In 18th century Britain horse breeding and racing was the passion of the aristocracy at the same time as it was becoming a popular spectator sport. Stubbs and his contemporaries were accustomed to recognising horses as individuals. Whistlejacket's individuality begins at the level of physiognomy and physical detail; Stubbs was an expert on animal anatomy, had even dissected a horse. By comparing this to his other paintings of horses you can see how much attention he paid to the horse's specific physical marks. The white area on Whistlejacket's back right foot functions as a cleft chin or a scar might on a human portrait, and the veins on his rear thigh stand up.

Yet this attention to external features is only one part of what makes this a great portrait. Stubbs is interested in the inner being of Whistlejacket, his character, his self, and that is what he captures here: the incredible tension, energy and sensitivity in the way the horse rears, the electricity in the taut muscles, the look of something that might be terror in his face.

Did they like it?
Whistlejacket wasn't saying, but aristocratic owners hired Stubbs to paint many more mares, foals and race winners, so the implication that the horse is a free spirit confined by an oppressive human society obviously passed them by.

Where is it?
The National Gallery, London WC2, (020-7747 2885).

webTitle: Can you learn to be a genius?

fields.headline: Can you learn to be a genius?
fields.trailText: What are the factors that lead to genius? Shoul it be perceived as an inherent quality, or is it a condition that any of us could achieve? In an interesting take on the nature versus nurture debate, Michael Howe, professor of psychology, and Ellen Winner, authority on child rearing, outline their conflicting positions.
fields.body:
Dear Ellen,
Geniuses are intensely curious, capable of sustaining concentration and focusing their minds on problems, and they are doggedly unwilling to be defeated. They tend to be self-confident and are invariably inventive.

But, as I told the British Psychological Society's annual conference last week, the qualities that set geniuses apart are acquired, not innate. There is no combination of genes that can create a genius. Geniuses create themselves, largely through their own efforts, very hard work and their own experiences. There is no convincing evidence that geniuses are born different.

Of course, not everyone can be a genius, and the great achievements that justify sticking the genius label on a creative individual are only rarely possible. But while a genius's accomplishments are beyond anything most people could dream of, geniuses spring from the same flesh and blood as everyone else, shaping their formidable capabilities from the same basic materials. This makes them all the more impressive.

Geniuses have to struggle, they find things difficult, and they only gain their remarkable powers as a consequence of hard efforts. The idea that geniuses form a special breed of individuals, who can forge ahead without lengthy training of the sort that other people need, is simply a myth. Equally mythical is the notion that the achievements of geniuses appear quite suddenly, out of the blue. In reality genius requires, and is born of, a period of intense preparation.

Yours sincerely,
Michael Howe,
Professor of psychology,
Exeter University

Dear Michael,
You say there is no convincing evidence that geniuses are born different. But most psychologists accept that there are individual differences based on biology. Twin studies have shown that genetics account for some portion of an individual's IQ. This means biology cannot be discounted.

For instance, child prodigies, some of whom go on to achieve the label of genius, show signs of unusual ability at a very early age, prior to any training.

The achievements of geniuses are, of course, a product of hard work. But this is not the whole story. One cannot select a child at random, subject that child to musical training as intense as that received by Mozart, and expect to produce a Mozart.

While no one has found a genetic formula for genius, this does not mean there is no genetic component. I would wager that there is indeed a genetic basis to genius, in the sense that geniuses are born with unusual abilities and perhaps also unusual temperaments. Genes are not enough, though. Geniuses need to be born at the right historical time, and into an environment that allows their abilities to flourish.

Yours sincerely,
Ellen Winner,
Professor of psychology,
Boston College,
Massachusetts

Dear Ellen,
Hard work is vital for geniuses. What makes geniuses special is their long-term commitment towards a specific goal and their firm sense of direction. Geniuses are happy to focus themselves, they enjoy their work.

The Brontë sisters did not suddenly begin writing great novels. They perfected their writing skills over a period of years. Even in the earliest years, two children can have very different experiences and gain contrasting preferences. As a result, when formal training begins, one child quickly takes to the activity being taught, while the other, being ill-prepared, struggles with no success. The vast majority of prodigies never produce the kind of outstanding creative achievements that justify calling someone a genius. And many geniuses were not at all precocious as children.

Darwin only gradually developed into a major scientist. The great railway engineer George Stephenson - a heroic figure whose amazing life rarely gets the attention it deserves - did not even learn to read and write his own name until he was 18.

Dear Mike,
We are not disputing whether hard work is important for the achievement of geniuses. Show me a genius and I'll show you a workaholic. But most workaholics are not geniuses.

At three, Arthur Rubinstein heard his sister playing the piano and played back her pieces faultlessly. The chess prodigy Josh Waitzkin, portrayed in the book and film, Searching for Bobby Fischer, watched but a few chess games, then invented a sophisticated strategy the first time he played, launching an attack using a combination of pieces.

One gifted child I have studied mastered reading at three by watching his mother read the same two books for two weeks, pointing to the words as she read. From then on, he read voraciously.

It is implausible that early experiences account for such extreme early skills or the ease with which such children master their domains. What kinds of early experiences would make a Rubinstein master music rapidly and hungrily, while another, often a sibling, plods along, or loses interest altogether? Just how would one teach a child to become a genius? If genius could be taught, it would be less rare.

Churchill and Darwin were not recognised as child prodigies because they were not scholastically precocious. Undoubtedly they were unusual children - intense, driven, curious. The engineer George Stephenson may not have been able to read until 18, but people in spatial professions have a disproportionate incidence of dyslexia.

The relevant question is whether Stephenson showed spatial gifts as a child. So far we have not had incontrovertible evidence that prodigies are born different. But two kinds of studies should help. Intensive training of randomly selected children should reveal whether they turn out to be well-trained seals or geniuses.

And functional brain imaging can tell us what is different about the brain of a genius (the world class solo violinist) and someone with the same amount of training but who does not merit the label genius (the first violinist of a symphony orchestra).

Yours,
Ellen

Dear Ellen,
Let's dispel some myths. The belief that their powers are mysterious or magical has encouraged people to regard geniuses as a separate breed. In Einstein's case, we are often told that he was a dyslexic child and a slow learner who miraculously began producing brilliant scientific theories in early adulthood. The reality was very difficult, as recent biographies have shown.

In 1886, at the end of his first year of school, Einstein's mother wrote to her sister that Albert was top of his class and had brought home a brilliant report. The persisting notion that Einstein failed to flourish at his Munich high school was refuted as early as 1929. Not all people who start life with exceptional potential become geniuses. Genius depends in many ways on self-confidence, luck, good connections and the intellectual climate of the time.

Genius flourishes with the right opportunities, supportive environment and encouragement. But I would hesitate to say that a parent can manufacture a genius, although there are cases in which something like that happened.

Yours,
Mike

Dear Mike,
It is important to distinguish between lay myths about genius and scientific views. All scientists acknowledge that genes are mediated by the environment.

If, as you say, innate gifts don't explain the difference between prodigies and typical children, then the environment must be the cause. Yet you admit that most of us could not be geniuses. Why not? If it's the environment, we could all, in principle, make our children into geniuses. This view is as much a myth as the view that geniuses are magical. The essential scientific question is whether there are people whose great achievements are made possible, in part, by biologically-based cognitive and temperamental factors.

Hard work will get you far, but it will not get you all the way to the genius finish line. For that, you need to start out ahead of the pack. Starting out ahead means being born with a nervous system that allows you to ferret out patterns in specific areas with a speed, accuracy, and intrinsic interest which the rest of us cannot even imagine.

Yours,
Ellen

fields.headline: China's challenge: fighting rural poverty
fields.standfirst: Education and health care are beyond the means of many peasants families
fields.trailText: Questions about annual per capita income mean nothing on a remote hillside in the south of Yunnan. The village head squats on the ground and searches for an answer. "If a family has a pig and sells it, then they can earn some cash," he says. "So maybe we could say 200 renminbi [£15] - but others have 100 or less."
fields.byline: John Gittings in Malipo, Yunnan province
fields.body:
Questions about annual per capita income mean nothing on a remote hillside in the south of Yunnan. The village head squats on the ground and searches for an answer. "If a family has a pig and sells it, then they can earn some cash," he says. "So maybe we could say 200 renminbi [£15] - but others have 100 or less."

The 33 households in this Miao minority village have cracked mud walls and thatched roofs, blackened with age. One third of its residents receive government grain to see them through the winter.

The village is called Tangzhibian - meaning Tang village next to the pond - where humans and animals drink from the same water. There are many others like it in Malipo county, one of the poorest in Yunnan province; Yunnan itself is one of the poorest provinces in China.

Mr Yang, the village head, looks longingly down on a fertile valley below. "That belongs to Loutizhai village; we have to scrape a living up the mountain."

The Tang villagers climb steep tracks, urging on their buffalo with swishes of a thin stick. The strongest man will carry the wooden plough and harness hooked over his back.

High in the clouds they build up fields, painfully terraced with boulders or simply planted on sheer hillsides.

The scenery in south-east Yunnan, close to the Vietnam border, is wild and beautiful. Rounded peaks straight out of a Song dynasty painting disappear in the mist.

The first ravine is a revelation - till the traveller realises that the whole world here is ravines.

Bare rock faces descend hundreds of metres; trees grow out sideways from almost vertical slopes. Lower down, there are splashes of colour from azalea flowers and wild fruit blossoms.

The province of Yunnan has 10% of China's officially designated poor counties, including Malipo and the neighbouring Pingbian.

Although Yunnan is one of the underdeveloped western provinces which have been targeted by Beijing for development, the aid may not reach Malipo.

Malipo's official statistics show that 38,500 of its 265,000 residents live below the poverty line - almost certainly an underestimate.

The same source makes the dubious claim that another 49,000 were "rescued from poverty" last year. In a culture of setting targets, local officials are tempted to exaggerate their performances.

China originally declared that it would eliminate poverty by the year 2000, but it now admits that 60m are still stricken.

Malipo's average annual per capita income is only £45, just above the £43 that marks the poverty line.

The Tang villagers have no expectation of being "rescued" from their poverty soon, or later; most villagers just give a helpless laugh when asked what they hope for the future.

"I would like a new house instead of this tumble-down one," says 28-year-old Yang Shunyu. "So that my two-year-old son will not be ashamed of me. But there is not the slightest chance."

Does he want his child to be educated? "Of course, but most children here never go beyond primary school," he says. "It's too difficult and they can't afford it."

The fortunate villagers in Loutizhai are only relatively better off: the school teacher says that the local per capita annual income is only £35. But the school has attracted foreign aid, with funds from Japan channelled via the Chinese ministry of foreign affairs.

Perched over a mini valley of paddy fields, the school provides free tuition, and the extra fees for books are only £6 a year. But that is too much for the poor neighbours in Tang village.

Health services in Malipo are also beyond the pocket of its poor. The brand new county hospital - also built with Japanese money - has 66 patients occupying some of its more than 100 beds. The out-patient fees are meticulously graded.

Stitching up a simple wound is 46p, but a complex one costs £3.80. It costs 86p to use the emergency room and the daily bed charge ranges from £2.30 to £4.60, depending on whether it is a "small or big emergency".

The maternity ward seems to operate in a different world than the Tang village; a normal pregnancy, says a hospital doctor, costs more than £77 and a Caesarean Section is twice as much.

Malipo's party secretary, Wang Chengcai, gives routine answers when questioned about poverty and school dropouts. Another 23,000 people, he says confidently will be "rescued from poverty" exactly by December 31 2000.

Some specialists criticise the haphazard way that aid agencies have poured money into counties like Malipo, with no unified approach and little monitoring. But on the ground it seems only too clear that some help must be better than none.

"I've seen a place in Jinping where the kids have no shoes and families share one set of men's clothes and one set of women's," says a foreign aid volunteer.

A foreign ministry official from Beijing has been seconded to Malipo for a year to help publicise the region's plight and to channel aid there. It is a sign of China's increasingly open attitude to admitting the problem of poverty.

In the provincial capital of Kunming, a senior official, Li Jiating, says that Malipo and similar counties suffer from material and educational poverty.

He too quotes targets for reducing poverty across the whole of Yunnan province, but says that they have not been met. He also admits that poverty is a relative concept.

"People may lapse into poverty, or may become poor by comparison with others," says Mr Li. "In 25 years' time, there may still be poor people by a different standard."

Back in Malipo, the signs of poverty are etched on the steep slopes where reclaimed land quickly degenerates and is abandoned, leaving an inflamed red scar.

There is a law against cultivation on a more than one-in-four incline, but desperate peasants will work slopes which even goats can hardly climb.

fields.headline: Nice shorts
fields.standfirst: Nicholas Lezard  on Penguin's admirable collection of modern essays
fields.trailText: Nicholas Lezard on Penguin's admirable collection of modern essays
fields.body:
The Penguin Book of Twentieth-Century Essays
edited by Ian Hamilton
(Penguin, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

This can't have been the most rancorous editorial meeting in publishing history. "I know, let's put out a book of 20th-century essays." "Who d'you think should edit it?" "Ooh, let's think for a sec - how about Ian Hamilton?" Well, sometimes the obvious choice turns out to be the right choice. This book does exactly what it says on the tin, as it were, and reviewing it is more a matter of description than evaluation.

There are 60-odd essays, one per writer, which, laid end to end, form a kind of history of the century. A quirky and monadic history, matters of personality and personal observation, generally; Anglo-American; and all the better for it. It is hard not to sound like an enthusiastic blurb: from GK Chesterton to Julian Barnes! F Scott Fitzgerald's "The Crack-Up"! Tom Wolfe on Radical Chic! Martin Amis on the 1988 Republican Convention! ("I reposed considerable hope in Pat Robertson, the one-time TV pastor and tithe mogul. Might Pat talk about Armageddon and Rapture? Might he denounce credit cards for harbouring the Mark of the Beast? Might he heal my jet lag?").

Maurice Baring's letter from Goneril to Regan is always a treat ("We have been having the most trying time lately with Papa"); AP Herbert's piece on bathrooms is the kind of silliness that is essential for a collection like this (he proposes an "emergency waste mechanism, by which the bath can be emptied in malice from outside"), and I experienced the pleasing symmetry of actually reading it in the bath.

Of course, there are regrettable omissions. But pretty much anyone can come up with a good half-dozen of those. Actually, I can only think of one, and that is Will Self's piece about flying first class that appeared in The Idler in 1995. ("I've never been able to cope with those miniature LCD video screens since the time I got on a Virgin flight to New York - admittedly well over the herbaceous border - and became convinced they were accurately portraying the thoughts of the person sitting in the seat in front of me.") Or maybe something by Gary Indiana from Let it Bleed (Serpent's Tail).

So while you couldn't reasonably expect anyone to have done a better job than the one Hamilton has, you do have that sense that you invariably get when dealing with chronologically arranged anthologies: they're always a tiny bit out of date, the editor invariably pulls back, almost timidly, from making the book close with true contemporaneity. Self would have been a little too shocking: too many uses of the f-word to sit comfortably in the company of Mencken, Mitford (N) and Barnes. Which is a shame, really.

And while it would have been logically impossible for him to have picked a duff Christopher Hitchens piece, for no such animal exists, it is interesting that he is represented by the one in which he reveals himself to be Jewish. (Or, quoting Jonathan Miller, Jew-ish .) It is one of his gentler pieces, tender almost, and not the precise evisceration of the hypocritical that we expect.

Of course, that is probably why it went in in the first place. I can imagine that Hamilton considered the essays with this question always in mind: "Now, is this a piece of fine writing ?" It would be deranged of me to suggest that this is not a suitable way of going about editing such a book; but sometimes there are, every so often, different kinds of fine writing to consider.

fields.headline: Elian seized from  relatives' home
fields.standfirst: More about the Elian Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: April 22 2000: On this day federal agents seized Elian Gonzalez from the home of his relatives in Miami. This is how the Guardian reported the news.
fields.body:
Federal agents seized Elian Gonzalez from the home of his relatives before dawn in Miami today. They fired pepper spray into an angry crowd as they took away the crying and screaming six-year-old boy for a reunion in Washington with his Cuban father.

More than 20 agents arrived at the home shortly after 5am [Miami time] using rams on the home's chain-link fence and front door to get inside and look for the boy, who was being hidden in bedroom closet by his great-aunt.

Also there was Donato Dalrymple, one of the fishermen who rescued him on Thanksgiving. In the bedroom, an agent in green riot gear and goggles pointed an automatic rifle at Dalrymple holding the frightened child.

A short time later, a woman and man brought Elian out of the home and put him in one of the vans, which sped off. Maria Elena Quesada, who was at the home, said Elian was screaming "Help me! Help me! Don't take me away!" in Spanish.

Ramon Saul Sanchez, leader of the anti-Castro Democracy Movement, was bleeding from one ear after the raid. He said he was knocked out by an agent using a rifle as a club.

By 6am, Elian was on a government plane headed for an airport near Washington and a reunion with his father. Juan Miguel Gonzalez was told about the raid as soon as Elian was safe and will meet his son at the airport, officials said.

"Juan Gonzalez wants to be with his son, and that will happen now," Attorney General Janet Reno said. She said she "did until the final moments try to reach a voluntary solution" with the boy's Miami relatives, but a deal was not reached and she felt she had no choice but order the raid. She said the boy would stay in the United States pending further court action, as the federal appeals court ruled.

She said: "Elian is safe and no one was seriously hurt."

On the plane were the female immigration agent who carried Elian from the house, a psychiatrist, a flight surgeon and the immigration agent who commanded the operation. They were explaining carefully what is happening to him, the official said. Elian was described as subdued and calm ont he plane. He has been given a play kit including toys, Play-Doh, an airplane, a map and a watch.

They fired pepper spray into an angry crowd as they took away the crying and screaming six-year-old boy for a reunion in Washington with his Cuban father. More than 20 agents arrived at the home shortly after 5am [Miami time] using rams on the home's chain-link fence and front door to get inside and look for the boy, who was being hidden in bedroom closet by his great-aunt. Also there was Donato Dalrymple, one of the fishermen who rescued him on Thanksgiving. In the bedroom, an agent in green riot gear and goggles pointed an automatic rifle at Dalrymple holding the frightened child. A short time later, a woman and man brought Elian out of the home and put him in one of the vans, which sped off. Maria Elena Quesada, who was at the home, said Elian was screaming "Help me! Help me! He said he was knocked out by an agent using a rifle as a club. By 6am, Elian was on a government plane headed for an airport near Washington and a reunion with his father. webTitle: Dobson attacks cost of traffic cuts plan

fields.headline: Dobson attacks cost of traffic cuts plan
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson's campaign for London mayor yesterday targeted its attacks on Ken Livingstone by rubbishing his manifesto plans for congestion taxes to cut road traffic by 15%.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson's campaign for London mayor yesterday targeted its attacks on Ken Livingstone by rubbishing his manifesto plans for congestion taxes to cut road traffic by 15%.

The former health secretary unveiled a poster site proclaiming: "Beware the Cost of Livingstone."

In a speech he claimed that motorists might have to pay £15 a day to cross three Livingstone congestion zones from the suburbs to the city centre - £5 per zone. Mr Livingstone has not suggested that formula, and is increasingly wary of details of his proposed congestion charge.

Last night Mr Livingstone said: "All that's being considered is a small area of central London and Frank knows that full well. Frank must be getting desperate to resort to arguments like this."

But Mr Livingstone is vulnerable to precisely that sort of attack because he has said different things to different audiences at different stages of his long, informal campaign. In Mr Dobson's struggle to get back into the race it looks as if he has decided this is a winning issue.

The Labour campaign has unearthed quotes from the past six months in which Mr Livingstone has talked about a 15% or even 20% traffic cut by 2001 or - in one case - 2010.

Coupled with the £5 a day charge for entering central London, which featured at an earlier stage of the Livingstone campaign, Labour's candidate argued that most experts divide the city into three zones. Multiply £5 a day by three zones and 20 working days a month and it produces the purple "£300 payable monthly" mock tax disc which Labour will start handing out next week.

In his speech Mr Dobson said the campaign issues are "job, crime and transport", and that his main rival - 30% clear of all other candidates - "won't answer the questions because he knows Londoners won't like the answers".

fields.headline: European cities of culture: Prague
fields.trailText: Almost ridiculously picturesque capital city of spires, domes, bridges and as much Baroque as you could ever want. Great to walk around. Also lots of annoying tourist-trade junk, though, with traders on Charles Bridge still selling brand new, mass-produced Communist era caps, badges and ephemera. Bad King Wenceslas (the IV) threw St John Nepomuk to his death into the river Vltava here in 1393; he should be here today to sort out the traders. The Jewish Museum (which includes the late 13th-century Gothic Staranova synagogue) houses a collection of objects the Nazis brought here in 1942 for a museum they planned to commemorate an "extinct people". On an upbeat note, there's the Mozart Museum in Villa Betramka, Mozartova 169, and nearby the apartment in which he wrote Don Giovanni. There are two puppet theatres, scores of tacky places to be ripped off as you eat badly and cybercafés in beneath cornices and between colonnades.
